THE POLICE SERVICE
The police service of Great Britain is organised in a number of large forces
linked with local government and subject to the influence and eventual control
of the Home Secretary in England and Wales and the Secretary of State for
Scotland in Scotland. In Northern Ireland the police force is controlled by an
Inspector General, who is responsible to the Minister of Home Affairs.
During the past three years a large number of police forces in Great Britain
have amalgamated in a nation-wide reorganisation of the police service,
and there are now 47 regular police forces in England and Wales and 20 in
Scotland. Each police force is responsible for a separate police area, but there
is constant co-operation between them.
In England and Wales the forces are defined according to area of responsi¬
bility as: county forces (5); county borough forces (6); combined forces (34),
which are forces whose area of responsibility extends over two or more
counties or county boroughs; the Metropolitan Police Force, which is
responsible for an area of approximately 15 miles radius from Charing Cross,
but excluding the City of London; and the City of London force. In Scotland
there are county forces, burgh forces and combined forces.
The strength of the regular police force in Great Britain is approximately
101,000, the size of individual police forces depending on the area and
population which they serve. In England and Wales, outside Greater London,
establishments range from 700 to 7,000, the majority being in the 1,000 to
2,500 range. The strength of the Metropolitan Police Force is about 25,000.
In Scotland forces range in strength from about 100 to 3,000.
In addition to the regular police forces, there are constabularies maintained
by the statutory transport and other public authorities, and by the Ministry
of Defence.
Each of the regular police forces is maintained by a police authority. In the
counties of England and Wales the authority is a police committee and in the
county boroughs a watch committee. Both are committees of the local council
and consist of councillors and justices in a proportion of two to one. Combined
police authorities, which also consist of councillors and justices, contain
representatives from each constituent area covered by an amalgamation
scheme.
The police authority for the Metropolitan Police Force is the Home
Secretary. In the City of London the Court of Common Council is the police
authority, although it usually appoints a standing committee to deal with all
police matters on its behalf.
In Scotland the police authority for the counties is the county council; in
the large burghs it is the town council; and where there are combined forces
there is a joint police committee.
The primary duty of the police authority is to provide an adequate and
efficient police force for the area for which it is responsible. To enable it to
carry out this duty, it is empowered, subject to the approval of the Home
Secretary or Secretary of State for Scotland, to appoint the chief constable
and the deputy and assistant chief constables of the force, and fix the author¬
ised establishment. It may also retire the chief constable in the interests of
efficiency, if the Home Secretary or the Secretary of State for Scotland agrees,
and must keep itself informed of the way in which the chief constables deal
with complaints from the public against police officers. In addition, police
X04 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
authorities, with the consent of the Secretary of State, provide the buildings
and equipment needed for their forces. In the Metropolitan Police District
the chief officer of police and his immediate subordinates are appointed by the
Crown on the recommendation of the Home Secretary.
Chief constables are responsible for the direction and control of police
forces and for the appointment, promotion and discipline of all ranks below
deputy or assistant chief constable; they are, however, generally responsible
to the police authorities on matters of efficiency, and are required to submit a
written annual report.
Central The Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Scotland, who have a
Authority general responsibility for the preservation of law and order throughout Great
Britain, are concerned both in the overall organisation of the police service
and in its administration and operation. In this regard, they must not only
approve the appointment of chief constables, but may require a police
authority to retire a chief constable in the interests of efficiency, call for a
report from a chief constable on any matters relating to the policing of his
area, or cause a local enquiry to be held. They are also empowered to make
regulations as to the government, administration and conditions of service
in police forces.
The police regulations cover such matters as ranks; the qualifications for
appointment, promotion and retirement; discipline; hours of duty, leave,
pay and allowances; and uniform and equipment. Some of these are first
negotiable on the Police Council for Great Britain; the others are discussed
on representative advisory bodies along with any general questions affecting
the police service.
The Home Secretary is advised on all matters concerning police efficiency
by Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary and nine inspectors, of
whom two are concerned with crime and traffic respectively, and one is in
charge of the Police Research and Development Branch. Six are individually
responsible for the inspection of a number of forces, and must be satisfied of
their continuing efficiency through formal annual inspection, and informal
visits and consultations when particular problems arise. The inspectors
report to the Home Secretary on the condition of all the forces, with the
exception of the Metropolitan Police Force. The Secretary of State for
Scotland is similarly assisted by Her Majesty’s Chief Inspector of Constabulary
in Scotland and one other inspector.
All police authorities receive a government grant equal to half their net
expenditure except the Common Council of the City of London, which
receives one-third. The Home Secretary and the Secretary of State for Scot¬
land are empowered to withhold the grant, in whole or in part, permanently
or for such time as they may determine, if they are not satisfied that a police
area is efficiently policed, that a force is properly maintained and administered,
or that the rates of pay or allowances are as prescribed or approved by them.
Police Officers In general, entry to the regular police force is open to men between the
ages of 19 and 30. Women entrants in England and Wales must be between
the ages of 19 and 35, and in Scotland between 20 and 30 years old. Men
over 30 years old, and women over 35, may, however, be appointed on the
recommendation of the appointing authority in special circumstances approved
by the Home Secretary in England and Wales. In Scotland the Secretary of
State may approve appointments of both men and women over 30 years old.
The standard police ranks in Great Britain, except in the Metropolitan

Civilian Staff
Special

Police Duties
LAW AND ORDER IO5
Police District, are: chief constable, superintendent, inspector, sergeant and
constable. Intermediate ranks may also be adopted in areas where varying
degrees of responsibility make them necessary. In the Metropolitan Police
District the chief officer is the Commissioner of Police of the Metropolis.
He is assisted by a deputy commissioner and four assistant commissioners.
Next in rank are commanders, then deputy commanders; the other ranks are
the same as in the rest of the country. In the City of London the ranks are the
same as in the regions except that the chief officer is the Commissioner of
Police and the second in command is an assistant commissioner.
No member of the police service may belong to a trade union, since it is a
basic principle of the service that its members must not only be free from
political bias, but must also be seen to be free of it. All ranks, however, have
their own representative associations which can make representations to
ministers or to police authorities on matters of interest or concern to their
members.
Police cadets are recruited by most forces from among boys between 16 and
18 years of age. They have no police powers but are given some training in
police work, partly as useful preparation for subsequent appointment as
constables and partly to give them sufficient insight into police duties to
enable them to decide whether or not they wish to make a career in the police
service. Some forces also recruit girl cadets.
Most police authorities employ civilians as shorthand-typists, switchboard
operators, mechanics, canteen staff and cleaners, in order to release uniformed
personnel for police duties.
All police forces have an attachment of special constables, who are volunteers
willing to perform police duties without pay in their spare time. In England
and Wales the function of special constables is to act as auxiliaries to the
regular force when required. In Scotland they are employed only in emer¬
gencies although they may be assigned for duty for training purposes.
Traffic wardens are extensively employed to discharge specified duties
connected with road traffic and vehicles, normally undertaken by the police.
In this connection they may be authorised to serve fixed penalty notices1 for
minor offences to which the fixed penalty system applies. They may also be
employed to act as parking attendants at street parking places, and as school
crossing patrols, if the police agree. Traffic wardens remain under the control
of the chief constable of the force to which they are attached, whatever duties
they may perform.
A police officer in Great Britain is an independent holder of a public office
and exercises his powers as a constable, whether conferred by statute or by
common law, by virtue of his office; he is an agent of the law of the land, not
of the police authority nor of the central Government and although his chief
officer of police has a vicarious liability for any wrongful act he may commit
in the performance of his functions as a constable, he himself may also be
sued in respect of his own wrongful act.
The many and varied functions of a police officer as a constable range from
the protection of persons and property, road or street patrolling and traffic
control to criminal investigation and the apprehension of offenders.
1 A fixed penalty notice gives the recipient the option of paying a specified sum to the
clerk of the appropriate magistrates’ court, instead of having his case tried in the
ordinary way.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The main departments in all police forces are the uniform department and
the criminal investigation department; many forces have specialised depart¬
ments, including traffic departments, river police (in districts which include
long stretches of navigable waterway), a mounted branch (for maintaining
order and safety in large crowds), and police dogs.
During recent years a number of common services have been provided by
the central government departments for the benefit of all forces; they supple¬
ment those provided by the police authorities for their own use and by
communal arrangements made between the forces themselves. The most
important of these services are: training services, which in England and Wales
provide training centres for recruit training and a central police college for
higher training and in Scotland a central police college with courses of recruit
training and higher training; a forensic science service in England and Wales
which provides eight regional laboratories (in addition to the Metropolitan
Police Laboratory); regional wireless services and wireless depots, which in
England and Wales supply and maintain wireless equipment for the police;
and central and provincial criminal records which are available to all forces.
In addition, regional crime squads, consisting of teams of experienced
detectives from several forces, operating under a committee of chief con¬
stables, are employed to investigate major crimes involving enquiries in
more than one police area. Arrangements are also made for everyday
assistance by one force to another.
The Home Office Police Research and Development Branch, directed by an
Inspector of Constabulary and staffed by senior police officers and scientists,
is charged with the planning of police methods, the development of new
equipment and the study of new techniques throughout Great Britain. A
considerable amount of the work in which the Branch is engaged involves
the use of operational research techniques.
Services provided by the Metropolitan Police Force for other forces include
(1) the publication of the Police Gazette,1 which contains particulars of people
wanted for crime and details of stolen property, and is supplied without
charge to the police forces of the United Kingdom and to certain other Com¬
monwealth and foreign forces; (2) the organisation and control of the special
branch of the criminal investigation department at New Scotland Yard,
whose duties include the protection of royalty, some ministers, and dis¬
tinguished foreign visitors; and (3) the carrying out of extradition orders
made by the courts. The Metropolitan Police Force is also available, on
request, to assist any other police force in England and Wales in criminal
investigations. Similarly, the services of the Fraud Squad, run jointly by
the Metropolitan Police Force and the City of London Police, are available
throughout Great Britain for the investigation of serious company frauds.
The National Central Bureau, which handles the business of the International
Criminal Police Organisation (Interpol) on behalf of Great Britain and the
British dependencies, is part of the Metropolitan Police Force. For certain of
these services, the Metropolitan Police Force receives an additional Exchequer
grant.

The strength of the Royal Ulster Constabulary is approximately 3,200. The
Inspector General has, under his immediate command, a deputy inspector
general, a commissioner for the City of Belfast, and a county inspector for each
of the six counties. The area is further sub-divided into districts, each district
coming under a district inspector and each sub-district under a head constable
or a sergeant. Conditions of service and pay follow closely on the lines of the
police service in Great Britain, and the general duties pertaining to the various
ranks are much the same. Although the more senior ranks bear different titles,
the ranks of head constable, sergeant and constable are broadly equivalent to
the three junior ranks in the police service of Great Britain.
The Ulster Special Constabulary, which may assist the Royal Ulster
Constabulary on special occasions, also comes under the direction of the
Inspector General. In the main, this force is a part-time body of some 8,700
part-time members, with a small nucleus (90) of full-time personnel for
organisation and training purposes.

4 DEFENCE
The foundation of Britain’s security now, as always, lies in the maintenance
of peace in Europe. Accordingly, the first priority of British defence policy is
to continue to give the fullest possible support to the North Atlantic Alliance,
and Britain’s defence effort is being concentrated mainly in Europe and the
North Atlantic area. The withdrawal of British forces from Malaysia and
Singapore is being accelerated for completion by the end of 1971, and
British troops will be withdrawn from the Persian Gulf by the same date.
Thereafter Britain will no longer maintain any special capability for use
outside Europe, but will still have a general capability, based in Europe,
which can be deployed overseas as—in the judgment of the British Govern-
ment—circumstances demand, and which could support United Nations
operations as necessary.
Britain still has, however, a great interest in the stability of the Middle and
Far East, and continues as a member of the Central Treaty Organisation
(CENTO) and the South East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO). Also,
Britain is ultimately responsible for the defence and internal security of her
remaining dependencies. More generally, the British Government is anxious
to strengthen the peace-keeping capacities of the United Nations and to make
progress in arms control and disarmament. Britain has signed, and strongly
supports, the 1963 treaty banning nuclear tests and the treaty agreed in 1967
governing the peaceful uses of outer space. After taking a leading part in the
preparatory negotiations, Britain became one of the three depositary powers
of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty of 1968 and was the first nuclear
weapon power to ratify the treaty.
Information about defence policy and the armed forces is provided by the
Government in an annual Statement on the Defence Estimates (Cmnd. 3927 in
1969) usually published in February.
The highest possible proportions of Britain’s regular forces are kept in
effective combat units. The Army has had more recent and varied fighting
experience than any other European army; the Royal Air Force, equipped
with the most modern combat aircraft, is second to none in Europe; while
the size and striking power of the Royal Navy is second only to that of the
United States within the North Atlantic Alliance.
The Government is concerned to keep defence costs within the country s
resources, and since the 1965-66 estimates were published there have been
successive reductions in the annual defence estimates as calculated at constant
prices. The defence estimates for 1969-70 totalled £2,266 million, which
was expected to amount to under 6 per cent of the gross national product.
PLANNING AND CONTROL
Supreme responsibility for national defence rests with the Prime Minister and
the Cabinet, who are responsible to Parliament. Defence problems and their
implications for foreign and economic policy are dealt with on the Cabinet s
behalf by the Committee on Defence and Oversea Policy, under the chair¬
manship of the Prime Minister.

Organisation

Services
COMMANDS
Royal Navy
109
The formulation of defence policy is the responsibility of the Secretary of
State for Defence. The two Ministers of Defence and the three Parliamentary
Under-Secretaries of State (see p. 48), together with the Chief of the Defence
Staff, the Chiefs of Staff, the Permanent Under-Secretary of State, the Chief
Adviser (Projects and Research) and the Chief Adviser (Personnel and
Logistics), sit on the Defence Council under the chairmanship of the Secretary
of State. The Defence Council deals mainly with major defence policy. The
Chiefs of Staff Committee, comprising the Chief of Defence Staff as chairman
and the Chiefs of Staff of the three Services, is responsible for giving pro¬
fessional advice on strategy and operations and the military implications of
defence policy.
The emphasis in defence organisation has been, in recent years, on a greater
degree of integration between the three Services and on overall, functional
planning of the defence effort as a whole. To this end, the three former Service
departments were amalgamated under a unified Ministry of Defence.
The day-to-day management of the three Services is the responsibility of the
Admiralty, Army and Air Force Boards of the Defence Council. The Service
Boards are chaired by the single-Service Parliamentary Under-Secretaries of
State, although the Secretary of State is formally chairman of each Board and
the functional Ministers are members and take the chair on occasions.
The Royal Navy has four main arms. These are: the Naval General Service,
which mans and maintains the surface fleet; the Fleet Air Arm; the Submarine
Service; and the Royal Marines, who provide a seaborne and airborne land
striking-force.
The Army is organised into some 30 arms and services which include the
Household Cavalry, the Royal Armoured Corps, the Royal Regiment of
Artillery, the Corps of Royal Engineers, the Royal Corps of Signals, the five
regiments of Foot Guards, the Infantry of the Line (being grouped into
divisions), the Army Air Corps, the Royal Corps of Transport, the Royal
Army Medical Corps, the Royal Army Ordnance Corps and the Royal
Electrical and Mechanical Engineers.
The Royal Air Force is organised in commands, on a functional basis at
home and on a geographical basis overseas.
The three women’s services, the Women’s Royal Naval Service (WRNS), the
Women’s Royal Army Corps (WRAC) and the Women’s Royal Air Force
(W RAF), are integral parts of the Navy, Army and Air Force respectively.
Servicewomen serve alongside servicemen in Britain and overseas. Nursing
services are provided by Queen Alexandra’s Royal Naval Nursing Service,
Queen Alexandra s Royal Army Nursing Corps and Princess Mary’s Royal
Air Force Nursing Service.
Operational control of the Forces in the Persian Gulf and Far East is exercised
through Unified Command Headquarters in Bahrain (see p. 113) and
Singapore respectively by a single commander, who may belong to any one of
the three Services; he is supported by an inter-Service staff co-ordinated by a
Chief of Staff.
The home and overseas commands of the Services are set out below.
Under a phased programme shore commands are being reorganised under a
single Commander-in-Chief in Portsmouth. Sea command has been
reorganised to bring under a single major operational commander, the

Entrants to the non-commissioned ranks of the three Services are given basic
training, and further training is given during the course of their careers.
Young servicemen have the opportunity to read for the General Certificate of
Education ‘O’ level (see p. 153). Trade and technical training, though
primarily designed for Service purposes, leads in many cases to nationally
recognised qualifications; completion of many Service trade or technical
courses followed by experience is recognised by trade unions as a qualification
for membership by men who have left the Services.
Commissions may be granted for short, medium or long terms. Promotion
from the non-commissioned ranks is possible in all three Services. In the
Royal Navy, the normal method of entry is through cadetships in the Britannia
Royal Naval College, Dartmouth; in the Army through cadetships in the
Royal Military Academy Sandhurst. This is followed by specialist training
which may include degree courses. In the RAF entry is through cadetships
in the RAF College, Cranwell, or civilian universities. There is special

provision in all three Services for the entry of men with appropriate qualifica¬
tions, including doctors, dentists and other graduates.
Selected officers of all three Services who have had previous staff training or
have been to the Royal Naval Staff College, Greenwich (London), the Army
Staff College at Camberley (Surrey), or the Royal Air Force Staff Colleges
(due to be merged in 1970) at Bracknell (Berkshire) or Andover (Hampshire)
go to the Joint Services Staff College at Chesham (Buckinghamshire), where
particular attention is paid to the inter-Service aspect of staff work. A few
specially selected and more senior officers from the Services, the Civil
Service, and from other Commonwealth and allied European countries are
sent to the Imperial Defence College in London. Considerable training is
done through Joint-Service and inter-allied exercises, on which increasing
emphasis is being placed.
In the defence estimates for 1969-70 £22 million is allocated to Reserve and
Auxiliary Formations.
The Regular Reserve consists of various categories of former full-time officers
and ratings liable to recall in emergency. The Voluntary Reserves comprise
the Royal Naval Reserve (with its associated women’s reserve) and the Royal
Marines Reserve, and carry out part-time training.
The Royal Naval Auxiliary Service, a civilian organisation composed of
men and women volunteers, is responsible in time of war for minewatching
duties around the coast and the waterways, and other duties.
Men who have completed the Colour portion of their service with the Regular
Army are retained on the Regular Reserve to complete a total engagement of
seven or 12 years, according to their initial commitment; they are liable to
recall to the Colours. Thereafter they are transferred to the Long Term
Reserve (LTR) where they remain until the age of 45 and are liable to recall
in an emergency.
The Territorial and Army Volunteer Reserve (T and AVR) consists of
independent and sponsored units. Independent units are recruited from a
limited area as existing formations. Sponsored units consist of specialists and
have to be recruited on a nation-wide basis. These units are divided, for
administration purposes, into Group A which have a liability for call-out
when war-like operations are in preparation or in progress; and Group B
which consists of miscellaneous units (for example, University Officer
Training Corps) with various liabilities.
The Regular Reserve consists of former full-time officers and airmen, of whom
a few are detailed for specific tasks in emergency and the remainder have a
statutory liability for recall. The Royal Auxiliary Air Force, consisting of
three maritime headquarter units controlled by Coastal Command (see p. 110),
and the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve, which includes the 16 University
Air Squadrons, are liable for part-time training and for recall in an
emergency.
The Government decided in 1968 to put civil defence arrangements on a care
and maintenance basis. The physical assets of civil defence organisations are
being preserved so far as is practicable, and training and planning continues
at the minimum level required to maintain knowledge and techniques and to

enable more active preparations to be resumed if this should appear to be
necessary. Total annual expenditure on home defence by civil departments—
which is additional to that carried on the Defence Budget—was reduced to
about £13 million in 1968-69, and is intended to fall in subsequent years to
about £7 million.
The arrangements being maintained include an emergency system for
decentralised governmental control and communications, and the United
Kingdom Warning and Monitoring Organisation, including the Royal
Observer Corps, which would provide public warning of an attack, of the
location and power of nuclear explosions, and of the distribution and level of
radioactive fall-out.
NATO COMMITMENT
From November 1968 the following British forces were assigned or ear¬
marked for assignment to the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO).
Virtually the whole of the Royal Navy is earmarked for assignment.
The British Army of the Rhine (BAOR) is assigned; 3 Division, which
includes 16 Parachute Brigade (two battalions), 22 Special Air Service Regi¬
ment, a logistic battalion, and an armoured reconnaissance squadron, are
earmarked for assignment.
Germany: RAF Germany is assigned. Britain: V-Bomber Force is assigned;
Canberra and Victor reconnaissance aircraft are earmarked; air defence
aircraft of Strike Command are assigned; long-range maritime reconnaissance
aircraft are earmarked; the short-range and close-support aircraft of No. 38
Group are earmarked. Malta: Canberra reconnaissance aircraft are assigned;
long-range maritime reconnaissance aircraft are earmarked.
DEPLOYMENT
In January 1969 British and locally enlisted uniformed troops were deployed
roughly as follows:
Britain, 246,000; European continent, 59,600 (nearly all in Germany);
Mediterranean and Near East, 17,500; Middle and Far East, 51,500
(including Gurkhas); and elsewhere, 37,000 (mostly Royal Navy at sea).
The deployment of forces is summarised below.
The Western Fleet operates in European sea areas; frigates, submarines and
coastal minesweepers carry out training, trials and fishery protection, and
ships of all classes spend periods at home for refitting. All ships at home have
NATO commitments in the Channel, Eastern Atlantic, and Mediterranean;
a frigate is assigned to the standing Naval Force Atlantic.
Stationed in Britain are Army Strategic Command, certain other field
headquarters and combat units, and training and logistic units.
The Royal Air Force in Britain consists of units of Strike Command,
comprising aircraft of the former Bomber and Fighter Commands, strategic
reconnaissance and tanker aircraft; Air Support Command, with strategic and
tactical transport aircraft, and ground-attack reconnaissance forces whose
DEFENCE
H3
Germafiy
Mediterranean
Persian Gulf
Far East
main role is to support the Army. Long-range maritime reconnaissance
aircraft for protection of sea routes, in conjunction with the Royal Navy, will
come within the Maritime Group of Strike Command. There are also units of
the Royal Air Force Regiment. The Ballistic Missile Early Warning Station at
Fylingdales Moor, Yorkshire, built under an Anglo-American agreement of
i960, is part of a chain of such stations starting in Alaska and Greenland.
Britain has stationed in the Federal Republic of Germany an army corps of
three divisions—BAOR—with associated troops and a tactical air force
including light bomber, reconnaissance and air-defence squadrons; also
fighter reconnaissance aircraft and a brigade in Berlin (which the NATO
powers have agreed to treat as part of the Atlantic Treaty area): giving a total
force of some 60,000. BAOR equipment includes, as tactical nuclear weapons,
the Honest John free-flight missile and the 8-inch howitzer. A brigade of
BAOR, together with a heavy air-defence regiment, is stationed in Britain.
In the Mediterranean Britain’s maritime presence generally includes an
aircraft carrier, a commando ship or an assault ship, and two frigates which are
earmarked for assignment to Supreme Allied Commander Europe (SACEUR);
a guided-missile destroyer will be added in 1970.
Britain contributes towards the defence infra-structure of the Central
Treaty Organisation (CENTO) area and keeps an RAF bomber force in
Cyprus for the defence of the region. Britain also supplies at its own expense
over 1,000 men for the United Nations Force in Cyprus (about 30 per cent
of the total). There are also small garrisons in Malta, Gibraltar and Libya.
British Land Forces in the Persian Gulf consist of infantry supported by
artillery, armoured cars and engineers stationed at Bahrain and Sharjah. RAF
forces also based at Bahrain and Sharjah include ground-attack and fighter
reconnaissance, tactical transport and long-range maritime reconnaissance
aircraft. Royal Navy frigates and coastal minesweepers, based at Bahrain,
operate in the Gulf.
In the South East Asia Treaty Organisation (SEATO) area, Britain provides
training facilities and, in particular, has built an airfield in Thailand with the
help of Australia and New Zealand.
Naval forces in Far East Command contain most types of warships and fleet
auxiliaries, including a commando ship, an assault ship, submarines, and
frigates. These forces operate in the Indian and Pacific Oceans and undertake
patrol duties in the Mozambique channel. Ships of the Royal Australian and
Royal New Zealand Navies operate with the Far Eastern Fleet.
Britain has retained in the Far East only army units required to assist in the
defence of Malaysia and Singapore, and of British dependencies, and for
commitments to SEATO. The reduction in the Brigade of Gurkhas has
continued towards the level of 6,000 men to be reached by 1971.
A small garrison of Gurkhas is stationed in Brunei. A substantial garrison,
including a Gurkha brigade, remains in Hong Kong.
The Far East Air Force, made up of units of the RAF and Royal Australian
and Royal New Zealand Air Forces, includes fighter, light-bomber, ground-
attack, tactical sea and long-range maritime reconnaissance, support heli¬
copter, short- and medium-range transport and surface-to-air missile
squadrons as well as squadrons of the Royal Air Force Regiment.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Two frigates, normally carrying a detachment of Royal Marines, operate in
the Caribbean. A small Royal Marine force and a hovercraft unit are main¬
tained in the Falkland Islands, and the Navy’s ice-patrol ship, HMS
Endurance, operates there seasonally.
A small Army garrison remains in British Honduras.
COMBAT FORCES
Combat forces can be divided into six major groups, according to their
functions and corresponding equipment, as described below.
During 1969, the Royal Navy took over from the V-bombers of the Royal
Air Force the entire task of making the British contribution to the Western
nuclear strategic deterrent. Three Polaris submarines, HMS Resolution,
HMS Repulse and HMS Renown are now operational, and a fourth, HMS
Revenge, has been accepted into service. Transferred to a tactical role the
Vulcan aircraft remain committed to NATO.
Each Polaris submarine carries 16 missiles with nuclear warheads and a
range of some 2,500 nautical miles. The submarines’ nuclear-powered engines
enable them to cruise, submerged, for long periods. The Polaris and other
submarines are supported by the Clyde submarine base completed in 1968.
Britain also provides facilities for a depot ship for United States Polaris
submarines at Holy Loch on the Firth of Clyde.
Britain has assigned its strategic nuclear forces to NATO. The British
Government considers it essential to associate the non-nuclear members of
NATO closely with the nuclear policy of the Alliance, and thus to strengthen
the nuclear interdependence of its members, and Britain has played an active
part in discussions for this purpose.
The cost of nuclear strategic forces for 1969-70 is estimated at £5 million
for the bomber force, and £55 million for the Polaris fleet.
The European theatre ground forces consist of the BAOR and an independent
brigade in Berlin. Their cost in 1969-70 is estimated at ^203 million. (RAF
Germany, is included among RAF Combat Forces, see p. 116.)
Armoured regiments are being equipped with the Chieftain main battle tank,
which incorporates many new features in protection and mobility, in succes¬
sion to the Centurion. Two armoured car regiments are equipped with the
Vigilant anti-tank guided weapon mounted on the Ferret scout car. Swingfire,
a long-range, guided, anti-tank weapon, was introduced into certain units
during 1969. The field artillery has been re-equipped. New weapons include
the British Abbot self-propelled 105 mm. gun with good cross-country
mobility, range, fire power and protection for its crew, and the American self-
propelled 155 mm. Mi09 and 175 mm. Mi07 guns. Missile regiments
equipped with the Honest John free-flight rocket and the 8-inch howitzer
provide surface-to-surface tactical nuclear support for the ground forces.
Infantry battalions have tracked armoured personnel carriers. Some armoured
personnel carriers in each battalion are being converted to fire the 81 mm.
mortar or the Wombat anti-tank gun, and some are being fitted with a mount
for the general purpose machine gun. The infantry have also been provided
with Carl Gustav anti-tank weapons, and with improved chemical and
nuclear defensive equipment. Brigade headquarters are equipped with Scout
helicopters, used mainly for reconnaissance. A semi-automatic multi-channel

trunk system for communications in the combat area came into operation
during 1968.
The naval general purpose combat elements of the Fleet1 comprise the
following: amphibious forces; aircraft carriers and squadrons; submarines
(excluding the Polaris force); cruisers, destroyers and frigates; mine counter¬
measures forces; and support and other ships. Any of these forces can be sent
to other theatres if needed in an emergency, either as reinforcements or to
carry out joint operations with the Army and Royal Air Force. Their cost in
1969-70 is estimated at £280 million.
The aircraft carriers HMS Eagle and HMS Hermes are to be in commission
during 1969. The carriers are equipped with the angled flight deck, the steam
catapult, the automatic aircraft positioning device for the catapult and the
projector sight (all British inventions). After refit and conversion HMS Ark
Royal will carry Phantom aircraft early in 1970. The main strike and fighter
strength is at present provided by Buccaneer, Sea Vixen and Phantom aircraft.
The Buccaneer Mark 2 is a long-range low-level strike aircraft with an
advanced weapon system. The Sea Vixen Mark 2 carries air-to-air missiles
Firestreak and Red Top for use against high-flying and supersonic targets.
An advanced air defence aircraft with true supersonic performance, the
Phantom, is equipped with both Sparrow and Sidewinder air-to-air missiles.
The carrier force will be phased out when the withdrawal of British forces
from Singapore and Malaysia is complete.
Amphibious forces are provided by the commando ships HMS Albion and
HMS Bulwark, the assault ships HMS Fearless and HMS Intrepid, and the
Royal Marine Commandos. Commando ships are equipped with landing
craft, Wessex Mark 5 helicopters, which can be armed with the SS 11 anti¬
tank guided missile, and Sioux helicopters. Of the three Tiger class cruisers
HMS Blake has been converted to carry Sea King helicopters and HMS Tiger
is being converted; it is planned to convert HMS Lion later. The cruisers have
fully automatic armament and the most modern control equipment. Destroyers
and frigates, the largest part of the Fleet, give the main surface protection
against enemy submarines and surface and air forces. Work on three new
classes of surface ship—cruisers, destroyers and frigates—is going ahead and
the first Type 82 guided-missile destroyer, HMS Bristol, launched in July
1969, will introduce into the Fleet in 1971 the new advanced area anti-aircraft
and anti-missile weapon system Sea Dart, as well as the anti-submarine
weapon, Ikara, specially developed to counter fast submarines.
The six County class guided-missile destroyers are to be joined by two more
in 1969. Leander class frigates have advanced anti-submarine equipment
including variable-depth and medium-range sonar and mortars; both they
and Tribal class frigates can carry Wasp anti-submarine helicopters.
All ships of frigate size and above are to carry helicopters. The Whirlwind
Mark 9 helicopter carries out search and rescue duties, and the Wessex Mark 1
and Wasp are for anti-submarine tasks. The yet more advanced Wessex
Mark 3, with a new anti-submarine system, is now in service, to be followed
in 1969 by the introduction of Sea King, a British-built and British-engined
1 In 1969 the following ships of the Fleet were operational, preparing for service, or

45 minesweepers, and an ice-patrol ship. In addition the following were in reserve or
undergoing long refit, conversion, etc.: 1 aircraft carrier, 2 cruisers, 11 destroyers,
14 frigates, 12 submarines and 20 minesweepers.

addition to their anti-submarine function, will be able, if required, to carry
out reconnaissance and light surface attack with air-to-sui face missiles.
The submarine has been revolutionised by nuclear power propulsion,
which enables it to operate submerged for prolonged periods at sustained high
speed. Three nuclear-powered Fleet submarines are now in service—
Dreadnought, Valiant and War spite. Two more, Churchill and Conqueror have
been launched; three more are under construction.
Support-ships replenish the Fleet and offer it maintenance and repair
facilities. They include submarine depot ships (equipped with workshops
and plant to support a squadron or more of submarines), a heavy repair and
maintenance ship and mine counter-measures support ships, all manned by
naval personnel. Ships of the Royal Fleet Auxiliary Service provide afloat
logistic support such as fuel, food, ammunition, stores and spare gear. These
ships fly the Blue Ensign and are manned by Merchant Navy officers and
seamen. The dockyards at Portsmouth, Devonport, Chatham and Rosyth
provide the Navy with major supplies and repair facilities in Britain.
Army general purpose combat forces consist of the ground forces deployed
outside Europe; the Army Strategic Command; and other front line units in
Britain. Their cost in 1969-70 is estimated at £154 million.
Army Strategic Command consists of most of the field force units stationed
in Britain and their supporting services. These units are capable of varying
operations and are available to NATO for use in Europe.
A general-purpose machine-gun has been introduced to replace the Vickers
and Bren in infantry battalions, which have also all been issued with the
81 mm. mortar. Some battalions have the Conbat, an improved version of the
Mobat heavy anti-tank weapon, while others are equipped with Vigilant anti¬
tank missiles. Other equipment includes night-fighting devices, engineer
equipment for crossing obstacles, and the Stalwart high-mobility load-carrier.
Field Artillery Computer Equipment (FACE) is being issued to units in
Britain. A new British air-portable bridge came into service early in 1969.
The Army’s force of helicopters is being increased. These can be used for
reconnaissance, to carry patrols, casualties and urgently needed stores, and
as airborne command posts. Armed helicopters have been used successfully
in operations. The Army also has Canadian Beaver light aircraft for liaison
purposes. The Landing Ship Tank (LST), for support operations, has been
superseded by the faster and more advanced Landing Ship Logistic (LSL).
An Army Hovercraft Unit has been formed, of four Westland hovercraft
modified for military use.
The Royal Air Force combat forces comprise all the front-line formations
and units, including the medium bomber force (when it is transferred to a
tactical role) but excluding transport and tanker forces. They fall into five
main categories: air defence, ground attack and fighter reconnaissance;
medium and light bomber and tactical reconnaissance; maritime recon¬
naissance; headquarters; and general support, including the Royal Air Force
Regiment, which is responsible for protecting bases. Their cost in 1969-70
is estimated at £367 million.
Fighter squadrons are equipped with Lightning Mark 3 and Mark 6 supersonic
aircraft, which carry Firestreak or Red Top air-to-air missiles and can be
refuelled in flight. Air defence is also the function of the Bloodhound Mark 2

New military radars and centralised data-handling equipment are being
installed in Britain as part of the integrated plans for air defence and national
air traffic control. The Ballistic Missile Early Warning Station at Fylingdales
(see p. 113) would provide warning of a missile attack on Britain and also
detects, tracks and identifies objects in orbit.
The Royal Air Force is being re-equipped with Phantom, Buccaneer and
Harrier aircraft. A first Phantom squadron became operational in May 1969,
replacing the Hunter in ground attack and army support roles. A squadron
for maritime air defence will be formed by the end of 1969. Transferred from
the Royal Navy, Buccaneer aircraft formed an RAF maritime strike squadron
during 1969; these will be supplemented by an additional order. On entering
squadron service in 1969 the Harrier became the first vertical take-off and
landing aircraft in the world to do so. A further squadron was ordered in
November 1968. It is planned that a strike version of the Anglo-French
Jaguar light-strike and trainer aircraft should release further Phantoms from
this role to replace the Lightning fighters. Overseas fighter-reconnaissance
squadrons are equipped with Hunter FR10 aircraft.
Reconnaissance forces comprise the Canberra PR7 and Victor Mark 2
aircraft. Maritime-reconnaissance squadrons are equipped with modernised
Shackleton Mark 2 and Mark 3 aircraft. In addition to their reconnaissance
functions they can also be used for attacking surface ships and submarines,
and as transport aircraft. The Shackleton Mark 2 is being replaced by the
Nimrod (the first all-turbo-jet maritime reconnaissance aircraft); a first
squadron will be operational early in 1970.
Air mobility forces are made up of the strategic and tactical transport forces,
tanker aircraft to refuel combat aircraft in flight, support helicopters and
communications aircraft. Their cost in 1969-70 is estimated at £98 million
(which includes £3 million on civil charter).
The strategic transport force includes Comet 4C, Britannia, Belfast and VC 10
aircraft. Tactical transport is supplied by United States Hercules aircraft and
the Argosy. The short-range tactical transports are the Pioneer and Twin
Pioneer aircraft, the Belvedere, Whirlwind and Wessex helicopters, and the
Andover Mark 1 short-range military freighter. The Victor tanker aircraft can
refuel two or three aircraft at the same time. The Basset (Beagle B 206) and
Andover C Mark 2 aircraft are used for communications.
WEAPONS AND EQUIPMENT
Responsibility for the supply of aircraft, guided weapons, nuclear weapons
and certain radar and other electronic equipment lies with the Ministry of
Technology. The Ministry of Defence is responsible for the procurement of
other weapons, stores and equipment. Total expenditure on research and
development for 1969-70 was estimated at ^236 million.
A substantial part of the equipment used by the Services is developed and
produced in Britain, some by private industry on a contract basis and some
by the Royal Ordnance Factories, the Royal Dockyards and other establish¬
ments operated by the Ministry of Technology and the Ministry of Defence.
Production of nuclear warheads is undertaken by the Atomic Energy Authority

Research and development are undertaken at a number of the Ministry of

establishments, and the progress of military research often contributes to related

Much experimental work has been carried out by the Navy and the Atomic
Energy Authority on nuclear-propelled submarines (see p. 116), and a nuclear
submarine power unit prototype is in operation at Dounreay (see p. 201). T e
Royal Naval College, Greenwich, has a low-power training reactor whic
provides facilities for basic education in nuclear engineering and research.
Guided missiles are tested at the Ministry of Technology’s research establish¬
ments and at the Woomera range set up in Australia under the Joint United
Kingdom/Australia Guided Weapon Project. Service firing trials of air-to-air
and surface-to-air missiles are carried out at Aberporth and at the Army
gunnery range in Anglesey; a range for testing surface-to-surface missiles has
been set up on South Uist in the Hebrides.
Research into nuclear weapons began in Britain during the second world war
It was continued, as an allied project, in the United States where the firs
atomic bomb was produced. After a subsequent period of independent
development in both countries, collaboration was resumed in 1955, and in
19C8 an agreement was concluded which made possible the exchange o
information on the design and manufacture of nuclear weapons This was
supplemented by a further agreement in May 1959, which contained provisions
to enable Britain to buy from the United States component parts of atomic
weapons and weapons systems other than actual warheads, and to make
possible the exchange of nuclear materials between the two countries.
Britain’s nuclear programme is based on an agreement of 19 3 ^ ^
Britain buys from the United States a number of Mure missiles, to be fitted
with British nuclear warheads, for submarines to be built largely by Bnta. .

In addition to research and development, there is support of a general nature
supplied in Britain to the Services as a whole. The major items include:

cost for 1969-70 is £846 million.
USE OF MANPOWER AND RESOURCES
Long-term reductions in defence manpower of some 75,000 uniformed
personnel and 80,000 civilians were originally envisaged in July 1967, to be
completed by the mid-1970s. These reductions are being accelerated, and it
is now expected that the reduction in uniformed personnel will be somewhat
greater and that it will be achieved during the financial year 1973-74. The
civilian reduction will also be larger and completed earlier than previously
forecast. Tables 7 and 8 below and diagrams on p. 120 show the actual

5 SOCIAL WELFARE
STATE AND VOLUNTARY SERVICES
In Britain the State is responsible, through either central or local govern¬
ment, for a range of services covering family allowances, social insurance, help
for war victims, financial assistance when required, health and welfare services
for mothers and young children, the sick, mentally disordered, elderly and
handicapped and for families in difficulties of various kinds, and the care of
children lacking a normal home fife (all described in this chapter); and for
education (see Chapter 6) and housing (see Chapter 7). Public authorities in
the United Kingdom are spending nearly £8,700 million a year on this range
of services; that is, over £157 a year per head of the population.
Voluntary organisations, especially the Churches, were the pioneers of
nearly all the social services. They provided schools, hospitals, clinics,
dispensaries, and social and recreational, clubs before these were provided by
the State. They made themselves responsible for the welfare of the very young
and the very old, the homeless and the handicapped. Gradually the State
accepted the primary responsibility for the major services, supplementing the
voluntary services and developing a comprehensive structure that ensured a
minimum standard of living and well-being for all citizens.
State and voluntary social services are now complementary and co-operative.
The State may work through voluntary agencies specially adapted to serve
particular needs and ensures that necessary standards are maintained. The
officers of central and local government, in carrying out their duties, co-operate
with the workers of many voluntary social service societies, while the resi¬
dential provision made by the State and by local authorities for the care of the
chronic sick and the aged is supplemented by voluntary homes of various
types. Most of the sick and elderly receive State pensions or benefits.
The Charity Commission, a government department, gives free advice to
trustees of charities, making schemes to modify their purposes or facilitate
their administration when necessary; it maintains central and local registers
of charities which are open to public inspection; and it works to promote
co-operation between charities and State services.
Voluntary The number of voluntary societies and institutions in Britain runs into
Organisations thousands; they range from national organisations to small individual local
groups. Most organisations, however, are members of larger associations or
are represented on local or national co-ordinating councils or committees.
Some are chiefly concerned with giving personal service, others in the forma¬
tion of public opinion and exchange of information. A number are concerned
with giving help to immigrants. In recent years there has been an increase in
organised service by young people.
Organisations concerned with personal and family problems and misfortunes
include the voluntary family casework agencies, of which the Family Welfare
Association, working mainly in London, is the best known; marriage guidance
centres affiliated to the National Marriage Guidance Council; the Family
Service Units; and the National Council for the Unmarried Mother and her
Child.
122
Social Workers
Urban
Programme
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Voluntary service to the sick and disabled in general is given by the British
Red Cross Society, the St. John Ambulance Association and Brigade and the
Leagues of Hospital Friends, but a number of societies exist to help people
with particular disabilities, such as the Royal National Institute for the
Blind, the Royal National Institute for the Deaf, the National Association for
Mental Health, the constituent members of the Central Council for the
Disabled and their Scottish equivalents.
Bodies working on a national scale whose work is specificall} religious in
inspiration include the Salvation Army, the Church Army, Toe H, the
Committee on Social Service of the Church of Scotland, the Church of
England Children’s Society, the Church of England Council for Social Work,
the Young Men’s Christian Association, the Young Women’s Christian
Association, the Society of Friends, the Crusade of Rescue, the Society of
St. Vincent de Paul, the Catholic Marriage Advisory Council and the Jewish
Welfare Board. J
A wide range of voluntary personal service is given by the Women s Royal
Voluntary Service, which gives help in every kind of practical difficulty, brings
‘meals on wheels’ to housebound invalids and old people, piovides flatlets and
residential clubs for the elderly, helps with family problems and assists in
hospitals and clinics, as well as doing relief work in emergencies.
A central link between voluntary organisations and official bodies concerned
with social welfare is provided in England and V ales by the National Council
of Social Service, which brings together most of the principal voluntary
agencies for consultation and joint action, either as a whole or in groups of
those concerned with particular aspects, such as youth work or old people’s
welfare. There are also the Scottish Council of Social Service ana the Northern
Ireland Council of Social Service, which perform similar functions. The
Citizens’ Advice Bureaux, of which there are now nearly 500 in Britain,
are steadily increasing in number. The primary role of the bureaux is to give
explanation and advice to the citizen who is in doubt about his rights or who
does not know about the State or voluntary services which could help him.
While the voluntary worker giving full-time or part-time service has done
pioneer work in many of Britain’s social services and continues to play an
essential part, social services of all kinds increasingly depend for their opera¬
tion chiefly on professional social workers, that is, full-time salaried workers
trained in the principles and methods of social work. Most proxessional social
workers are employed by local authorities (for child care, welfare, mental
welfare and probation work), by hospitals (for medical and psychiatiic work),
or by voluntary organisations. Training for many forms of social work
consists of a basic university degree, diploma or certificate course in social
science followed by a university course in applied social studies or specialised
training for a particular service. The latter is sometimes organised by the
profession concerned. The Council for Training in Social Work also
promotes the training, in the first instance, of workers in the local authority
health and welfare services and similar services run by voluntary bodies.
Full-time courses lasting two years, which may be taken at colleges of further
education, lead to the Council’s Certificate in Social Work. Advice on social
work training is given by the Social Work Advisory Service.
A four-year urban programme providing for Government-aided local
authority expenditure of some £20-£2$ million was launched at the end of
1968 to assist areas of special social need, in particular to relieve problems
SOCIAL WELFARE
123
resulting from overcrowding, inadequate housing and schools, and other
forms of deprivation. Projects being undertaken include help for play-groups
and the provision and improvement of nursery schools and classes, day
nurseries, playgrounds, language classes for immigrants, in-service training
courses for teachers, children’s homes, and family advice centres.
An experiment in community development has also been started by
the Government. This will involve bringing together those services, both
statutory and voluntary, which are concerned with reheving various forms of
social handicap and encouraging the resources of self-help within the
community.
SOCIAL SECURITY
National insurance, industrial injuries insurance, family allowances and
supplementary benefits together with (in a special category) war pensions
constitute a comprehensive system of social security in the United Kingdom.
The Department of Health and Social Security administers these services
in Great Britain; within the Department the Supplementary Benefits Commis¬
sion is responsible for the system of supplementary benefits. In Northern
Ireland the first four of these schemes are administered by the Ministry of
Health and Social Services which contains the Supplementary Benefits
Commission for Northern Ireland. Pensions and welfare services for war
pensioners and their dependants are the responsibility of the Department of
Health and Social Security throughout the United Kingdom. Appeals
relating to claims for insurance benefits, family allowances, war pensions, or
for supplementary benefit, are decided by independent authorities.
Although the development of public provision for social security in Britain
can be traced back for several centuries (the Poor Relief Act of 1601 may be
regarded as specially important in England and Wales), the modern system of
comprehensive provision is a creation of the twentieth century. Non-contri¬
butory old age pensions were introduced in 1908, and the first contributory
pensions for old people, widows and orphans in 1926. A contributory National
Plealth Insurance Scheme was begun in 1912, and in the same year a scheme
of unemployment insurance was introduced which in 1920 was extended to
cover the great majority of employees. By the beginning of the second world
war social security provision in Britain was among the best in the world, but
lacked co-ordination because of its piecemeal development, and not everyone
came within its scope. In the immediate post-war years a series of Acts
introduced the present comprehensive system, which became fully operative
on 5th July 1948. Statutory provision for the war disabled goes back to the
end of the sixteenth century, but the main lines of the present war pension
provisions were laid down during the first world war.
Family allowances and national insurance benefits or allowances, other than
maternity, unemployment or sickness benefit, are included in the taxable
income on which income tax is assessed. On the other hand, various income
tax reliefs and exemptions are allowed on account of age or liability for the
support of dependants. War disablement pensions are not taxable.
leciprocity The national insurance, industrial injuries and family allowances schemes of
Great Britain and those of Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man operate as a
single system. Reciprocal agreements on industrial injuries, family allowances
and most national insurance benefits are in operation with Belgium, Denmark,
Finland, the Federal Republic of Germany, Jersey and Guernsey, Norway,
124
FAMILY
ALLOWANCES
NATIONAL
INSURANCE
Contributors
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Sweden, Switzerland, and Yugoslavia. Agreements with France, the Republic
of Ireland, Israel, Italy, Luxembourg, Malta, the Netherlands, and Turkey
cover industrial injuries and most national insurance benefits. With Australia
and New Zealand there are agreements on family allowances and most
national insurance benefits. An agreement with Cyprus covers all national
insurance benefits. There is a limited agreement with Canada. Northern
Ireland and the Isle of Man are also party to most of these agreements with
other countries.
Family allowances are provided in Great Britain under the Family Allowances
Act 1965 (which consolidated the Acts of 1945-64), and in Northern Ireland
under its own legislation. Over 6-6 million allowances are being paid in Great
Britain to more than 4 million families with two or more children, and in
Northern Ireland to 129,000 families. An allowance is paid for each child other
than the first child below the age limits. The age limits are 15 years for
children who leave school at that age, 16 years for certain incapacitated
children, and 19 for children who remain at school or are apprentices.
The rate of the allowance is 18s. a week for the second child below the age
limits and 20s. a week for the third and each subsequent child. .
Family allowances are paid from the Exchequer and their object is to benefit
the family as a whole; they belong to the mother, but may be paid either to
the mother or to the father. There is no insurance qualification for title to
the allowances, but there are certain residence conditions.
The National Insurance Acts apply, in general, to everyone over minimum
school-leaving age living in Great Britain. There are similar schemes in
Northern Ireland and the Isle of Man. (The National Insurance Act 1965
consolidated the provisions of the National Insurance Acts 1946-64.)
The national insurance scheme1 provides benefits in specified contingencies
where contribution conditions have been fulfilled. The benefits are paid for
partly by insured persons’ contributions, partly by contributions of employers
in respect of their employees, and partly by a contribution made by the
Exchequer out of general taxation. . _
The original system was based on flat-rate contributions and benehts.
Contributions varied only with the sex and insurance class of the insured
person and benefits were at standard rates. (In both cases lower rates apply to
those under 18.) Two modifications were subsequently introduced to provide
additional earnings-related contributions and benefits, dor retirement,
graduated contributions and pensions were introduced in 1961. For the first
six months of sickness, unemployment or widowhood the National Insurance
Act 1966 introduced a scheme for earnings-related supplements to the flat-rate
benefit and contributions. In November 1969 changes are to be made in the
graduated contribution scheme as a step towards the new fully earnings-related
scheme (see above) and new contributions and benefit rates are to be
introduced. The rates given in the following pages are those in force from
that date.
Contributors under the national insurance scheme are divided into three classes:
Class 1. Employed people. Those who work for an employer under a contract
of service or are paid apprentices—over 23 million.  
1 In a White Paper published in January 1969 (see Bibliography p. 473) the Government
proposed a sctemeof earnings-related social security to replace the present national
insurance scheme.
SOCIAL WELFARE
Contributions
125
Class 2. Self-employed people. Those in business on their own account and
others who are working for gain but do not work under the control of an
employer—about milhon.
Class 3. Non-employed people. All those insured who are not in class 1 or
class 2—about a quarter of a million.
There is a general liability to pay flat-rate contributions according to this
classification but certain people are excepted. These include full-time students,
prisoners, people whose weekly earnings are £4 or less, and most people in
receipt of national insurance benefits. Self-employed and non-employed
persons whose income is about £312 a year can apply for exception. Married
women can choose to pay contributions and receive benefit in their own right
or not to pay flat-rate contributions (if they are working they must pay
graduated contributions) and rely upon their husband’s insurance for
maternity grant, retirement pension (at a lower rate), widow’s benefit, and
death grant. If a married woman works for an employer he must pay his
full share of the flat-rate contributions even if she has chosen not to pay
flat-rate contributions.
Flat-rate contributions are credited to students up to the age of 18,
and to most people in receipt of national insurance benefits. People who are
excepted from liability to pay but are not entitled to credits may pay contribu¬
tions at the non-employed rate if they wish to safeguard entitlement to
retirement pension and widow’s benefit.
An employed person ceases to be liable for national insurance contributions
at the age of 70 for men, 65 for women, or when he retires from regular
employment after reaching minimum pension age (65 for men, 60 for women),
whichever is the earlier. If he does any work as an employed person thereafter,
he must pay an industrial injuries contribution; the employer still has to pay
his full share of the flat-rate contribution.
Flat-rate contributions are normally paid by means of national insurance
stamps bought from a post office and fixed, for each contributor, to a single
contribution card. All three classes pay flat-rate contributions (see Table 9).
The stamps for class 1 contributors also include the employer’s redundancy
contribution (to help to provide for payments in certain circumstances to
employees whose work is terminated, see p. 418) and the selective employ¬
ment tax paid by employers (see p. 365); and for all contributors the National
Health Service contribution (which for convenience is paid with the national
insurance contribution although the two services are separately administered).
It is the employer’s responsibility in the first place to see that the class 1
contributions are paid, but he can deduct the employees’ share from their
wages. The self-employed and non-employed must stamp their own cards.
Flat-rate contributions are usually credited for weeks of unemployment,
sickness or injury, or if widow’s benefit is being paid.
In general graduated contributions are payable by employed people (includ¬
ing married women but not retirement pensioners) aged between 18 and 70
(65 for women) who earn more than £9 a week. The range of graduated
contributions is given in Table 9. Employees whose job provides them with
an occupational pension of at least £3 9s. yd. a year for each year of service
(£2 18s. for women) may be ‘contracted out’ of the graduated pension part
of the scheme. Contracted out employees pay graduated contributions at the
rate of half per cent of that part of their weekly pay lying between £9 and
£18 and 3J per cent on earnings between £18 and £30; their employers pay

Their employers pay the same amount.
Graduated contributions provide a graduated addition to retirement pension
and meet the cost of earnings-related supplements to sickness and unemploy¬
ment benefit and widow’s supplementary allowance. The contributions are
collected through the same machinery as is used to collect Pay-as-you-earn
(deduction at source) income tax.
The scheme provides payments to contributors in the event of unemployment
(if normally working for an employer), sickness (if normally working for an
employer or self-employed), and confinement and the weeks immediately
before and after (for women normally working for an employer or self-
employed and paying national insurance contributions at the full rate).
Retirement pensions are paid to people who have reached 65 (60 for women)
if they have retired from regular work and from the age of 70 (65 for women
Amounts
SOCIAL WELFARE I2y
even if they continue to work; widows receive benefit in the first 26 weeks
after bereavement and subsequently while they have young children or if they
have reached the age of 50 when widowed or when their children have grown
up; and there are two kinds of allowance in respect of orphan children where
a widow’s pension is not payable. The scheme also provides lump-sum cash
grants for two expensive contingencies—the birth of a child and a death.
For most of the benefits there are two contribution conditions. First, before
benefit can be paid at all, a minimum number of contributions must actually
have been paid since entry into insurance; secondly, the full rate of benefit
cannot be paid unless a specified number of contributions have been paid or
credited over a specified period. There are special rules to help a widow who
does not become entitled to a widow’s pension at widowhood or when her
children have grown up, to qualify for sickness or unemployment benefit in
the period before she can have established or re-established herself in insur¬
ance through her own contributions; there are also provisions to help a
divorced woman who was not paying contributions during her marriage.
The basic amount of the majority of flat-rate benefits is -£5 a week which
may be reduced if insufficient contributions have been paid, but is not affected
by other unearned income or the previous level of earnings. Earnings received
while the benefit is in payment, however, may cause its reduction or with¬
drawal: unemployment benefit cannot be paid to a person earning more than
a specified amount from a subsidiary occupation; retirement pensioners under
the age of 70 (65 for women) have their pensions reduced in step with earnings
over certain specified amounts; sickness benefit, though not affected by
continued payment of wages during illness, is not normally payable to a person
doing any actual work. Exceptions to the basic flat rate are the higher rate of
£7 a week payable to widows during the first 26 weeks after bereavement and
the increased retirement pension earned by someone who has continued at
work and paid contributions beyond minimum pension age; and the lower
rate of £3 10s. a week unemployment or sickness benefit payable to married
women who pay contributions. The standard rate of retirement pension for a
woman on her husband’s insurance is £3 2s. a week.
Standard increases of flat-rate benefit are payable for dependants at the rate
of ^3 2s. for an adult (generally a wife), £1 1 is. for the first or only child under
the family allowances age limits; 13s. for the second child and ns. for each
other child over and above any family allowances payable (see p. 124). The
sum payable to a widow for her children is £2 9s. for each child inclusive of
family allowances.
The allowance provided for a child who has lost both parents (one of whom
was insured under the National Insurance Acts) is a guardian’s allowance of
£2 9s. a week. It is paid to the person in whose family the child is, for the
time being, included. For certain fatherless children there is a child’s special
allowance also of £2 9s. a week inclusive of family allowances; this is
payable to a woman whose marriage has been dissolved or annulled and who
has not remarried, if her former husband dies and she has a child to whose
support he was contributing before he died.
The graduated addition to retirement pension is at the rate of 6d. a week
for each £7 10s. of all graduated contributions paid by a man and for each £9
of such graduated contribution paid by a woman (with, in each case, the
matching amount of graduated contribution coming from the employer). The
earnings-related supplements to flat-rate unemployment and sickness benefit
are one-third of that part of a person’s average weekly earnings between
£<) and £30, but the supplements cannot raise the total benefit, including

increases for dependants, beyond 85 per cent of earnings. The supplement is
also paid to widow beneficiaries who have the appropriate record of earnings,
if they become unemployed or sick.
An earnings-related supplement is paid on top of the widow’s allowance to
widows whose husbands were under 70 and had not retired from regular
employment; this supplement is one-third of that part of the husband’s
average weekly earnings between £9 and £30.
The rates of grants are varied: £25 maternity grant is payable for a confine¬
ment and a further -£25 grant for each additional child born at the same
confinement living 12 hours after birth; and £30 death grant on the death of an
adult (less for a child, or for an adult who was within 10 years of minimum
pension age when the scheme started).
In general, national insurance payments are paid as long as the situation
requiring them lasts. However, sickness benefit cannot be paid for more than
a year if fewer than 156 contributions have been paid (possible in three years
for a contributor continuously at work) and unemployment benefit is payable
for a maximum of one year. The supplement to unemployment and sickness
benefit is paid for a maximum of six months starting from the thirteenth day
of unemployment or incapacity for work. Maternity allowance begins 11 weeks
before the expected week of confinement and ends after the sixth week
following the expected week or the actual confinement if this is later.
Similarly, a widowed mother’s allowance at the full rate ceases when her
children are no longer dependent on her, though a mother can continue to
receive £5 a week for herself while she has living with her a son or
daughter under 19. The widow’s pension payable to the childless widow,
provided she is over 50 (and had been married at least three years when her
husband died), or the similar pension normally paid to the widowed mother
who has reached 50 when her widowed mother’s allowance ends, continues
until she has reached minimum pension age and retired, or at most till the age
of 65. If she has satisfied the conditions she then becomes entitled to a
retirement pension.
The industrial injuries insurance scheme, which, in July 1948, replaced the
workmen’s compensation scheme (first introduced by the Workmen’s
Compensation Act of 1897), provides benefits for personal injuries caused by
accidents arising out of, and in the course of, employment, and for prescribed
diseases due to the nature of employment. It covers practically everyone in
class 1 of the national insurance scheme and certain others. Like the national
insurance scheme, the industrial injuries scheme is financed partly from
contributions (see Table 9) and partly from taxation. The legal basis of the
scheme is the National Insurance (Industrial Injuries) Act 1965 which
consolidated the 1946 Act and subsequent legislation. Similar cover against
industrial injuries and diseases in Northern Ireland is provided by Northern
Ireland’s legislation.
Injury benefit for an adult is .£7 15s. a week plus £3 2s. for an adult dependant,
j£i ns. for the first or only child under the family allowances age limits, 13s.
for the second child and ns. for each other child in addition to any family
allowance payable. It is paid when the insured person is incapable of work as
a result of an industrial accident or prescribed disease, and payment can
continue for a maximum of 26 weeks beginning on the date of the accident or
development of the disease. A person entitled to sickness benefit who draws
