BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Girls’ Venture Corps, with about 7,000 members, has an Air Wing offering
aviation courses.
The National Federation of Young Farmers’ Clubs in England and Wales
has about 40,000 members between 10 and 25 years old, the Scottish Associa¬
tion of Young Farmers’ Clubs has about 7,500 and Northern Ireland Young
Farmer Clubs about 4,000 members: in addition to encouraging interest in
agriculture and appreciation of country life, the clubs provide training in the
arts of citizenship and develop ability to serve the community.
The Welsh League of Youth (Urdd Gobaith Cymru) has a membership of
about 44,500; its aim is the ‘development of Christian citizenship among the
youth of Wales’.
The Youth Hostels Associations in England and Wales, Scotland and
Northern Ireland have a network of hostels for walkers and cyclists, particu¬
larly intended for young people of limited means. They seek to promote
knowledge and love of the countryside, and are closely linked with each other
and with similar organisations in other countries.
Adult organisations with youth sections include the British Red Cross
Society, St. John Ambulance Association and Brigade and the political parties.
Other King George’s Jubilee Trust was established in 1935 by King George V to
Organisations promote the welfare of the younger generation. Since its inauguration it has
Concerned with disbursed nearly £2 million to the headquarters of the principal voluntary
Youth Work youth organisations and to many local projects, particularly those of an
experimental nature.
In 1968 about 130,300 young people between the ages of 14 and 20 took
part in the Duke of Edinburgh’s Award, which is a scheme operated by local
authorities, schools, youth organisations, industrial firms and other bodies,
and is designed as a challenge to boys and girls to reach certain standards of
achievement in leisure-time activities. There are three separate levels of
Award—Gold, Silver and Bronze—each comprising four sections. Three of
the sections, entitled service, pursuits and interests, and expedition, are
common to boys and girls; the fourth section is physical activity, for boys, and
design for living, for girls. A number of Commonwealth countries, including
Canada, Australia and New Zealand, now operate the scheme.
The Outward Bound Trust maintains in Great Britain five schools for boys
which offer 26-day character-building courses, based on adventure and
overcoming testing experiences. There is a similar school for girls, with
modified courses. About 5,000 boys and 5,000 girls, between the ages of 14
and 19I, take part each year. There are also courses for young men over 20.
The aims of the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the Scottish
Council of Physical Recreation and the National Playing Fields Association
bring them into touch with many youth organisations (see Chapter 19).
In addition to organisations on a nation-wide basis, there are a large number
of town, district or village social clubs run by voluntary groups for general or
particular purposes, for instance, photographic societies, folk dance, table
tennis or jazz clubs.
7 PLANNING AND
HOUSING
TOWN AND COUNTRY PLANNING
Britain is one of the most densely populated areas in the world: it is, therefore,
essential to plan land use for a satisfactory national distribution of employment
and population, to undertake a programme of urban renewal, to build new
towns and to preserve the amenities of the countryside.
From 1909 successive Acts of Parliament recognised the principle of the
planned use of land, but because the pattern of development over much of
the country had already hardened into large unplanned urban concentrations
the powers granted to local planning authorities were inadequate.
The 20 years between the two world wars were decades of rapid social
and industrial change and of developments in industry, engineering, house¬
building, and motor transport; the population was increasing and becoming
more mobile; there was a widespread demand for improved standards of
accommodation and consequently a greater need for systematic planning than
had hitherto been required. At the beginning of the 1930s a major effort was
made to strengthen planning law and to extend the planning powers of central
and local authorities. This resulted in the Town and Country Planning Acts
of 1932 which remained the basis of planning law for 15 years.
Although inter-war planning legislation improved sanitary and environ¬
mental conditions and did something to preserve amenities, its general effect
was unsatisfactory mainly because it failed to deal adequately with the prob¬
lems involved in compensating property owners who stood to lose by the
introduction of positive planning schemes. Local authorities often hesitated to
exercise their powers effectively for fear of being involved in financial
liabilities beyond their means, and as a result there was still much unregulated
urban development spreading over the countryside.
Renewed efforts to tackle these problems were made immediately before
and during the second world war. Between 1937 and 1942 three expert com¬
mittees were appointed to study and report upon the unregulated growth and
spread of industry; the restriction of planning by the financial and administra¬
tive difficulties of compensation and betterment; and the encroachment of
urban development upon the countryside. After the second world war other
committees studied the question of new towns and national parks. Almost all
the principal planning recommendations of these committees have now been
incorporated in Acts of Parliament. Two comprehensive Town and Country
Planning Acts (one for England and Wales and one for Scotland), introduced
in 1947, imposed compulsory planning duties on all local planning authorities
(the larger local authorities) and gave them extensive powers to acquire and
develop land for planning purposes. The Acts also established a centralised
planning structure under which the Minister of Housing and Local Govern¬
ment and the Secretary of State for Scotland (and since 1965 the Secretary of
State for Wales) had the duty of approving all development plans and making
decisions on appeals against development control decisions. Over the past few
years the increase in population, leading to a demand for more and better
Regional
Planning
The Location
of Industry
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
housing, and the growth in the volume of motor traffic with its effects on the
structure of towns and on the countryside (see p. 175), have overstrained the
planning system.
The Town and Country Planning Act 1968 provides for a new procedure
to reduce administrative delays; to place emphasis on a positive approach to-
provide pleasant surroundings in which people might live and work, rather
than on negative controls; and to enable the public to play a greater part in
the planning process than hitherto. The Act provides for ‘structure’ plans to
be drawn up by local planning authorities (the councils of counties and county
boroughs, the London authorities and, in some cases, joint planning boards)
in England and Wales and submitted to the Minister of Housing and Local
Government or the Secretary of State for Wales for approval. These plans
set out ‘broad policies’ for land use in counties and major towns and relate
these policies to transport patterns. They also indicate ‘action areas’ where
development, redevelopment or improvement is expected to start within a
specified period.
In addition, under the new system, local planning authorities prepare local
plans which they formally adopt, generally without the need for ministerial
approval. These plans contain detailed proposals (including plans for the
action areas) within the framework of the structure plans. All the plans may
be amended periodically. The new procedure is being introduced progress¬
ively where the local planning authorities are suitably staffed and organised
to draw up satisfactory structure plans, for example, in Greater London. It
may be adapted to whatever form the structure of local government might take
in the 1970s (see p. 66). Similar legislation was passed in 1969 for Scotland.
The interests of the public are safeguarded in a number of ways. All
proposals for development must be widely advertised. In the case of large
development schemes of regional importance, such as the siting of an airport,
the Ministers responsible may decide to set up Planning Inquiry Commissions
to study the proposals in depth. Appeals against other major development
proposals are dealt with at ministerial level but, in order to speed up planning
procedures, the responsibility for decisions on small-scale residential develop¬
ment is delegated to inspectors.
In Northern Ireland applications for permission to undertake development
are the responsibility of local planning authorities, with a right of appeal to
the Northern Ireland Ministry of Development. Proposals for changes in the
administration of planning have been published. A Central Development
Office would be responsible for the continuing review of the region’s plan and
for the preparation of area plans under the guidance of steering committees
composed of local authority representatives. Local planning authorities would
be responsible for preparing ‘action plans’, including urban renewal schemes
and other development projects in a defined area.
Advisory machinery for planning on a regional basis has been set up by the
Government (see p. 238). Local planning authorities are advised to consult the
regional economic planning councils before drawing up their development
plans. Studies showing the economic and social resources in several regions
have been made (see Bibliography, p. 480) and certain areas, where land,
communications and facilities are favourable, have been proposed as places
where development should be concentrated.
Provisions relating to the location of industry and offices have been made in
the Town and Country Planning Acts, the Local Employment Acts 1960-66,
New Towns
PLANNING AND HOUSING I7I
the Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965, and the Industrial
Development Act 1966. General problems of industrial development are
dealt with jointly by a number of government departments, but the consent
of the local planning authority is, as a rule, required for any new industrial
building, any extension of a building or any change in the use of an existing
building. Financial incentives to encourage the location of industry in particular
areas have been made available by successive governments (see p. 253). There
is special control on office building in south-east England and the Midlands.
The New Towns Act 1946 (now consolidated in Acts passed in 1965 and 1968)
gave the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of
State for Scotland power to make an order designating any area of land
(which may include any existing town or other centre of population) as the
site of a new town; in 1965 the same power was given to the Secretary of State
for Wales. The Minister of Development in Northern Ireland has powers to
designate areas as new towns or for special development under the New
Towns Act (Northern Ireland) 1965. The appropriate minister must consult
the local authorities in the area about the proposal and an opportunity is given
for objections to be made by the public. Once the site has been designated,
the Minister appoints a development corporation (a development commission
in Northern Ireland), consisting of a chairman, a deputy chairman and up to
seven other members, to be responsible for the development of the new town,
including the preparation of a ‘master plan’.
The development corporations have powers in general (subject to the
consent of the appropriate minister) to acquire, by agreement or compulsory
purchase, land or property within the designated areas, or, in some cases,
land near to or outside those areas, and they may provide buildings, roads and
services essential for the development of the towns. Ministerial approval of
proposals for development, given after consultation with the local planning
authority, constitutes planning permission.
The capital cost of developing the new towns is advanced from public
funds and is repayable over 60 years out of the income from the property.
The corporations submit annual reports (which include copies of their
audited accounts) to Parliament.
Thirty-one new towns have been, or are being, established in Britain;
twenty-two in England and Wales, five in Scotland and four in Northern
Ireland. Eleven of the new towns in England and Wales (Basildon, Bracknell,
Crawley, Harlow, Hatfield, Kernel Hempstead, Milton Keynes, Northamp¬
ton, Peterborough, Stevenage and Welwyn) are designed to help relieve
housing problems in the Greater London area. Of the others, Aycliffe, Corby,
Cwmbran, Peterlee and Washington are serving the special needs of their
areas; Runcorn and Skelmersdale are to meet the overspill needs of Liverpool
and north Merseyside; Telford and Redditch will take population from
Birmingham; and Warrington will be expanded to take people from Man¬
chester. Newtown in mid-Wales is to be developed to promote economic
growth in the area.
To help further in solving the housing problem in Manchester and Liver¬
pool large-scale development in the Preston-Leyland-Chorley area of
Lancashire is proposed. Studies are also being made of the possibilities of
development in the Dundee and Tayside area and the region of the Severn
river to provide for a rapidly growing population.
The Scottish new towns (Cumbernauld, East Kilbride, Glenrothes, Irvine
and Livingston) are helping to house people from Glasgow. Irvine and
172
Town
Development
Schemes
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Livingston are also to be centres for industrial activity in the central belt of
Scotland.
In Northern Ireland, Craigavon is being developed as a new city and is
expected to become an area of major industrial growth. Other new towns,
of which two, Antrim and Ballymena, have been designated, are also to be
developed as centres of economic growth. Londonderry and the surrounding
district has been designated as an area of special development.
Four new towns, Crawley, Hatfield, Hemel Hempstead and Welwyn,
have been substantially completed and their development corporations
dissolved. Their assets and liabilities have been handed over to the Commis¬
sion for the New Towns—a government-appointed agency set up in 1959.
The new towns represent a notable achievement in positive land use. They
are generally recognised as one of the most successful post-war experiments,
both socially and industrially, and as a profitable long-term investment. More
than half a million people have moved into the new towns during the past
20 years; young people form a higher proportion of their populations than in
the country as a whole. An extensive building and civil engineering programme
has provided houses, flats, factories, schools, shops, churches, health centres
and libraries as well as public buildings including the town hall and law
courts. Roads, water supplies, sewerage, gas and electricity, police, fire and
bus stations, postal, telegraph and telephone facilities have also been provided;
most of the towns are well equipped with parks and playing fields of various
kinds. All towns have become concerned with the increasingly high level of car
ownership of their inhabitants and are making more adequate provision for
parking and the segregation of pedestrians from motorists.
A number of the more developed towns are becoming regional centres and,
as the populations grow large enough to give the necessary support, offices,
hotels and department stores, as well as full entertainment and recreational
facilities such as skating rinks, dance halls, bowling alleys, swimming
pools, sports stadia, golf courses and youth centres are gradually being
provided. The proposed expansion of such large existing towns as Peter¬
borough represents a further development in the evolution of new towns
policy which has the advantage, among others, that many of these facilities
are already available.
Under the New Towns Act 1946 Parliament approved a fund of £50 million
to provide for advances to the development corporations for work on the new
towns. This fund was increased by subsequent Acts and now stands at £1,100
million; a total of some £640 million had been advanced to the corporations
by March 1969.
The Town Development Act 1952 makes provision for the relief of congestion
in large industrial towns in England and Wales (such as London and
Birmingham) by encouraging the transfer of population from these areas to
country areas suitable for expansion where employment is provided. Schemes
have been approved for providing some 150,000 dwellings in this way, of
which about a half have been completed or are under construction. Some of
the expanding towns, for example, Aylesbury, Basingstoke, Swindon and
Thetford, are already well established; further large-scale development is to
take place at Swindon. In other places, like Cramlington and Killingworth,
the expansion is based on relatively undeveloped areas. The Housing and
Town Development (Scotland) Act 1957 makes similar provision for Scotland.
Schemes have been approved for some 30,000 dwellings; about a quarter of
these have been completed.
PLANNING AND HOUSING
173
Urban
Renewal
Historic
Buildings
Green Belts
Other Measures
to Protect the
Environment
The renewal and re-shaping of existing towns and cities is being undertaken
to meet the growth in population and the impact of more traffic. Glasgow,
for example, has started a programme of rebuilding 30 areas, housing nearly
a third of its population and accommodating much of the industry and
commerce of the city. The Buchanan report (see p. 334) which assessed the
conflicting demands of traffic and environmental standards has influenced
many authorities’ redevelopment plans. The Government believes that the
greater integration of land use and transport planning is of basic importance.
A centre for environmental studies financed by the Government and the
Ford Foundation (see p. 162) is sponsoring research into the problems of
urban planning.
Responsibility for the preservation of the historic, scenic and architectural
beauties of Great Britain rests mainly with the Minister of Housing and Local
Government, the Secretary of State for Scotland, the Secretary of State for
Wales, and the local planning authorities. Lists of buildings of special
architectural or historic interest are being compiled (covering 114,860 so far).
Close supervision is maintained over development proposals that might affect
these buildings so that their character is not destroyed and emphasis is placed
on finding appropriate new uses for them. The respective Ministers (on the
recommendation of the appropriate Historic Buildings Council) are
responsible for administering the grants available for the repair and main¬
tenance of buildings of outstanding historic or architectural interest. Grants
totalling over £7! million have been made under the Historic Buildings and
Ancient Monuments Act 1953 towards the cost of urgently needed repairs to
over 1,500 historic buildings in England, Scotland and Wales. Under the Civic
Amenities Act 1967 local authorities have powers to protect areas of special
architectural or historic interest in towns. Special studies have been made
in Bath, Chester, Chichester and York to consider the particular difficulties
of preserving features of historic interest in ancient towns, in the face of com¬
mercial development and of the increase in motor traffic. The Minister of
Public Building and Works and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and
Wales are responsible for the maintenance of royal parks and palaces and
(under the Ancient Monuments Acts) for the protection of ancient monu¬
ments of which over 750 of the more important are in their care. They are
visited by some 10 million people annually.
In order to restrict the further sprawl of large built-up areas, to prevent
adjacent towns merging into one another, and in some cases to preserve the
special character of a town and the amenities of the countryside, the policy has
been adopted of establishing ‘green belts’ around all or part of certain urban
areas. Green belts are areas which it is intended should be left permanently
open and where, in consequence, there is a presumption against most new
development.
Local planning authorities have power to protect trees and woodlands by
means of tree preservation orders (some 8,200 of which are in force throughout
Great Britain) and to ensure that trees are protected or replaced on sites
undergoing development. Increasing use is being made of the planting of
semi-mature trees for landscaping purposes. The authorities have powers to
prevent mineral workings becoming permanent eyesores by attaching suitable
conditions to planning permissions, to regulate the display of advertisements
in the interests of amenity and safety and to make it an offence to leave litter,
i?4
National Parks
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
including bulky rubbish such as old cars, on open land. They may, for health
reasons, declare ‘smoke control areas’, in which the emission of smoke from
chimneys constitutes an offence. River authorities (see p. 297) are responsible
for the prevention of pollution of rivers.
Voluntary organisations have been particularly active in ensuring that
development takes full account of considerations of amenity. The National
Trust for England, Wales and Northern Ireland, which was founded in 1895
and now has some 160,000 members, is among the biggest land-owners in the
United Kingdom. It owns and protects from harmful development 400,000
acres of land and nearly 200 historic buildings for the benefit of the public—
often acquired through gifts (sometimes by arrangement with the Treasury in
lieu of death duties, see p. 364). With government support it is at present
engaged on a £2 million campaign, Enterprise Neptune, to preserve 900 miles
of coastline. The National Trust for Scotland is an independent body founded
in 1935. It has about 31,000 members and has under its care some 70
properties, covering in all about 70,000 acres.
The Civic Trust, financed through covenants from leading industrial
firms, was founded in 1957 to encourage high quality in architecture and
planning and to stimulate public interest in the protection of beauty in town
and country. It has, for example, produced plans for the redevelopment of
town centres and for a recreational area in the Lee Valley. The Trust makes
use of local initiative; it has separate sections in the north-east and north-west of
England and in Wales and Scotland and advises some 600 local civic societies.
Other amenity societies dependent upon the support of their members
include: the Council for the Preservation of Rural England, the Association
for the Preservation of Rural Scotland and the Council for the Preservation of
Rural Wales; the Commons, Open Spaces and Footpaths Preservation
Society; the Ramblers’ Association; the Society for the Protection of Ancient
Buildings; the Georgian Group; the Victorian Society; the Pilgrim Trust;
and the Historic Churches Preservation Trust.
The National Parks and Access to the Countryside Act 1949 provided that
selected areas of beautiful and relatively wild country in England and Wales
should become national parks, where the characteristic landscape would be
safeguarded and facilities for open-air recreation provided or improved.
A National Parks Commission, now replaced by the Countryside Commis¬
sion (see p. 175), was set up by the Act and given responsibility for selecting
national parks and ‘areas of outstanding natural beauty’ and making proposals
for the creation of long-distance footpaths and bridleways. Ten national parks
have been established: Northumberland, the Lake District, the Yorkshire
Dales, the North York Moors and the Peak District in the north of England;
Snowdonia, the Pembrokeshire Coast and the Brecon Beacons in Wales;
Exmoor and Dartmoor in the south-west of England. They cover a total area
of some 5,260 square miles, or 9 per cent of the total area of England and
Wales. They have various forms of administration, based on representation
of the local planning authorities of the areas in which they are situated, as well
as members appointed by the Minister of Housing and Local Government
or by the Secretary of State for Wales. By 1969, 25 areas of outstanding natural
beauty had been designated covering some 4,300 square miles.
The land in these parks and designated areas generally remains in private
ownership, but agreements or orders to secure additional public access may be
made by the local authorities. Steps are taken to preserve and enhance the
natural beauty of the landscape by high standards of development control, and
PLANNING AND HOUSING
175
Countryside
Commissions
Forest Parks
Nature
Reserves
by positive measures, for which government grants are available, such as tree
planting and preservation, and the removal of eyesores. In national parks,
public enjoyment is promoted, for example, by the provision of car parks and
camping and caravan areas and the setting up of information centres. All
national parks and some other designated areas have warden services. Nearly
1,300 miles of long-distance footpaths and bridleways had been approved by
1969. Large stretches of these paths are already public rights of way; the first
long-distance footpath to be completed, the Pennine Way, stretches for some
250 miles. Further routes are being established.
Under the Amenity Lands Act (Northern Ireland) 1965 the Ulster Country¬
side Committee advises on the establishment of national parks and the
designation of areas of outstanding natural beauty. Seven areas have been
designated.
Although there are no national parks as such in Scotland, five large areas
are subject to a special planning control under ministerial supervision. The
areas are Loch Lomond—Trossachs; Glen Affric—Glen Cannich—Strath
Farrar; Ben Nevis—Glen Coe—Black Mount; the Cairngorms; and Loch
Torridon—Loch Maree—-Little Loch Broom.
Under the Countryside Acts 1967 (for Scotland) and 1968 (for England and
Wales) Countryside Commissions have been set up to replace and extend the
work of the National Parks Commission because of the need for additional
facilities for leisure-time activities for a rising and increasingly mobile
population. The Commissions (with an advisory committee for Wales)
encourage the provision and development of opportunities for open-air
recreation in the countryside to relieve pressure on the national parks.
Measures envisaged include the creation by local authorities and others of
country parks within easy reach of towns; the establishment of camping sites
and picnic areas; and the increased use of reservoirs and canals for bathing,
sailing and other activities. The Commissions are also responsible for
encouraging and promoting measures to conserve and enhance the natural
beauty and amenity of the countryside and may undertake research projects
and experimental schemes, working in consultation with local authorities and
such bodies as the Nature Conservancy and the Sports Councils (see p. 449).
Grants are available from the Government for certain approved schemes and
the Commissions have powers to make grants or loans to people working for
the same purposes.
The Forestry Commission (see p. 323) has formed, and opened to the public,
seven Forest Parks in some of the finest country in Britain: Argyll, Glen Trool,
Glen More, and the Queen Elizabeth Forest Park in Scotland; the Forest
of Dean and the Wye valley woods on the borders of England and Wales;
Snowdonia in Wales; and the Border Forest Park on the borders of England
and Scotland. The total area of the seven parks approaches half a million acres.
Camping and other recreational facilities are provided in all the parks.
The historic New Forest, in Hampshire, although not a Forest Park, is also
open to the public.
Northern Ireland has three forest parks, Tollymore Park, Gortin Glen
Forest and Castlewellan.
Responsibility for nature conservation in Great Britain is exercised by the
Nature Conservancy on behalf of the Natural Environment Research Council
(see p. 202), of which the Conservancy is a component body. The Conservancy
176
Housing
Policy
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
derives its powers from its royal charter and the National Parks and Access to
the Countryside Act 1949, as amended by the Science and Technology Act
1965. In Northern Ireland nature reserves are designated on the advice of the
Nature Reserves Committee under the Amenity Lands Act (Northern
Ireland) 1965.
In the reserves wild plants and animals and the environment in which they
live are protected, and facilities for the enjoyment and understanding of
nature are provided. There are 127 national nature reserves in Great Britain,
covering some 262,500 acres. The largest (covering more than 64,000 acres) is
in the Cairngorms. Nineteen local nature reserves are managed by local
authorities in consultation with the Conservancy.
Thirteen forest nature reserves have also been set up; of these a number
have been created by agreement between the Forestry Commission and the
Nature Conservancy and are managed by the Commission.
There are also some 2,200 sites of special scientific interest scheduled by the
Conservancy and the Northern Ireland Ministry of Development in Britain.
The Council for Nature (established in 1958) is an independent voluntary
organisation of some 450 natural history and conservation societies concerned
with averting threats to wild life in Britain. It receives grants from the
Department of Education and Science and other bodies.
HOUSING
There are some 18-5 million dwellings in Britain: nearly 16-5 million in
England and Wales, 1-7 million in Scotland and more than 400,000 in
Northern Ireland. Nearly half the dwellings are owned by their occupiers,
about a third by public authorities (in Scotland the figure is almost one in
two), and most of the remainder (mainly older houses) are rented from private
landlords. Although the numbers of households and dwellings in Britain are
roughly equal they are unevenly distributed and there is a heavy demand for
housing in the areas of economic prosperity, like London and Birmingham.
Between 1945 and March 1969 over 6-6 million new houses and flats were
built; one family in three now lives in a post-war dwelling. Most of the new
dwellings in Britain are houses (usually of two storeys) with gardens; the
remainder are flats or maisonettes, mostly in blocks of from 2 to 20 storeys,
although a few blocks may be higher. High blocks are generally built in
central urban areas where they replace old, overcrowded dwellings.
Accommodation in a house designed for a family of four or five people
includes one or two living rooms, a kitchen, a bathroom and a water closet and
two or three bedrooms. A typical 3-bedroom house built by a local authority
in England and Wales in 1968 had a superficial area of about 960 square feet
and cost an average of £3,030. There are three people in the average British
household. Comparative European statistics show that the degree of over¬
crowding in Britain is lower than in most other countries.
Some 425,800 dwellings were completed in Britain in 1968—an all-time
record. The standard of new housing has improved significantly in recent
years, particularly in the floor space provided and heating systems installed
(see p. 178).
In view of the demand for home ownership, the Government believes that
about half the new dwellings built annually should be for owner-occupation
and has launched a scheme to help people with low incomes to buy their own
PLANNING AND HOUSING
177
Research and
Development
Standards of
Building
houses (see p. 178). The first priority of the Land Commission, established in
1967, is to make land more readily available at reasonable prices for private
enterprise housebuilding.
At the same time housing subsidies from the Government enable the 1,500
or so local housing authorities1 to provide some 200,000 new dwellings a year,
primarily for letting at relatively low rents to large families or those with
small incomes. In recent years about one-quarter of the dwellings built by
local authorities have been of the single bedroom type, suitable for old people.
A survey of existing housing in 1967 showed that there were some 4-5 million
old dwellings in England and Wales which were structurally sound but needed
repair or the installation of amenities such as bathrooms. Under two Housing
Acts 1969 (one for England and Wales, and one for Scotland) the Govern¬
ment offers greater financial incentives for the rehabilitation of older houses
and their environment (see p. 180). Programmes of slum clearance have been
speeded up in recent years particularly in the large conurbations (see p. 180).
In 1967 it was estimated that some i-8 million dwellings needed to be
demolished in England and Wales.
Responsibility for formulating housing policy and supervising the housing
programme is borne by the Minister of Housing and Local Government in
England, by the Secretaries of State in Scotland and Wales and the Minister
of Development in Northern Ireland.
Local authorities are responsible for ensuring that the provision of housing
in their areas is adequate. In England and Wales and Northern Ireland the
local housing authorities are the councils of county boroughs, boroughs,
urban districts and rural districts, the Greater London Council, the London
borough councils and the Common Council of the City of London. In
Scotland all town and county councils are housing authorities. The actual
building of dwellings is undertaken by the local authorities (or by building
firms under contract to them) and by private builders, usually for sale to
owner-occupiers.
Research into building techniques and into new methods of house construction
as well as into the needs of families, is carried out by the Research and
Development Groups of the Ministry of Housing and Local Government and
of the Scottish Development Department, the Building Research Station, the
architects’ departments of major local authorities and the research groups in
big constructional firms. All government building research and development
is co-ordinated by the Directorate-General of Research and Development at
the Ministry of Public Building and Works. Advice on ways of increasing
productivity in housebuilding is given by the National Building Agency,
economic development committees set up for the civil engineering and
building industries, and by a committee of the Ministry of Public Building
and Works, which is concerned with small builders who undertake the
maintenance and improvement of existing houses where, for example, pre¬
fabricated plumbing and bathroom units can be used.
Control of building standards is generally exercised through regulations made
by the central departments, which also give guidance on design and layout to
local authorities in circulars and bulletins.
1 Including most new town authorities, the Scottish Special Housing Association, a
statutory body established in 1937 to erect houses for letting to supplement building
by local authorities (it now owns about 68,000 houses and builds at the rate of some
3,000 houses a year), and the Northern Ireland Housing Trust set up in 1945 for a
similar purpose which has built about a quarter of Northern Ireland’s post-war houses.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Central Housing Advisory Committee, a statutory body, issues reports
on housing standards. For example, the Parker Morris report (see Biblio¬
graphy, p. 475) suggested standards that should be achieved in new dwellings*
some relating to space and heating have been made mandatory for local
authority housing schemes, and now nearly 90 per cent of all new dwellings
have central heating. For building in the private sector the National House-
Builders’ Registration Council sets standards and enforces them by inspection
and certification. Some 90 per cent of all houses built in 1968 for owner-
occupation were guaranteed in this way. Many building societies and local
authorities make a condition that they will lend money on mortgage (see below)
only for dwellings built by house-builders registered with this Council or
built under professional supervision.
About 40 per cent of dwellings in the public sector are built by industrialised
methods, which offer the advantages of rapid construction on the site with the
use of fewer skilled workers and greater independence of weather conditions
compared with traditional methods. A number of local authorities work in
consortia to make the best use of industrialised systems (with standardised
components) in their house-building programmes.
Loans to enable people to buy their houses by a system of instalment purchase
are available from various sources, including building societies, insurance
companies, industrial and provident societies and local authorities. The local
authorities are expected to concentrate their efforts primarily to helping people
with special housing needs who are unable to obtain loans from other sources.
Building societies, of which there are some 550, are the most important of
these agencies. They do not build houses themselves but provide long-term
loans on the security of property bought for owner-occupation. They usually
advance 80 to 90 per cent of the value of the houses. Loans are repayable over
periods of up to 25 or even 30 years, by equal monthly instalments to cover
capital and interest. The societies advanced more than £1,500 million in 1968;
the average price of houses mortgaged was £4,700. In response to the demand
for owner-occupation a scheme to help people with low incomes to buy their
dwellings on mortgage was introduced under the Housing Subsidies Act 1967.
Under the scheme borrowers have the option of either claiming income tax
relief on interest payments on their loan (a system which helps people who'
pay a high rate of tax more than those who pay little or none), or receive
through the lending agency a government subsidy, whichever they consider
to be of the most financial benefit to them. The subsidy reduces the rate of
interest they pay by up to 2 per cent, subject to a minimum remaining interest
charge which in most cases is 4 per cent. The Minister has power to adjust,
by order, the percentage rate of subsidy following changes in interest rates or
taxation. A person taking part in the scheme whose circumstances change
may revert to tax relief on 31st March 1973 or after, provided he has held
his mortgage for at least five years.
The option scheme has been extended to include a provision by which
mortgage loans of up to 100 per cent of the valuation of a house (not exceeding-
£5,000) may be made to those participating in the scheme.
The Housing Act 1961 authorised Exchequer loans to approved non-profit-
making housing associations for the building of houses to let at unsubsidised
rents. This provision was increased and extended by the Housing Act 1964
under which the Housing Corporation was set up to stimulate the formation of
housing societies. Building societies advance to a housing society two-thirds

179
Public Sector
Housing
Privately
Rented
Housing
of the cost of each approved housing scheme, the Corporation providing
the remaining third. The housing societies build dwellings either for
co-ownership by a group of occupants, which gives them most of the advan¬
tages of house ownership at a lower cost, or to let at unsubsidised rents.
The capital cost of houses built by or for local authorities is met by raising
loans; current expenditure, including loan repayment and interest on loans,
is met from rents supplemented by subsidies from the Exchequer and, in
some cases, from the rates (see p. 72). Local authorities may raise loans for
housing on the open market or by borrowing from the Public Works Loan
Board (see p. 73). In Northern Ireland local authorities, the Housing Trust
and housing associations may borrow from the Government Loans Fund.
Housing subsidies, at varying rates and for different purposes, have been
provided in Britain since 1919, when they were first introduced to enable
local authorities to build houses for letting at moderate rents. However, the
value of normal flat-rate subsidies has been eroded by rising building costs
and interest rates. A new kind of subsidy was introduced in the Housing
Subsidies Act 1967 which provides a basic subsidy equal to the difference
between the interest charge (at current borrowing rates) on a loan raised to
cover the approved capital cost of a dwelling and the charge if the loan had
borne interest at 4 per cent a year. For example, the basic subsidy payable on
a house costing £3,800, assuming a borrowing rate of 7 per cent, would be
about £103 a year for 60 years. Supplementary subsidies are paid for high
building; to councils with insufficient resources to provide urgently needed
houses; for houses required in connection with a major transfer of industry;
for expensive sites; for precautions against subsidence; for building in certain
materials; and for overspill. Similar subsidies are paid in Scotland. In Northern
Ireland annual subsidies are paid to local authorities, the Northern Ireland
Housing Trust, new town development commissions and housing associations
and ‘lump-sum’ subsidies are paid to private people who build dwellings for
letting or owner-occupation.
In selecting tenants for council dwellings local authorities must give prefer¬
ence to families living in overcrowded or unsatisfactory conditions. Rents are
generally low in comparison with current building costs. Over two-fifths of
the housing authorities in England and Wales operate rent-rebate schemes,
under which tenants with low incomes or with large families are able to claim
a reduction in the standard rent. In Scotland nearly half the councils operate
rebate schemes, although rents generally are lower than in England and
Wales. The Government is encouraging the expansion of such schemes so
that housing subsidies are used to help people who need them most.
A declining proportion of the available housing in Britain (about one-sixth)
is rented from individual landlords and property companies.
Rent control was originally introduced in 1915 as a temporary war-time
measure and successive Acts have varied its scope. Under the Rent Act 1957
there was a large measure of decontrol but the Rent Act 1965 re-introduced
control over most privately rented unfurnished dwellings—those of annual
rateable value up to £400 in London and £200 elsewhere. Most rent legisla¬
tion has been consolidated in the Rent Act 1968. Tenants have a wide degree
of security of tenure and a fair rent may be fixed on application by landlord
or tenant. Fair rents are determined by rent officers or, if the landlord or
tenant objects to the rent determined by the rent officer, by a rent assessment
committee on the assumption that, for similar dwellings, demand does not
l8o BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
greatly exceed supply. Once determined, the rent is not normally reviewed
for at least three years. For furnished premises under the rateable value limits
a tenant may go to a rent tribunal for determination of a reasonable rent and
may be given security of tenure for up to six months with a possibility of
further periods if the tribunal so decides. Eviction without a court order from
furnished or unfurnished premises of any rateable value and harassment of
occupiers are criminal offences with severe penalties.
Measures of control and de-control also apply in Northern Ireland. In 1951
and 1956 legislation was passed which permitted prescribed increases in the rent
of certain controlled houses. The 1956 Act also released from control houses with
a net annual value of over ^50 (with certain safeguards) and houses with a net
annual value of over £26 of which the landlord was in actual possession when
the Act came into force, or of which he subsequently obtained possession.
Improvement Private owners in Great Britain can obtain grants from local authorities for the
of Houses improvement of houses or conversion of large houses into smaller units or
other buildings for housing. The grants are made to householders to install
basic amenities such as baths and to make other improvements to their
houses. The grants amount to 50 per cent of the approved cost of the work,
the normal upper limits of the grants being £200 and £1,000 {£1,200 in
Scotland) and the maximum grant for the conversion of a house of three or
more storeys into flats, £1,200 for each flat. Grants amounting to £2,500 per
flat obtained are available to local authorities and housing associations to buy
houses for improvement and conversion.
To enable local authorities to tackle, systematically, areas of out-worn
housing in private ownership, the Housing Acts 1969 give them powers to
declare ‘general improvement areas’ in which they can actively encourage
householders to improve their dwellings with the aid of grants. In addition,
the local authorities can spend up to £100 per house on improving the
general environment with the help of a 50 per cent government grant.
Grants are also provided in Northern Ireland with, in addition, provision
for accommodation for farmers, agricultural workers and approved workers.
Slum Clearance More than 2-25 million people have been rehoused since the mid-1950s
as a result of slum clearance programmes. It is expected that within the
next ten years the great majority of the housing authorities in Great Britain
will have succeeded in getting rid of all their present slums. In certain
areas, however, particularly the older industrial towns, including Birmingham,
Glasgow, Liverpool and Manchester, four of the biggest cities in the country,
clearance may take longer. Local authorities with major slum and over¬
crowding problems are being given priority to clear their slums and to under¬
take major programmes of urban renewal. Their housebuilding programmes
have increased sharply in recent years and in many cases the designation of
new towns nearby has further eased their housing problems (see p. 171).
Housing authorities are obliged to see that other accommodation exists, or
can be provided by them, for people displaced from slum clearance areas.
Where an unfit house is demolished by order of the local authority and the
owner retains his land, he normally receives no compensation. If the local
authorities acquire an unfit property in order to demolish it themselves and to
rebuild on the land, the normal basis of compensation amounts to the market
value of the house as it stands or the value of the site after clearance, whichever
is the less, but for owner occupiers compensation is at market value.
8 THE CHURCHES
Every person living in Britain has the right of religious freedom and may
manifest his faith in teaching, worship and observance without interference
from the community or the State. Churches and religious societies of all kinds
may own property, conduct schools, and propagate their beliefs in speech and
in writing.
Freedom of conscience in religious matters was achieved gradually from the
seventeenth century onwards; the laws discriminating against minority
religious groups were gradually administered less rigorously and then finally
repealed. Heresy ceased to be a civil offence with the passing of the
Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction Act 1677, and the Toleration Act of 1688 granted
freedom of worship to protestant dissenters. In 1828 the repeal of the Test
and Corporation Acts freed nonconformists from political disabilities and
made it possible for them to be appointed to public offices; Roman Catholics
gained political emancipation under the Roman Catholic Relief Act 1829; the
Jewish Relief Act 1858 enabled Jews to become members of Parliament; while
religious tests that had been imposed on prospective students and members
of the academic staff of the universities of Oxford, Cambridge and Durham
were successively abolished by Acts of 1854, 1856 and 1871. Nowadays, there
is no religious or denominational bar to the holding of public office, except in
the case of the Lord Chancellor, where there is some doubt whether existing
statutory provisions would permit this office to be held by a Roman Catholic.
In the services administered by the State, such as the armed forces, the
national hospitals and the prisons, the clergy of the established Church of
England or the Church of Scotland provide the principal ministrations and
are paid a salary by the State for this part of their work. Priests of the Roman
Catholic Church and ministers of other denominations may also be appointed
or specially called in as required. Voluntary schools (see p. 148) provided by
churches of any religious denomination may be wholly or partly maintained
from public funds.
There is no precisely accurate or uniform method of assessing the number
of adherents to the various churches in the United Kingdom, since no enquiries
are made about religious beliefs in population censuses or other official
returns, and each church adopts its own criteria in counting its members.
The membership figures given in this chapter are therefore approximate.
The Church of The Church of England is the established church, and claims to be the ancient
England catholic church of the land. At the Reformation in the sixteenth century, it
repudiated the supremacy of the Pope, but retained the historic episcopate,
and the creeds and sacraments upon which its doctrines are based; therefore
it claims to be both ‘catholic’ and ‘reformed’. Its form of worship is embodied
in the Book of Common Prayer, which was first compiled in 1549.
The Church is uniquely related to the Crown in that the Sovereign, who
must be a member of the Church of England, is called ‘Defender of the Faith’
(a statutory title as protector of the Church) and promises on his or her
accession to uphold it. The coronation of the Sovereign is performed by the
Archbishop of Canterbury; prayers for the Sovereign and other members
of the royal family are said in all the statutory services of the Church; Church
182 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of England archbishops, bishops and deans are appointed by the Sovereign
on the advice of the Prime Minister1; and all clergymen take the oath of
allegiance to the Crown.
The Church is also linked with the State through the House of Lords, in
which the archbishops of Canterbury and York and 24 senior diocesan bishops
have seats (see p. 31). This makes it possible for the views of the Church
leaders to be expressed freely on any moral issue raised in connection with the
corporate conduct of the State as well as on specifically ecclesiastical issues—
a matter of particular significance in view of the fact that the clergy of the
Church of England (together with those of the Church of Scotland, the
Church of Ireland and the Roman Catholic Church) are legally disqualified
from sitting in the House of Commons.
The Church must obtain Parliament’s consent2 to change its form of
worship, as laid down in the authorised Book of Common Prayer; canons
(Church rules) cannot be made or amended without the consent of the Queen;
and the Measures of the Church Assembly (as distinct from its regulations)
also require parliamentary approval and the Royal Assent.
Church The Church of England is organised by geographical areas into two provinces
Organisation and and 43 dioceses. The Province of Canterbury contains 29 dioceses and that
Government of York 14. Each diocese is subdivided into ecclesiastical parishes, of which
there are about 14,500. The Archbishop of Canterbury is Primate of All
England and bishop of his own diocese of Canterbury; the Archbishop of York
is styled Primate of England and is bishop of his own diocese of York.
The baptised membership of the Church is about 27^ million, that is two-
thirds of the population born and resident in the two provinces but only about
35 per cent of this number is confirmed.
Spiritual authority in the Church rests with the bishops. The authoritative
bodies in matters of doctrine, belief and practice are the Convocations of
Canterbury and York, each presided over by its archbishop, and consisting
of an upper house of bishops, and a lower house of representatives of each
cathedral chapter, archdeacons and elected clergy. The Convocations may
meet three times a year.
The legislative and central administrative body of the Church is the
National Assembly of the Church of England, which is commonly called the
Church Assembly. It was set up in 1919 at the request of the two Convocations,
and was given power to legislate by measure by the Church of England
Assembly (Powers) Act 1919. It can discuss any matter connected with the
Church of England, but may not make any doctrinal statements, nor infringe
upon the rights of the Convocations. It consists of three Houses: Bishops,
Clergy and Laity. The first two Houses are composed of the members of the
Convocations; the House of Laity consists of men and women elected every
five years by the lay members of diocesan conferences, and the constitution
allows for ten co-opted members.3
The Church Assembly usually meets three times a year. Measures, after
passing through various stages in the Assembly, are presented to an ecclesias¬
tical committee of both Houses of Parliament, consisting of 30 members, of
1 The Church Assembly has appointed a commission to consider what constitutional
modifications are desirable and practicable in the present relationship between Church
and State.
2 Consent has been obtained for the experimental use of alternative forms, if and when
authorised by the Church.
3 A measure setting up a General Synod, which will take over the authority of the
Convocations of Canterbury and York and bring the laity into closer contact with
the clergy in all church matters, has been passed by Parliament.

THE CHURCHES
Church Finance
183
whom 15 are appointed by the Lord Chancellor and 15 by the Speaker of the
House of Commons. This committee lays the measures, together with a report
upon them, before both Houses. If both Houses so resolve, the measure is
sent to the Sovereign for Royal Assent, after which it has the same force and
effect as an Act of Parliament. Parliament, though it may reject a measure, has
no power to amend it.
The Church Assembly is the centre of an administrative system consisting
of boards and councils dealing with various aspects of the Church’s work, such
as education, recruitment and training for the ministry, and Church work at
home and overseas. The Church Assembly, through the Schools Council of its
Board of Education, is responsible for some 7,100 Church of England schools
of all types, for about half of which the Church bears a fifth of the cost of
improvements, alterations and repairs.
Parochial church councils were set up in 1921 to associate the laity with
the government of the Church in the parish. The members of these councils
are appointed by the parochial electors, that is, people who are baptised, are
not members of any other church, are 17 years of age and over, and have
applied for membership of the electoral roll of the parish where they usually
live or worship. The estimated number on the parish electoral rolls is some
2-| million.
The Church of England has its own ecclesiastical courts. Their jurisdiction
today consists largely of faculty cases, with very occasional cases of discipline
against clergy, either for moral or ecclesiastical offences. A faculty is necessary
for any specific alteration or addition to the fabric or ornaments of a church or
to a churchyard.
There are 25 Church colleges of education in England and two in Wales, all
of which are run by independent governing bodies. With substantial grants
from the Department of Education and Science a major programme of
expansion, including the opening of two new colleges, has been taking place;
this has raised the total number of students in the colleges to nearly 17,000.
The cost to the Church, mainly from funds provided by the Church Assembly,
has been about ^3 million.
The Church Assembly has also completed a programme of modernising and
improving theological colleges (of which there are 25) and establishments for
the training of women in the pastoral work of the Church, and has provided
grants for the greater part of the cost.1
Each parish is responsible for its own finances, and also contributes an annual
apportioned quota to diocesan funds, and each diocese similarly contributes
to the Church Assembly. In the diocese, the financial authority is the diocesan
board of finance, which administers the money contributed by the parishes,
and acts as trustee on behalf of the parochial church councils, which have only
limited powers of holding property. The Central Board of Finance administers
the Church Assembly Fund, supported by diocesan contributions, and devoted
to the maintenance of central services, including capital expenditure on
training colleges and theological colleges and the grants for training candidates
for ordination.
Although the State pays for or contributes towards services provided by the
Church (see p. 181), it makes no direct financial contribution to the expenses
of the Church as such.
1 A radical reorganisation of Church of England theological colleges, the effect of
which would be to amalgamate the 25 existing colleges to provide a maximum of 14,
has been recommended in the report of a working party set up by the Archbishops of
Canterbury and York.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The endowment income of the Church (from its assets amounting to over
£400 million in land and investments) is mainly administered by the Church
Commissioners, the body largely responsible for the payment of clergy
stipends and the provision of finance for pensions. The total net income
(more than £21 million in 1968) has greatly increased during the past ten
years; in broad terms, this has meant a rise in the stipends of the poorer
clergy and that the Commissioners have been able to embark on schemes of
assistance for providing better parsonage houses, for Church buildings in
new areas of population, and for better pensions for clergy and their widows.
The present basic pension for a clergyman is £600 a year and £300 for a
clergy widow. Retired Church dignitaries receive larger pensions.
The Anglican The Anglican Communion comprises 19 autonomous provinces in the United
Communion Kingdom and overseas and two regional councils overseas with a tota
membership of over 40 million. _ ,
In the British Isles, in addition to the established Church of England, there
are unestablished Anglican Churches in Ireland, Scotland and Wales: the
Church of Ireland has 14 dioceses; the Episcopal Church in Scotland,
7 dioceses and some 98,000 members; and the Church in Wales, 6 dioceses
and some 165,500 Easter communicants.
The Lambeth Conference for unofficial consultation between all Anglican
bishops meets every ten years; the latest meeting was in July-August 1968.
The conference is presided over by the Archbishop of Canterbury; it
has no executive authority, but enjoys great moral prestige, and its
findings on doctrine, discipline, relations with other communions, and on the
attitude of the Anglican Churches to political and social questions are widely
studied. . . , . c
The Executive Officer of the Anglican Communion is the secretary of the
Anglican Advisory Council on Missionary Strategy, and exercises general
supervision on behalf of the consultative body of the Lambeth Conference (of
which he is also the secretary) over all matters affecting the welfare of the
Anglican Communion which call for attention between the meetings of the
conference.
The Church of
Scotland
The Church of Scotland, established by law, has a presbyterian form of
government. It has been described as ‘the supreme example of a church which
is established and yet is free’. Its position, defined in the Treaty of Union 1707,
was further safeguarded by the Church of Scotland Act 1921, under which
it has complete internal self-government within the terms of the schedule to
the Act, ‘Articles Declaratory of the Faith of the Church of Scotland .
Whereas in episcopacy church government is a hierarchy of persons, in
Presbyterianism there is a hierarchy of courts. All ministers are °f equal status,
and each of the 2,126 congregations is governed locally by the Kirk Session,
consisting of the minister and elected elders (of whom there are about 48,942);
above this is the Court of the Presbytery, then the Court of the Synod, and
finally the General Assembly, which meets annually and consists of elected
ministers and elders presided over by an elected Moderator who serves for one
year. The Sovereign, when not present in person, is represented at the General
Assembly by the Lord High Commissioner. The Church of Scotland has
complete freedom in all spiritual matters and the right to appoint its own
officers and to decide all matters of doctrine and discipline. Its decisions are
not subject to parliamentary debate, modification or appeal to the civil courts.
Women may now be admitted to its ministry.
THE CHURCHES
185
The training for the ministry, which lasts at least six years, has given the
Church a high reputation for scholarship and has in turn influenced the
standard of education in Scotland. The membership of the Church of Scotland
is estimated at about 1,200,000.
The Free
Churches
The Methodist
Churches
The Congregational
Church
The Baptist
Church
The Unestablished
Presbyterian
Churches
The phrase ‘Free Churches’ is now commonly used to describe those churches
in England which were more generally known in the past as ‘nonconformist’
churches; and protestant churches in Scotland (except the established Church
of Scotland), Wales and Northern Ireland. The main Free Churches are the
Methodist, Baptist and Congregational Churches, and the unestablished
presbyterian churches throughout Britain. In addition, there are a number of
other protestant denominations in the United Kingdom as well as such
religious associations as the Society of Friends and the Salvation Army, which
have certain links writh the main Free Churches.
The word ‘nonconformist’ signifies dissent from certain of the formularies
and practices of the established church. In general, the Free Churches base
their reason for existence on their distinctive convictions regarding organisa¬
tion and worship.
The largest of the Free Churches, the Methodist Church, which originated
in the eighteenth century following the evangelical revival by John Wesley,
took its present form in 1932, with the union of the majority of separate
Methodist Churches. It has some 667,000 adult full members. The supreme
authority is the annual conference and the system of government is in many
ways presbyterian, the leaders’ meeting corresponding to the kirk sessions,
with circuit meetings and district synods resembling presbytery and synod.
One of the characteristics of Methodism is its strong emphasis on lay leader¬
ship. There are some 22,400 trained lay preachers sharing the work of about
4,200 ministers and preaching in many local churches.
Methodist Churches which did not join the union in 1932 include: the
Independent Methodists (over 6,900), in which ministerial service is on a
purely voluntary basis and women (many of whom are ministers) have full
equality with men; and the Wesleyan Reform Union (with some 5,200
members) which, while retaining the essential Methodist doctrine, gives
autonomy to each of its 155 individual churches.
The Congregationalists are the oldest community of dissenters in Britain. In
1831 most of their churches were formed into the Congregational Union
(which in 1966 was reconstituted as the Congregational Church in England
and Wales). Local churches have formed county and national unions, whose
secretariat and assemblies have much influence, but no compulsive authority
over them, since great importance is attached to the autonomy of local church
meetings. Adult membership is about 187,000.
The Baptists are for the most part grouped in associations of churches and the
majority of these belong to the Baptist Union formed in 1813. Baptists differ
from nearly all other churches in that they practise the baptism of believers
only; they do not baptise infants. The Baptist Churches have about 280,000
members.
The Presbyterian Church in Ireland has a membership in Northern Ireland
of about 390,000. The Presbyterian (or Calvinistic Methodist) Church of
Wales, which arose from the revivalist movement led by Howell Harris in
1735, numbers some 117,000. The Presbyterian Church of England has nearly
66,000 members; its highest court is its general assembly; women are admitted
to the eldership and ministry.
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Other presbyterian churches in Britain include: the Free Church of
Scotland; the United Free Church of Scotland; the Free Presbyterian Church
of Scotland; the Reformed Presbyterian Church of Scotland; the Reformed
Presbyterian Church of Ireland; and the Non-Subscribing Presbyterian
Church of Ireland.
Among other protestant denominations in the United Kingdom are: the
Unitarian and Free Christian Churches; the Churches of Christ (known also
in the United States of America as Disciples of Christ), which have been an
organised community in Britain since early in the nineteenth century, the
British Province of the Moravian Church, which is an international missionary
church; the Free Church of England (or Reformed Episcopal Church), which
was formed in 1844 as a direct result of the Oxford Movement; the Society of
Friends; and the Salvation Army.
The Society of Friends (Quakers) came into being in the middle of the
seventeenth century under the leadership of George Fox. A distinctive feature
is the way of worship: outward sacraments are not observed and there is no
separate ministry. The Society places great emphasis on work for peace, and
their influence in many parts of the world, especially in social reform and in
the relief of suffering, is very wide in relation to their numbers. There are 440
Quaker Meetings in Britain and nearly 21,000 members; and the Society has
nine schools (the pupils and staff of which are not exclusively Quaker).
The Salvation Army, founded in 1865 (as the Christian Mission), is a
religious movement, composed of men and women who seek the spiritual and
social betterment of their fellows, primarily by preaching the gospel to those
hitherto untouched by religious effort. The movement, which is quasi¬
military in structure, has branches all over the world. Internationally it
provides a greater variety and volume of social service than any other single
voluntary society.
The Christian Scientists, who are in no way connected with any other
church, have about 330 branch churches and societies in Britain.
ioe The Roman Catholic hierarchy in England and Wales, which became
Catholic Church temporarily extinct during the sixteenth century, was restored in 1850; the
Scottish hierarchy became extinct in the early seventeenth century and was
restored in 1878, while the Irish hierarchy never became completely extinct.
The normal government of the Roman Catholic Church, namely by territorial
archbishops and bishops, is once again the rule in the whole of the United
Kingdom. ,
The central territorial unit of the Roman Catholic hierarchical organisation
is the province or archdiocese under the metropolitan, who is always an
archbishop. A province normally comprises several dioceses, each under a
bishop aided by a chapter of canons and others, and by priests in charge of
the parishes into which the diocese is subdivided. In England and Wales
there are five provinces and archdioceses (Westminster, Liverpool, Birming¬
ham, Cardiff and Southwark), 14 dioceses, and nearly 2,300 parishes (the
chairman of the Bishops’ Conference in England and Wales is the Archbishop
of Westminster); in Scotland there are two provinces and archdioceses (St.
Andrews and Edinburgh, and Glasgow), six dioceses, and about 400 parishes;
in Northern Ireland there are six dioceses (several of which have territory
partly in the Irish Republic and partly in Northern Ireland since there is one
hierarchy for the whole of Ireland) and about 170 parishes. In the whole of the
United Kingdom there are some 6 million adherents (including children) to
the Roman Catholic faith.
Other
Denominations
THE CHURCHES
l87
The Roman Catholic Church attaches great importance to the education
of its children in their own faith, and requires that the children of marriages
between its own members and members of any other denomination should be
brought up as Roman Catholics. Many schools for Roman Catholic children
in the United Kingdom are staffed by members of the religious orders for men
and women, who also undertake other social work such as nursing, child care,
and the conduct of homes for old people.
Jews first settled in England at the time of the Norman conquest, but were
expelled at the end of the thirteenth century by an edict of Edward I. The
present Anglo-Jewish community dates from 1656, the earliest arrivals being
the Sephardi (from Spain and Portugal). At the end of the seventeenth
century an Ashkenazi community (from Germany and East Europe) was
established, which increased rapidly and spread to the principal provincial
cities. As a result of the virtual destruction of whole Jewish communities on
the Continent during the second world war, the Anglo-Jewish community of
some 450,000 became the largest group of Jews in Europe.
The Anglo-Jewish community is divided into two schools of thought, each
of which has its own form of worship and its own services: the Orthodox (the
original groups) and the Reform. The Reform Movement, which does not
insist on the permanently binding character of Jewish law and therefore
attaches less religious importance to some of the traditional rituals and
practices of the Jewish faith, began in 1840. It was followed in 1901 by the
establishment of the Liberal Jewish Movement which made the breach with
the traditional section wider by laying emphasis on the re-interpreta¬
tion of traditional Judaism in the light of modern thought and custom. Of
the Jews in Great Britain who belong to any kind of synagogue, about 90 per
cent are Orthodox. The Chief Rabbi is the head of the largest group (Ashkenazi)
within Orthodox Jewry; the Haham is the head of the Sephardi group.
Synagogues in Britain number more than 390. There has been an increase
in the number of Jewish denominational schools, which are now attended by
about one in seven Jewish children; other Jewish children attend the ordinary
State or independent schools and receive extra-curricular instruction in the
Jewish faith.
Many immigrants to Britain from overseas Commonwealth countries and
foreign countries have established centres for worship for their own com¬
munities in the United Kingdom, and especially in London. The Christian
communities include the Greek, Russian, Polish and Serb Orthodox, with
some Estonian and Latvian Orthodox, and also the Armenian Church. There
are also churches belonging to the Lutheran Churches of Denmark, Finland,
Germany, Norway and Sweden, and centres where Estonian, Latvian and
Polish Lutherans worship according to their creed. In addition, the French,
Dutch, Swiss, Hungarian and Polish Reformed Churches are represented in
Britain, the first three having their own places of worship. There are also a
number of other religious sects of British or foreign origin; figures of
membership in Britain of most of them are not available.
The principal non-Christian communities in Britain, apart from the Jews,
are the Muslims and the Buddhists.
The Muslims are the more widely represented, their number in Britain being
estimated at several hundred thousands of whom over 130,000 are in London
where the London Central Mosque and Islamic Cultural Centre, the Shiah
Islamic Assembly Centre and the East London Mosque are situated. The

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Shah Jehan Mosque is at Woking, Surrey, and there are mosques or Islamic
centres in Manchester, Liverpool, Bradford, Cardiff and in many of the other
larger cities in Britain.
There are several thousand adherents of Buddhism in Britain. The Buddhist
Society has its headquarters in London, with a Shrine Room, there are also
Shrine Rooms in the three Viharas in London, one of which is run by Thai
monks and supported by the Thai Government. In Scotland there is a Shrine
Room at the Tibetan Centre.
The British Council of Churches, composed of official representatives from
almost all the churches of the British Isles, with consultant observers from the
Roman Catholic Church, and presided over by the Archbishop of Canterbury,
facilitates common action between the churches and seeks to further the cause
of Christian unity. Proposals for union between the Anglican and Methodist
Churches, which have gained a large measure of support, have not yet been
finally accepted. Most, though not all, of the Free Churches in England and
Wales are members of the Free Church Federal Council, the aims of which
are to promote unity and joint action between the Free Churches, and to
provide a channel through which the Free Churches can communicate and
negotiate with central and local government authorities as a united body.
The Anglican, Presbyterian and Free Churches in the British Isles also
participate in the World Council of Churches, which was constituted at
Amsterdam, Netherlands, in 1948. The council links together 226 churches in
over 70 countries for co-operation in action and the study of common problems.
The Council of Christians and Jews works for better understanding between
members of the two religions and deals with problems in the social field.
9 PROMOTION OF THE
SCIENCES AND
THE ARTS
THE PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES
The Government is the main source of funds for scientific research and
development as a whole though private industry contributes a larger pro¬
portion of funds for civil research and development. Considerable sums are
also provided by public corporations, independent trusts and foundations,
and learned societies. The Government also keeps under review facilities for
training scientists and ensures that adequate research is directed to matters
of national interest.
THE GOVERN¬

Expenditure
According to Statistics of Science and Technology 1968 (see Bibliography,
p. 478) total expenditure on research and development has risen from
£771-4 million in 1964-65 to £882-9 million in 1966-67. This represents
2-7 per cent of the gross national product at factor cost. The percentage of
the total carried out by the Government (including the research councils) has
continued to decline, falling to 22 per cent compared with 24-9 per cent two
years previously. The proportion of the total carried out in the universities
and establishments of further education has remained about the same, over
the two years, at just over 7 per cent. The proportion of the total finance for
research and development provided by the Government has declined from
54-6 per cent in 1964-65 to 50-2 per cent in 1966-67. This is due to the
relative drop in the proportion accounted for by defence. The expenditure
of the research councils amounted to £72-6 million in 1967-68, and is
expected to rise to £87 million by 1969-70, though the rate of increase is now
declining.

Central
