BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Central Advisory Council for Science and Technology was established in
January 1967, under the chairmanship of the Chief Scientific Adviser to the
Government, to advise the Government on the most effective national strategy
for the use and development of the country’s scientific and technological
resources. The Council includes representatives of the Council for Scientific
Policy (see below), the Advisory Council on Technology (see p. 191), and the
Royal Society (see p. 193), and a number of independent members.
Under the Science and Technology Act 1965 central responsibility for
basic and applied civil science rests with the Secretary of State for Education
and Science, who, advised by a Council for Scientific Policy in relation to
the natural sciences as a whole, is responsible for directing and financing the
research councils (see below). Responsibility for technology rests with the
Minister of Technology, who is advised by an Advisory Council on Techno¬
logy. Other government departments are responsible for research and
development related to their executive responsibilities.
The Department
of Education
and Science
The Council
for Scientific
Policy
The Department of Education and Science (see also p. 49) is responsible,
among other things, for the universities and basic and applied civil science
throughout Great Britain. The Department’s relations with the universities
are conducted through the University Grants Committee (see p. 159); and its
responsibilities for basic and applied civil science are discharged mainly
through the five research councils: the Science Research Council (see p. 195)’
the Medical Research Council (see p. 197), the Agricultural Research Council
(see p. 198), the Natural Environment Research Council (see p. 202), and the
Social Science Research Council (see p. 203). Others may be established under
the terms of the Science and Technology Act. The Department also has, in
consultation with other departments, general governmental responsibility for
Britain’s scientific space research programme, which is co-ordinated by the
Science Research Council. The Department is responsible for some aspects of
international scientific relations (see p. 205), and for promoting more efficient
handling and use of scientific and technical information. For the latter purpose
it has set up the Office for Scientific and Technical Information (see p. 204).
In the exercise of his responsibilities for the formulation and execution of
government scientific policy (but excluding, at present, the social sciences)
the Secretary of State for Education and Science is advised by the Council
for Scientific Policy (CSP), which replaced the former Advisory Council on
Scientific Policy. The Council, which was set up in January 1965, consists of
a chairman and 13 independent members. There are, in addition, assessors
from the research councils and from the University Grants Committee.
Among the issues with which the Council is concerned is the balance of
scientific effort in those areas for which the Secretary of State is responsible.
The Ministry The Ministry of Technology (see also p. 56), which came formally into being
of Technology in 1964, took over responsibility for the United Kingdom Atomic Energy
Authority (AEA) (see p. 200) and the National Research Development
Corporation (see p. 205). Go the dissolution of the Department of Scientific
and Industrial Research (DSIR) in 1965 many of its functions and resources
were transferred to the Ministry, and in February 1967 the Ministry incorpor¬
ated the functions and responsibilities of the former Ministry of Aviation with
the exception of those civil aviation responsibilities which were transferred to
the Board of Trade (see p. 56).
The Ministry, among other things, has responsibility for engineering
standards and weights and measures and for the British Standards Institution

(see p. 251). It has direct control of a number of research stations and estab¬
lishments (see p. 196); it also aids with grants about 40 autonomous industrial
research associations (see p. 196).
The Minister of Technology is chairman of the Advisory Council on Tech¬
nology, set up to advise on the application of advanced technology in British
industry. There is a deputy chairman and ten other members, representing
scientific, economic, trade union and industrial interests.
An Advisory Committee on Highly Qualified Manpower was set up in 1969
to replace the former Committee on Manpower Resources for Science and
Technology. It advises the Government, through the Secretary of State for
Education and Science, on the problems of highly qualified manpower as a
whole. Its members include representatives of academic and industrial life.
Three new advisory boards to replace steering committees were created in
1969 in consultation with the Royal Society (see p. 193) and the Confederation
of British Industry (see p. 244) to advise the Minister of Technology on
matters relating exclusively to three research establishments. Advisory
committees were also set up to advise on certain research programmes.
A number of other government departments remain responsible for certain
branches of research.
The Ministry of Transport is concerned with research and development
relating to inland transport and ports. Research into road construction,
traffic flow and safety is carried out mainly at the Ministry’s Road Research
Laboratory at Crowthorne, Berkshire. There are also collaborative arrange¬
ments for research in inland transport with the Ministry of Technology.
Economic and operational research studies are carried out in the Ministry
of Transport’s headquarters and are commissioned from consultants and
universities. The Ministry of Technology is responsible for sponsoring
research and development in aviation.
Research on radio aids for marine navigation is undertaken by the Ministry
of Defence, which is also responsible for inter-Service electronic valve
research at the Services Electronics Research Laboratory. Research on marine
nuclear propulsion is undertaken by the AEA.
The Ministry of Power is responsible for research into safety and health of
mineworkers. The coal, electricity and gas industries are required to settle
their general programmes of research in consultation with the Minister, who
is assisted by an Advisory Council on Research and Development. Similar
provisions apply to the British Steel Corporation’s general programme of
research and technological development.
The Ministry of Defence finances the Meteorological Office, which is respon¬
sible for research in meteorology and geophysics, mainly for civil purposes.
The headquarters of the Office and most of its research sections are at
Bracknell, Berkshire. The Ministry also makes grants for fundamental
meteorological research carried out under the auspices of the Royal Society or
in university departments.
The Ministry of Public Building and Works has a Directorate General of
Research and Development (see p. 299) and is responsible for the Building
Research Station, Garston, Watford, Hertfordshire, which is concerned with
the techniques of building design and construction, and the organisation,
productivity and economics of building work.

THE LEARNED

BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Ministry of Housing and Local Government sponsors certain geo¬
graphical, geological, economic and sociological research relating to the use and
development of land in England and Wales. Similar arrangements are made in
Scotland by the Scottish Home and Health Department, and in Northern
Ireland by the Ministry of Development. A Centre for Environmental Studies
has been set up as an independent educational trust for research into the
problems of urban planning and dealing with the effects of a fast-growing
mobile population.
The Post Office undertakes research and development on many aspects of the
science and engineering of communications, both in its own laboratories and
in close association with industry, the universities and government depart¬
ments. The main research station is at Dollis Hill, London, and there are
laboratories at Backwell, near Bristol, at Castleton, near Cardiff, and also at
Martlesham, near Ipswich, where a new research station is being built.
The Royal Botanic Gardens, Kew (founded in 1759), together with its
400-acre estate at Wakehurst Place, Ardingly, Sussex, is administered by
the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and has the largest collection
of living plants in the world. Its research departments are: the herbarium,
concerned primarily with the classification and accurate determination of
plants; and the Jodrell Laboratory, for the study of plant anatomy and plant
physiology, cytology and genetics. There are two museums concerned
mainly with the economic exploitation of plants. The library, attached to the
herbarium, was founded in 1853; it consists of more than 100,000 botanical
books, about 140,000 reprints and separately issued items and a collection of
over 160,000 drawings and paintings of plants. The Royal Botanic Garden,
Edinburgh, founded about 1660, has, since April 1969, been administered
by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland.
A Select Committee of the House of Commons on Science and Technology
was set up in December 1966. It is one of two specialist committees established
experimentally to give back-bench Members the opportunity to investigate
the policies and administration of the Government and to participate in the
formation of policy. The Members of the Committee (not more than 15 in
number) are nominated by the House. The Committee has power to call
witnesses and generally takes evidence in public.
The Parliamentary and Scientific Committee, founded in 1939, provides for a
regular exchange of information between members of Parliament and scientists.
Membership is open to members of Parliament of any party in both Houses,
and also to nominated representatives of such non-profit-making scientific and
technological organisations in Britain as may be affiliated under its constitution.
Although today most research is conducted under other auspices, the learned
societies have retained their traditional function of facilitating the spread of
scientific knowledge. At present there are over 200 of them in Britain with
approximately 400 scientific publications. There are also numerous technical
institutions and professional associations, many of which are playing a
distinguished part in promoting their own branches of science or are interested
in the education and professional well-being of their members.
The Council of Engineering Institutions, established in 1965, promotes
the co-ordination of the engineering profession. The Council of Science
and Technology Institutes—a federal body with five member institutes
Royal Society
Royal Society
of Arts
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 193
representing biologists, chemists, mathematicians, metallurgists and
physicists—was formed in 1969.
The most eminent of the learned societies concerned with science in its
broadest aspects (as distinct from those societies with specialised interests and
activities) are the Royal Society, Royal Society of Arts, Royal Institution and
British Association.
The Royal Society, or more fully, the Royal Society of London for the
Improvement of Natural Knowledge, founded in 1660, occupies a unique
place in the country’s scientific affairs and corresponds to national academies
of sciences in other countries. Election to it is regarded by scientists as a high
honour. The Queen is Patron. There are today three main categories of
Fellowship: Royal Fellows, comprising the Queen Mother and three Royal
Dukes; Foreign Members, of whom there are about 70, and the main body of
Fellows numbering about 700. Election to the Fellowship, which is for life,
was for many years restricted to 25 persons a year and the foreign membership
to four a year but in 1965 the former was increased to 32 with the intention of
awarding some of the new places to applied scientists in both the physical and
biological sciences. The Society is governed by a council of 21 members.
Its activities include the holding of scientific meetings; publication of
research work, mainly in the Philosophical Transactions and the Proceedings',
the presentation of medals; the giving of endowed lectures; and the award of
research appointments and grants. Among its research appointments are the
Foulerton, Wolfson and Sir Henry Dale Research Professorships and nine
other research professorships supported by parliamentary grant-in-aid. The
highest medal awarded is the Copley Medal, for which scientists from all
countries are eligible; there are also three Royal Medals, and the Rumford,
Darwin, Buchanan, Sylvester, Hughes, Leverhulme and Mullard Medals.
There are five lectureships: the Croonian (biology); the Bakerian (physical
sciences); the Ferrier (nervous system); the Wilkins (history of science); and
the Leeuwenhoek (microbiology). The Society has set up committees, some
of them jointly with other bodies, to promote improvements in education in
science and to emphasise the importance of applied sciences, especially
engineering.
Although an independent private corporation, the Society has always had
a special relationship with the Government, which makes grants for certain of
its activities. The President of the Society is consulted on scientific appoint¬
ments to government research councils and Fellows serve on most govern¬
mental advisory councils and committees concerned with research.
The international relations of the Royal Society are extensive. It represents
the United Kingdom in the international unions comprising the International
Council of Scientific Unions and appoints national committees for each of
them. It also plays a leading part in international scientific programmes such
as the International Biological Programme (1965-70), and promotes exchange
visits of scientists with many academies throughout the world. Its European
Programme to further relations between scientists of Western Europe receives
financial support from the Government and other sources.
The Royal Society of Arts (properly, the Royal Society for the Encouragement
of Arts, Manufactures and Commerce) has a character at once scientific,
artistic, technical, industrial and commercial. Since its foundation in i754> one
of the Society’s principal objects has been to promote the progress and appli¬
cation to useful ends of all departments of science. Today it fulfils this
i94
Royal
Institution
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
purpose chiefly by disseminating new scientific knowledge. The Society
regularly holds lectures, and publishes a monthly Journal, thus providing
effective media for the exposition and assessment by leading authorities of
developments which have a public as well as a specialist interest.
The Royal Institution was founded in 1799 as a public body for facilitating
the introduction of useful mechanical inventions and improvements, and for
teaching the application of science to everyday life. Later it undertook the
‘promotion of chemical science by experiments and lectures for improving
arts and manufactures’, and ‘the diffusion and extension of useful knowledge’.
Its character, however, was largely determined by the work of Sir Humphry
Davy and Michael Faraday, who established a tradition of research. Today,
the Royal Institution has extensive research laboratories, and lectures are given
on recent developments in science and other branches of knowledge. Its library
of some 60,000 books includes many early scientific works and manuscripts.
British The British Association for the Advancement of Science was founded in 1831
Association to promote general interest in science and its applications. One of its chief
activities is the Annual Meeting, attended by many young students as well as
by eminent scientists. In addition the Association plans special lectures,
exhibitions and discussions (some designed for young audiences), the publica¬
tion of pamphlets, the organisation of conferences, the appointment of study
groups and liaison with the Press and with sound and television broadcasting
services. The Association has area committees and three lectureships for
young scientists—the Kelvin, the Darwin and the Lister lectureships, dealing
respectively with the physical, biological and sociological sciences—to
encourage scientists to make their activities known to wider audiences. The
British Association has an organised relationship with over 150 scientific
bodies and learned societies. It has also made an important contribution to the
development of science by taking or recommending action to remove obstacles
to the discovery and application of scientific knowledge.
THE UNIVER¬
SITIES AND
INSTITUTIONS
OF UNIVERSITY
STATUS
In 1967-68 the total estimated university expenditure on research was about
^51-7 million. The largest government contribution was through the
University Grants Committee (UGC) (see p. 158).
Scientific research in the universities is also supported through the research
councils. This support takes two forms. First, about half the postgraduate
students in science and technology in the universities receive maintenance
awards from the research councils, through postgraduate scholarships,
studentships or fellowships. These awards are in some cases for periods of up
to three years for training in research work and in others for shorter periods
for advanced studies. The cost of these awards is currently about £7-2 million
a year. Second, grants are given to the universities by the research councils
for specific projects, particularly in new or developing fields of research. In
recent years the research councils, in addition to making grants of this kind,
have made funds available for expensive items of university equipment
required for specific programmes of research. The research councils’ support
for research in the universities, excluding expenditure by the Medical Research
Council and the Agricultural Research Council on their own research units
within the universities (which remain under the control of, and are wholly
financed by, the councils) amounted in 1968-69 to over million.
The other main channels of support for scientific research in the universities
are various government departments, the Royal Society, industry and the

SCIENCE

INDUSTRIAL

195
independent foundations. The contributions from sources other than the
University Grants Committee amount to nearly a third of the total university
expenditure on research.
In addition to the universities, colleges of advanced technology in England
and Wales, which are acquiring the status and title of universities, and central
institutions in Scotland are playing an increasing part in scientific and techno¬
logical research and development. These colleges and institutions are financed
by the education departments but are now making a growing demand on the
support for research provided by the research councils.
Universities in industrial centres have tended to acquire outstanding
reputations in studies relating to their local industries, and on a national scale
close relationships are fostered between the universities, industries and the
Government in numerous joint projects. The Ministry of Technology’s
industrial liaison officers (see p. 204) are based on universities or technical
colleges. Six Industrial Units have been opened (five at universities and one at
the College of Aeronautics, Cranfield) under a Ministry of Technology scheme.
They offer consultancy and research and development resources and are
expected to become self-supporting within a few years.
According to Statistics of Science and Technology there were in Great Britain
in 1966 about 327,400 persons holding qualifications in engineering,
technology and science (179,900 with qualifications in engineering and
technology, and 147,400 in science). The 1965 manpower survey showed
that, of the persons holding qualifications in engineering and technology,
5-6 per cent were employed in education, 47-3 per cent in manufacturing
industry, and 14-4 per cent in government and research associations;
comparable percentages for persons holding qualifications in science were
36-5, 26-2 and 10-2.
The Science Research Council (SRC), which came into formal existence on
1 st April 1965 and consists of a chairman and 15 other members, covers all
branches of fundamental science other than those for which the other research
councils are responsible. It also supports research in engineering and techno¬
logy in the universities. Provision is made for it to carry out research and
development through its own establishments; to encourage and support similar
research by any other person or body; to provide and operate equipment for
common use by universities, technical colleges and similar institutions; to
make grants for postgraduate studies; and to disseminate knowledge of science
and technology. Its establishments include the Royal Greenwich Observatory,
Herstmonceux, the Royal Observatory, Edinburgh, the Radio and Space
Research Station, the Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, the Daresbury
Nuclear Physics Laboratory, the Atlas Computer Laboratory, and the
Astrophysics Research Unit at the Culham Laboratory. The SRC also
co-ordinates the British scientific space research programme (see p. 201) and
provides the United Kingdom contribution to the European Organisation
for Nuclear Research (CERN) and the European Space Research Organisation
(ESRO) (see also p. 201).
The greater part of industrial research in Britain is undertaken in government
establishments and in the research organisations of the larger firms. Research
organisations in industry vary widely between the largest firms employing
thousands of qualified staff and some employing very few; though the
emphasis is on commercial development, some fundamental research is done.
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Other main agencies are universities and technical colleges, industrial
research associations, independent institutes for sponsored research and
consultant laboratories.
Ministry of
Technology’s
Research
Resources
Research
Associations
The net total expenditure for 1968-69 on the Ministry of Technology’s
establishments was about £55 million, made up of about £10 million for the
ten industrial research establishments and £45 million for the eight aviation
establishments. Most of the latter was on supporting and monitoring contracts
with industry for developing defence projects. Of the Ministry’s total
expenditure on research and development (excluding the AEA) less than
one-fifth is spent in Ministry establishments. Its non-industrial staff number
about 22,000, including about 2,860 qualified scientists and engineers
employed on research and development. These resources are estimated to
represent the largest block of research and development facilities and man¬
power available to any government outside the United States and the Soviet
Union.
The activities of the civil research stations include aeronautics and water
pollution. Besides research and development for industry these establishments
are engaged on the application of techniques and discoveries to design,
production, quality control, distribution, marketing and sales. In addition,
there are the industrial research associations grant-aided by the Ministry
of Technology.
The scheme by which the Government gives financial help to groups of firms
with similar interests to form organisations known as research associations, to
carry out industrial research co-operatively, was started in 1917 and is now
operated by the Ministry of Technology. There are now 43 such associations,
with a combined income of £14 million (compared with ^5-1 million in 1955),
of which a little more than a quarter was contributed by the Government.
Suitably specialised associations are now available for about 60 per cent of
British industry, varying in size from the Production Engineering Research
Association with an annual income of ^1 - 8 million, of which about one-third
is provided by government grant, to the British Brush Manufacturers
Research Association with an income of only ^1,900. The largest are those
dealing with ships, production engineering, coal utilisation, electrical
manufacturing, cotton and man-made fibres, welding and wool. (Particulars
of these and other associations are given in Chapter 11, Industry.) The
amounts of the government grants are related to the contributions made by
the industries concerned.
The research associations are autonomous bodies governed by their own
councils, the members of which are mostly representatives of industry,
although the Ministry of Technology is also represented. The councils are
advised in preparing research programmes, for which they have complete
responsibility, by research committees representative of their industrial
members, often with the addition of university or government scientists. The
Ministry of Technology appoints two Visitors for each association; normally
one is a scientist and the other an industrialist—both of some eminence.
Nearly all research associations admit to membership manufacturers in
Commonwealth countries and many also admit those in foreign countries.
The associations make the results of their work known to member firms by a
variety of methods, among which are bulletins, technical reports, lectures,
films, training classes, exhibitions and mobile demonstration units. A Con¬
ference of Industrial Research Associations was set up in 1969.

MEDICAL

Some of the public corporations which run the nationalised industries have
their own research organisations (see Chapter 11), in particular those con¬
cerned with fuel and power, steel and transport. They also give support to
organisations concerned with research on matters of interest to them.
According to Statistics of Science and Technology 1968, total expenditure on
research and development by the different industrial sectors in 1966-67
(excluding establishments of less than 100 employees) was as follows (in
£ million): aerospace 159-3; electronics no; chemicals and allied industries
73-7; electrical engineering 37-5; mechanical and marine engineering and
shipbuilding 6o-i; metal manufacture 19; fabricated metal manufacture
9- 3; motor vehicles, locomotives, etc., 46-8; scientific instruments 14-1;
textiles, leather, etc., 14-3; food, drink and tobacco 17-2; petroleum products
10- 4.
These figures include funds from government sources. Firms in science-
based industries such as chemicals, pharmaceuticals, electrical and electronic
equipment, oil refining, steel, vehicles and scientific instruments commit
large private funds to research and development in the course of business.
A number of institutes for sponsored research have been established to
extend the facilities for private research for industrial firms by studying
problems which are not within the scope of the average industrial laboratory.
In these institutes research for private firms is carried out confidentially, the
results remaining the property of the sponsor.
A Medical Research Committee was appointed in 1913 to administer the
research funds provided under the National Health Insurance Act 1911. In
1920 the Committee was superseded by the Medical Research Council
(MRC), established under Royal Charter and supported by a grant-in-aid
provided by Parliament, now through the Secretary of State for Education and
Science. The MRC was granted a new charter in 1966.
In addition to financing the MRC, the Government gives substantial
support to medical research through block grants to universities distributed
through the University Grants Committee; and to clinical research through
the National Health Service. Certain government-financed research for defence
purposes, for example, at the Microbiological Establishment at Porton,
Wiltshire, has civil applications related to medical science.
Important contributions to the support of research in particular subjects
are made by industry, especially the pharmaceutical industry, and by private
charities or voluntary organisations, such as the Nuffield Foundation and the
British Empire Cancer Campaign.
The Medical Research Council is responsible to the Secretary of State for
Education and Science and consists of a Chairman, a Deputy Chairman, and
from 10 to 14 other members. Not less than three-quarters must be scientific¬
ally qualified, representative of the different branches of medical knowledge
and actively engaged in research. All members are appointed by the Secretary
of State, the scientific members after consultation with the President of the
Royal Society and the existing Council; and the Chairman and Deputy
Chairman after consultation with the Council.
The MRC’s chief function is to promote research into all aspects of health
and disease. In planning and carrying out its research programme the Council
is assisted by bodies specially appointed to advise on particular subjects.
Three of the more important of these are the Clinical Research Board, set up
[q8 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
in consultation with the health departments to assist the development of
clinical research; the Tropical Medicine Research Board, appointed in
consultation with the Ministry of Overseas Development, to advise on the
promotion and co-ordination of research in this field; and the Biological
Research Board, which advises on the promotion of research in the non-
clinical field. In addition, the MRC is advised by committees concerned
with particular aspects of its work. The MRC’s arrangements for the
support of research fall under four main headings: (1) investigations by
members of its scientific staff, mostly working in its own establishments;
(2) short-term grants to workers in universities and elsewhere; (3) long-term
grants in support of specific research programmes in university medical
departments (‘research groups’); and (4) fellowships and scholarships tenable
both at home and abroad. The programme includes fundamental studies
of the structure and natural processes of the body; clinical and laboratory
studies of disease; the development and evaluation of special methods of
treatment and also of prophylaxis and diagnosis; and the study of social and
occupational factors affecting health and the efficiency of body and mind.
The National Institute for Medical Research, at Mill Hill and Hampstead,
London, is the MRC’s main research establishment; in addition, there are
over 70 smaller establishments, known as research units, which are attached
in most cases to universities and hospitals in the United Kingdom. By 1970
it is hoped that the first phase of the Clinical Research Centre being built at
Northwick Park in north-west London as an integral part of the new district
hospital for the North West Metropolitan Regional Hospital Board will be
ready. The Centre will be the clinical counterpart of the National Institute
for Medical Research.
The MRC also undertakes work overseas and, with additional support
from the Ministry of Overseas Development, maintains laboratories in The
Gambia and units in Uganda and Jamaica.
AGRICULTURAL Agricultural research is carried out by the Agricultural Research Council, the
RESEARCH government agricultural departments and by private industry.
Agricultural
Research
Council
The
Government
Agricultural
Departments
The Agricultural Research Council (ARC), established in 193L consists of not
less than 15 and not more than 18 members, including the Chief Veterinary
Officer and certain appointments made by the Ministers of the agricultural
departments. In addition to distinguished scientists, the membership includes
people with practical farming experience. The ARC is under the general
oversight of the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The ARC is responsible for 14 independent state-aided agricultural
research institutes and also has nine institutes under its direct control and
12 units which it has established under distinguished scientists associated w ith
universities. Also there are eight independent institutes in Scotland financed
by the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland with advice
from the ARC on their scientific programmes, staffing and equipment.
The ARC makes special research grants to support promising new lines of
work in university departments. It awards a limited number of postgiaduate
training awards for those wishing to undertake a career in veterinary research.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food carries out applied and basic
research in its own veterinary laboratories at Weybridge, Surrey, and at
Lasswade, Midlothian, and also at its plant pathology laboratory at Harpenden,
Hertfordshire; while at its infestation control laboratory at Tolworth, Surrey
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
199
NUCLEAR
ENERGY
(with a field station at Worplesdon), it co-ordinates work on the control of
insect pests of stored food and conducts research on the control of harmful
mammals and birds. The Central Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge has
been appointed by the World Health Organisation (WHO) as the third
international laboratory for biological standards. In Scotland research work
at East Craigs, Edinburgh, by the Agricultural Scientific Services of the
Department of Agriculture and Fisheries is mainly concerned with the
problems of healthy seed potato production, seed pathology, cultivation,
taxonomy and vertebrate pest control. In Northern Ireland the Ministry of
Agriculture is responsible for the promotion of agricultural research and
have research divisions dealing with a variety of aspects.
The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food maintains four laboratories
for marine, shell-fish and salmon and freshwater fisheries research, and four
marine research vessels. The Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for
Scotland maintains a marine research laboratory and six research ships at
Aberdeen, and a freshwater fisheries research laboratory at Pitlochry.
With the guidance of the Chief Scientific Adviser (Food), the Food
Standards, Science and Safety Division of the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food is responsible for formulating the Ministry’s general policy
on the acquisition and dissemination of scientific and technical information
about food and the food handling and processing industry; for furnishing
scientific advice to the other divisions of the Ministry; and for sponsoring or
carrying out experimental work. The division has its own experimental
laboratories in London and Norwich. The Food Research Advisory Com¬
mittee advises on food problems requiring investigation or research.
The Forestry Commission undertakes experimental work relating to
silvicultural and allied problems (see p. 324). By means of grants, it also aids
forest research work undertaken by various universities and other institutions,
including the Commonwealth Forestry Institute, Oxford.
The Atomic Energy Authority (AEA), set up under the Atomic Energy
Authority Act 1954, is responsible for research and development in nuclear
energy. It is answerable to the Minister of Technology, who is responsible
under the Atomic Energy Acts 1946 to 1949 for promoting and controlling
the development of nuclear energy and ensuring that the proper degrees of
importance are attached to its various applications. The AEA has a large
programme of research into, and development of, the peaceful applications of
nuclear energy. As an essential part of the British Government’s nuclear
power programme, the AEA has developed new types of nuclear power
stations for the generation of electric power on a commercial scale and for this
purpose it builds and operates experimental and prototype nuclear reactors.
Construction of the nuclear power stations themselves is carried out by
industry to the order of the electricity authorities, which supervise their
operation. Two new consortia, with AEA participation, to design and
construct nuclear power stations were formed in 1968 and 1969. Under the
Science and Technology Act 1965 the functions of the AEA have been
extended so that the Minister may, after consultation, require it to undertake
research and development outside nuclear energy. Non-nuclear work is
absorbing a rising proportion of the AEA’s research resources and includes
research into desalination, hydrostatic extrusion, satellite design, biological
centrifuges, tribology, non-destructive testing, ceramics, atmospheric
pollution and carbon fibres.

The Atomic
Energy
Authority
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Secretary of State for Defence became responsible for the development
and production of nuclear weapons for the Services in 1966; in practice,
however, the AEA produces the explosive nuclear material and assemblies for
nuclear weapons under contract and carries out weapons research.
The Department of Education and Science and the AEA collaborate with
a number of other government departments and with the Radiological
Protection Service on various aspects of health and safety in relation to atomic
energy. Expert advice on radiation hazards is provided by the Medical and
Agricultural Research Councils and by the Radioactive Substances Advisory
Committee, appointed by the Secretary of State for Education and Science.
The Ministry of Technology and the AEA are jointly responsible for
co-operation with other countries in nuclear energy, partly through the
medium of bilateral agreements with a large number of individual countries
and partly through British membership of bodies such as the International
Atomic Energy Agency and the European Nuclear Energy Agency.
The Atomic Energy Authority, the members of which are appointed by the
Minister of Technology, consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and up to
14 other members, some of whom may be part-time.^
The AEA like other statutory public corporations, is free from day-to-day
government control (subject to the power given to the responsible minister
to issue directions to the AEA in matters of overriding national importance),
but differs from them in that most of its revenue is derived from money
voted by Parliament. Some of the commercial activities of the AEA are
financed through a trading fund with an initial capital of about £37 million.
The organisation has a London office, responsible for central financial an
administrative matters and for procuring raw materials. Its Radiochemical
Centre at Amersham produces and markets radioisotopes, about one-ha 01
export. The rest of its establishments are divided into four groups.
The Research Group’s principal laboratory is the Atomic Energy Research
Establishment (AERE), at Harwell. AERE undertakes research in support
of the AEA’s reactor programme and has a growing programme of applied
nuclear and non-nuclear research and a supporting programme of under-
lying research. Research is mainly on materials, their properties and the
effects on them of radiation. Facilities include materials testing reactors and
particle accelerators. The education and training department provides courses
on reactor technology, isotope techniques, radiological protection and other
subiects. Many of the courses are open to overseas students.
A second laboratory, at Culham, carries out research into plasma physics
and controlled thermo-nuclear fusion.
The Weapons Group, centred on Aldermaston, conducts research on and
development of nuclear weapons and other research work with civil, as well as
defence, applications. It has outstations at Foulness and Orfordness.
There are two groups with headquarters at Risley, in north-western
England. The Reactor Group works on the design, development and applica¬
tion of nuclear power reactors. It has developed the Advanced Gas-Cooled
Reactor (AGR), a prototype which has been operating successfully at
Windscale since February 1963. This system has been chosen for the first
stations of Britain’s second nuclear power programme (see p. 290).
The Reactor Group establishment at Winfrith in Dorset, a principal cen re
for reactor systems research, operates the Steam Generating Heavy ater
Reactor (SGHWR) and is also the location of the Dragon project, a 20 MW
(thermal) reactor financed jointly by the member countries of the European
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
201
Nuclear Energy Agency of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation
and Development (OECD). The Group also operates research laboratories
at Risley, Culcheth, Springfields and Windscale.
The Reactor Group also includes the Dounreay experimental reactor
establishment in the north of Scotland, which houses a materials-testing
reactor and an experimental fast-breeder reactor (DFR). Successful operation
of the DFR has led to the design of a fast-breeder reactor power station (PER)
of 250 MW (E) under construction at Dounreay. The Production Group
provides complete fuel services for the United Kingdom nuclear power
programme. It also sells these services to reactor operators overseas and
almost all its activities are now conducted on a commercial basis. The Group
consists of the fuel element factory at Springfields (Lancashire), the diffusion
plant for the enrichment of uranium at Capenhurst (Cheshire), the plutonium
factory at Windscale (Cumberland), and the nuclear power stations at Calder
Hall (Cumberland) and Chapelcross (Dumfriesshire). Plans exist to set up a
plant for the manufacture of enriched uranium by the gas centrifuge process
under a tripartite agreement with the Federal Republic of Germany and the
Netherlands.
High Energy
Physics
SPACE
ACTIVITIES
The provision of expensive facilities for research in high energy physics is the
function of the Science Research Council (see p. 195). The SRC establish¬
ments concerned are the Rutherford High Energy Laboratory, Chilton, with
a 7,000 million electron volt (MeV) proton synchrotron (particle accelerator),
completed in 1963 and the Daresbury Nuclear Physics Laboratory, Cheshire,
with a 4,000 MeV electron accelerator, completed in 1966.
Government responsibility for space activities is divided between the Secretary
of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for Defence, the
Minister of Technology and the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications.
Total expenditure on civil space activities in 1968-69 is estimated at about
£23-8 million; of this, ^8-2 million represents expenditure on Britain’s
national programme and ^15-6 million contributions to international bodies
such as the European Space Research Organisation (ESRO), the European
Space Vehicle Launcher Development Organisation (ELDO) and Intelsat.
The first two of these were set up to give European countries the opportunity
of participating more fully in space research and technology. ELDO was
established to develop large satellite launchers; the British Blue Streak is
being used as the launching vehicle for ELDO’s Europa rockets. ESRO was
founded to provide facilities for scientific experiments in space; it has a
programme of launchings of sounding rockets and satellites of various sizes.
Under two inter-related international agreements reached in 1964, in
Washington, Britain, together with the US and other countries in Europe and
elsewhere, is taking part in International Telecommunications Satellite
Consortium (Intelsat). The Government announced in April 1968 that it
would cease to contribute to ELDO after 1971 but would be prepared to
accept a growth rate of up to 6 per cent a year for ESRO.
The execution of the civil scientific space research programme is the
responsibility of the Secretary of State for Education and Science, through
the Science Research Council.
Scientific space experiments are arranged by scientists in the universities
and in government research establishments, under the general supervision of
the Space Research Management Unit of the Science Research Council. The
Royal Society represents Britain in non-governmental international scientific

groups such as the Committee on Space Research (COSPAR) of the Inter¬
national Council of Scientific Unions (ICSU).
In addition, Britain is co-operating with the United States in a programme
which includes the launching of the Ariel series of satellites and the incorpora¬
tion of British experiments in US satellites. The third such artificial earth
satellite, Ariel 3, launched in May 1967, and the upper atmosphere Skylark
rockets used in the British national and the ESRO programmes were designed
and produced in Britain, as will be UK-4 due to be launched in 1971.
The Ministry of Technology is responsible for conducting research into,
and for developing and producing, launchers, space vehicles and their
ancillary equipment. As an example, it is responsible at the Royal Aircraft
Establishment for the development of the Skylark rockets and is also carrying
out a programme for the development of an all-British satellite launcher
vehicle, Black Arrow, developed from the successful Black Knight research
rocket, on which some £3 million a year is being spent.
The Post Office is responsible for the use of satellites for civil communica¬
tions purposes and undertakes research work in connection with communica¬
tions systems using satellites. The Post Office ground station at Goonhill}
in Cornwall is one of the most successful in the world, and British firms are
building such stations overseas.
The satellite prediction centre at the Radio and Space Research Station,
Slough, also the home of one of the three World Data Centres for space
research, co-ordinates optical tracking activities in Britain. Optical observation
of satellites is carried out regularly by many individual observers in Britain
and by the Royal Edinburgh Observatory’s outstation (see below); radio
tracking is undertaken at the Radio and Space Research Station and by radio
telescopes at Jodrell Bank and the Royal Radar Establishment at Malvern.
Large optical telescopes were first constructed in Britain by Herschel and
Rosse in the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries. The latest addition to the
equipment at Herstmonceux is the 98-inch Isaac Newton telescope, the largest
in Western Europe, completed in 1967' Grants by the SRC to the Radcliffe
Trustees have enabled British optical astronomers to have continued access to
the 74-inch telescope at the Radcliffe Observatory in South Africa for
observations in the southern skies. In April 1967 the SRC assumed responsi¬
bility for supporting and managing this telescope. The Royal Edinburgh
Observatory has been re-equipped with modern instrumentation for use m
stellar spectroscopy and photometry. The British and Australian Governments
are building jointly a 130-inch optical telescope in New South Wales.
Radio astronomy, developed since 1931, is carried out mainly at Cambridge
University, at the Jodrell Bank Experimental Station of Manchester University
in Cheshire, and at the Royal Radar Establishment at Malvern. Britain
occupies a pre-eminent position in this branch of research.
The Natural Environment Research Council (NERC) was established oy
Royal Charter in June 1965 under the Science and Technology Act 1965 to
encourage, plan and conduct research in those sciences, both physical and
biological, that relate to man’s natural environment. The work of the NERC
falls into five main groups: the solid earth, its physical properties and mineral 1
resources (geology, geophysics and geochemistry); the inland waters and theii
living resources (hydrology, freshwater biology, ecology and fisheries); the
terrestrial communities, their resources and amenities (terrestrial ecology,
forestry and conservation); the seas and oceans, their behaviour and their
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS

OTHER

Zoological

Scientific

203
living and mineral resources (oceanography, marine biology and ecology, and
fisheries); and the atmosphere (some aspects of meteorology). The NERC
administers the British Antarctic Survey, the Institute of Geological Sciences,
the Institute of Hydrology, the National Institute of Oceanography, the
Institute of Coastal Oceanography and Tides, the Nature Conservancy, and
the Research Vessel Unit. It is also responsible for supporting the Marine
Biological Association, the Scottish Marine Biological Association, the
Freshwater Biological Association, the Fisheries Helminthology Unit and the
Marine Invertebrate Biology Unit.
Many of the activities of the NERC are related to university research in the
environmental sciences, which it supports by postgraduate training awards,
research grants and fellowships.
Further responsibilities of the NERC include the support of long-term
forestry research in consultation with the Forestry Commission; financial and
policy control of research in seismology and geomagnetism carried out by the
Meteorological Office; and the co-ordination of research in meteorology
generally with that carried out by the Meteorological Office.
The Social Science Research Council (SSRC) was set up in December 1965,
with the same status as the other research councils. It provides grants for
research projects at universities and other institutions, and makes training
awards to postgraduate students. The SSRC’s fields of interest include
economics; political science; psychology; social anthropology; social and
economic statistics; sociology and social administration; education; manage¬
ment; and various aspects of a wide range of other disciplines.
Several government departments have funds allocated for social research
related to their responsibilities, including the Home Office, which has a large
research unit which carries out a wide variety of sociological studies. The
Social Survey conducts sample survey enquiries at the request of government
departments and from time to time also carries out studies in collaboration
with universities and other independent research organisations.
Zoological research is among the activities of the world-famous Zoological
Gardens, extending over 34 acres in Regent’s Park, London, which were
opened by the Zoological Society of London in 1828. A natural zoo of 500
acres was opened in 1931 Whipsnade, in Bedfordshire, by the Society.
Among other well-known zoos are those at Edinburgh, Bristol, Chester and
Dudley, and a small, private one at Chessington, Surrey.
The British Museum (Natural History) is the principal centre in the
Commonwealth for the general study of natural history; it has extensive
collections of extant and fossil animals and plants and of minerals, rocks and
meteorites. The Science Museum illustrates the development of pure and
applied science in all countries, but chiefly in Britain, which has always held
a leading place in engineering, agriculture, navigation, mining, aeronautics,
and in the development of industrial machinery and processes. The geology of
Britain is probably known in more exact detail than that of any other country
in the world, and the Geological Survey has an outstanding collection of
exhibits in its Geological Museum. These three museums are in South
Kensington, London.
Other important collections are those of the Museum of Science and
Industry, in Birmingham, and the Museum of the History of Science, at
Oxford.

DISSEMINATION

Information
Services
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The dissemination of the results of research to other research workers and
to ultimate users has become a problem of some magnitude as the volume of
information has grown. The traditional method of scientific publication, in
which results are written up into papers and published in journals, is still the
main means of communication among scientists. The leading learned societies
have for long been important agencies for communicating scientific
information.
A Libraries and Information Systems Branch has been set up in the Depart¬
ment of Education and Science to concentrate the Department’s responsi¬
bilities in relation to libraries. The new Branch includes the Office for
Scientific and Technical Information (OSTI), set up in 1965 to promote more
efficient handling and co-ordination of scientific and technical information.
The National Lending Library for Science and Technology (NLL) at
Boston Spa, Yorkshire, also within the Department, aims to collect for loan
purposes all literature which is likely to be of interest to the practising
scientist and technologist, covering all branches of science and technology
(including agriculture and medicine) and, since 1967, the periodical literature
of the social sciences. Besides collecting all available translations of Russian
scientific literature the library is responsible for arranging the translation of
some Russian periodicals, books and articles. Details are published monthl)
in the NLL Translations Bulletin. The Library acts as a centre for MEDLARS,
the Computer Board Medical Information Service, produced by the US
National Library of Medicine. (A description of general library services
which also cater for scientific needs is given on p. 220.)
Aslib, a specialised library service, undertakes research into the operation
of information services, gives assistance in setting up and running them,
provides membership services, and holds a Commonwealth Index of Transla¬
tion covering scientific subjects. _ . .
The National Reference Library of Science and Invention, administered
by the British Museum, is at present divided between two separately housed
divisions. The Holborn Division, formerly the Patent Office Library, is one
of the great scientific libraries of the world. The Bayswater Division has
substantial collections, especially in the life sciences.
An Advisory Committee for Scientific and Technical Information was set
up in October 1965 to advise the Secretary of State for Education and Science
particularly in relation to the work of OSTI and the co-ordination of this
work with other government departments and independent organisations.
The Ministry of Technology and the AEA devote considerable sums to
advisory information services. The former has nine regional offices and
sponsors over 70 industrial liaison centres, based on universities or technical
colleges, which make contacts with local industries to promote greater use
of existing scientific and technical knowledge. A Production Engineering
Advisory Service equipped with mobile demonstration units brings knowledge
of new techniques directly to the workshop floor. The grant-aided industrial
research associations circulate research reports and provide information
services to members. Besides information services provided by its various
groups, which include the Ceramics Centre and the Non-destructive Testing
Centre at Harwell, the AEA has an information centre at its London head¬
quarters, and a network of regional advisers on the use of radioisotopes.
In agriculture, the Commonwealth Agricultural Institutes and Bureaux
(see p. 206) provide abstracts and an information service in various branches
of agricultural science. The ARC publishes an Index of Agricultural Research

in Progress, and gives an account of current developments in its annual reports.
The advisory services of the agricultural departments bring research results
directly to the farmer.
Medical research results are communicated mainly through journals and
periodicals; but the MRC issues special reports and includes special articles
in its annual reports.
The National Research Development Corporation (NRDC), an independent
body for which the Minister of Technology has statutory responsibility, was
set up under the Development of Inventions Act 1948 to secure the develop¬
ment and exploitation of inventions in the public interest. The NRDC
can also assist research work where this is likely to lead to an invention.
Under the Development of Inventions Act 1967, up to £25 million could be
advanced to the Corporation from public funds without time limit. This was
increased to £50 million under the Industrial Expansion Act 1968.
Projects so far sponsored include hovercraft, computers, advanced types of
electric motor, towed flexible barges (Dracones), diesel engines, insecticides,
fuel cells and antibiotics. NRDC is increasingly funding speculative projects
on a joint venture basis with industrial firms. NRDC support for hovercraft
development has been given mainly through a wholly owned subsidiary,
Hovercraft Development Ltd., which holds and manages the hovercraft
patents. Another subsidiary, Tracked Hovercraft Ltd., was formed in 1967 to
develop an air-cushioned tracked vehicle. NRDC is a minority shareholder
in the British Hovercraft Corporation Ltd., a company formed in 1966 to
design and build hovercraft.
Most government departments concerned with science and technology make
special arrangements for dealing with international scientific relations but the
DES, through its International Scientific Relations Division, has a number
of inter-departmental responsibilities including the recruitment and scientific
support of Britain’s scientific counsellors overseas, who are seconded to the
Diplomatic Service. In areas of non-governmental collaboration, the primary
representative of the United Kingdom is the Royal Society.
The Government is concerned with inter-governmental organisations.
These include: specialised agencies of the United Nations, for example, the
United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO),
the World Health Organisation (WHO), the Food and Agriculture Organisa¬
tion (FAO); nuclear energy, for example, the International Atomic Energy
Agency (IAEA), the European Nuclear Energy Agency (ENEA) and the
European Organisation for Nuclear Research (CERN); space research, for
example, ESRO; and the International Agency for Research on Cancer
(IARC). There are agreements between the United Kingdom AEA and other
atomic energy authorities, including that of the Soviet Union (and there are
permanent representatives of the United States Atomic Energy Commission
in London and of the United Kingdom AEA in Washington). Also, there are
inter-governmental agreements with Euratom, and bilateral agreements with
other countries. Britain is also represented on the three scientific committees
of the OECD.
The Commonwealth Scientific Committee (CSC) consisting of the heads of
the national research organisations of Commonwealth countries, formed in
1958 from the previous Standing Committee set up in 1946, meets biennially.
Operating under the CSC is an executive sub-committee, membership of

which consists of officials responsible for scientific matters in the Common¬
wealth Missions in London, and representatives from British Government
departments, the research councils and the Royal Society. There are various
specialist committees. The secretariat for the Committee and its executive
sub-committee is provided by the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices.
A British Commonwealth Scientific Conference held in 1946 recommended
the continuance and extension of the scientific collaboration of the war years
by the creation of the Commonwealth Scientific Liaison Offices, a group at
present consisting of the Scientific Liaison Offices in London of Australia,
Canada and New Zealand together with the International Scientific Relations
Division of the Department of Education and Science.
The Commonwealth Agricultural Bureaux, financed by contributions from
all Commonwealth countries, comprise three Institutes and 11 Bureaux, all
of which except one Institute are in Britain and each of which is concerne
with a particular branch of agricultural science. They act as clearing houses
for the interchange of information of value to research workers m agncu tural
science throughout the Commonwealth and increasingly throughout the
world. Seventeen Abstract Journals, one Primary Journal and an Index are
published periodically and have a combined annual circulation of about 29,000
copies. The Institutes and Bureaux also issue monographs on their own
particular subjects and deal with enquiries received from research workers m
all parts of the Commonwealth.
The Ministry of Overseas Development’s (ODM) promotion of scientific
research in the interests of developing countries covers specialist advice from
Britain, advisory visits, conferences for exchange of information, training
scientists from overseas in universities and research institutions in Britain,
recruiting scientific staff from Britain, and providing support for existing
research services overseas, for example, in East Africa and the Caribbean
Some equipment is also given to encourage scientific training and applied
research. It administers and supports the work of, for example, the A
Locust Research Centre in London, internationally recognised as a world
centre for locust research since 1931. The Ministry is also responsible for the
Tropical Products Institute in London which aims at improving the economic
viability of the less-developed tropical countries, especially those within
the Commonwealth, by research into new uses for tropical plant and animal
products. The ODM provides about £3 million a year for research for
benefit of developing countries.
The principal aims of the British Council (see p. 163) in the sciences (including
agriculture, medicine and technology) are to foster co-operation between
British scientists and scientists of other countries, to promote among overseas
specialists a better understanding and knowledge of Britain and ijs scientific
achievements, and, in the developing countries, to assist in curriculum refer
at school level and in the training of teachers of science and mathematics.
Much emphasis is placed on the interchange of scientists between Britain
and other countries. Overseas tours and advisory visits by British specialists
are arranged and scientists recruited for overseas posts. In the other direction
the Council invites senior specialists to Britain for visits and discussions with
British experts, and makes awards to postgraduate students; it also admimsters
the programmes of a large number of senior specialists and students who
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
207
travel to Britain under the auspices of the UN specialised agencies, or under
various bilateral technical assistance schemes, or as private individuals. The
Council is also responsible for administering travel grants awarded under the
Foreign and Commonwealth University Interchange Schemes.
Information on Britain’s scientific achievements is provided either through
the Council’s overseas libraries or direct from the London headquarters
which includes specialist departments (and libraries) for medicine and science.
Material published or compiled by these London departments includes
British Medical Bulletin, British Medical Book List, British Medical Index,
part of Scientific Research in British Universities and Colleges (see Bibliography,
p. 478), and publications listing facilities for education and training in Britain.
THE PROMOTION OF THE ARTS
This section describes the assistance and encouragement given to the arts
by the Government, local authorities, voluntary societies and other organisa¬
tions. Although valuable support comes from private sources, including
trusts and commercial concerns, the Government and local authorities are
taking an increasingly active part. In 1964, for the first time, a minister was
appointed to take special responsibility for the arts. The Government
considers that its role is not ‘to dictate taste or restrict the liberty of even the
most unorthodox and experimental of artists’ but to support the arts so that
a high level of artistic achievement can be sustained and the best in the arts
made more widely available (A Policy for the Arts, see Bibliography, p. 478).
The main educational functions concerning the arts are carried out in
England and Wales through the Department of Education and Science, in
Scotland through the Scottish Education Department and in Northern
Ireland by the Ministry of Education. In partnership with local education
authorities and voluntary bodies, they are concerned with schools, colleges
of further education and community centres. The Department of Education
and Science is also concerned with public libraries in England and Wales
and is responsible for the Victoria and Albert Museum, and the Scottish
Education Department is responsible for the Royal Scottish Museum.
The Government aids the preservation of Britain’s cultural heritage by
means of grants which largely finance most of the national museums and
galleries; through the Ministry of Public Building and Works, which looks
after ancient monuments, and the Ministry of Housing and Local Government,
which is responsible for historic buildings; and by giving financial help to
independent bodies concerned with preservation, such as the National Trust
(see p. 174).
General help for the arts is given through government grants for music,
drama, literature, painting and sculpture; these are channelled for the greater
part through the Arts Councils of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, which
contribute to the aspects of the arts not provided for by other agencies. Other
state-aided organisations include the British Film Institute and the Council
of Industrial Design.
Estimated government expenditure on the arts in Great Britain in 1969-70
is £17-i million. Direct allocations included £8-2 million for the Arts
Council of Great Britain (.£450,000 more than in 1968-69) and about £7
million for the running costs of national museums and galleries. In addition
over £2 million was allocated for the preservation of historic buildings and
ancient monuments.
2o8 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Arts Council of Great Britain was established in 1946 under a Royal
Charter. (A new charter was granted in 1967.) Its members are appointed by
the Secretary of State for Education and Science, in consultation with the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales. Its main objects are to develop
and improve the knowledge, understanding and practice of the arts, to increase
the accessibility of the arts to the public, and to advise and co-operate with
government departments, local authorities and other organisations.
The Arts Council of Northern Ireland, which has similar aims, receives
a grant from the Northern Ireland Government. In 1969-70 this amounted
to £184,800.
The British Council (see footnote, p. 163) takes an active part in displaying
overseas the best in British drama, ballet, music and the visual arts.
Local Support Local authorities do valuable work in encouraging the arts. Under the Local
Government Act 1948 they may levy up to a sixpenny rate in England and
Wales for expenditure on entertainment in all its forms, including cultural
activities. By amending legislation (the Local Government (Scotland) Act
1966), the same rate applies to Scotland. They may also spend money on
buildings for the arts and provide and maintain museums and art galleries;
the Arts Councils are authorised to give financial help to house the arts. Many
towns support orchestras and theatres. The Greater London Council which,
as the London County Council, built the Royal Festival Hall, has agreed to
contribute equally with the Government towards the cost of the National
Theatre on the south bank of the Thames.
Private Many voluntary bodies are concerned with promoting the arts and include char-
Contributions itable trusts and foundations which give financial support. Industrial patronage
includes continuing support from the independent television companies.
The arts benefit most when the patrons—central and local government,
voluntary bodies, industry, the universities and individuals—combine. The
outstanding example is the Edinburgh Festival Society. Other arts festivals
organised on a similar basis include those held in the City of London,
Aldeburgh, Bath, Belfast, Cheltenham, Harrogate, King’s Lynn, Leeds,
Norwich and York.
Regional co-operation in arts patronage is growing with support from the
Government which encourages the formation of regional arts associations to
ensure that the whole range of the arts is more widely available to people
throughout the area. Such associations have been established in the north,
the north-west, Lincolnshire, the midlands, the south-west, Greater London,
southern England and north Wales. Plans are advanced for regional associa¬
tions covering East Anglia and Yorkshire.
DRAMA Government support for drama is given through the Arts Councils of Great
Britain and of Northern Ireland which grant subsidies to drama companies
which are registered as charities (that is, are non-profit making), provided
that such companies have given evidence of serious aims and of consistently
high standards of practical competence. The Arts Council of Great Britain
operates a scheme to promote new drama: guarantees may be offered to
managements giving the first professional production of selected new plays;
and promising authors may be awarded bursaries. Schemes are also in
operation to train stage designers, producers and those wishing to take up
theatre administration.

Professional
rheatre
The British Council makes the British theatre better known abroad by
organising and sponsoring international tours by leading British theatre
companies and individual actors and producers, and by sending overseas
drama lectures and exhibitions of theatrical design or of books dealing with
the British theatre, and by providing newly published plays through its
overseas libraries.
There are about 200 professional theatres in Britain. The centre of theatrical
activity is in London, where there are some 30 principal theatres in the
‘West End’ and several more in the suburbs, but important developments
are taking place in the regions. In London, with six exceptions (Covent
Garden, Sadler’s Wells Opera at the London Coliseum, the Old Vic, the
Royal Court, the Mermaid and the Aldwych) the theatres are let to some 25
producing managements on a commercial basis for each production.
Among London companies receiving Arts Council grants are the National
Theatre and the Royal Shakespeare Company, the English Stage Company,
which produces contemporary plays mainly at the Royal Court Theatre, and
the Mermaid.
The National Theatre Company was formed in 1963; it will eventually
play in the new National Theatre, to be built on the south bank of the Thames
in London. The capital costs of the theatre will be met by the Exchequer and
the Greater London Council; grants towards the Company’s running costs
are being made by the Arts Council and the Greater London Council.
The Company, whose repertoire consists of classical and modern plays from
all countries, is large enough for simultaneous productions to be undertaken
in London (at the Old Vic Theatre) and in the provinces or overseas.
The Royal Shakespeare Company presents Shakespearean plays at the Royal
Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon, and international classical and
modern plays at the Aldwych Theatre, London. It will eventually have a perm¬
anent London home in the proposed City of London arts centre in the Barbican.
The provincial theatres are served by productions touring either before or
after London presentation, by companies specially formed for touring, and
by local repertory companies. An important development is the growth of
the civic theatre. The term is generally taken to include some companies
which have the use of their own theatres (as in Lincoln, Liverpool, Birming¬
ham and Dundee) or rent them from a local authority (as at Bristol, Chester¬
field and Edinburgh) and those like the Belgrade Theatre, Coventry, and the
Nottingham Playhouse which were built by the city councils. These com¬
panies are assisted by the Arts Council. Many leading dramatists, producers,
designers, actors and actresses are associated with such companies and
standards are high.
A number of new theatres have been opened both in London and the
provinces in recent years, including, in London, the Mermaid Theatre and
the completely reconstructed Queen’s Theatre. Coventry’s Belgrade Theatre,
opened in 1958, was the first major theatre to be built by a civic authority
since 1939. Other new theatres include the Chichester Festival Theatre (1962),
the Nottingham Playhouse, the Phoenix Theatre, Leicester (1963), the
Yvonne Arnaud Theatre, Guildford (1965), the Northcott Theatre, Exeter,
the Octagon Theatre, Bolton (1967), the Forum Theatre, Billingham, and the
Gateway Theatre, Chester (1968). Civic theatres have been built at Croydon,
Eastbourne, Torquay and Weymouth, and smaller theatres at East Grinstead,
Middlesbrough, Richmond (Yorkshire), Whitehaven (Cumberland) and
Worcester.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In Northern Ireland the Ulster Group Theatre in Belfast specialises in
Ulster comedy; and the Belfast Arts Theatre presents some international
drama and lighter theatrical entertainment. Also in Belfast the Lyric Players
Theatre, a non-profit-making organisation, presents Irish and international
drama in a small theatre recently built with Arts Council support. Professional
theatres are eligible for grants in respect of specific productions agreed with
the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
All plays produced in Great Britain are subject to the provisions of the
Theatres Act 1968. This repealed the Theatres Act 1843 which gave the Lord
Chamberlain (the senior officer of the Royal Household) powers to censor
stage plays. There is now no censorship but the new Act makes it a criminal
offence to present or direct an obscene performance of a play in public or in
private (including in theatre clubs), an obscene performance being defined as
one which tends ‘to deprave and corrupt persons who were likely ... to attend
it’. Provision is made in the Act for a defence against a charge of obscenity on
the grounds that the performance was for the public good in the interests of,
for example, drama, opera or literature.
Most managers and artists are members of professional organisations such
as the Theatres’ Advisory Council, the London Theatre Council, the Pro¬
vincial Theatre Council, the Society of West End Managers, the Theatrical
Managers’ Association, the Council of Repertory Theatres, British Actors
Equity (the actors’ trade union) and the League of Dramatists. The trade
union of theatre staffs is the National Association of Theatrical and Kine
Employees.
There are thousands of amateur dramatic societies in Britain with an active
membership of some half a million. They are encouraged by local education
authorities, by other public bodies, and by four special organisations the
British Drama League, the Standing Conference of Drama Associations, the
Scottish Community Drama Association and the Association of Ulster Drama
Festivals. Amateur companies which stage productions in their own theatres
belong to the Little Theatre Guild of Great Britain; for instance, the People’s
Theatre in Newcastle upon Tyne and the Questor’s Theatre, Ealing.
Most universities have active amateur drama clubs and societies; an
International Festival of University Theatre, inaugurated by Bristol in 1959,
is held annually.
Training for the theatre is provided mainly in drama schools. Among the
most important are the Royal Academy of Dramatic Art (which is grant-
aided and provides a two-year course in all branches of stage work), the
Central School of Speech and Drama, the Rose Bruford Training College,
the London Academy of Music and Dramatic Art, the Webber-Douglas
School, the Guildhall School of Music and Drama and the Arts Educational
Schools, all of which are in or near London; and the Old Vic School in
Bristol. In Scotland there is the College of Dramatic Art, which is an integral
part of the Royal Scottish Academy of Music in Glasgow and is grant-aided
by the Scottish Education Department. An increasing number of universities
offer courses in drama.
The Society for Theatre Research brings together those interested in the
history and technique of the British theatre. The International Theatre
Institute has a British centre in London. The main purpose of the institute is
to foster international goodwill and understanding by interchange of students,
theatrical companies, personnel and theatrical information.
