Many schools and youth clubs put on plays and provide some education in
drama. A drama centre for the London education service is provided at
Toynbee Hall in east London; and there are youth theatres in the London
boroughs of Camden and Hillingdon. At Coventry special productions are
arranged for school children and members of the Belgrade Theatre’s staff
teach at local schools. Sheffield’s Theatre Vanguard puts on plays for and by
children and Nottingham has a Youth Theatre Workshop.
A large number of organisations such as the Unicorn Theatre for Children
and Theatre Centre present children’s plays in London and the provinces. The
National Youth Theatre, whose members are all young people, presents
mainly Shakespearean productions in London, the provinces and abroad.
Music in all its forms draws large audiences; and music festivals, orchestral
concerts, choral singing, brass bands, chamber music, opera and ballet are
important features of British cultural life. The increase in musical appreciation
in recent years is shown by the size of audiences for concerts and for broadcast
music. Nearly 99 million gramophone records (of which half were estimated to
be of serious music) were produced during 1968.
The City of Westminster houses the Central Music Library which lends to
other libraries and individuals. Another well-known music collection is the
Henry Watson Music Library at the Manchester Central Library.
The Arts Council of Great Britain makes grants to a number of orchestras,
opera and ballet companies, and music societies. The British Council gives
financial assistance to some of the overseas tours of British orchestras, soloists,
and opera and ballet companies; it sponsors recordings of works by British
composers and maintains 102 libraries of British music (scores and records)
in 67 countries overseas and, at its London headquarters, a reference library
of records, scores and books on music.
The National Music Council, representative of many aspects of British
musical activity, is affiliated to the International Music Council which is
associated with UNESCO.
Seasons of orchestral concerts are promoted every year in many of the large
towns and cities of Britain. In London the principal concert halls are the
Royal Festival Hall on the south bank of the Thames, adjacent to which are
the Queen Elizabeth Hall and the Purcell Room which were opened in 1967
for smaller-scale performances; the Royal Albert Hall, Kensington, where
the annual summer season of Promenade Concerts is given; and the Wigmore
Hall, an important recital centre.
Among the leading British orchestras are the London Philharmonic, the
London Symphony, the Royal Philharmonic, the New Philharmonia, the
Royal Liverpool Philharmonic, the Halle (Manchester), the City of Birming¬
ham Symphony, the Bournemouth Symphony, the Scottish National and the
BBC Symphony, Northern and Scottish orchestras. There are also specialised
string and chamber orchestras such as the Northern Sinfonia, the Philomusica
of London, the English Chamber Orchestra and the London Mozart Players.
Many of these receive financial aid from the Arts Council of Great Britain and
local authorities; some of them also receive assistance from commercial
television and other business organisations. In Northern Ireland the Ulster
Orchestra receives financial aid from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
The principal choral societies in Britain are the Royal Choral, the BBC
Choral, the Huddersfield Choral, the Halle Choir, the Liverpool Philharmonic
.

Choir, the London Philharmonic Choir, the New Philharmonia Chorus, the
Bach Choir, the Royal Edinburgh Choral Union and the Belfast Philharmonic
Society. These and many other choral societies are associated with famous
orchestras in major choral works; most of them, together with hundreds of
similar choral and orchestral societies and music clubs, are affiliated to the
National Federation of Music Societies, through which they are supported
with funds provided by the Arts Council. Among societies which specialise
in encouraging the performance of the work of living musicians are the
Society for the Promotion of New Music, the Music Section of the Institute
of Contemporary Arts, and Macnaghten Concerts.
Music festivals in Britain, originating with the Three Choirs Festival held
annually in Gloucester, Worcester or Hereford in rotation, have been in
existence for over 200 years. The famous Edinburgh International Festival
lasts three weeks; other festivals such as at King’s Lynn, last a week or less.
Among the better known are the Royal National Eisteddfod of Wales; the
Llangollen International Eisteddfod; the National Gaelic Mod, held at a
different place in Scotland each year; the Cheltenham Festival, largely devoted
to contemporary British music; the Aldeburgh Festival; the Bath Festival,
the Coventry Festival; the Haslemere Festival; the biennial York Festival;
and the Leeds and Norwich Festivals, which include important choral
music, and which are held triennially. An annual international festival of folk
song and dancing is held by the English Folk Dance and Song Society.
Interest in amateur music-making is encouraged by the work of County
Music Committees (some of which are voluntary and some sub-committees
of local education authorities), which are aided by the Carnegie United
Kingdom Trust and united in the Standing Conference for Amateur Music.
The Rural Music Schools Association is concerned with music-making by
amateurs in country districts; it brings together professional musicians,
teachers, administrators and amateurs.
Professional organisations which look after the interests of music and
musicians include the Musicians’ Union, the Incorporated Society of Musi¬
cians, the Composers’ Guild, and the Songwriters’ Guild.
Regular seasons of opera and ballet are given at the Royal Opera House,
Covent Garden, London, leased by the Government on behalf of the Royal
Opera House, Covent Garden, Limited, which was formed in 1944 to make
the famous opera house the home of a national opera and ballet, and which
receives a grant from the Arts Council. The Royal Opera House has its own
opera company (The Royal Opera) and two ballet companies (The Royal
Ballet). The opera company numbers about 200 and has a permanent
orchestra. The Royal Ballet has a high international reputation and has made
many overseas tours; its second company tours extensively in Great Britain.
Seasons of opera and operetta are also given by the Sadler’s Wells Company
in London; with two permanent opera companies, Sadler’s Wells plays in
London throughout the year, and for about 30 weeks in other centres.
At Glyndebourne, in Sussex, an opera season, for which an international
cast is specially assembled, is held every summer. Other opera companies
include the English Opera Group, noted for its performances of chamber
operas by Benjamin Britten and other composers; the New Opera Company,
formed by members of the Cambridge Opera Group to produce new operas
in London; the Handel Opera Society; the Intimate Opera Company, which
performs works for very small casts in any hall available; and the Welsh

National Opera Company. Scottish Opera presents annual seasons in several
Scottish towns. Opera in Northern Ireland is promoted with financial
support from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland. The Arts Council of
Great Britain presents three small operatic groups (Opera for All) which
specialise in introducing opera to audiences in small towns. There are also a
number of amateur opera societies.
Among other ballet companies are London’s Festival Ballet, the Ballet
Rambert (Britain’s oldest ballet company) and the Western Theatre Ballet
which specialises in contemporary works. The work of the Patricia Mulholland
Irish Ballet Company in Northern Ireland, which is sponsored by the Arts
Council of Northern Ireland, combines traditional music, dancing and mime.
Professional training in music is given at colleges of music, of which the Royal
Academy of Music and the Royal College of Music in London, and the Royal
Scottish Academy of Music in Glasgow are grant-aided. There are also
the Trinity College of Music and the Guildhall School of Music and Drama,
both in London, the Royal Manchester College of Music and the Birmingham
School of Music.
The London Opera Centre for Advanced Training and Development
provides some rehearsal and other facilities for the Royal Opera House,
Covent Garden. Its courses last two or three years. The leading ballet schools
are the Royal Ballet, the Rambert Ballet School and the Royal Academy of
Dancing which, with many private schools, have played an important part in
raising British ballet to its present high standard. Other schools offering
general education combined with drama and/or ballet are run by the Arts
Educational Trust and the Italia Conti School.
Young people are encouraged to take an interest in music, opera and ballet.
There are frequent concerts for children and the National Youth Orchestra of
Great Britain, the National Youth Orchestra of Wales and the London
Schools’ Symphony Orchestra are noted for their high standard of perfor¬
mance. A Youth and Music organisation, affiliated to the international
Jeunesses Musicales, encourages opera, ballet and other performances for
young people.
In schools, more children are learning to play musical instruments; and
some 128,000 candidates a year (children and other students) take the exami¬
nations of the Associated Board of the Royal Schools of Music, the largest
proportion (over 60 per cent) choosing the piano as their instrument.
The Royal Ballet sponsors a small group, Ballet for All, to give lecture-
demonstrations to the public and to schools.
Although cinema attendance has been steadily declining in Great Britain since
its peak of 1,635 million in 1946 to 237 million in 1968, and the number of
licensed cinemas has declined from 4,709 to 1,631 over the same period,
British films, actors and creative and technical talent are appreciated both at
home and abroad and frequently achieve success at international film events.
Television offers very large potential audiences for films and provides
opportunities of employment for technicians and actors.
London is one of the most important centres for the making of films for
international markets and export earnings are an important part of total
earnings. The Film Production Association of Great Britain is the trade
association to which many feature film producers belong.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The documentary tradition in short film production in Britain goes back to
1929, when a group of directors began making factual films of a distincthe
and imaginative kind on behalf of the Government, and later for commercial
organisations. The war years saw a big expansion in this field and, since then,
British documentary technicians have continued to produce high quality
factual films which have won numerous international awards. The British
Industrial and Scientific Film Association promotes the use of films in
industry, science and commerce. The Federation of Specialised Film Associa¬
tions, the trade association of documentary, short, industrial, advertising and
cartoon film makers, has about 100 members.
Films from abroad made in languages other than English often draw large
audiences in London and other large cities.
Although over half of British main feature production is supported by United
States interests at present, the Rank Organisation and Associated British
Picture Corporation maintain a substantial interest in production, distribution
and exhibition. Most British film producers are independent but make films
in association with these major interests. There are numerous companies,
many of them small, which produce short films.
There is no state-owned film production unit in Britain, but the National
Film Finance Corporation lends money for feature film production. Its
members are appointed by the Board of Trade and its funds are limited by
statute to £8 million. In recent years the Corporation was financially concerned
with about half the main feature films made in British studios, but this
proportion has now fallen in view of the American support a\ ailable.
There is also a levy on cinema admissions to provide a film production fund.
The money so raised is paid out as a percentage of a film’s takings, so that the
more successful a film is at the box-office, the more it receives from the fund.
Started by the industry in 195° on a voluntary basis, the scheme became
statutory under the Cinematograph Films Act 1957.
The Government sponsors a wide range of films to inform audiences
overseas about British life and achievements, including documentary films,
television programmes and newsreels; they are produced thiough the Central
Office of Information (COI), which commissions their production by private
companies. These, together with films acquired from private industry and
public bodies, are distributed throughout the world, in English and many
foreign languages, by British Information Services. The British Council also
distributes overseas a wide range of specialised films mainly on the arts,
education, medicine, science and technology.
Films are also sponsored by the Government, some for specialised
audiences, on such subjects as science, agriculture, health and industiy,
as well as films for the general public on, for example, road safety and health
education.
A large number of films are sponsored by industrial concerns and other
organisations, such as the British Travel Association and the British Produc¬
tivity Council. The best of these and industrial films from other countries are
available through the COFs Central Film Library and other agencies.
The Films of Scotland Committee promotes the production of Scottish
films covering the industries and cultural traditions of Scotland.
To help British films to meet the keen American competition, legislation
passed in 1927 introduced the quota system (continued by subsequent
legislation), under which a certain proportion of British films must be shown

in British cinemas each year. The proportion is fixed by the Board of Trade
annually after consultation with the Cinematograph Films Council, any
change being effected by statutory instrument approved by both Houses of
Parliament. For main feature films it has stood at 30 per cent since 1950.
The State takes no part in the censorship of films in Britain, but before it can
be shown a film must be licensed by the local licensing authority. There are
about 700 of these (usually the local authorities or, in some areas, magistrates).
In considering the suitability of films the authorities normally rely on the
judgment of an independent body, the British Board of Film Censors, to
which are submitted all films (other than newsreels) intended for public
showing.
The British Board of Film Censors was set up in 1912 on the initiative of
the cinema industry, to ensure that a proper standard was maintained in the
films offered to the public. The Board, which does not use any written code
of censorship, may require cuts to be made before granting a certificate to a
film; very rarely, it refuses a certificate. Films passed by the Board are placed
in one of three categories: ‘U’ (suitable for universal showing); ‘A’ (more
suitable for adults than children who are admitted only if accompanied by an
adult); and ‘X’ (suitable only for adults; children are not admitted).
Film reviews appear regularly in the press and on sound and television
programmes and many organisations are interested in different aspects of the
film. There are numerous private film societies.
The development of the film as an art is promoted by the British Film
Institute, founded in 1933, which is financed partly by an Exchequer grant.
The Institute encourages the making and showing of good films. It also
administers the National Film Theatre in London and the National Film
Archive, runs an annual summer school, and maintains a film library from
which films may be hired, a library of books on the film and an information
service. It makes grants to the Federation of Film Societies, the British
Universities Film Council and the Society for Education in Film and
Television.
The National Film Archive contains over 17,000 films, including newsreels
and other miscellaneous items, besides scripts, art designs, posters and about
650,000 photographic stills, selected to illustrate the history and the art of the
film and as significant social and historical records.
The National Film Theatre, on the south bank of the Thames, in London,
shows films of outstanding historical, artistic or technical interest; it holds
a unique position as a cinema offering regular programmes unrestricted by
commercial considerations or by the age or nationality of the films shown.
The British Film Institute promotes the development of regional film theatres
on the lines of the National Film Theatre and is empowered to make grants
towards their recurrent and capital costs. Grants towards similar projects in
Northern Ireland are made by the Arts Council of Northern Ireland.
T he Society of Film and Television Arts, formed in 1958 by the amalgamation
of the British Film Academy and the Guild of Television Producers and
Directors, has as its aim to improve the standard of film and television
production and to stimulate public appreciation of the arts.
The National Film Theatre organises an annual London Film Festival, which
includes films receiving their first showing as well as films which have been
successful in international competitive festivals. A council on which leading

British film organisations are represented organises a film festival as part of

The Cinematograph Act 1952 (which came into force in January 1956)
provided for the making of regulations by the Home Secretary to protect the
health and welfare of children attending film shows. Cinemas which give
children’s shows require a special licence from the licensing authority, which
may impose conditions. There are about 75® children s cinema clubs which
provide special programmes on Saturday mornings. An important contribu¬
tion to these programmes is made by the Children’s Film Foundation, which
produces and distributes entertainment films specially designed for children
and publishes at intervals a list of films particularly suitable for children and
for exhibition at children’s matinees. The Foundation is a non-profit-making
body set up by the British film industry in 195^ under the Cinematograph
Films Act 1957, it receives grants from the British Film Fund Agency.
A number of modern British painters and sculptors have a high international
reputation, winning 72 international prizes since 1949 and commissions for
major works in foreign cities. The growth of interest in the visual arts at
home has been stimulated by an increasingly lively attitude towards display
on the part of museums and galleries, and by the varied activities of many
institutions, societies, private galleries and the growing number of local art
centres. t .
Painting and sculpture receive state support by grants to national institu¬
tions and, indirectly, through purchase grants made to local art galleries and
museums, to local education authorities for art schools and other means of
promoting education in art, and to the Arts Council which takes an active
part by organising exhibitions and building up its own collections of
contemporary British art. The Government is advised on grants and matters
of museums policy by the Standing Commission on Museums and Galleries
and the Royal Fine Art Commissions for England and Wales and for Scotland.
Knowledge of Britain’s fine arts is fostered overseas by the British Council’s
exhibitions and lectures. In 1968-69 fine art exhibitions organised by the
Council were shown in 65 countries and the Council was also responsible for
British participation in eight international exhibitions.
Over 900 museums and art galleries are open to the public in Britain.
There are 20 national museums and art galleries. Those in London probably
contain between them the most comprehensive collection of objects of artistic,
archaeological, scientific, historical and general interest ever to exist within
one city. They are the British Museum, the Victoria and Albert Museum,
the National Gallery, the Tate Gallery, the National Portrait Gallery, the
Imperial War Museum, the National Maritime Museum, the London Museum
(to be amalgamated with the Guildhall Museum into the Museum of London),
the Wallace Collection, the British Museum (Natural History), the Geological
Museum and the Science Museum (see p. 203).
There are six national museums and art galleries in Edinburgh: the National
Museum of Antiquities of Scotland, the National Gallery of Scotland, the
Royal Scottish Museum, the National Portrait Gallery of Scotland, the
Scottish United Services Museum, and the Scottish National Gallery of
Modern Art. The National Museum of Wales, in Cardiff, has a branch at
Other Collections

St. Fagan’s Castle where the Welsh Folk Museum is housed; and in Northern
Ireland there is the national Ulster Museum in Belfast.
Other important collections in London include the Armouries (Tower of
London), the Public Record Office (see p. 221) and the Sir John Soane’s
Museum. In Buckingham Palace there is a small gallery for exhibition of
pictures from the extensive royal collections. Most cities and large towns and
many other towns have a museum devoted to art, archaeology and natural
history, usually owned by the municipal authority but sometimes by a local
learned society or privately by individuals or trustees. Both Oxford and
Cambridge are rich in museums, many of them, as in other towns, associated
with the universities—for example, the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford,
founded in 1683, the oldest in the country, and the Fitzwilliam Museum in
Cambridge. There are important museums and art galleries in Birmingham,
Bristol, Glasgow, Leeds, Leicester, Liverpool, Manchester, Norwich, Read-
ing, Southampton and York. In Northern Ireland there are notable museums
and galleries in or near Belfast (the Ulster Folk Museum and the Northern
Ireland Arts Council Gallery), in Armagh City and in Londonderry.
In recent years there has been a notable development of *period-house
museums’, for which outstanding private houses have been taken over by
national and municipal authorities, and of folk museums. Many private art
collections housed in historic family mansions, including those in the owner¬
ship of the National Trust (see p. 174), are open to the public.
In the past decade several new or extensively altered museum buildings
have been opened, including those at Coventry, Derby, Doncaster, Durham
(the Gulbenkian Museum at the university), Leicester (Jewry Wall Archaeo¬
logical Museum), Liverpool, Manchester (Whitworth Art Gallery), Scun¬
thorpe and Sunderland. Developments are planned for museums in Belfast,
Bristol, Cardiff, Hull, London and Newcastle. County councils are playing a
greater part in the provision of museums and museum services; there are
schemes in Oxfordshire (jointly with Oxford City Council), County Durham,
Staffordshire, Pembrokeshire, Rutland, Worcestershire and Hampshire. New
projects are also being initiated by local associations for the arts.
A function of the Standing Commission on Museums and Galleries is to
advise the Government on the relationship between national and provincial
institutions. Close relations are fostered by the eight area museum councils
which cover the whole of Great Britain. They are grant-aided by the
Government and help to improve technical facilities.
The Museums Association, to which museums and art galleries and their
staffs throughout the country belong and which also has many overseas
members, is an independent organisation. The Association serves as a central
body for the collection of information and the discussion of matters relating
to museum administration, and as a training and examining body for
professional qualifications.
Temporary exhibitions organised and sent on tour by the Arts Councils, the
Circulation Department of the Victoria and Albert Museum, the Science
Museum and the Art Exhibitions Bureau are a regular feature of many
museums. The Tate Gallery, the Victoria and Albert Museum and the Royal
Academy show loan exhibitions; the Whitechapel Art Gallery, the Camden
Arts Centre and the Institute of Contemporary Arts (at their new premises in
The Mall) also show temporary exhibitions. The Greater London Council
exhibits modern sculpture in one of its parks on the south bank of the Thames
periodically and in the summer of 1968 opened a new exhibition gallery, the

Hayward Gallery, administered by the Arts Council, where major exhibitions
are shown. Commercial exhibitions of works by old masters and living artists
are held throughout the year in the galleries of the art dealers of London
(largely in the Bond Street area).
The various national art exhibiting societies include the Royal Academy;
the Royal Scottish Academy; the Society of Scottish Artists, the Royal
Society of British Artists; the Royal Society of Painters in Water Colours; the
Royal Society of Portrait Painters; the Artists’ International Association; the
Women’s International Art Club; and the London Group (all associations
of professional painters). Some of these societies, notably the Royal Academy
at Burlington House, have their own galleries in London. In Northern Ireland
there are the Royal Ulster Academy of Arts, the Ulster Society of Women
Artists and the Ulster Arts Club. Among regional societies are the Newlyn
Society of Artists, the Midland Group of Artists (Nottingham), the Birming¬
ham Society of Artists and the Penwith Society of Arts, while an increasing
number of amateur art societies throughout Britain hold local exhibitions and
encourage local interest in the fine arts. There are also exhibitions of children’s
art, including the National Exhibition of Children’s Art sponsored annually
by the Sunday Mirror.
All national collections are financed from government funds, both those that
are the direct responsibility of the Department of Education and Science (the
Victoria and Albert and the Science Museums) and of the Scottish Education
Department (the Royal Scottish Museum) and those run by trustee bodies.
Besides meeting the administrative costs, provision is made for annual
purchase grants which totalled £987,35° ^ 1969-7°- The Government also
provides special ad hoc purchase grants and collections may receive works of
art acquired by the Treasury in lieu of estate duty. The buildings are main¬
tained by the Ministry of Public Building and Works. Local museums and art
galleries, which are maintained from rates or endowments, can be helped in
building up their collections through the annual government grant (£102,000
in 1969-70) administered by the Victoria and Albert and Royal Scottish
Museums. Financial help and pictures are also given to museums and galleries
by certain trusts and voluntary bodies, particularly the National Art-
Collections Fund and the Contemporary Art Society.
The Council of Industrial Design (CoID), set up in 1944 by the Government
to promote higher standards of design in British industry, is concerned with
all aspects of industrial design from durable consumer goods to capital goods.
The CoID, with its Scottish Committee, is a grant-aided body sponsored by ^
the Board of Trade; its members include industrialists, retail management,
architects, designers and educationists. At the Design Centre in the Hay-
market, London, a selective but changing display of modern British consumer 1
goods is maintained; exhibits are chosen from Design Index, the CoID’s
illustrated record of more than 10,000 well-designed products. Special
exhibitions on particular themes are also arranged regularly. An annual awards
scheme, Council of Industrial Design Awards, covering capital goods and
engineering equipment as well as consumer products, was introduced in 1967.
The Duke of Edinburgh also presents his annual Prize for Elegant Design.
The Scottish Committee runs the Scottish Design Centre in Glasgow, and
there are three independent regional design centres, each maintaining a
duplicate of the Index, at Liverpool, Manchester and Nottingham. I he CoID
organises temporary exhibitions in regional centres and overseas; arranges [
regular conferences and training courses; and undertakes industrial study
Art Education
Architecture
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 2ig
tours in Britain. It publishes a monthly magazine, Design, and maintains
extensive reference and photographic libraries.
Other bodies concerned with industrial design include the Royal Society of
Arts (see p. 193), the Society of Industrial Artists and Designers, which is the
representative professional body in Great Britain of designers engaged in
industry and commerce, and the Design and Industries Association (DIA), a
voluntary association of industrial companies, designers, and others interested
in the promotion of good design in industry. The Crafts Council of Great
Britain, the Crafts Centre of Great Britain and the Scottish Craft Centre are
all grant-aided by the Board of Trade. Their aims are to improve craft design
and to promote closer relations between craftsmen and industry.
Formal art education is given in publicly supported art colleges, university
art schools, the Royal Academy Schools and a few private art schools. There
are the colleges, art schools and classes administered by the local education
authorities; and at a senior level there is the Royal College of Art, London,
whose students have usually completed a course at a local education authority
college, and which awards its own degrees. Art is also taught at an advanced
level at the four Scottish Central (Art) Institutions administered by the
Scottish Education Department. University art schools include the Slade
School of Fine Art and Goldsmiths’ College (London), the Ruskin Drawing
School (Oxford), the Reading School of Art, the Department of Fine Art of
the University of Newcastle upon Tyne, and the School of Art of University
College, Aberystwyth.
The leading academic institutions for the teaching and study of the history
of art are the Courtauld Institute of the University of London, the Depart¬
ment of Classical Art and Archaeology in University College, London, and
the Warburg Institute, also a part of London University.
In England and Wales three-year full-time courses leading to a Diploma in
Art and Design are available to students who have successfully completed a
foundation course. The Diploma is broadly comparable to a university pass
degree, and is administered by the National Council for Diplomas in Art and
Design (an independent self-governing body set up by the then Minister of
Education in 1961). The Council also administers a scheme of post-diploma
studies in a small number of colleges. In Scotland each of the four schools of
art awards a diploma which is roughly equivalent to the pass degree of a
university.
Art has a place in the curriculum of every type of school, and the Society
for Education through Art, among other activities, encourages the purchase
by schools of original works of art by organising an annual Pictures for Schools
exhibition. Pictures may also be borrowed from an increasing number of
public libraries (see p. 222).
Official responsibility towards the nation’s architecture is concerned with
encouraging the best in new building and preserving the best that has been
inherited from the past.
Several government departments are concerned with architecture and help
to promote good design. The Ministry of Housing and Local Government,
the Scottish Development Department, and the Northern Ireland Ministry of
Development are responsible for approving the layout and design of local
authority housing schemes, and set standards for local authority housing. The
Ministry of Housing and Local Government is responsible for the work of
the National Building Agency (see p. 298) which carries out development and

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
research concerning new building techniques. The Ministry of Public Building
and Works is also responsible for the design, building and maintenance
work of all government departments; it also has a research and development
group which co-ordinates similar groups throughout the government service.
The Architects and Building Branches at the Department of Education
and Science and the Scottish Education Department carry out research for
school building programmes. The Department of Health and Social Security
is implementing a very large building programme and the Regional Hospital
Boards, through their architectural departments, are responsible for the
design and construction of a large number of hospitals and ancillary buildings.
Government departments are assisted in an advisory capacity by the Royal
Fine Art Commissions for England and Wales and for Scotland, which also
advise planning authorities and other public bodies on questions of public
amenity or artistic importance, including new building developments.
A number of professional, advisory and other societies and institutions
exist to further the interests of architecture, and the Civic Trust (see p. 174)
seeks to promote high standards in architecture and civic planning and to
encourage a wider interest in the appearance of towns and the countryside.
The Minister of Public Building and Works and the Secretaries of State
for Scotland and Wales have responsibilities for the preservation of ancient
monuments and certain historic buildings and the Minister of Housing and
Local Government (together with the Secretaries of State) is responsible for
administering the grants available for the repair and maintenance of buildings
of outstanding historic or architectural interest; in Northern Ireland these
responsibilities are vested in the Ministry of Finance.
In Britain it is illegal for a person to practise under the title of ‘architect’
unless registered with the Architects’ Registration Council of the United
Kingdom. Most students train at a full-time school of architecture; there are
28 schools recognised for exemption from the Intermediate and Final
examinations of the Royal Institute of British Architects (RIBA) and five
recognised for the intermediate examination only. In addition to these schools,
which may also have part-time courses, there are six schools of art and
technical colleges which have full-time courses leading to the external
examinations of the RIBA.
The Royal Institute of British Architects, the leading professional
architectural institution in Britain, has a membership of nearly 23,000 with
some 6,000 students. Allied to it are 51 architectural societies covering the
whole of the United Kingdom and countries overseas. The RIBA has one of
the largest and most important architectural libraries in the world. It is
concerned with a wide range of activities covering professional practice,
science, technology, statistics, architectural competitions, professional and
public relations; arranges lectures and discussions on a variety of subjects,
presents exhibitions; and, through its Board of Education, controls the
training and examination of architects. The Royal Gold Medal for Archi¬
tecture is awarded annually by the Queen on the recommendation of the
RIBA. Among other associations are the Incorporated Association of Archi¬
tects and Surveyors, the Institute of Registered Architects and the Faculty of
Architects and Surveyors. Societies include the Architectural Association,
the Architecture Club, and several which cover particular aspects of archi¬
tecture, such as the Modular Society.
The study of literature is included in the curricula of all schools, colleges
and universities. There are free public libraries throughout the country,
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS
221
private libraries and a large number of private literary societies. Book reviews
are featured in the press and on radio and television and there are numerous
periodicals concerned in whole or in part with literature.
Government help is given through the Arts Council of Great Britain
which supports literature in a number of ways, including grants for writers,
a fund to aid literary projects, and subsidies to festivals of literature and poetry.
Similar provision is made, through the Arts Council of Northern Ireland, for
bursaries, poetry readings, and aid for publications.
Recognition of outstanding literary merit is given in the form of literary
prizes, a number of which are awarded annually, for instance, the Queen’s
Gold Medal for Poetry, the James Tait Black Memorial prizes for biography
and literature, the John Llewellyn Rhys Memorial prize for young writers of
promise, the Hawthornden prize for imaginative writing, the Winston
Spencer Churchill Literary Award for an outstanding work in the history
of the English-speaking peoples, the Library Association Carnegie Medal
for an outstanding book for children, the Kate Greenaway Medal for the best
children’s book illustration and the Somerset Maugham award for young
writers.
Libraries The British Museum Library in London (over 7 million volumes) is the largest
in Britain. The National Library of Scotland (over 2 million volumes) is in
Edinburgh, and that of Wales in Aberystwyth (nearly 2 million volumes).
Together with the Bodleian Library of Oxford University (over 3 J million
volumes) and the Cambridge University Library (4 million volumes) these
comprise the ‘copyright’ libraries of the country and are entitled to receive
a copy of each new book published in Britain: the British Museum Library
must receive a copy, the other libraries may claim one.
In addition to the British Museum Library the principal national library
institutions in England are the National Central Library (see p. 223), the
National Lending Library for Science and Technology (see p. 204), the
British National Bibliography, the Science Museum Library and the National
Reference Library of Science and Invention. The establishment of a National
Libraries Authority to co-ordinate their services and operations (except
for the Science Museum Library) was recommended in 1969 by the Dainton
Committee, which had been appointed to ensure their development in the most
effective way (see Bibliography, p. 478).
The Victoria and Albert and the British Museum (Natural History) in
South Kensington also have large libraries and many government departments
have old-established libraries of considerable size and importance, for example,
those of the Board of Trade, Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food
and the Ministry of Defence. The Public Record Office contains the records
of the superior courts of law and of most government departments, as well
as such famous historical documents as Domesday Book. The National
Register of Archives (maintained by the Historical Manuscripts Commission)
contains particulars of local and private records.
Besides the few great private collections, such as those of the John Rylands
Library, Manchester, the Signet Library, Edinburgh, and the London
Library, there are the rich resources of the learned societies and institutions
(for scientific societies and institutions, see p. 192). Examples are the libraries
of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, the Royal Commonwealth
Society, the Commonwealth Institute, the Royal Geographical Society, the
Royal Institute of British Architects (see p. 220), the Royal College of
Physicians, the British Drama League (see p. 210), the Royal College of

Music, Royal Academy of Music, the Central Music Library (administered
by Westminster City Council), the National Library for the Blind and the
National Book League.
The great expansion in education in recent years has increased the strain on
library resources at all levels of education. The ancient university libraries of
Oxford and Cambridge are not matched by any of the more recent founda¬
tions, although the combined library resources of the colleges and institutions
of the University of London total over 4 million volumes and the university
libraries of Edinburgh, St. Andrews, Glasgow, Birmingham, Liverpool,
Manchester and Leeds each have over half a million volumes. However,
many universities have succeeded in building up large and important research
collections in special subjects; for example, the Barnes Medical Library at
Birmingham and the Brotherton Library of English Literature at Leeds. The
new universities, including the new technological universities, are also rapidly
building collections.
The importance of good libraries is recognised at all levels of the education
system. School libraries, most of which are maintained by local education
authorities, often receive co-operation from the public library service,
including loans of books. School children are regularly introduced to the
public library system, which they can use in addition to the school library.
Britain is served by a complete network of public libraries, administered by
485 public library authorities (county councils, county borough councils,
London borough councils, municipal borough councils and urban district
councils). The authorities in Great Britain, which provide more than 11,500
service points, have a total stock of over 100 million books. (These figures
do not include the libraries in the publicly maintained schools.) Nearly
one-third of the total population are members of public libraries.
Under the Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964 the Secretary of State
for Education and Science is charged with the supervision of the public
library service in England and Wales, acting on the advice of the two Library
Advisory Councils, one for England, the other for Wales. Under the Act,
public library authorities are designated and have a duty to provide an
efficient and free lending and reference library service for books and periodi¬
cals. Outlying areas may be served by mobile libraries, of which 530 are in
service, and facilities exist for people who are unable to visit a library.
In addition to lending books, about a quarter of the library authorities now
lend gramophone records of various kinds and a growing number are adding
loan collections to works of art, either originals or reproductions. Nearly all
library authorities provide children’s departments and reference sections and
art, music, commercial and technical departments meet the growing and more
specific demands in these fields.
Most library authorities possess a significant collection of books and
documents on the history of their localities. Qualified and specialist staff are
available for consultation in all but the smallest service points.
The public library is often a local cultural centre. Film shows, lectures,
adult education classes, book-week exhibitions, drama groups, gramophone
recitals and children’s story hours are among the many activities. An increasing
number of libraries provide special facilities for these extension activities.
The Public Libraries and Museums Act 1964 gave statutory recognition to
the voluntary system of library co-operation in England and Wales which
had grown up since the first quarter of this century. The ten regional library
bureaux in England and Wales (consisting mainly of public libraries in each
Library
Associations
Books
PROMOTION OF THE SCIENCES AND THE ARTS 223
area) aim to be largely self-sufficient in the interlending of current British
books by means of a national system of subject specialisation. They organise
co-operation through their own member libraries and through the National
Central Library, which is responsible for interlending at national and inter¬
national level and has a bookstock of its own of nearly 450,000 volumes built
up by purchase, gift and the operation of the British National Book Centre
exchange scheme with foreign libraries. The combined resources of libraries
available to the National Central Library, which includes university, industrial
and other non-public libraries, amount to over 100 million books and many
thousand sets of periodicals.
There is a growing number of schemes for the exchange of specialist books
and periodicals as well as information. These are organised by associations of
industrial and commercial libraries which combine their resources, normally
through the local public or technical college library.
The Scottish Central Library carries out functions similar to those of the
regional bureaux and the National Central Library. Both Central Libraries
are financed in part by Exchequer grants. In Northern Ireland access to the
stocks of all co-operating libraries is available on application to the Belfast
public libraries, Queen’s University Library and the county libraries.
The principal professional organisation is the Library Association, which was
granted a Royal Charter in 1898 to unite all people engaged or interested in
library work; to promote the better administration of libraries and, inter alia,
to hold examinations in librarianship and to issue certificates of efficiency.
The Association in 1969 had a membership of over 16,500 of whom nearly
1,500 were from overseas countries. It maintains a Register of Chartered
Librarians, publishes books and pamphlets, a Yearbook and an official journal,
The Library Association Record. The Association and its branches, groups and
sections hold regular conferences. There are also associations of libraries of
which Aslib (the Association of Special Libraries and Information Bureaux,
see p. 204) and the Standing Conference of National and University Libraries
(SCONUL) are of major importance.
New books constitute the large majority of all books published in Britain. In
1968 British publishers issued 31,420 separate titles, of which 22,642 were
new books and the rest reprints or new editions. In recent years there has been
a great increase in the number of paperbacked books of all kinds.
The above figures include only a small selection of government publications
by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office, which is the largest publishing organisa¬
tion in Britain. The great majority of books, however, are produced by about
300 of the principal commercial publishers. These include the university
presses, notably the Oxford University Press (including the Clarendon Press)
and the Cambridge University Press.
Using the copies deposited under copyright law in the British Museum, the
British National Bibliography is published weekly, with three, six, nine and
twelve monthly cumulations, listing in a classified order, with indexes, all new
books and new editions, excluding reprints, of books published in Britain.
Leading organisations representing the interests of those concerned with
book production and distribution are the Publishers’ Association and the
Booksellers’ Association; the Book Development Council promotes British
books overseas. The Society of Authors is a professional association of writers.
The National Book League has a membership covering all who are interested
in books: authors, publishers, booksellers, librarians and readers. It
encourages an interest in books and arranges exhibitions in Britain and overseas.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Knowledge of British books and periodicals overseas is greatly assisted
by the British Council through the lending and reference libraries (over 180)
which it runs or supplies, and through the many touring book and periodicals
exhibitions. (For sales and exports of books in 1968, see p. 279.)
Societies for the promotion of literature include the English Association and
the Royal Society of Literature. The British Academy for the Promotion of
Historical, Philosophical and Philological Studies, generally known as the
British Academy, is the leading society of humanistic studies and receives a
grant from the Treasury.
A number of societies sponsor poetry readings and recitals; the Poetry
Society, the Apollo Society and the Barrow Poets are among the best known.
Poetry also plays an important part in various annual festivals, including the
National Eisteddfod—the bardic festival held in Wales—the Stratford-upon-
Avon Festival of Poetry, the Cheltenham Festival of Literature, and the
biennial poetry festival organised by the Poetry Book Society in London.
Among the specialist societies are the Early English Text Society, the
Bibliographical Society, the Harleian Society, the Saltire Society, and several
societies devoted to particular authors, of which the largest is the Dickens
Fellowship. There are a number of clubs and societies, such as the Book
Society and the Poetry Book Society, which exist to distribute selected new
books to their members.
lO THE NATIONAL
ECONOMY
BACKGROUND
Britain ranks about 75th s^ze arnong the countries of the world, with
about 0-18 per cent of the world’s land area. In population, approaching
2 per cent of the world’s inhabitants, it ranks tenth. In density of population
it is fourth: of the major countries, only Japan, Belgium and the Netherlands
are more crowded; and there are nine times as many people to the square
mile in the United Kingdom as in the United States. In terms of national
income per head it ranks appreciably below the United States and also below
Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Sweden and Switzerland, and slightly
below France and the Federal Republic of Germany. In world trade, it
ranks third, accounting for nearly one-tenth of the total. It takes about a fifth
of the world’s exports of primary products, and provides about one-eighth of
the world’s exports of manufactured goods.
Britain, from its own soil, provides only about half of the food it needs,
and apart from coal, low-grade iron ore and natural gas—it has few natural
resources; thus it is the world’s largest importer of such products as wheat,
meat, butter, fodder grains, citrus fruits, tea, tobacco, wool, and hard timber.
In return, it is one of the world’s largest exporters of aircraft, motor vehicles,
electrical equipment, chemicals, textiles and most types of machinery. No
other major country has such a small proportion of the working population
engaged in agriculture (about 3 per cent).
The United Kingdom is also the central banker of the sterling area, an
area with a quarter of the world’s population. Many countries outside the
sterling area use sterling in their international transactions, and it is the
currency in which about one-third of the world’s trade is conducted.
^ Earlier During the nineteenth century Britain secured a leading position as world
Development manufacturer, merchant, carrier, banker, and investor and so was able
ot the Economy to support a rapidly increasing population at a rising standard of living.
During the period from 1870 to 1890 British industrial expansion had a
clear lead over that of other countries. Between 1890 and 1914 growing
industrial competition from Europe and North America began to make
itself felt, but its effects on Britain’s staple export industries, particularly
cotton textiles and coal, were offset by the general rise in world trade, by
the continued demand for British textiles from India and other eastern
countries, and by the continued high level of overseas investment.
During the 1920s and 1930s, Britain’s older industries met increasing
competition, for example, coal and iron and steel from other European
countries and textiles from some eastern countries where labour was cheaper.
At the same time Britain failed at first to gain a compensating share of world
trade in the newer types of engineering products. Some countries sought
deliberately to protect nascent and even established industries by tariffs and
(later) quotas and exchange restrictions. The result was heavy unemployment
in Britain’s older industries, the rate of which averaged 14 per cent in the
years 1921-39, reaching a peak of 22 per cent in 1932, when the slump in
L
226
Effects of
the Second
World War
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
world trade was at its worst. In some districts relying mainly on the most
heavily affected industries, the rate was much higher. Income from invisible
earnings (for example, on overseas investments, shipping and insurance)
and relatively cheap imports, particularly food, however, cushioned the
effects of the fall in the volume in exports.
After 1932 levels of production and employment improved, stimulated by
an increase in home investment which was aided by the policy of cheap money,
by some revival in world trade and, after 1935, by the armament programme.
The decade saw a strong expansion in the vehicles, electrical, chemicals and
aircraft industries, while the construction of 3 million houses brought about
a large growth in the building and ancillary industries. By 1937 average real
income per head was about 14 per cent higher than in 1929.
The second world war is estimated to have run down British domestic
capital by about £3,000 million, through shipping losses, bomb damage, and
arrears of industrial maintenance and replacements. Some £1,000 million
worth of overseas investments were sold, nearly half in North America, and
new external debts of £3,000 million were accumulated. By 1944 exports had
fallen to less than one-third of their 1938 volume as a result of the war effort.
The Post-war Economic conditions in the immediate post-war period led to many of the
Period war-time restrictions remaining in force. Holdings of gold and foreign
exchange had been greatly depleted to pay for the essential war-time supplies
from overseas, and the export trade had to be rebuilt. Thus, rationing and
other war-time controls could only be relaxed gradually with the expansion
of production and the progress of recovery, this process being largely
completed by about mid-1954. The abolition of quantitative restrictions on
imports, other than from the dollar area, was largely completed by 1955.
Exchange controls on transactions between the sterling area and the rest of
the world were also progressively lifted, and in 1958 convertibility of sterling
on current account for all non-residents was introduced.
The period since 1945 has been one of rising living standards and of
high levels of industrial production and employment. This has been
accompanied, however, by persistent economic problems, especially inflation
and a tendency for the growth of imports to outstrip the expansion in exports
and foreign exchange earnings generally, particularly in periods of rapid
economic growth. This has meant that the average current surplus on visible
and invisible trade together has not been sufficient to finance Britain s over¬
seas expenditure and private investment and uphold its position as banker to
the overseas sterling area. Successive governments have sought to deal with
recurring balance of payments deficits mainly through deflationary policies in
the hope that the resulting margin of spare capacity would lead to an increase
in exports and a fall in imports. Domestic demand was curtailed mainly
through increases in taxation and restrictions on credit while a high bank
rate was needed to maintain overseas confidence in sterling. However, these
policies tended to result in undesirable fluctuations in economic activity and
made it impossible to realise the full growth potential of the economy.
Devaluation A further serious deterioration in the balance of payments in 1967 and loss
of Sterling of overseas confidence in sterling was brought about largely by a decline in
exports as a result of slackening economic activity in certain major overseas
markets, by the increased costs of imports, particularly oil, on account of the
Middle East hostilities in June 1967 and by a series of dock strikes in the
autumn. To meet the situation the Government decided to undertake a

devaluation of sterling from $2.80 to $2.40 = j^i. The primary aim is to secure
a substantial balance of payments surplus by improving the competitive
position of British exports and by giving industry an incentive to find home
substitutes for the relatively more expensive imports. A number of fiscal
and monetary measures were taken at the time of and following the devaluation
to restrain the growth of consumer demand and to reallocate resources in
favour of exports. A far-reaching review of public expenditure was also under¬
taken (see p. 234).
During 1969 the Government has continued its economic policies in
support of devaluation so as to put the balance of payments on a secure and
healthy basis, but the needed shifts in the use of resources have proved
somewhat slower to achieve than expected.
THE FRAMEWORK OF THE ECONOMY
The following sections sketch briefly the salient features of Britain’s national
economy in recent years. The source of Tables 11 to 14 is Preliminary
Estimates of National Income and Balance of Payments 1963 to 1968 (Cmnd.
3983), and Economic Trends, April 1969.
In 1968 Britain’s gross national product at factor cost (the measure of the
value of total goods and services produced at home and net income from
abroad) is estimated to have totalled £36,358 million. In real terms, that is,
after allowing for price changes, the increase over the ten-year period to
1968 has amounted to just under one-third.
The working population had been rising slowly up to 1966, but has since
fallen slightly. Over the ten years to the middle of 1968, there was an increase
of nearly 1 million (or some 4^ per cent) to about 25 J million, of whom two-
thirds are males. The expansion of the national income over the same period
has, therefore, been mainly the result of higher productivity. Unemployment
has remained very low, on average less than 2 per cent of the employee
population being out of work, but has been somewhat higher since 1966.
It has tended to remain above the national average in Northern Ireland,
Scotland, Wales and the north and certain other parts of England (where
special measures are encouraging additional employment), but in London,
the south-east and the Midlands, where the number of unfilled vacancies
is large in relation to the registered unemployed, there has been strong com¬
petition among employers for labour. While some industries, notably coal¬
mining, the railways, cotton textiles and agriculture, have undergone a
marked reduction in their labour force—of the order of 500,000 in the last
five years to June 1968—the needs of the expanding sectors of the economy
have not always been fully met.

since 1958 at 1963 prices, divided between personal consumption, public

Manufacturing industry contributes about one-third of the total output
of goods and services, and together with mining and quarrying, construction
and public utilities (gas, electricity and water) makes up just under half of
the total; agriculture, forestry and fisheries account for just over 3 per cent;
and transport and communications, together with the distributive trades, for
20 per cent. The remainder, just over one-quarter of total output, includes
public administration, education, health and finance and other services. Over
the past ten years there has been a marked decline in the proportion con¬
tributed by agriculture (though agricultural output is still rising).
It will be seen from the diagram above that the share attributable to fixed
capital formation rose appreciably between 1958 and 1968, in part reflecting
the rapid growth of public investment, while public authorities consumption
which declined between 1953 and 1959 as a result of reductions in defence
expenditure—has also risen over the five years to 1968 although much less
rapidly. Over the whole period 1958 to 1968 there has been an expansion of
the gross national product in real terms of 35 per cent. This rate of increase
has been exceeded in the case of capital formation (80 per cent) and exports
(46 per cent), while consumer expenditure (32 per cent) and public authorities’
current expenditure (28 per cent) have grown more slowly.
Gross fixed investment has risen markedly during and since the 1950s. In
1951 fixed investment in the United Kingdom was about 15 per cent of the
gross national product; it has been maintained at a high level in recent years,
reaching over 20 per cent in 1968. Fixed investment in manufacturing, which
accounts for 20 per cent of all fixed investment, in 1968 amounted to £1,526
million at current prices; compared with 1967 it showed a rise of 4 per cent,
although it was practically constant in real terms. Investment has, however,
been especially high in the public sector on account of the investment pro¬
grammes of the transport, communications, electricity transmission and
generation, and gas industries, although in 1968 investment in gas, electricity
and water fell by 18 per cent at constant prices. Investment in housing has
also expanded substantially; in 1968 it was well over two-thirds higher at
current prices than in 1963. In some years, such as 1951, i960 and 1964,

An assessment of the value of the stock of fixed capital in the United
Kingdom at the end of 1967, made by the Central Statistical Office, gives a
total of £113,000 million at 1958 replacement cost. This is about 36 per cent
higher than in 1958, on the same basis of calculation. About 30 per cent of
the total was attributable to dwellings and 22 per cent to assets in manufac¬
turing (excluding textiles) and construction.
The growth of investment has been accompanied by a substantial growth
in savings by the economy as a whole, amounting to £7,556 million in 1968
(after allowing for stock appreciation) compared with £3,947 million in 1958.
Personal saving after showing a marked increase up to 1966, declined in
the two following years, amounting in 1968 to £1,882 million, about £200
million below the 1966 level. As a proportion of personal disposable income
it stood at 6-9 per cent in 1968. Personal saving takes a variety of forms.
There has been increased investment by the personal sector in new dwellings
and fixed assets, largely through building societies, although life assurance
premiums and contributions to superannuation funds are the largest forms of
personal saving; they have grown almost without interruption for many years.
National savings have failed to maintain the strong rate of growth in evidence
up to 1964; they rose by only £80 million in 1968 to a total of £8,543 million.
The largest contribution to savings comes from companies. Up to 1959,
these provided about half the total, but the proportion has since fallen,
amounting to about a third in 1968. Public corporations, as part of the policy
of financing a larger share of their investment needs from their own resources,
have raised their savings total considerably in recent years and the 1968
level accounted for about a tenth of total savings.

Current expenditure, that is, excluding public investment and other capital
expenditure but including interest paid on debt, by the central Government
(including the national insurance funds) and the local authorities rose by
58 per cent at current prices over the period 1963 to 1968 and in the latter
year amounted to about 45 per cent of the gross national product. The main
causes of this increase have been the continuing growth of the social services,
especially education. Defence expenditure, which has been growing rather
more slowly in recent years, accounted for 14! per cent of the total current
expenditure of the public authorities in 1968 (compared with a peak of 27 per
cent in 1953). It is now only slightly larger than expenditure on national
insurance benefits.
Several appreciable increases in taxation rates, imposed partly to reduce
the volume of demand on resources, have raised sharply the inflow of revenue.

Income from employment in 1968 totalled £25,046 million and accounted for
70 per cent of total personal income (against 60 per cent in 1938). The diagram
on p. 232 shows the composition of personal income and expenditure in 1968.
Of a total of 27-7 million incomes in 1966, there were only about 58,000
incomes of more than £5,000 a year after tax. About a quarter (6-6 million) of
incomes after tax were in the £250-£499 range and 5-6 million were in the
next range of £500~£749- The number of incomes after tax of £1,000 a year
and above rose from i-i million in 1955 to 8-2 million in 1966. Over 75 per
cent of the yield from income tax and surtax came from persons with annual
incomes in this latter category, although the total incomes before tax of this
group accounted for just over a half of total income.
The ownership of property and personal assets tends to be more concen¬
trated than income after tax. Estimates made by the Board of Inland Revenue
indicate that in 1967 some 13 J million individuals (a quarter of the total
population) had a net personal wealth of up to £5,000, which accounted
for some 30 per cent of total net wealth in Britain amounting to £83,600
million. Just over 50,000 individuals had a net personal wealth of over
£100,000.

While consumer expenditure rose by 76 per cent at current prices between
1958 and 1968 to reach a total of £27,045 million, in real terms (that is, after
discounting the effect of price changes) the increase was only about 32 per
cent. The proportion devoted to food has been falling slightly each year
and now accounts for 21 per cent of consumer expenditure at current prices
(1958, 26 per cent); outlay on tobacco and alcoholic drinks is about 12 per cent.
In real terms expenditure on tobacco fell slightly between 1963 and 1968, but
substantial increases in taxes over the same period caused total outlay to rise by
23 per cent at current prices. At current prices housing absorbs 12 per cent of
total expenditure, and fuel and light about 5 per cent. Spending on motor
cars and motor cycles rose in 1968 by i2| per cent. There has also been a
substantial growth in spending on household electrical equipment (except
in 1966), fuel and light, and clothing. Outlays on running costs of vehicles
rose from £344 million in 1958 to £1,348 million in 1968. In general the
pattern of consumer spending reflects the social changes and other develop¬
ments outlined in Chapter 1. The diagram below shows the change in con¬
sumers’ expenditure since 1958 in real terms and at current prices.

Measures to

ECONOMIC POLICY AND PLANNING
The Government’s economic policy is to secure steady economic growth
with a high level of employment based upon a favourable balance of payments
and thereby to ensure a continuing improvement in output and living
standards. In order to achieve the substantial balance of payments surplus,
which it is hoped the devaluation of sterling of November 1967 will help to
bring about, a switch in resources has to be made from home consumption
to exports, import saving and investment. The Government has taken action,
therefore, to restrain home demand in the public and private sectors by
means of tax increases and a reduction in the rate of growth of public ex¬
penditure. Along with this, an effective prices and incomes policy is seen to be
essential in preventing the erosion by rising industrial costs of the competitive
advantage gained by devaluation. At the same time by encouraging structural
changes in industry, by the more efficient use of manpower, by improved
industrial relations, and by its regional development policies the Govern¬
ment is seeking to make more efficient use of the nation’s resources.
The intentions of the British Government for the domestic economy were
set out in the Letter of Intent sent to the IMF in June 1969 when a new
stand-by facility was requested (see p. 395). It observes that in the financial
year ending March 197° the objective is to obtain a balance of payments
surplus of at least ^300 million on the current and long-term capital account.
In the same period it also aims to restrict domestic credit expansion (the
borrowing of the public and private sectors, including net repurchases of
public sector debt from the private sector, excluding the banks) to not more
than £400 million compared with some £1,225 million in 1968-69. Objec¬
tives for public expenditure and prices and incomes policy are as described
below.
To further strengthen the balance of payments, the Government is encourag¬
ing industry through the Economic Development Committees and other means
to bring about savings in imports, which in the past decade have increased
in volume by over 4 per cent per annum. Likewise, services for exporters (see
PP- 39°~2) have been expanded to assist exports which have been rising at
some 3 per cent per annum in volume over the same period, although at a
greater rate since 1965- Measures are being taken where possible to increase
earnings from invisible exports (services).
All aspects of the Government’s overseas expenditure are included in its
annual survey of public expenditure (see below). The most important
items are overseas military expenditure which rose from £181 million to
£292 million between 1958 and 1968 and economic grant assistance to
less-developed dependent territories which rose from £51 million to £88
million; in addition, there are government loans to overseas countries and
multilateral assistance in the form of contributions to international agencies.
Britain also has to make repayments of capital and pay interest in respect
of post-war loans from the United States and Canada, totalling about £85
million a year.
There are exchange control restrictions on the movement of capital from the
United Kingdom to non-sterling countries and a voluntary programme to
restrict investment in certain developed countries in the sterling area is also
in operation (see p. 396). Britain’s private direct overseas investment over

the past few years, a large part of which is to the less-developed countries,

net flow has been outward.
Surveys of public expenditure (see p. 360) have been made annually since 1961
and forward planning has been undertaken with the object of relating public
expenditure programmes and their demand on national resources to the
expected development of the economy. Following the devaluation of sterling in
November 1967 reductions in the rate of increase in public expenditure were
announced in January 1968. These reductions, which were confirmed in the
1969 review, involved the setting of a target for the increase of public expendi¬
ture (excluding the capital expenditure of the nationalised industries and
debt interest) of 1 per cent in 1969-70 and 2 per cent in 1970-71 at constant
prices, plus a further margin in the latter years of up to 1 per cent for con¬
tingencies. Table 15 shows the estimates of public expenditure in 1969-70

In line with attempts to restrain home demand by means of the policies
on government expenditure and taxation, restrictions are being maintained
on bank credits. Since the 1950s this has taken the form of official requests
to the London clearing banks and other financial institutions to restrain their
lending and the use of special deposits (see p. 370). Most recently in November
1968 the clearing banks were asked to reduce by mid-March 1969 the level
of their advances to the private and overseas sector, except for exports and
shipbuilding, to 98 per cent of the level prevailing at the time of devaluation.
The Government has taken other steps to reduce the volume of credit
available to private borrowers. From July 1969 personal loans, except for the
purchase or improvement of land or buildings and in certain other special cases,
subject to transitional arrangement, ceased to qualify for tax relief. Hire-
purchase regulations have been tightened (see p. 406), and in November 1968
a system of prior deposits on imports (see p. 387) was introduced with the
intent partly of reducing some of the excess liquidity in the banking system.
Government action to improve industrial efficiency and to increase produc¬
tivity has taken several forms. Among the most important is the work of the
Economic Development Committees in examining the obstacles to economic
growth in a wide range of industries and services; the Ministry of Technology
in fostering the introduction and development of advanced techniques; the
National Board for Prices and Incomes (NBPI) in its detailed investigations
into the efficiency of public and private industry; and the Department of
Employment and Productivity in promoting through its Manpower and
Productivity Service the more efficient use of manpower and productive
resources. The Government also uses the purchasing power of the public
sector to assist industry in improving its efficiency and the Industrial Re¬
organisation Corporation promotes desirable amalgamations and reorgani¬
sations in industry. Taxation policy is being used to strengthen manufacturing
industry relative to services and other non-manufacturing activities by the
use of investment grants and a selective employment tax (see p. 365). This has
been accompanied by special financial assistance to industry in development
areas where resources are under-employed and by incentives to improve
labour mobility including legislation providing for redundancy payments and
improved re-training facilities. Efforts are being made to eliminate restrictive
practices in both sides of industry and legislation against monopolies and
mergers has been strengthened.
As in many other countries where full employment has prevailed over the past
decade and the demands on resources have been strong, Britain has had to deal
with continuing inflationary pressures. The almost uninterrupted upward
trend in prices has resulted principally from the tendency for money incomes
to rise faster than the volume of production, thus raising costs throughout the
economy.
Since 1958 the average annual rate of increase in domestic incomes has
been about 6 per cent, while the increase in the gross domestic product per
head of the labour force has been only between 2 and 2| per cent. Retail prices
rose on average by 3 per cent a year between mid-January 1958 and mid-
January 1969; while over roughly the same period average weekly earnings
of manual workers went up by about 5! per cent a year. Company profits
are subject to large cyclical swings, but in general they have increased more
slowly than employment incomes.

Productivity,
Prices and
Incomes Policy
National Board
for Prices
and Incomes
Early Warning
System
Development of
the Policy
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The Government recognises that a generally stable price level combined with
sustained economic growth can be achieved only within the framework of an
incomes policy designed to keep the rise in money incomes broadly in line
with the long-term rate of growth in national production.
The present Government’s productivity, prices and incomes policy has
been developed since 1964 in consultation with representatives of management
and workers beginning with the Joint Statement of Intent on Productivity,
Prices and Incomes signed in December 1964, which formulated the lines
of action to be taken by the Government and by management and unions.
In April 1965 the National Board for Prices and Incomes was set up to
investigate prices and incomes questions referred to it by the Government.
It sits in private using evidence provided both by the parties involved and
by independent enquiries. It is required to produce its report within three
months but extensions of time may be granted by the Government. Up
to end-August 1969 the NBPI had published over 120 reports on references
made to it. It also publishes an annual report on its work during the year.
It is obliged by law to have regard to considerations contained in successive
White Papers on prices and incomes policy, the most recent of which was
published in 1968 (Cmnd. 3590).
In the autumn of 1965, the Confederation of British Industry and the Trade
Union Congress agreed to co-operate with the Government to establish
a voluntary ‘early warning’ system for prices and incomes, the purpose
of which was to give the Government adequate opportunity of considering
proposals to increase wages or prices and whether to refer them to the NBPI.
This system remains in operation on a voluntary basis. Under the system
significant proposals for price increases are notified to the appropriate govern¬
ment department, while significant pay claims and proposed settlements in
the private sector are notified to the Department of Employment and Produc¬
tivity or the TUC. A decision whether to refer a case to the NBPI is required to
be taken within 28 days.
Although conceived as essentially long-term, the policy has had to operate
in difficult economic circumstances and has been modified from time to time.
The consistent objective of prices policy has been to maintain stable and,
wherever possible, bring about lower prices and criteria have been given
for both increases and reductions.
Incomes policy, however, has undergone several changes. The policy intro¬
duced in April 1965 with the agreement of management and unions (set out
in the White Paper Prices and Incomes Policy, Cmnd. 2639) included a 3-3^
per cent norm—which was related to the average annual increase in money
incomes per head consistent with stability in the general level of prices.
Above average increases could be justified under four criteria: in cases of
manpower shortage; where pay was seriously out of line with that for similar
work elsewhere; where pay was too low to maintain a reasonable standard of
living; and where there was a direct contribution to increased productivity.
But pressure of demand was high at the time and there was an acute
shortage of labour. The 3! per cent norm was considerably exceeded, and in
July 1966, among measures designed to meet the balance of payments
problems, the Government imposed a six-month standstill on pay and price
increases in the second half of 1966, followed by a further six months of
severe restraint, when new pay settlements were allowed only in exceptional
cases. From mid-1967 there was no automatic entitlement to a pay increase,
Prices and
Incomes Acts
Economic
Planning
National
Economic

Council
Economic
