THE NATIONAL ECONOMY 237
and increases were permitted only when they satisfied the criteria mentioned
above.
After the devaluation of sterling in November 1967, pay increases became
subject to a ceiling of 3^ per cent a year, although increases paid as part of a
productivity bargain were exempted where the increase in productivity was
sufficient to justify a larger increase.
The Government acquired statutory powers in the Prices and Incomes Act
1966 although these powers were not often used. Under Part 2 of the Act a
standstill could be imposed on a proposed pay or price increase for a period
of up to three months while it is being considered by the NBPI. Further
powers under the Prices and Incomes Acts 1967 and 1968 enabled the
Government to extend the standstill for a further three months and eight
months, respectively, after a report of the NBPI if that report was adverse.
The 1968 Act also included reserve powers to enforce dividend restraint, to
moderate and phase increases in house rents, and to require price reductions
in cases where these were recommended by the NBPI. The powers under the
1967 and 1968 Acts expire at the end of 1969. The Government intend,
however, that Part 2 of the 1966 Act should continue in force in 1970.
A framework for longer-term economic planning and consultation between
government and both sides of industry has been worked out in recent
years. The Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) is responsible for pre¬
paring assessments of the possible development of resources in future years
and for planning the balanced development of the regions. Its work forms the
basis for consultation with industry about major issues of economic policy and
in the implementation of decisions. The DEA works with representatives of
management and unions directly and through the National Economic
Development Council (NEDC), the Economic Development Committees
(EDCs) and with the regional planning bodies dealing with the special
problems of Scotland, Wales and the English regions.
The NEDC, which was set up in 1962, brings together representatives of
government, management and the trade unions, and provides a forum for the
discussion of future policy and planning of the economy. It meets regularly
under the chairmanship of the Prime Minister. Other members are the
ministers of the main economic departments, representatives of management
and trade unions and the nationalised industries, independent members, the
chairman of the NBPI and the Director General of the National Economic
Development Office (NEDO). The NEDC is supported by the NEDO,
which provides the secretariat for the NEDC and the EDCs. It is independent
of the Government, but publicly financed. The NEDO publishes a series of
booklets based on work by the EDCs aimed at improving particular aspects
of efficiency in specific industries and annually provides a general review of
productivity, prices and incomes.
The NEDC has set up 21 Economic Development Committees. With one
exception—the EDC for the Movement of Exports—each committee is
concerned with an individual industry and under an independent chairman
is composed of members from management, the trade unions, NEDO, the
DEA, the government department responsible for that industry, and up to
three independent members. The EDCs study and promote the application
of measures to improve efficiency and competitive power in each industry.

Regional

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
They also assist in planning by advising on the implications for their industries
of proposals contained in national planning documents.
The DEA published in February 1969 a planning document, The Task
Ahead: Economic Assessment to 1972, which has been the subject of discussion
in the NEDC. It contains the Government’s view of the likely development of
the economy over the four years to 1972. It is intended to provide a basis for
the continuing process of consultation between the Government and both
sides of industry about major issues of economic policy. The planning
document, unlike the National Plan which was published in 1965, is not a
fixed plan with a single target; instead a ‘wedge’ approach has been adopted
showing a widening range of possible outturns up to 1972 from the current
trends in the economy. Within the limits of the country’s resources and taking
full account of the Government’s economic strategy and the requirements of
the balance of payments, it discusses a range of possible growth rates from an
average of a little below 3 per cent a year to an average of around 4 per cent a
year and takes a basic case of 3^ per cent for detailed discussion. It is hoped
that action based on the results of further studies and consultation with
industry will enable a higher rate of growth to be achieved.
The aim of regional economic planning is to secure a full and balanced
development of the country’s resources and to help achieve a faster and
steadier expansion in national output.
A system of regional economic planning councils and boards established in
Great Britain in 1965 provides the basic machinery for regional economic
planning. The regional economic planning councils consist of about 25 to 30
part-time members appointed for their wide knowledge and experience of
their regions. The councils are advisory bodies with no executive powers;
their main tasks are to study and advise on the needs and potentialities of their j
regions, and to advise the central Government on aspects of national policy |
which have a bearing on regional development. The regional economic :
planning boards consist of senior civil servants representing the main govern- I
ment departments concerned with aspects of regional planning in their
respective areas. Their functions are to co-ordinate the regional economic
planning work of the government departments and to co-operate with the
economic planning councils in developing long-term strategies for the regions.
For purposes of regional planning England has been divided into eight
regions—Northern, Yorkshire and Humberside, East Midlands, East Anglia,
South-east, South-west, West Midlands, and North-west; Scotland has ^
its own economic planning council and board, and there is a Welsh Council
(supported by an economic planning board) concerned with both economic |
and social affairs in Wales.
All the regional economic planning councils in England have published
major reports on their regions; a development plan for Scotland up to 197°
was published by the Government in 1966 and one for Wales in 1967-
The present stage is one of formulating medium- and longer-term strategies,
with sub-regional studies of areas with particular problems. The strategies take
into account all the factors including the distribution of population, industry
and employment within the region.
The Northern Ireland Government has set up an economic council, comprising
representatives of both sides of industry and other interests, to examine
means of furthering Northern Ireland’s economic development. As Northern
Ireland government departments have responsibilities for planning in
THE NATIONAL ECONOMY

Summary
Northern Ireland, it was not necessary to set up a special planning board.
An economic report on Northern Ireland was published in 1965 containing
targets up to 1970.
Viewed as a whole the British economy has made considerable progress over
the past decade. Its rate of growth, if not so fast as that of some other industrial
countries, has been higher than in any earlier period over the past 50 years.
At the same time relatively full employment has been maintained and con¬
sumption and living standards have improved steadily. Moreover, moderni¬
sation of productive industry and the distributive system have progressed
despite persistent balance of payments difficulties, accentuated by the role
sterling plays as a world reserve and trading currency, and a high level of
overseas commitments in the form of development aid and defence.
11 INDUSTRY
The Structure
of Industry
Manufacturing
ORGANISATION AND PRODUCTION
The United Kingdom v/as the first country in the world to become highly
industrialised, and today fourteen people work in mining, manufacturing and
building for every one engaged in agriculture. It is the world’s third largest
exporter of manufactured goods, and the range of its industrial manufactures
reflects its position as one of the most important workshops of the world.
The pattern of ownership and organisation in industry is varied. Personal,
corporate, co-operative and public enterprise all assume a number of different
forms, and all are important in the economy. Industrial enterprises vary from
the many small workshops to vast organisations such as the National Coal
Board, a public corporation with about 360,000 employees; Imperial Chemical
Industries Ltd., a limited liability company which, with its subsidiaries,
employs 140,000 persons in the United Kingdom; and the Co-operative
Wholesale Society Ltd., with about 50,000 employees.
Most manufacturing is in the hands of private enterprise. Exceptions include
fissile materials and radioactive isotopes made by the Atomic Energy
Authority, locomotives and rolling-stock built in the workshops of British
Railways, and military equipment and supplies made in establishments of the
defence services. Staff of the Stationery Office do some printing and book¬
binding. Certain factories giving employment to the severely disabled are
operated by Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making public company financed on
the Vote of the Department of Employment and Productivity, which appoints
the directors (see p. 414). The Government holds about 49 per cent of the
equity of a major oil company, British Petroleum Limited, and has a
controlling interest in a few other companies.
Surveys of the size of all manufacturing establishments employing more
than ten persons are made periodically by the Department of Employment and
Productivity; the results of the most recent show that in 1961 nearly a third of
all employees in such establishments are in those employing from 100 to 499
persons, while slightly over a third are in those employing 1,000 or more. A
high proportion of the biggest establishments are in the heavy industries; the
average size of establishments in industries making consumer goods is smaller
than in manufacturing industries as a whole. Comparisons with results
obtained in earlier years suggest a slow but significant trend towards increased
average size of establishments.
The size of establishments is not in itself an indication of the size of manu¬
facturing enterprises, as a single enterprise may own several establishments,
not all of them necessarily engaged in the same or similar activities. The most
recent analysis of manufacturing enterprises by size (employment) relates to
the Report on the Census of Production for 1958. An enterprise, as defined in
the Census, normally consists of either a single firm or a holding company
together with its subsidiaries. Just over half of all employment in British
manufacturing industries in 1958 was accounted for by about 950 large
private enterprises employing 1,000 or more people, the largest 70 or so
accounting roughly for a quarter. A further indication of company size is the
INDUSTRY
Building and
Civil Engineering
Mining and
Quarrying
Monopolies and
Restrictive
Practices
241
value of capital employed (net assets). For a few of the very largest including
the Imperial Chemical Industries group, the figure exceeds £1,350 million;
about 50 companies registered in Britain have over £100 million net assets.
In some industries a small number of big companies and their subsidiaries
are responsible for most of the total production. Examples are oil refining,
non-ferrous metal smelting, the manufacture of motor vehicles and com¬
ponents, aircraft and aero-engines, heavy electrical equipment, bicycles,
tobacco, cement, and basic chemicals. Shares in these companies are usually
distributed among a great number of holders and it is rare for a few large
holders to have a controlling interest. For example, five of the largest public
companies each have more than 100,000 shareholders. With intensified
competition in the economy and in many branches of industry the growing
dependence of profitable operation on concentration and an increasing scale
of production, the trend towards mergers and regroupings has gathered
momentum throughout the 1960s. Larger units of control have been established
in almost all the leading industries, for example, motor vehicles, aircraft
frames and aero-engines, electrical engineering, machine tools, brewing,
textiles, and newspaper and magazine publishing.
A new departure was the setting up of the Industrial Reorganisation
Corporation by the Government in 1966 with resources of up to £150 million.
Its function is to participate in schemes for concentration, rationalisation and
modernisation of industry, in particular the merging and regrouping of firms
into larger units to meet the changing situation in the markets for many of the
most important products, and it has been instrumental in furthering large
mergers in motor vehicle manufacturing, the heavy electrical, computer and
a wide range of other industries. The Industrial Expansion Act 1968 extends
the Government’s powers to give financial support to industrial projects
calculated to improve efficiency; to create, expand or sustain production
capacity; to promote or support technological improvements.
An account of some of the principal manufacturing industries is given on
pp. 255-80.
In building and civil engineering, large-scale work is usually carried out by
private contractors, although the Ministry of Public Building and Works is
the largest single employer of building labour while some 45 per cent of the
industry’s output is for public authorities. Building firms may be divided into
those undertaking general building and civil engineering work and those
concerned with highly specialised work, many of which operate outside as
well as inside the building industry. Building is an industry of small firms;
more than three-quarters of the firms employ fewer than 20 employees. For
a fuller account of the building and civil engineering industries, see p. 297.
Much the most important of the British extractive industries is coalmining.
The coalmining industry of Great Britain (see p. 282) is operated as a single
co-ordinated enterprise under National Coal Board direction (see p. 282).
Nearly all other mining and quarrying (sand, gravel, chalk, limestone, salt,
tin, slate, oil shale and china clay) is undertaken by private enterprises, usually
owned and operated by limited liability companies; about 62,500 workers
are employed, excluding coalmining.
Legislation exists for scrutinising and, if desirable, for the investigation by an
independent administrative body of monopoly situations and for the judicial
examination of restrictive trading agreements.
The Restrictive Trade Practices Act 1956 and 1968 govern the registration
and judicial examination of restrictive agreements. They require the entry in
242
Role of Public
Enterprise
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
a public register of the particulars of a wide range of restrictive agreements
(including those relating to common prices, approved lists of dealers and the
limitation of production) which affect the supply or processing of goods for
the United Kingdom market. Proposed agreements of national importance
which promote efficiency or provide for new productive capacity, can be
exempted from this requirement for a specified period by the Board of Trade.
The Registrar of Restrictive Trading Agreements is responsible for keeping
the register and for bringing the agreements before the Restrictive Practices
Court set up under the 1956 Act. The Court, which includes laymen but is
presided over by one of Her Majesty’s judges, is, in effect, responsible for
deciding whether or not an agreement is in the public interest. If the parties
to an agreement fail to satisfy the Court that any restriction in their agreement
produces one or more of seven beneficial effects set out in the Act, and that
the restriction is not unreasonable, having regard to the balance between the
benefit it confers and any public detriment likely to result from its operation,
that restriction must be found contrary to the public interest. Agreements are
void in respect of restrictions so found. The Court can make orders preventing
the parties from operating their agreement, or from making new arrangements
having the same effect. Agreements relating exclusively to exports are not
subject to this procedure but have to be notified to the Board of Trade.
Under the 1956 Act collective enforcement of resale price maintenance was
prohibited, but individual suppliers remained free to enforce resale prices in
the courts. The Resale Prices Act 1964 made minimum resale price mainten¬
ance unlawful, except in respect of classes of registered goods for which
temporary exemption has been sought under the provisions of the Act.
Where resale price maintenance is prohibited, it is also unlawful to notify to
dealers prices stated or calculated to be understood as the minimum price
which may be charged on the resale of goods in the United Kingdom, or to
seek to maintain such prices by withholding supplies. Suppliers may continue
to practise resale price maintenance on registered goods, pending a decision
by the Restrictive Practices Court as to whether a case for exemption has
been made out against the criteria in the Act. Periodically, the Registrar of
Restrictive Trading Agreements issues lists of classes of goods in respect of
which the Court has refused to make an Order exempting them from the
terms of the Act. Only one class of goods (books and maps) has so far gained
exemption under an order from the court; nearly 500 classes have been
refused exemption.
Monopolies and kindred arrangements (other than those within the scope
of the Restrictive Practices Court) may, in circumstances indicated in the
Monopolies and Mergers Acts 1948 and 1965, be referred by the Board of
Trade to the Monopolies Commission for investigation and report. The
Board of Trade, in co-operation with the production departments (see p. 249)
concerned, take appropriate action on reports but no Order can be made
without parliamentary approval. The 1965 Act strengthened and extended
the legislation on monopolies. It reorganised and enlarged the Monopolies
Commission; provided for the investigation, at the reference of the Board of
Trade, of services and of proposed or recently completed mergers; made
special provision for newspaper mergers; and improved and extended the
Government’s powers for taking action on the basis of the Monopolies
Commission reports including new powers to prohibit mergers and break up
undesirable monopolies and mergers.
Direct State participation in productive and commercial activities is effected
mainly through special statutory bodies set up to deal with a particular
INDUSTRY
243
activity. Such bodies, though not part of a government department, are under
a considerable but varying degree of public control (see below). The most
important of these statutory bodies are the public corporations which operate
major industries and services in the public interest. Altogether 10 per cent
of the labour force works for these bodies. Their managing boards and staffs
are chosen for their experience and competence in a particular field; they are
not civil servants, and, although accountable to Parliament for their actions
in a variety of ways, it is they and not the ministers of the sponsoring
departments who are responsible for the management of the corporations.
Certain of the corporations are self-supporting; others receive Exchequer
grants to help them carry out duties with which they have been charged.
The following corporations are now operating or controlling large-scale
industries or services: United Kingdom Atomic Energy Authority (see p. 200);
British Overseas Airways Corporation, British European Airways, British
Airports Authority (see pp. 348-50); Bank of England see (p. 369); British
Broadcasting Corporation, Independent Television Authority (see p.433);
National Coal Board (see p. 282); Electricity Council, Central Electricity
Generating Board, Area Electricity Boards, North of Scotland Hydro-
Electric Board, South of Scotland Electricity Board, Northern Ireland Joint
Electricity Authority, Electricity Board for Northern Ireland (see p. 287);
Gas Council, Area Gas Boards (see p. 292); British Steel Corporation (see p.
257); British Railways Board, British Transport Docks Board, British Water¬
ways Board, National Freight Corporation, National Bus Company and
Scottish Transport Group (see p. 334), London Transport Board, Transport
Holding Company (see p. 334), Northern Ireland Transport Holding
Company (see p. 346), and Post Office Corporation (see p. 353).
The extent to which the responsible minister has power over the working
of the boards which have been set up to run the nationalised industries varies
from industry to industry, but two features are common to almost all of them.
First, the minister appoints (and may dismiss) the chairman and members of
each board, and, secondly, he has power to give general directions as to
how the industry should be run, but does not interfere in day-to-day manage¬
ment. It is usually also laid down that the board shall give to the minister
any information, statistics and financial accounts which he may require. In
practice, as the responsible minister is kept fully informed and major policy
decisions are reached in consultation with him, there is very seldom occasion
for him to issue a formal directive.
The minister also has financial powers and responsibilities. The usual
statutory requirement is that the board is required to conduct its business so
that receipts at least balance outgoings taking one year with another. The
responsible minister is usually empowered (subject to Treasury approval) to
say what shall be done with any surplus revenues which may accrue. As
regards finance of capital expenditure, the present system is that such finance
as cannot be met from internal sources is mainly provided, in the form of
interest-earning loans, by the minister from the Exchequer, bank advances
being used only for normal requirements of short-term capital.
It is usual for the minister responsible for each nationalised industry to be
required by statute to take steps to see that the interests of the industry’s
customers are protected. This is generally done by the establishment of
representative consumers’ councils to consider complaints and suggestions
made to them, and to advise the board or the minister on the changes they
think desirable.

Industrial
Association
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Financial targets have been agreed by the Government with the different
industries (or are under discussion) ranging from 12-4 per cent gross return
on capital employed to ‘breaking even’ after interest and depreciation have
been allowed for. In addition the industries are expected to apply a test
discount rate for new investment of 8 per cent.
Government policy towards the nationalised industries is subject to the
approval of Parliament. Opportunities for parliamentary discussion are
afforded by debates, including debates on their annual reports and accounts,
and by answers to parliamentary questions, which, in principle, are admissible
only if concerned with policy rather than details of administration. A House
of Commons Select Committee on the Nationalised Industries, which
examines the reports and accounts of the nationalised industries and reports
to Parliament, has been in operation since 1957.
From the middle of the nineteenth century, private industrial undertakings
have increasingly entered into voluntary association for a number of different
purposes. Some of the more important of these are classified as: (1) the
provision of common services, the exchange of information, liaison with the
Government, and representation of their members’ point of view; (2) the
regulation of trading practices, sometimes including the regulation of prices
(see p. 242); (3) negotiation with trade unions on wages and conditions of
work. Associations for the first and third of these purposes cover, with
varying completeness, most of British industry, but there are wide sectors of
industry where there are no collective agreements to regulate trading practices.
Employers’ organisations which deal with labour matters usually consist of
firms engaged in the same type of operation or manufacturing process. Trade
associations mainly concerned with representations to the Government,
provision of common services or the regulation of trading practices are built
up round a product or an allied group of products. In an industrial sector
concerned wholly with an allied group of products, a single association may
undertake all the required functions.
There are about 80 national federations and probably altogether about
1,500 employers’ organisations (mostly regional or local, and members or
branches of the national federations) all concerned with negotiation of wages
and conditions of work. The number of manufacturers’ associations concerned
with providing common services is not known precisely, but according to a
survey carried out between 1953 and 1956 by Political and Economic Planning
(an independent research organisation) some 1,300 were in existence, varying
greatly in importance, structure and activities.
The central body representing British industry nationally is the Confedera¬
tion of British Industry (CBI). It is recognised by the Government as a
channel for consultation between government departments and representatives
of private employers as a whole. For its members it acts as an advisory and
consultative body providing them with information and statistics, ascertaining
their collective views and representing them nationally to the Government
and the public and also internationally, for example in the Council of European
Industrial Federations. CBI representatives sit on a number of government
advisory committees, on other statutory bodies and on voluntary bodies
concerned with matters affecting industry.
The CBI membership consists of some 13,000 companies and over 200
trade associations and employers’ federations. Nationalised industries have
joined as industrial associates. The CBI has a regional organisation in the
United Kingdom and is widely represented abroad.
INDUSTRY
245
In matters of common concern the CBI often acts jointly with the chambers
of commerce. These are open to all kinds of producers and traders and exist
to promote the interests of local industry and commerce. The Association of
British Chambers of Commerce, founded in i860, is the central organisation
to which 95 local chambers of commerce (together with 18 British Chambers of
Commerce operating abroad) are affiliated. In Scotland there is an additional
central organisation, the Council of Scottish Chambers of Commerce, and in
Northern Ireland, the Northern Ireland Chamber of Commerce and Industry
to which local chambers are affiliated.
vocation The following is a summary of the geographical distribution of British industry
today, grouped by the areas covered by the regional economic planning
machinery (see p. 238).
Greater London and London, lying at the head of ocean navigation on the Thames estuary, is
he South-east Britain’s capital and main communication centre, probably still the world’s
legion most important financial centre, and one of the world’s three largest cities
(with Tokyo and New York) and three largest ports (with New York and
Rotterdam). It is the main centre in Britain of printing, cinema film produc¬
tion, and the manufacture of clothing, food and drink, furniture, materials for
the arts, precision instruments and many other specialised products. Small
firms predominate in many of these industries and the average size of manu¬
facturing firms (particularly in the central area) is well below the national
average. London is also, especially its outer ring, important for light engineer¬
ing, chemicals and consumer goods and has some heavy engineering plants
and a number of leading research establishments.
Towards the periphery of Greater London (population 7,880,760) and in
the new urban development outside it, industry, particularly the electronics
and a variety of consumer goods industries, has expanded greatly; some
of the largest aircraft plants are in these areas, for example at Weybridge
and Hatfield, as well as factories, at Dagenham, Luton and Dunstable, of two
of the four main motor vehicle manufacturers. There are other major motor
vehicle manufacturing plants at Cowley, Oxford (109,000), some 50 miles
north-west of London. Along the lower Thames and Medway estuaries there
are large oil refineries as well as some smaller shipyards, engineering works
and major concentrations of the paper and pulp and cement industries.
A great part of the Channel coast eastwards from Poole (population 97,500)
and Bournemouth (150,000) consists of built-up areas, which from Brighton
(162,000) eastwards are partly dormitories for people working in London.
Holiday resorts fringe the coast. Portsmouth (219,000) is a naval port with
some shipbuilding and general manufactures. Southampton (210,000) is
Britain’s largest port for ocean-going liners; its industries include ship
repairing, oil refining, cable-making, electronics and synthetic rubber. Dover,
Folkestone and Newhaven are packet ports.
South-west England Devon and Cornwall have a considerable tourist trade. Bristol (429,000) is a
leading port and commercial centre with aircraft, aero-engines, tobacco, food
processing, paper, printing and other industries and important non-ferrous
metals and basic chemicals plants at Avonmouth. Gloucester (88,000), origin¬
ally an inland port and commercial town, Cheltenham (75,500), originally a
resort town, and the area between and adjacent to them produce a variety of
manufactures, including machinery, instruments and accessories, and cloth.
Swindon (98,000), besides railway workshops, has important engineering

works. Bath (86,000), originally a resort town and centre of an agricultural
district, has become noted for engineering and other manufacturing.
Besides being one of the most productive agricultural regions, the eastern
counties possess some sizeable towns. Cambridge (100,000) is a leading centre
of research-based industry; Ipswich (122,000) and Peterborough (66,000) are
noted for diesel engines and engineering generally; and Norwich (121,000)

Great Yarmouth (52,000) and Lowestoft (49,000) have fish processing plants,
and are also becoming important bases for companies engaged in natural gas
exploitation in the North Sea.
The West Midlands conurbation, which stretches from Birmingham
(i, 102,000) to Wolverhampton (267,000) and includes parts of Staffordshire,
Worcestershire and Warwickshire, has an unusually wide variety of industry,
including the manufacture of metals, electrical and engineering products of all *
kinds and also jewellery, rubber products, chemicals and domestic metalware.
The largest concentrations of motor vehicle manufacture (including com¬
ponents and accessories) in Britain are in Birmingham and Coventry (334,000).
The smaller conurbation of North Staffordshire, centred on Stoke-on-Trent
(276,000), is devoted chiefly to the manufacture of pottery and china and to
coalmining, although other industries are growing in importance, while
Stafford (52,500) has heavy electrical and other engineering works.
Other industrial centres are Rugby (56,500), electrical engineering;
Worcester (70,000), machinery; Burton-on-Trent (50,000), brewing and
rubber; and Kidderminster (45,500), carpets.
The thriving industrial cities and towns of the East Midlands include Leicester
(283,000) noted for hosiery and knitwear, boots and shoes and machinery for
making these products; Derby (217,000) for general engineering, aero-engines
and man-made fibres; Nottingham (310,000) for hosiery, cycles and a variety
of other engineering products, lace, pharmaceutical products and tobacco;
Northampton (122,000) footwear and engineering; Chesterfield (70,000)
engineering. Corby (45>000), R new town in Northamptonshire, has a steel
industry. Part of Britain’s richest and most highly mechanised coalfield lies
under the north-east of the area. Some of the towns on the coalfield, such as
Mansfield (55,500), have important manufacturing industries, particularly
textiles.
Manchester (616,500) is the commercial hub of the cotton and man-made
fibre textile industries, a very important financial and commercial centre and
a major port. It is also one of the chief centres for electrical and heavy
engineering and the production of machine tools, petro-chemicals, dyestuffs,
and pharmaceutical goods, while it has a wide range of other manufactures.
In the traditional cotton-manufacturing towns man-made fibres are also
processed alone or blended with cotton; the largest of these are Bolton
(156,500), Oldham (110,000), Rochdale (87,000), Stockport (141,000), Burnley
(78,000), Blackburn (101,000), Preston (106,000) and Bury (64,500). In the
majority of these towns engineering industries, notably the manufacture of
printing, paper making, textile and electrical machinery and heavy commercial
vehicles (especially in the Chorley-Leyland area), have been expanding while
the cotton industry has been declining. The Lancashire coalfield also lies
in the Manchester-Wigan area.
The Manchester Ship Canal, which carries a substantial volume of overseas
trade, links Manchester with Merseyside. It passes through Warrington

(74,000) with its metal industries (such as wire-drawing), Widnes (54,500) and

Liverpool (705,000) is the second port of Britain, a great commercial and
insurance centre and, after London, the greatest centre for processing imported
foodstuffs and raw materials, noted especially for flour milling, soap manu¬
facture, sugar refining and rubber products. Among its older industries is
ship repairing; shipbuilding is a major industry across the river at Birkenhead
(143,500). Many new industries, including electrical engineering, manufacture
of heavy industrial equipment and, more recently, of motor vehicles, have been
established around Liverpool. Salt, extracted in Cheshire, is used by chemical
works on Merseyside.
Barrow (64,500), in the north-west of Lancashire, is well-known for ship¬
building and marine engineering. Blackpool (151,500) on the coast is Britain’s
most popular holiday resort.
About three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s worsted and woollen indus¬
tries are found in the West Riding of Yorkshire. Bradford (297,000) is the
commercial centre of the wool trade and important for worsted; Wakefield
(60,000) produces both worsted and woollens; Morley (43,500) and Leeds
(508,000) have specialised in cheaper cloths, and Batley (41,000), Dewsbury
(53,0°o) and Spenborough (38,000) in heavy cloth, but their production is
becoming more diversified. Huddersfield (130,000) has a reputation for fine
woollens and worsteds and Halifax (95,000) for carpets. In most of the larger
centres of the wool industry a variety of engineering products are manu¬
factured. Leeds, the commercial capital of the area, has a large ready-made
clothing industry and important engineering plants. Farther south is the
heavy engineering centre of Sheffield (534,000), famous for its high quality
steels, cutlery and tools. The area’s extensive coalfields provide nearly a
quarter of Britain’s coal; Doncaster (86,000), also with tractor and nylon
manufacturing, and Barnsley (76,000) are the largest towns on the coalfield.
York (110,500) is noted for chocolates and confectionery manufacture and
has important railway workshops, and Hull (296,000), one of the world’s
largest fishing ports and with many manufacturing industries, including
engineering, vegetable oil processing, paints and sawmilling, is the most
important industrial town in the East Riding of Yorkshire.
On the south (Lincolnshire) side of the Humber lie Scunthorpe (71,000),
another important steel-making centre, and the major fishing port of Grimsby
(95>000) which has a food processing industry and also growing chemicals and
textiles industries close by at Immingham.
The greater part of this region (Northumberland, Cumberland, Westmorland,
Durham and the North Riding of Yorkshire) is an area of mountains, lakes and
moors and is relatively thinly populated. Most of its population is concen¬
trated in the coastal strip from the coalfields north of the Tyne to the Tees.
Within this area the main centres are Tyneside, including Newcastle upon
Tyne (251,500), Gateshead (101,000), Tynemouth (72,500), South Shields
(108,000), Wallsend (48,000) and Jarrow (29,000); and Teesside (392,500) and
Hartlepool (98,000). Other large towns are Sunderland (219,000), Darlington
(85,000) and, in the west, Carlisle (71,000).
The whole region is more dependent than other parts of England on
traditional heavy industries, notably coalmining, iron and steel manufacture,
shipbuilding and repairing and chemicals (the complex of chemical plants on

both banks of the Tees is probably the most extensive in Europe), which
together employ nearly a third of the male workers. This proportion has been
falling steadily as the result of the region’s efforts, with government help, to
attract new types of enterprise. It is one of the most important areas for the
manufacture of electrical plant, and the many other industries include mining
machinery, rolling mill plant, earth-moving equipment, machine tools, ropes,
paint, glass, clothing and scientific instruments. An aluminium smelter is
under construction on the Northumberland coast. Atomic energy is important
in Cumberland, with two nuclear power stations and other installations.
Nearly two-thirds of the population of Wales and Monmouthshire live in the
two counties of Glamorgan and Monmouthshire. In this area are the coal
mines which, though long worked and operating at increasing depths, still
produce nearly all Britain’s anthracite and much of its steam and other
specialised coals, and employ more workers than any branch of manufacturing
industry. Rhondda (98,000) and Merthyr Tydfil (57,000) are the largest
centres in the coalmining area. The steel industry, with some of the most
modern plants in Europe, supplies almost all Britain’s output of tin plate and
much of its sheet steel. In the past 35 years many new industries have been
established, often on government industrial estates; they include plastics,
synthetic fibres, clothing, electronics, motor vehicle components and light
engineering.
The main urban centres are also the three major ports Cardiff (289,000),
Newport (113,000) and Swansea (171,000). Milford Haven (13,000), a magni¬
ficent deep-water harbour recently developed, has two major oil refineries.
In North Wales a number of light industries, notably man-made fibres, are
located in the seaside resorts and some other towns, particularly Wrexham
(37,000), and there is a large steelworks in Flintshire.
About three-quarters of Scotland’s population (5-2 million) is concentrated in
the central Lowlands between the Firth of Clyde and the Firth of Forth. The
principal cities in this area are Glasgow (960,500) and Edinburgh (468,000).
Clydeside, which includes Glasgow, is Britain’s largest shipbuilding and
marine engineering centre; it also has a great variety of general engineering
enterprises and other industries. The steel industry, sited mainly in north
Lanarkshire, produces a wide range of products. The widely dispersed
electronics equipment industry is represented by a growing number of firms
in such centres as Glasgow, north Lanarkshire, Dundee and central Fife, as
well as in Edinburgh, where this and other modern industries are expanding
alongside the long-established engineering, printing and brewing industries.
Motor car manufacture has been established in Renfrewshire and in West
Lothian there has been a major expansion of commercial vehicle building.
Outside the central Lowland belt there is considerable industrial concen¬
tration in and around Dundee (182,000) and Aberdeen (182,000) and a number
of towns outside these areas have attracted light industries in recent years.
Dundee’s traditional manufacture, jute, has been supplemented by office
machinery, clocks and watches, refrigerators and electronic products. In
north-east Scotland is the largest concentration of whisky distilleries.
Most of northern Scotland is mountainous and much of southern Scotland
is hilly and rugged. These regions are sparsely populated, but the Scottish
Highlands possess significant resources of hydro-electric power (see p. 289).
There are high-quality tweed and knitwear industries both in the valley towns
of the southern uplands and in the Highlands and Islands. Small engineering
and electronics industries have recently been established in towns in the

southern uplands. Small-scale manufacturing has also been introduced in the
Highlands, and larger enterprises include the experimental atomic reactor
establishment at Dounreay and the aluminium smelter being built at
Invergordon.
Although the area of Northern Ireland is relatively small and it lacks minerals,
there is substantial and growing industrialisation, particularly in and around
Belfast, the capital city (397,500). Britain’s largest single shipyard is in
Belfast; other long-established activities include the manufacture of textile
machinery and other engineering products; ropes, twine, tobacco and clothing.
Northern Ireland has also long been an important centre for textiles—it is
particularly well known for linen. The textile industry is now extensively
diversified; Northern Ireland is one of the most important areas in Europe for
man-made fibre production and provides about one-fifth of Britain’s output.
There has also been extensive development in vehicle components, oil-well
equipment, electronic instruments, telephone switchgear, toys, shoes, carpets
and synthetic rubber.
The Government can influence industrial activity in a number of ways 
through fiscal and monetary policy, through the level of public expenditure,
through the placing of government contracts, through the policies of publicly
owned enterprises, by physical controls, by inducements, by exhortation and
by the provision of services, information and advice. Apart from labour
legislation (see Chapter 16) and certain export and import controls over a
small range of products (see Chapter 15), there are few physical controls over
industry the main ones are the use of the legislation concerning monopolies
and restrictive practices already described (see p. 241) and the operation of
powers to control new industrial and office building and changes in land use
(see p. 253).
There is a close association between industry and the Government through
such channels as the National Economic Development Council, the main
forum for consultation on economic affairs between the Government,
management and the trade unions, and Economic Development Committees
(EDCs), which cover particular sectors of industry and are under the aegis of
industry. Within the Government, the Department of Economic Affairs
(DEA) has general responsibility for the Government’s economic strategy in
the application of resources including the co-ordinating of industrial and
regional policies. Policies for productivity, prices and incomes and manpower
are the concern of the Department of Employment and Productivity. The
department through which the Government’s day-to-day relations with trade
and industry are chiefly conducted is the Board of Trade (which has regional
offices in certain principal industrial centres). Other departments concerned
with particular subjects of concern to industry generally are the Treasury,
which is responsible for fiscal and monetary policy; and the Department of
Education and Science, which is responsible for the promotion of education
and for civil science, operating in the main through the research councils.
The Ministry of Technology is responsible for the application of advanced
technology in industry generally; it has nine regional offices linking 70
industrial liaison centres and maintains a number of research establishments
offering a range of services to industry (see p. 204).
For particular industries a system has grown up whereby a particular
government department acts as the main point of contact, the ‘production’ or
‘sponsor department’, for each major industry. The Ministry of Technology
is the sponsor department for the mechanical and electrical engineering
2^0 BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
industries and for those manufacturing electronic equipment, computers,
machine tools, telecommunications equipment, shipping, aircraft and aero¬
engines. The Board of Trade is the sponsor department for the chemicals,
non-ferrous metals and most of the consumer goods industries. Others
include the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the Ministry of Public
Building and Works and the Department of Health and Social Security.
There are separate departments of the Northern Ireland Government for
matters within the competence of the Northern Ireland Parliament. The
Ministry of Commerce deals with industry, especially the encouragement of
industrial development.
Statistical The Central Statistical Office, which is attached to the Cabinet Office,
Services is the central body for government statistics. Although departments them¬
selves compile statistics relating to their responsibilities (for example, business
statistics at the Board of Trade’s Business Statistics Office), and may publish
them in their own standard publications, the comprehensive statistical
publications are prepared by the Central Statistical Office, which acts as
co-ordinator. (For the principal regular series of statistics published, see
Bibliography p. 479.)

Productivity and gas, electricity and water) was in the first half of 1969 nearly 4 per cent

Production 1 rends double the pre_war ievel. The course of production and employment from
1962 to 1968 is shown in Table 16.
Among manufacturing industries output rose fastest between 1958 and 1968
in the chemical and allied industries (82 per cent), in engineering and elec¬
trical goods (57 per cent), and in paper, printing and publishing (52 per cent);
in the gas, electricity and water group there was an advance of 64 per cent and
in construction of 49 per cent.
The size of the labour force has scarcely changed in the last five years and
the increases in production have been due mainly to a variety of factors
influencing productivity, including advances in products, machinery, pro¬
cesses and methods of work; the rate of fixed capital formation, more
intensive competition and sales promotion; and improved management.
Although gross fixed capital formation at home has, as a whole, been well
maintained since 1966, the proportion devoted to manufacturing has tended
to fall. Nevertheless, the total in 1968 amounted to 4-3 per cent of the gross
domestic product and was estimated to be 39 per cent greater than in 1959-
Part of this rising investment is linked with the introduction of new tech¬
niques and equipment and in particular of machines and instruments which

lessen the demand for human skill and supervision though they may require
more skill from fewer people. This process of automation is giving rise to far-
reaching changes in the pattern of industry and in the internal organisation
and labour requirements of business enterprises and has already been respon¬
sible for consequential increases in production and efficiency which, in the
long run, are likely to be very large. Much investment, however, still consists
of replacements, additions and improvements of a more traditional kind.
Both the long-term and the short-term growth of productivity thus depend
most directly on the decisions of individual undertakings. But though the
promotion of productivity is regarded as primarily a matter for industry,
government departments and educational and research establishments also
have an important contribution to make. Government budgeting and financial
policies also have a strong influence on the extent and direction of demand,
and government purchasing policies take account of national industrial
objectives. Leading industrialists act as advisers to the DEA to help overcome
specific obstacles to efficiency and industrial expansion.
Within industry employers’ organisations often provide technical assistance,
conduct market surveys, and support schemes of vocational education and
training, and many trade unions organise special training schemes and courses
to promote understanding of modern management techniques. Changes in
working methods to facilitate higher output feature in a number of produc¬
tivity agreements negotiated between management and workers. Private
consultants specialising in management and work study are available to advise
firms on measures to increase their productive efficiency, there are also many
specialist institutions, both public and private, concerned with various aspects
of productivity. The British Productivity Council (BPC) was established by
both sides of industry to stimulate interest in methods of raising productivity.
It is an independent body on which are represented the Confederation of
British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the Association of British
Chambers of Commerce, and the nationalised industries; its work is financed
by contributions from these bodies and by a government grant-in-aid. Most
of the BPC’s work is done through more than 130 local productivity com¬
mittees and associations throughout the country, but it is also responsible for
special countrywide campaigns. The local organisations arrange meetings,
inter-factory visits, courses, conferences, films shows and exhibitions.
The British Standards Institution (BSI) is a voluntary non-profit-making
body incorporated by Royal Charter. It prepares and promulgates standards
252 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
in respect of, inter alia, quality, performance, dimensions, testing methods and
codes of practice. Voluntary acceptance of such standards by manufacturers,
buyers and sellers reduces unnecessary variety and simplifies the specification
of requirements. The BSI is governed by a council consisting of representa¬
tives of the main organisations of employers and workers, professional
institutions and the larger government departments.
The DEA is responsible for co-ordinating government policies in industrial
policy. EDCs (see p. 249) are particularly concerned with removing obstacles
to efficiency; the DEA is represented on the EDCs by its industrial advisers
seconded to the department from industry. The Board of Trade administers
the government grants to the BPC and the Council of Industrial Design. The
Ministry of Technology is charged with extending the introduction of auto¬
matic control systems and advanced techniques into industry, sponsors the
BSI, the British Calibration Service1 and the National Computing Centre,
supports the National Data Processing Service, and provides technical
advisory services. It is also concerned directly with research into such factors
as productivity measurement techniques, group technology, production
engineering and fatigue among operators. The Manpower and Productivity
Service of the Department of Employment and Productivity advises firms
on productivity, particularly aspects connected with manpower utilisation
and industrial relations. A number of other departments have responsibilities
which bear on productivity.
Management In Britain, as elsewhere, management is recognised as a subject requiring
special skills and knowledge. This is reflected both in a change in the general
educational qualifications of recruits and in the spread of systematic education
and training for management.
The British Institute of Management (BIM) is the central national manage¬
ment body, independent, non-political and non-profit-making. Its purpose is
to study and promote scientific management, including management education
and training, throughout industry, commerce, and public administration. The
BIM receives an annual government grant of about £100,000 to help it expand
services to industry. The Industrial Society works to promote better use of
human resources; it advises members and conducts conferences and courses.
Management studies and education for management are expanding rapidly
in Britain and have become a recognised feature of higher education (see
p. 161). There are graduate business schools in London and Manchester.
Training courses for higher management are held at several universities and
colleges, including the Administrative Staff College, Henley-on-Thames,
and Ashridge College of Management, Berkhamsted. The larger firms,
especially those with wide responsibilities, often provide general management
courses for senior executives, and systems of informal training within an
organisation are numerous. There are also bodies concerned with specialised
branches of management, for example, the Institute of Personnel Manage¬
ment, the Institution of Works Managers, the Institute of Office Management
and the Institute of Marketing.
The growing number of professional personnel working as management
consultants—now over 3,000—and the use of the services of independent
management selection firms in the appointment of senior staff are further
indications of interest in the science of management in Britain. A government
1 Set up in 1966 to provide reliable calibration facilities for industries producing
scientific instruments and industrial test gear.

Encouragement
of Expansion
in Selected
Industries
Under the Industrial Development Act 1966 cash grants were introduced in
place of certain tax allowances for capital expenditure on plant or machinery
used in the manufacturing, extractive and construction industries. The grant
scheme, which is administered by the Board of Trade, also covers capital
expenditure on computers, ships, hovercraft and mining works. The standard
rate of grant is 20 per cent. In order to maintain a greater incentive to invest¬
ment in development areas (see below) the rate of grant is 40 per cent for
plant or machinery for use in development areas. Over 40 per cent of the total
amount paid is at the development areas rate. A separate system of grants
and loans to encourage hotel development has been operating since 1968.
Government
Help for
Industry in
Development
Areas
Some parts of Britain have long been less prosperous than others. Their rate of
economic expansion has been below average and their level of unemployment
above average as a result of the decline of some traditional industries or the
lack of job opportunities. For many years unemployment has remained a
persistent problem in Scotland, Wales and the north-east and some other
parts of England. This regional imbalance has been aggravated by the tendency
for new industries to concentrate in the Midlands and the south-east where, as
a result, the demand for labour is high and there are increasing problems of
congestion. An important aim of the Government’s regional policy is to
achieve a better distribution of industrial development between the different
parts of the country. The Government has in recent years taken important
measures aimed at securing balanced economic development.
Government aid to areas of high unemployment began in the 1930s and
has been developed in various ways since the end of the second world war.
Since August 1966 large parts of Britain have been designated as ‘development
areas’ where industrial development is to be encouraged. They cover northern
England, Merseyside and nearly the whole of Scotland, Wales, Cornwall and
north Devon and contain a fifth of Britain’s working population. The Board
of Trade provides businessmen with detailed information on industrial
location within the development areas and offers a wide variety of inducements
to new or expanding businesses in these areas, the first priority being given
to smaller ‘special development areas’.
Besides the capital investment grants there is a wide range of financial and
other inducements available under the Local Employment Acts 1960-66 to
encourage industry to expand in the development areas. The Board of Trade
may build factories for leasing at favourable rents or sale on deferred terms;
make building grants of 25 per cent (and 35 per cent in special cases) of the
cost of an industrialist’s own factory; make grants towards initial costs
incurred on starting a project in a development area (for example, removal of
plant machinery and stock); and make loans for the general purposes of an
undertaking (for example, working capital, plant and machinery, etc.).
Factory building and estate management are undertaken on the Board of
Trade’s behalf by the English, Scottish and Welsh Industrial Estates Corpor¬
ations ; premises administered by the three Corporations total over 60 million
square feet and give employment to over 250,000 people.
Assistance from other government departments includes 85 per cent capital
grants to local authorities for clearing derelict or neglected sites and for
254
Northern Ireland
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
improving basic services; and help from the DEP with the cost of training
additional labour in development areas and of transferring workers in
connection with establishing new enterprises.
Employers in the manufacturing industry in development areas are entitled
not only to refund of selective employment tax (see p. 365) but also to a
premium of 7s. 6d. a week for every full-time male adult employee. In addition
they receive regional employment premiums of 30s. a week. (Lower rates for
women, part-timers, boys and girls apply to both premiums.)
A committee set up in 1967 to investigate the needs of ‘Intermediate
Areas’—those areas with special economic problems but situated outside
the development areas—published its report in 1969. The Government has
announced that legislation is to be enacted to give certain such areas special
assistance, similar to that available under the Local Employment Acts,
including grants amounting to 25 per cent of factory building costs, additional
provisions for industrial training and help in a clearance programme of
derelict land.
Since 1948 control of new industrial building has been exercised through
the use of a system of Industrial Development Certificates. Any application
under the normal town and country planning machinery for planning
permission for industrial development involving more than 5,000 square feet
of floor space (or 3,000 square feet in the Midlands and south-east) must be
accompanied by a certificate from the Board of Trade certifying that the
development in question can be carried out consistently with the proper
distribution of industry. In considering applications the Board of Trade is
required to have particular regard to the need for providing appropriate
employment in the development areas. In practice this obligation has led the
Board of Trade normally to refuse certificates for projects outside the
development areas unless satisfied that the project could not reasonably be
undertaken in a development area or in Northern Ireland. Subject to this
priority, the control is also used to encourage dispersal of industry to new or
expanded towns taking population from the more congested areas. Under the
Control of Office and Industrial Development Act 1965 the Board of Trade
also controls office developments of over 10,000 square feet in most of the
Midlands, and in the south-east other than Greater London where the limit
is 3,000 square feet.
Nearly per cent of workers employed in manufacturing industries in
1966 were in plants opened since 1945 by firms whose manufacturing base
was in some other region. A further 3 J per cent were in those opened by firms
whose base was in some other part of the region. The development areas (and
Northern Ireland) have made net gains of employment in the last two decades
by the movement of manufacturing industries.
Under its own legislation Northern Ireland provides for the payment of
investment grants at 40 per cent of the cost both of new plant and machinery
and of new buildings for the manufacturing, construction and extractive
industries in Northern Ireland. There is also provision for assisting firms by
means of loans to carry out major schemes of re-equipment, to move to
another area in particular need of industrial development or to undertake a
rehousing of their business in association with a major scheme of modernisa¬
tion and reorganisation. Help under the investment grants legislation is
largely made without regard to how much employment is created as a result.
As an alternative means of assistance the Northern Ireland Government
continues to use its comprehensive and flexible powers authorised under the
Industries Development Acts for projects which offer a reasonable amount of
Councils to
Promote
Industry
Rural Industries
industry 255
employment. In such cases capital assistance of 45 per cent would normally
be available instead of the 40 per cent referred to above. For those projects
which offer exceptionally attractive returns in employment or location within
Northern Ireland, the assistance offered could include tenancy of a govern¬
ment-built factory at a very low rent, grants towards operating costs in the
initial stages, and grants towards costs of removing existing machinery and
installing it in a factory in Northern Ireland. The regional employment
premium and selective employment premium apply also to Northern Ireland.
Since 1945 over 250 new firms have been established in Northern Ireland
with government assistance, giving employment to some 70,000 people.
The Ministry of Commerce is the Northern Ireland government department
concerned with the administration of industrial development policies. The
Northern Ireland Economic Council was set up in 1965 to assist in furthering
economic growth. The chairman is the Minister of Commerce, and the
membership includes representatives of industry, commerce and the trade
unions.
Certain regions and areas in England have industrial development associa¬
tions concerned with promoting local industry. These are sponsored mainly
by local authorities, trade associations and individual firms.
Several voluntary associations are concerned with Welsh industry. The
Development Corporation for Wales, founded in 1959, is the most prominent.
In Scotland, the Highlands and Islands Development Board, set up by
statute in 1965, works to stimulate the economic and social development of
the seven ‘crofting’ counties (see p. 314). It provides grants and loans to
industrial, commercial and other enterprises; it may also acquire land,
provide management and other advisory services and set up and carry on
businesses. The Scottish Council (Development and Industry), a voluntary
association, promotes the general economic development of Scotland.
Encouragement is given to the development of rural industries. Much of this
work is done under the aegis of the Development Commission1 with finance
from the Development Fund, notably advice and guidance to small businesses
in rural areas and country towns and loans for assistance to tourism in the
rural parts of development areas. In England and Wales this service is
provided by the Council for Small Industries in Rural Areas acting in con¬
sultation with the Rural Community Councils through their Small Industries
Committees in the counties; by the Small Industries Council for Rural Areas
of Scotland; and in Northern Ireland by the Rural Industries Development
Committee of the Northern Ireland Council of Social Services. Another
service provided by the Commission is the financing of small factories to
stimulate rural industries and to combat rural depopulation.
Under the Finance Act 1968 hotels in certain rural parts of the develop¬
ment areas qualify for a refund of selective employment tax (see p. 365).
MANUFACTURING INDUSTRIES
Britain’s manufacturing industries supply a wide range of products, many of
which are of major importance in world trade. Output has increased by over
two-fifths since 1958, and in 1968 was 5-2 per cent higher than the previous
1 The Development Commission recommends, and the Treasury approves and
administers, advances by grants or loans from the Development Fund, established by
the Development and Road Improvement Funds Acts 1909 and 1910. At the present
time the Fund may be used to help and expand the rural economy (including accom¬
modation of tourists) and also to promote the development and improvement of
fisheries.

year; output per head showed an advance of 6-6 per cent in 1968, bringing the
rise since i960 to 26 per cent. In 1968 this sector spent £1,526 million on
fixed capital equipment, 70 per cent of which was spent on plant and
machinery. The number of employees in manufacturing industry (including
the unemployed and those absent from work through sickness and other
causes, but excluding employers and the self-employed) was 8-6 million in
June 1968, 38 per cent of the total number of employees.
The employment and production figures listed in Table 17 give an indica¬
tion of the relative importance of broad sectors of manufacturing industry.
Expansion has been particularly rapid in those industries utilising advanced
technologies such as electronics, the newer branches of mechanical engineer¬
ing, most branches of the chemical industry and man-made fibres. The
diagram on page 251 shows the changes in production between 1958 and 1968
in the major groups of industry.
In the subsequent sections, statistics of employees refer to numbers at
June 1968, and export statistics are taken mainly from the Overseas Trade
Accounts of the United Kingdom.

non-ferrous metals in 1968 had an aggregate value of £538 million.

INDUSTRY
Iron and Steel
257
Britain pioneered the application of coal to the smelting of iron ore from the
seventeenth century onwards and British inventors were responsible for the
discovery of the processes which led to the great expansion of steelmaking in
the second half of the nineteenth century. Today Britain is the world’s fifth
largest steel producing nation. Output of crude steel in 1968 totalled 25-9
million ingot tons, 8-2 per cent more than in 1967. Capacity utilisation in 1968
averaged 82 per cent, compared with 77 per cent in 1967. Total capacity at the
end of 1968 was almost 31-5 million tons. Pig iron production in 1968
amounted to 16-4 million tons.
Net deliveries of finished steel amounted to 20-7 million tons in 1968. The
4-5 million tons of iron and steel products which were exported had a value
of ^266 million; the United States (£58-7 million), Sweden (£13-8 million)
and Spain (£13 million) were the main overseas buyers.
The main producing districts are: South Wales (25 per cent of total crude
steel output); the north-east of England (16 per cent); Sheffield and district
(13 per cent); Scotland (12 per cent); Lincolnshire (12 per cent); and
Lancashire and Flintshire (10 per cent). South Wales concentrates mainly on
the manufacture of flat products, especially sheet steel and tinplate; the
output of the north-east coast and Scotland is predominantly of heavy steel
products (plates, sections and rails), but a wide strip mill for sheet production
is now in operation in Scotland. Production of special alloy steels is centred
on Sheffield.
During the period 1955-67 over £1,750 million was spent on major
development schemes. Capital expenditure reached a peak in 1961 of over
£230 million, due mainly to the strip mill expansion programme, falling back
to about £90 million in 1968. The emphasis is increasingly on improving
efficiency rather than raising total capacity. Britain has some of the most
modern plant in Europe, and by 1968 steel production by the converter
processes had increased from 8 per cent of output in i960 to nearly 30 per
cent; steel from electric furnaces had increased from 7 per cent to 16 per cent;
and the share of the older open hearth process had fallen from 84 per cent to
55 per cent.
Output per blast furnace has risen markedly in recent years, due both to an
increase in average size and to improvements in efficiency, such as improved
preparation of raw materials, the injection of fuel and oxygen, and the use of
higher blast temperatures. Industry-wide scientific and technological research
is carried out by the Inter-Group Laboratories of the British Steel Corpora¬
tion. Total annual expenditure by the industry is about £10 million.
Outstanding development projects completed in the last few years include
wide strip mills at new integrated works at Newport (Monmouthshire) and
at an existing works in Scotland; a new plant at Stoke-on-Trent, which is
based entirely on continuous casting for supplies of semi-finished steel; an
advanced unit for the mass production of alloy and special carbon steels at
Sheffield; the world’s largest electric melting shop and a steelworks in which
a linked three-computer system controls production planning throughout,
both at Rotherham.
The iron and steel industry has been subject to some form of public
supervision since 1932. The Iron and Steel Act 1967 brought into public
ownership 13 major steel companies together producing well over 90 per cent
of Britain’s crude steel and employing some 70 per cent of the manpower in
the industry. Their shares and securities were vested in July 1967 in the
British Steel Corporation. The Corporation’s specific duties include pro¬
moting the efficient and economic supply of iron and steel products, exports,
258
Iron Castings
Non-ferrous
Metals
MECHANICAL
ENGINEERING
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and research and development; it is statutorily responsible for the finances of
the nationalised industry. The Corporation’s second Report on Organisation,
published in March 1969, recommended the dissolution of the companies
taken into public ownership and the replacement of the four regional groups
set up in 1967 with a number of smaller divisions corresponding to products.
The remaining private sector includes some 200 companies accounting for
about one-third of the value of the industry’s sales.
Output of iron castings totalled 3-56 million tons in 1968, 0-5 million tons
less than the record level of 1965. The main users of iron castings are the
general engineering industry, accounting for nearly one-third of the total
tonnage sold and about one-half of the industry’s turnover, the motor vehicle
industry, the manufacturers of pressure pipes and fittings, the building and
associated industries and the steel industry. There are about 1,000 firms in
the iron founding industry with some 109,000 employees. Exports are
included in the total of steel exports in the previous section.
The non-ferrous metals industry is the largest in Europe and as a consumer
of aluminium, copper and lead Britain is second only to the United States
among western countries. Output in 1968 included: aluminium, 38,000 tons
of virgin metal and 185,000 tons of secondary metal; refined copper, 49,000
tons of virgin copper and 146,000 tons of secondary metal; lead, 141,000 tons
of secondary metal refined from scrap and 91,000 tons of virgin lead refined
from imported lead bullion; zinc, 141,000 tons of slab metal; and tin, 28,000
tons. Mining in Britain is confined to the small-scale working of tin, although
detailed investigation is taking place into the possibilities of a considerable
expansion in this field.
In 1968 exports of non-ferrous base metals were valued at £271-7 million.
The main products exported, including semi-finished products, were copper
and copper alloys (£89-9 million), nickel and its alloys (£44-6 million),
aluminium and its alloys (£21-1 million) and tin and its alloys (£16-4 million).
The United States (£50-9 million), the Federal Republic of Germany (£45-7
million), and Italy (£17 million) were the largest purchasing countries.
Indirect exports are also substantial.
Nearly half of the industry is situated in the Midlands; other centres
include South Wales, London, Tyneside and Avonmouth, where one of the
world’s largest zinc smelters (capacity 120,000 tons a year) came into
operation in May 1968. Firms are engaged in smelting, casting and fabrication
by rolling, extrusion and drawing and the techniques of powder metallurgy
and pressure diecasting are also employed. Two major aluminium smelters
(combined annual capacity 200,000 tons) are being built with government
loans at Invergorden (Scotland) and Anglesey (Wales). Together with a third,
being built at Lynemouth (Northumberland), they will provide over half the
domestic requirements by 1974.
Britain is also a major producer of the newer specialised metals including
uranium, zirconium and beryllium for the nuclear energy industry; niobium
for aircraft production; and selenium, silicon, germanium and tantalum for
electronic apparatus. Scientific and technological research for the industry as a
whole is conducted by the British Non-Ferrous Metals Research Association.
Mechanical engineering comprises a wide range of industries, including all
types of machinery, machine tools, engineers’ small tools, mechanical handling
equipment, construction equipment, industrial plant, ordnance and small
INDUSTRY

arms, watches and clocks, and scientific instruments. Vehicle engines are
included in the section on vehicles (p. 265). The number of employees is
1 -3 million and the volume of production from these industries rose by 53 per
cent between 1958 and 1968. The aggregate value of the main products
of all sections other than tractors, small arms, scientific instruments and
watches and clocks was ,£2,376 million in 1968. Exports of non-electric
machinery were valued at ;£ 1,269 million in 1968, 22 per cent more than
in 1967.
There are over 300 firms, employing 35,000 people, in the agricultural
machinery industry, including three large firms with more than 1,000 workers.
In 1968 deliveries, excluding tractors, were valued at £76 million and exports
were worth ^27-2 million; the main overseas markets were the Republic of
Ireland, France, the United States, and South Africa.
The number of self-propelled combine harvesters, forage harvesters, pick¬
up balers and grain driers in use has increased in Britain in recent years.
Deliveries in 1968 included 3,700 combine harvesters, 7,000 milking machines,
13,600 pick-up balers and 1,500 grain and grass driers.
The bulk of British tractor output and exports consists of agricultural tractors.
Some 179,000 agricultural and industrial wheeled tractors were delivered in
1968, 136,000 (73 per cent) for export. In addition, 32,100 small market garden
tractors were delivered. Exports of new agricultural and track-laying tractors
were valued at ,£97-4 million in 1968. Agricultural tractor production is
dominated by two large organisations. Tractors are exhibited at the annual
Royal Smithfield Show and Agricultural Machinery Exhibition in London;
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world (see p. 309).
Britain was the birthplace of the modern machine tool industry. The industry’s
output today ranges from watchmakers’ lathes weighing a few pounds to
machines weighing hundreds of tons, and to electronically controlled machine
tools giving accuracies of one-ten-thousandth part of an inch. Over 2,200
numerically controlled machine tools have been installed in Britain. The
Government, through the Ministry of Technology, is assisting the industry in
various ways, including pre-production purchase schemes, numerical control
advisory services and the placing of research and development contracts.
Deliveries of machine tools were valued at ,£153 million in 1968, compared
with ,£156 million in 1967. Exports in 1968 had a value of £59 million,
21 per cent up on 1967, and of the orders on hand at the end of December 1968
(£106 million), 46 per cent were for export. The United States (£10-8 million),
the Soviet Union (j£6-6 million), Australia (j£6-i million) and South Africa
(j£3-6 million) were the main overseas markets in 1968. Seven major groups
account for almost two-thirds of the industry’s output although the high
degree of specialisation makes it possible for the small firm to flourish. The
industry is centred mainly in the Midlands, Yorkshire and Lancashire, and to
a lesser extent near London and Glasgow. There are 59,000 persons
employed.
The Machine Tool Trades Association of Great Britain is the representative
body of most manufacturers and importers, and is responsible for the
International Machine Tool Exhibitions held in Britain every four years, the
next being due in 1972. The industry is served by its own research body,
the Machine Tool Industry Research Association, and its customers by the
Production Engineering Research Association.
