Britain manufactures a wide range of industrial engines. Deliveries of engines
(including parts) had a value of ^164 million in 1968 and exports (including
marine engines) were worth ^37-4 million; in addition, parts exported were
valued at £25-6 million. The total brake horse-power of the 330,000 internal
combustion engines delivered was 12-1 million, ranging in size from under
3 b.h.p. to over 4,000 b.h.p. Production is concentrated among the large firms
in the industry, and a total of 37,000 people are employed.
One of the oldest of Britain’s mechanical engineering industries, the textile
machinery industry’s range of output embraces all stages in textile manufac¬
turing processes. Deliveries in 1968 were valued at ^127-3 million and
exports (including products of some associated industries) at ^101-3 million.
Principal markets were the Soviet Union (^17-9 million), the United States
(£9 million), Pakistan (£8-5 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany
(£7 million).
The industry, which has 46,000 employees, comprises many firms and is
situated mainly in Lancashire, Yorkshire, Northern Ireland, Dundee,
Leicester and Nottingham. It makes a wide range of machines and accessories
for the manufacture and processing of yarns and fabrics from all types of
natural and man-made fibres.
Almost every industry makes use of mechanical handling equipment; the
products of the industry range from individual units and accessories to
complete operating systems. The value of deliveries in 1968 was ^167-5
million, the main products being cranes and bridge transporters, lifts,
escalators, conveyors, elevators and hoists. In addition, British firms produced
18,200 powered industrial trucks, including 13,400 fork-lift trucks. Exports
of mechanical handling equipment (including industrial and works trucks) in
1968 were valued at ^46-5 million. There are many small firms in the industry;
in all, 59,000 people are employed.
Almost the whole range of plant required by the construction industry is
produced. These include crawler tractors, motor graders, scrapers, trenchers,
dozer equipment, dumpers, excavators and loading shovels, and crushing,
pulverising and screening plant. The labour force numbers 39,600.
The value of deliveries from the industry was ^205-6 million in 1968; by
far the most important single item was earth-moving machinery including
crawler tractors (with a value of £167 million). Deliveries of contractors’
plant for export in 1968 totalled ^97-6 million; France, Australia, Spain
and Sweden are important markets.
The office machinery industry has been expanding rapidly. In 1968 the value
of deliveries of office machinery was £82-7 million including £42-8 million
for export. Deliveries in 1968 included 93,000 standard typewriters and 278,000
portable typewriters. The value of deliveries of accounting and similar
machinery was £45-8 million, of which ^26-3 million was for export, and of
other office machinery £26-g million, of which £14-6 million was for export.
Exports of all office machinery (including electronic computers and data pro¬
cessing equipment) were valued at £go million. The most important overseas
purchasers were the Federal Republic of Germany (^n million), the United
States (£10-4 million), France (£9-6 million) and Australia (£4-8 million).
British subsidiaries or associates of United States firms are prominent in the
office machinery industry. There are 52,000 persons employed.

The manufacture of engineers’ small tools and gauges is an expanding
industry; deliveries increased in value from ^55 million in 1959 to ^101
million in 1968; the main products were hard metal-tipped tools (^13 million),
other metal cutting tools (^43-2 million), jigs and fixtures (^17-2 million) and
press tools, moulds, etc. (£20-3 million). Export deliveries in 1968 totalled
£18 million. The industry has a labour force of 68,000 persons.
British industry manufactures almost every type of industrial plant and
steelwork, and 174,000 are employed in this branch. Of particular importance
are steam-raising boilers, lime and cement kilns, gas and coke oven plant,
sintering plant, metallurgical furnaces and plant, chemical and mineral oil
refining plant, nuclear reactors, water and sewage treatment plant, and
steelwork for bridges, buildings, etc. The industry has several large-scale
enterprises. In 1968 the aggregate value of deliveries (including rolling mills)
totalled £507 million.
British companies delivered water tube boilers to the value of £89-8 million
in 1968; shell boilers and other boilerhouse plant accounted for a further
£47-8 million. Water tube boilers of advanced design and of large steam¬
raising capacity are produced for power stations, whereas shell boilers are
used for steam-raising and heating in factories and buildings. Exports of
vapour generating boilers in 1968 amounted to £12-5 million.
The steelworks plant industry provides, in association with firms producing
rolling mills, almost all Britain’s requirements as well as plant for export.
The value of deliveries in 1968 was £26-5 million; rolling mills and ancillary
equipment accounted for a further ^14-4 million. This industry consists
of a small number of firms, most of which are business associates or members
of a consortium. Spain, Yugoslavia, Finland and South Africa are a few of the
countries in which British firms are undertaking major steelworks plant
projects.
The manufacture of specialised equipment for the chemical and oil refining
industries has expanded rapidly in recent years. Deliveries of chemical plant
were valued at £118 million in 1968 compared with £128 million in 1967.
Britain ranks second to the United States as a supplier of equipment for the
petroleum industry. The range of chemical plant produced includes distilla¬
tion columns, heat exchangers, high-vacuum drying equipment, and plant
for the manufacture of chemicals from all feedstocks including petroleum.
Two major consortia, consisting of leading firms in the heavy electrical
engineering, civil engineering, boiler, instrument, and associated industries,
were formed in 1968 to build nuclear power stations for the United Kingdom
electricity authorities (see p. 289). These replaced the three groups formed
in 1959. The Atomic Energy Authority grants them non-exclusive manu¬
facturing licences and is working in close collaboration with them in research
and development.
In addition to the mechanical engineering firms described in preceding
sections, there are about 2,000 enterprises whose principal product is a type
of machinery not so far mentioned. The main products include: mining
machinery, printing and book-binding machinery, refrigeration appliances,
space heating, ventilation and air-conditioning equipment, pumps and pump¬
ing machinery, industrial valves and cocks, compressors, scales and weighing
machinery, portable power tools, food preparing machinery and many other

This industry makes a wide range of equipment and appliances, extending
from domestic and commercial refrigerators of varying sizes to industrial
refrigeration equipment for cold stores, manufacture of chemicals and other
products, ice-making plant and refrigeration plant for ships. Total deliveries
of refrigerating machinery had a value of ^64 million in 1968; 878,000
domestic refrigerators wrere for the home market and 207,000 were exported.
The value of deliveries of space heating, ventilating and air-conditioning
equipment has been rising and in 1968 reached ^84-8 million. Exports were
valued at ^8-6 million.
Industrial valves controlling the movement of liquids and gases are a vital
component in many industrial processes, particularly in the chemicals, oil and
electric power industries. The value of deliveries of pumps and valves in 1968
was £161-8 million and that of air and gas compressors and exhausters £46-1
million. Exports of pumps and centrifuges totalled £58-4 million and exports
of industrial valves £29-6 million.
The value of deliveries of other major products in 1968 was: mining
machinery, £62-4. million; food and drink machinery, £52-9 million; pack¬
aging machinery, £32-4 million; and other machinery, £343 million.
Important export products in 1968 included: food and drink processing
machinery, £19-6 million; cigarette-making machinery, £13 million; paper¬
making machinery, £19-5 million; and printing and bookbinding machinery,
£25-2 million.
The industry manufactures photographic, scientific, surgical and industrial
instruments; it has a labour force of 139,000 persons. A rapidly expanding
sector is that making industrial process measuring and control instruments—
an essential element of automation in industry—deliveries of which amounted
to £75 million in 1968, compared with £41-3 million in i960. The value of
deliveries of other broad categories was: optical instruments, £10-2 million;
electric, electronic, and nucleonic instruments, £27-9 million; and nautical and
aeronautical instruments, £27 million. The total deliveries for 1968
amounted to £187 million.
Export deliveries of scientific instruments have been rising markedly,
amounting to £58 million in 1968, compared with £27-9 million in i960. The
Scientific Instrument Research Association conducts research on behalf of the
industry.
Deliveries of photographic equipment in 1968 totalled £12$ million, including
£55-2 million for export. The main products in 1968 were: film (other than
cinematograph film), £42-i million; sensitised paper and cloth, £23-9 million;
and cinematograph film, ^17-1 million. Deliveries of photographic cameras
were valued at £3-3 million.
The present industry is largely a post-war development. It employs 14,000
people, the great majority skilled craftsmen, and many of its factories are
located on new industrial estates in the older industrial areas, particularly in
Scotland. Output in 1968 included clocks (£7-9 million), watches (£5-3
million) and time switches {£8-9 million); export sales were valued at
£4-4 million.

263
Behind the firms manufacturing the major products outlined in this section
are nearly 4,000 enterprises, employing 247,000 people, whose main functions
are to supply parts and components, to conduct research and development
work, and to undertake general sub-contracting and repair work. (Some enter¬
prises are included because the mixed character of their work makes it
impossible to classify them under any single industry.) They include several
large undertakings with more than 5,000 employees. Ball and roller bearings,
and chains, are important products; exports of the former were valued at
£15-4 million in 1968, and exports of chains at £67 million.
The electrical engineering industry, with a labour force of 910,000, is engaged
in the manufacture and installation of a wide variety of electrical equipment,
including all types of generating, transmission and distribution equipment;
motors; telecommunications apparatus; domestic appliances; and specialised
laboratory and electronic equipment. Annual output rose in volume by
three-fifths between 1958 and 1968, and the total value of production in 1968
was estimated at over £2,500 million.
Exports of electrical machinery, apparatus and appliances in 1968 were
valued at £410 million, 19 per cent more than in 1967. Products are ex¬
ported to all parts of the world; in 1968 South Africa (£43-i million), the
United States (£31-6 million), Australia (£277 million), the Federal
Republic of Germany (£23-1 million) and Canada (£17-9 million) were the
main markets.
The industry’s leading representative organisation is the British Electrical
and Allied Manufacturers’ Association; scientific and technological research
on behalf of the industry as a whole is carried out by the Electrical Research
Association.
Electrical
Machinery
Electrical
and Radio
Equipment
British scientists and engineers have been responsible for many of the basic
advances in the generation and transmission of electric power. The experi¬
ments of Michael Faraday pointed the way to the production of electricity
as a source of cheap and abundant power. Sir Charles Parsons produced and
patented the first turbo-dynamo, the forerunner of the giant turbo-generating
sets of today.
In 1968 deliveries of electrical machinery were valued at £456 million,
comprising ^173 million worth of rotating electrical machinery (motors,
generators and rotary converters), £61-5 million worth of transformers for
lighting, heating and power, £187 million worth of switchgear and control
gear and £33-8 million worth of other electrical machinery.
Exports of generators, motors, converters, transformers and rectifiers
amounted to £59-6 million in 1968, the main purchasers being Australia
(j£6-8 million) and the United States (£5-6 million). Switchgear, starting and
control gear exports were valued at £57-2.
About 600 firms manufacture electrical machinery, but recent mergers have
led to the creation of the largest electrical engineering group in Europe and
the trend is towards larger units of control. The total labour force numbers
213,000. Manufacture takes place in many areas, including Manchester,
Rugby, Tyneside, Stafford and Larne (Northern Ireland).
Production of electronic equipment is one of the most rapidly expanding of
British industries. United Kingdom scientists and inventors have made many
basic contributions to electronics—the thermionic valve, the development of
radar, the first public transmission television service, and the ‘printed circuit’,

which has led to far-reaching changes in methods of production in the radio
industry. The industry employs 350,000 people.
Total deliveries of electronic equipment (excluding telephone apparatus)
were valued in 1968 at £423-8 million, including £153 million for export.
(Indirect exports incorporated in ships, aircraft and machinery are consider¬
able.) Computers are the most important product of the capital equipment
sector, which accounts for 26 per cent of total output. Britain has the largest
indigenous computer industry outside the United States and has supplied
over 1,500 installations in Britain. The merger in 1968 of the two major
British computer concerns created a single group, responsible for almost
all domestic output. Deliveries, which have more than doubled in the last
three years, were valued at £110 million in 1968 and exports at £43-6
million.
Deliveries of radar and navigational aids were valued at £97 million in 1968,
over six times the i960 level, and over one-third of total output was exported.
Three-quarters of the world’s radar-fitted merchant ships use British equip¬
ment, as do most of the world’s civil airports outside the American continent.
All-weather landing systems and inertial (automatic) navigation systems are
amongst recent developments. Other important items of capital equipment
include electronic control equipment (£53 million), radio communications
equipment (£44 million) and electronic measuring and testing equipment
(£43 million).
The consumer goods sector of the industry manufactures radio and television
sets and radiograms. The industry is dominated by several large firms.
Output of television sets in 1968 rose to 1-96 million (including 140,000 colour
television sets); the total sales value of £93-6 million was almost all in the
home market. Production of radios and radiograms numbered 1-74 million in
1968 and total sales were worth £21-6 million.
The industry produces cables and wires for the distribution of electric power,
for telegraph and telephone networks and for many other purposes; its
products include submarine cables and cables insulated by a great variety of
materials. It is supplying the high voltage cable to carry the expanding output
of electric power in Britain (see p. 288). The value of deliveries in 1968 was
a record £274 million. Exports of electric cables, wires, etc., were worth
£42-6 million; the main purchasers were South Africa and the United States.
The industry has a labour force of 58,000 persons and includes three firms
with over 5,000 employees.
Britain is one of the largest exporters of telegraph and telephone equipment.
Shipments overseas had a value of £34-3 million in 1968. Research and
development work is done by firms in the industry in co-operation with the
Post Office. The industry employs 91,000 persons, and three firms are
responsible for almost all output.
Deliveries of other electrical goods in 1968 included domestic electrical
appliances, £182-3 million; electrical equipment for motor vehicles, cycles
and aircraft, £106-1 million; batteries and accumulators, £64-5 million;
electric lamps, £34-9 million; and other electrical goods, £117-8 million. In
terms of volume, deliveries included: 1-5 million electric blankets, i-8 million
vacuum cleaners, 0-9 million domestic washing machines and 2-3 million
electric irons. In 1968 exports of domestic electrical equipment were valued at

and accumulators in 1968 were valued at ^15'7 million. The industry has a

The industries which manufacture vehicles and aircraft provide a significant
contribution to exports; exports of transport equipment in 1968 had a value of
£910 million, accounting for almost 15 per cent of total exports. The labour
force numbers 1,001,000 and includes: 473,000 in motor vehicle manufacture,
240,000 in aircraft construction and repairing, 192,000 in shipbuilding and
marine engineering, 65,000 in the manufacture of locomotives and railway
wagons and carriages, 25,000 in cycle and motor cycle manufacturing, and
4,500 in the making of perambulators and hand trucks.
In both size and value the largest section of the vehicle industry comprises the
manufacture of cars and commercial vehicles.
The industry was at one time located mainly in the Midlands and London
areas, but during the past decade manufacturing and assembly plants have
been established on Merseyside, in Wales and in Scotland.
Car and commercial vehicle output is dominated by the four largest firms
(British Leyland Motor Corporation, Ford, Rootes and Vauxhall), which
account for over 95 per cent of complete vehicle production; the balance is
in the hands of smaller, specialist producers of heavy commercial vehicles,
omnibuses, coaches, limousines and sports cars. The principal trade associa¬
tion is the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT), which
holds a motor show annually in London and a Commercial Motor Exhibition
every two years. The Motor Industry Research Association carries out
collective research on vehicles and components.
Car output in 1968 totalled 1-82 million units, compared with 1-56 million
units in 1967* Exports in 1968 amounted to 677,000 cars with a record value
of ^280 million, one-third higher than in 1967. The United States (^58-8
million) was again the largest single purchaser, followed by Canada (£21-5
million), Belgium and Australia. About one-fifth of all exports went to BETA
member countries and one-fifth to the EEC.
Production of commercial vehicles, including chassis, increased from 146,000
in 1946 to 409,000 in 1968. Exports in 1968 of new commercial vehicles
numbered 142,000 with a record total value of ^122-5 million. Australia
(£i5‘i million), South Africa (^14-8 million) and EFTA countries (^16-2
million) were the main markets for commercial vehicles. Since 1961 Britain
has been one of the world’s largest exporters of commercial vehicles. The
prototype of a gas-turbine powered commercial vehicle was demonstrated
in 1968.
Exports of parts and accessories for cars and commercial vehicles in 1968 had
a value of ^181 million; engines and parts for motor vehicles were valued at
a further £61-2 million. Caravan and trailer exports totalled £10-5 million.
Deliveries of bicycles have declined in recent years, but in 1968 amounted to
1-5 million, slightly more than the previous year. About 80 per cent of British
manufacturing capacity is in the hands of a single group of companies, and
output is concentrated in the Nottingham area. About 931,000 cycles worth
^8-9 million were sent overseas in 1968; the United States (^2-7 million) was

much the largest single market. A small-wheel bicycle, developed in Britain,
is the first major technical change in the bicycle for 60 years.
Deliveries of all types of motor cycle amounted to 96,200 in 1968. The total
included 10,800 mopeds and 12,200 three-wheeled vehicles. Manufacture is
dominated by one large group. Exports of motor cycles and parts totalled
^19-1 million in 1968, with the United States by far the biggest market.
The British Railways Board has its own workshops which supply British
Railways and certain other users in Britain; private firms build locomotives,
carriages and wagons for British Railways, for industrial users and for export.
Deliveries in 1968 included 75 electric locomotives, all of which were for
export, 188 diesel and diesel-electric locomotives, 635 coaching vehicles and
2,900 wagons. The total value of exports of railway vehicles and parts in 1968
was £12-2 million; Kenya (^1-9 million), South Africa and Pakistan were the
largest purchasers.
Almost all the aircraft produced by the British industry today are based on
civil and military applications of the gas-turbine aero-engine, first developed
by Sir Frank Whittle. The most notable turbo-prop aircraft in current
production and operation are the Hawker Siddeley 7^5, of which 200 have
been sold or are on order, and the Handley Page Herald. A second generation
of jet airliners, the medium-haul Trident, the longer-haul Vickers VC 10,
the BAG One-Eleven, the world’s first jet transport designed to operate
economically on short-haul routes, have been in service for over five years.
Other civil aircraft in production include the HS125 executive jet, the Beagle
range of light aircraft, using piston and turbo-prop engines, the Handley
Page Jetstream executive airliner seating up to 18 passengers, the Sky van
and the Islander, an economical feeder-line aircraft. The Concorde, the world’s
first supersonic airliner, developed jointly by Britain and France, made its
maiden flight in February 1969.
The industry produces a wide range of military aircraft, including the
Jaguar, in collaboration with France, and the Harrier vertical take-off strike
aircraft. It is also engaged on work on rockets, earth satellites and other aero¬
space requirements, including the Blue Streak and Black Arrow satellite
launchers.
Hovercraft, a new type of transport vehicle invented in Britain, are being
increasingly used throughout the world. More than 130 have been built in
Britain up to 1969 and a number of types, including a 160-ton version, the
SRN 4, are in production or under development.
In 1968 exports of the aerospace industry totalled £282 million, 54 per cent
up on 1967. Exports of new aircraft and parts in 1968 (excluding electrical
equipment) had a value of ,£135-1 million, compared with £97-6 million in
1967. Leading buyers included the United States (£25-5 million) and the
Federal Republic of Germany (^9-8 million). In addition, exports of instru¬
ments were worth ,£3-9 million, and tyres £i-2 million.
The construction of aircraft is dominated by two large airframe manufac¬
turers and one helicopter concern, though there are a few important smaller
companies outside these groups. Besides extensive research work by the
industry, research on a substantial scale on problems of aircraft and their
engines is carried out by the Government, chiefly at the Royal Aircraft
Establishment and the National Gas Turbine Establishment, both at Farn-
borough, and the Royal Aircraft Establishment at Bedford. The British

aero-space industry has over 50 collaboration agreements with overseas

Aero-engines and parts provided some £966 million in export earnings from
1946 to 1968. In 1968 exports of new and used engines and parts totalled
^146-8 million (two-thirds more than in 1967); major customers were the
United States (£74 million), France (^18-9 million) and the Federal Republic
of Germany (^6-i million). Twelve different British jet engines power over
30 types of aircraft currently in production overseas. Famous engines in
production include the economical Dart turbo-prop, the Spey turbo-jet and
the revolutionary Pegasus lift-thrust engine for vertical take-off and landing
(VTOL) aircraft. Advanced technology turbofan engines, currently under
development, have secured large overseas orders as power plants for air¬
buses. The power plant for the Concorde is a further development of the
Olympus.
One company is responsible for almost all aero-engine production.
The building of large ocean-going vessels is concentrated in four main areas:
the river Clyde in Scotland, the north-east and north-west coasts of England
and Belfast in Northern Ireland. Numerous yards around the coast build
smaller vessels such as fishing vessels, yachts and harbour craft.
Co-operative research into shipbuilding and marine engineering is under¬
taken by the British Ship Research Association with its headquarters and a
research station on the river Tyne.
A gradual fall in tonnage launched from the 1955 peak of 1 - 5 million tons was
halted in 1964, and launchings in 1968 totalled 0-9 million gross tons, 400,000
tons below the 1967 level. British launchings were the fourth largest in the
world in 1968 accounting for 5-3 per cent of the world total, compared with
8-2 per cent in 1967. Eighteen oil tankers, totalling 80,800 gross tons, vrere
launched in 1968. Launchings also included 25 bulk carriers totalling 552,000
gross tons and 11 cargo ships between 8,000 and 10,000 gross tons. At the
end of 1968 orders on hand for merchant vessels of 100 gross tons and over
were 233 (180 in 1967) totalling 3-6 million gross tons with a value of ^401
million, 57 per cent higher than in 1967. Of these vessels, 66 (1-2 million
gross tons) were for export.
Modernisation in British shipyards over the last few years has involved the
replanning of yards, the erection of large prefabrication shops for welding
massive sections under cover, the installation of heavy-lift travelling cranes,
and much other reconstruction. A new building dock, nearing completion at
Belfast, will be capable of accommodating the largest vessels required in the
future.
Large-scale mergers on Tyneside and Clydeside, and plans for re-grouping
in other areas, have resulted from proposals of the Shipbuilding Industry
Board, established in 1965.
There are many specialist ship-repairing establishments and most of the
larger shipbuilding firms also carry out repair work; about one-quarter of
ship-repairing activity is concentrated on the north-east coast of England.
Repair yards and dry docks are situated in all the large ports.
Many of the larger shipbuilding yards maintain or have closely associated
engine building works, constructing various types of marine slow-speed diesel
engines, usually under licence. One firm designs large low-speed diesel engines

and there are two independent builders of these engines. Steam turbines of
the highest powers are also built.
The group of industries manufacturing metal products not already described
consists of a large number of companies with a total labour force of 559,000
in 1968; the main groups were bolts, nuts and screws (44,000 persons), wire
and wire manufactures (42,000), cans and metal boxes (34,000), jewellery,
plate, and refining of precious metals (27,000), tools and implements (22,000),
cutlery (12,600), and other metal industries (377,000). The total value of
exports in 1968 was about £176 million.
The production of cutlery and flatware is centred mainly in the city of
Sheffield and the industry’s reputation has been built up on the skill of its
craftsmen. Mass-production methods are, however, extensively used except
in the case of some of the highest quality wares, although firms remain mainly
small. The value of sales of cutlery and flatware in 1968 was £15-1 million,
including export sales of £4 million.
This industry, located mainly in the Midlands, Lancashire, Yorkshire, South
Wales and London, produces a wide range of domestic utensils, such as
saucepans, buckets and dustbins, mainly from aluminium and wrought steel.
The value of sales in 1968 was ^23-9 million, of which £2-9 million were sales
for export.
The manufacture of hand tools is one of the oldest British industries, covering
the manufacture of such tools as files, saws, hammers, axes and spades;
Sheffield, Birmingham and other Midland towns are the most important
centres. The value of sales of implements and tools, other than machine tools
and portable power tools, was £41-7 million in 1968, of which £13 million
worth were exported; the totals included sales of hand tools, at home and for
export, valued at £24-6 million and ^12-8 million respectively.
The making of jewellery, gold and silver ware and the refining of precious
metals is an industry in which British craftsmen are heirs to a long tradition.
Most of the firms in the industry are small. The law requires that gold and
silver plate shall not be sold until it has been hall-marked at one of the Assay
Offices situated in London, Birmingham, Sheffield and Edinburgh. The
Birmingham office, located in the main centre of the jewellery industry, is by
far the most important. The total value of sales of jewellery, goldsmiths’ and
silversmiths’ wares and electro-plated nickel silver wares in 1968 was £29-6
million, of which £5-2 million was for export.
The chemicals industry, with a labour force of 460,000, comprises the manu¬
facture of: chemicals, dyestuffs, fertilisers and pesticides (223,000 employees),
pharmaceutical and toilet preparations (77,000 employees), explosives and
fireworks (26,000 employees), paint and printing ink (46,000 employees), oils,
fats, soap and detergents (35,000 employees), synthetic resins and plastics
(39,000 employees), polishes, gelatine and adhesives (15,000 employees). The
industry is capital intensive; the fixed capital expenditure of the industry,
excluding mineral oil refining, amounted to over ^1,188 million during the five
years 1962-67 and totalled £233 million in 1968. The value of exports in 1968
was £S99 million, or 9-7 per cent of total British exports. Production in the
general chemicals industries rose by 86 per cent between 1958 and 1968.

269
Over half the output of the inorganic chemicals industry consists of a limited
number of relatively simple chemicals, such as sulphuric acid, caustic soda,
chlorine and ammonia, produced in very large quantities and serving as basic
materials for industry. Sulphuric acid has the largest production of any
chemical and 3 -3 million tons were produced in 1968. The remaining output of
this sector consists of a very wide range of chemicals of varying complexity.
Substantial quantities of inorganic chemicals are used in the manufacture
of such products as fertilisers, detergents, paint, glass and metals. About
one-sixth of output is estimated to be exported directly.
Production of organic chemicals (which include coal-tar chemicals) rose
by 196 per cent between 1958 and 1968. To an increasing extent petroleum is
the raw material used and it is estimated that in 1968 petroleum-based
chemicals accounted for 78 per cent of the total output of organic chemicals;
deliveries of feedstock for the petroleum chemical plants totalled 5-3 million
tons in 1968 compared with i-i million tons in 1959. The most important
products (by weight) in 1968 were ethylene (691,000 tons) and propylene
(411,000 tons). The main outlets for organic chemicals are plastics materials,
solvents, synthetic rubber, man-made fibres and detergents. Consumption of
dyestuffs is geared to demand by the textile industry; about 31,000 tons of
synthetic dyestuffs were produced in 1968.
Exports of chemical elements and compounds amounted to £151-4 million
in 1968. Exports go to a large number of countries including, in 1968, the
Netherlands (£20-9 million), the United States (£8 million), Australia (£7-7
million), France (^7-7 million), Sweden, and the Federal Republic of Germany.
The first plastic, Parkesine (later called Celluloid), was produced and patented
in Britain in 1865 by Alexander Parkes; other British discoveries include
polyethylene. Plastics manufacture is one of the fastest growing sections of the
economy. Output of synthetic resins has increased by 217 per cent since 1958
and total production in 1968 was 1,243,000 tons (an increase of 14 per cent over
1967), of which 873,000 tons consisted of thermoplastic resins.
Expansion in recent years has mainly been in thermoplastic materials, of
which the most important are polyethylene (used in coverings and packaging—
notably for foodstuffs), polyvinyl chloride (known as PYC and used for a
wide range of industrial purposes and consumer goods) and polystyrene
(a cheap non-inflammable material used for toys, light mouldings and many
consumer goods). One of the newer thermoplastic materials is polypropylene,
a versatile material which can be fabricated as mouldings, films and fibres.
A new family of plastic materials is now in commercial production in Britain.
Reinforced with carbon fibres, the materials are up to three times the strength
but only half the weight of steel. Rapid expansion of capacity for all the main
types of plastics materials is planned. Exports in 1968 amounted to 433,000
tons, valued at ^110-4 million. The main purchasers were Australia (£11-4
million), South Africa (£8-5 million), Sweden (£7-4 million) and the United
States (£7 million).
The first general purpose synthetic rubber to be manufactured on a com¬
mercial scale in the United Kingdom was marketed in 1958. High styrene
rubbers for shoe soles and flooring, and nitrile rubbers for use where oil
resistance is required, are in large-scale production, and neoprene rubber is
manufactured in Northern Ireland. Production in 1968 amounted to 233,000
tons, most of which came from the styrene-butadiene plant at Hythe, near
Southampton. Exports of synthetic rubber and latex totalled 69,000 tons.

The development of artificial fertilisers owes much to the pioneer work of
the British scientists Sir John Lawes and Sir Joseph Gilbert. Two firms
predominate in the production of fertilisers and there are a number of firms
marketing compound fertilisers from the principal constituents—nitrogen,
phosphorus and potassium. To encourage use, sales on the home market are
assisted by government subsidies paid to the farmer (see p. 312). Output of
nitrogenous fertilisers (in terms of nitrogen content) has been increasing and
in 1967-68 totalled 842,000 tons, while 435,000 tons (in terms of phosphate
content) of phosphatic fertilisers were produced; production of compound
fertilisers amounted to 2-9 million tons in 1967-68. The use of ammonium
nitrate (35 per cent nitrogen), ammonium phosphate, and, to a limited extent,
urea (mostly 45 per cent nitrogen) is resulting in more concentrated fertilisers.
The value of exports of manufactured fertilisers, mainly nitrogenous, was
£7-2 million in 1968.
Manufacturers’ sales of paint and varnish during 1968 amounted to over
98 million gallons (including 15 million gallons of emulsion paint) valued at
£144 million. Britain is one of the largest exporters of paints in the world;
exports of pigments, paints, varnishes and related materials in 1968 amounted
to £39 million. The industry’s indirect contribution to exports in the form of
surface coatings for finished goods is also considerable.
In recent years many improved techniques have been introduced, in
particular, new ranges of synthetic resins and pigments; quick-drying paints
and paints needing only one application have been developed.
The whole range of drugs is produced in the United Kingdom, including
antibiotics, sulphonamides, anti-malarial drugs, anti-histamine products,
anaesthetics, vaccines, sera and naturally occurring drugs. Research expendi¬
ture totalled £15 million in 1968.
Notable British contributions to the development of new products include:
the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its evaluation by Sir
Howard Florey and E. B. Chain; the evaluation of sulphapyridine (M & B 693)
by Sir Lionel Whitby; the discovery of griseofulvin; and, more recently,
the isolation of the penicillin nucleus and the development of several
semi-synthetic penicillins and the cephalosporin antibiotics. Several of the
larger pharmaceutical companies in Britain are subsidiaries of overseas
firms.
In 1968 exports of medicinal and pharmaceutical products and goods rose
by 23 per cent to the record level of ^96-1 million, of which -£25-3 million
worth were antibiotics. The largest purchasers were the Republic of Ireland
(j£5'3 million), Australia (^4-9 million), France (£4 million) and the United
States (£4 million).
Notable discoveries by the British crop protection industry include the
insecticidal activity of BHC (benzene hexachloride), the first selective weed¬
killer, MCPA, and more recently Gramoxone, a non-residual general
herbicide based on paraquat. Sales of pesticides and allied products were
valued at £33 million in 1968, 18 per cent higher than in 1967; herbicides
(£22 million) were the largest single category. Exports of insecticides,
fungicides and weedkillers in 1968 totalled j£i8*6 million, 21 per cent more
than in 1967.

Sales of toilet preparations were valued at £123 million in 1968, including
export sales of £17-4 million; home market sales of hair preparations totalled
about ^31 million. Petroleum is the source of the principal raw materials
used in the manufacture of organic surface-active agents in detergents; the
other main constituent, polyphosphates, is derived from inorganic sources.
Sales of synthetic detergents amounted to 414,000 tons in 1968, including
70,000 tons for export. Deliveries of soap totalled some 311,000 tons; two
companies supply about 90 per cent of home sales. Sales of polishes in 1968
were valued at ^18-7 million, including floor and furniture polishes worth
j£8-7 million. Exports of perfumery and toilet preparations, soap and asso¬
ciated products were valued at ^52-1 million.
The textile industries in 1968 had a labour force of 690,000 persons, half of
whom are women; 43,000 employees are engaged in the production of man¬
made fibres, 86,000 in the spinning and doubling of cotton, flax and man-made
fibres, 76,000 in the weaving of cotton, linen and man-made fibres, 110,624
in the woollen and worsted trades, 129,000 in hosiery and knitted goods,
61,000 in textile finishing and 44,800 in carpets. The total value of textile
exports in 1968 at £300 million wras one-fifth more than in 1967. Production
of textiles rose by 13 per cent in 1968 and was 29 per cent higher than in 1958.
Considerable vertical integration is taking place connected with the
increasing use of man-made fibres. Four multi-fibre, multi-process groups,
founded under the leadership of man-made fibres manufacturers, control the
bulk of Britain’s spinning and warp knitting activities.
Anew statutory body, the Textile Council for the Man-made Fibres, Cotton
and Silk Industries, was established in 1967 superseding the Cotton Board.
It is financed by a levy on the industry.
Scientific and technical research for the industry is carried out principally
by the Cotton, Silk and Man-made Fibres Research Association.
Cotton was Britain’s chief consumer goods industry and cotton piece-goods
its largest export during the nineteenth century. Increasing low-cost competi¬
tion has cut progressively into British markets and a global limit has been
placed on imports of cotton goods from most countries during 1966-70.
Output in 1968 consisted of: 376 million lb. of single cotton yarn, 149
million lb. of spun man-made fibre and mixture single yarn, 225 million lb. of
doubled yarn, 60 million lb. of textured yarn, 733 million linear yards of
woven cotton cloth, and 556 million linear yards of man-made fibre and
mixture cloth. In 1968 exports of cotton yarn and woven fabrics (excluding
man-made fibres) were worth ^37-8 million, including woven fabrics valued
at £27 million, for which the Irish Republic and South Africa were the most
important markets.
Most of the industry is located in Lancashire, the north-east of the county
being mainly concerned with weaving and the south-east with spinning.
Manchester is the commercial centre and Liverpool is the chief port of entry
for raw cotton. Under legislation to assist the reorganisation of the industry,
Exchequer funds have paid for two-thirds of the cost of removing surplus
capacity, and also provided grants of about one-quarter towards the cost of
approved re-equipment and modernisation schemes.
The wool textile industry, one of the largest in the world, is the most ancient of
Britain’s staple industries and has been important since medieval times. There
are two main branches—woollen and worsted. The small or medium-sized

business predominates, with only a few large firms. While the West Riding of
Yorkshire is by far the most important producing area, Scotland and the West
of England remain famous as specialised producers of high-quality woollen
cloth. In recent years an increasing amount of man-made fibre has been
blended with wool.
In 1968 output included 213 million lb. of wool and hair tops and 325
million lb. of woollen yarn. Deliveries of worsted yarn amounted to 217
million lb. and of woven fabrics to 295 million square yards. In addition,
large quantities of raw wool are scoured and cleaned in Britain. Consumption
of raw wool in 1968 was 391 million lb., compared with 509 million lb. in 1959.
Exports in 1968 included wool yarns (£20 million), woollen fabrics (^40-5
million) and wool worsted fabrics (^23 million). The main buyers of woollen
fabrics were the United States (£5-3 million), Canada and Japan. Raw wool
(cleaned or scoured in Britain) and other animal hair and tops exported had
a value of £49 million. Research is carried on mainly by the Wool Industries
Research Association.
Much of the early development of viscose rayon and acetate took place in
Britain. Production is spread throughout the country with Northern Ireland
of growing importance. Large firms predominate in the industry. There has
been a rapid expansion of output in recent years, the 1963 record total of
1,187 million lb. being 24 per cent higher than in 1967 and 42 per cent more
than in 1964. Output consisted of 656 million lb. of staple fibre and 533 million
lb. of filament yarn in 1968. Of the staple fibre, 66 million lb., and of the
continuous filament, 75 million lb., were of fully synthetic materials.
Two main types of man-made fibres are manufactured: those made from
cellulose (such as rayon) and those produced by fully synthetic processes from
chemical substances (such as nylon). Viscose rayon is still the most widely
used of all man-made fibres and output in 1968 totalled 479 million lb. The
world’s largest rayon staple factory is at Greenfield (North Wales), with an
annual output of over 200 million lb., while other large rayon plants are at
Grimsby, Preston and Wolverhampton. Almost all the rayon produced in
Britain is made by a single company and its subsidiaries.
Production of nylon, the first fully synthetic fibre, in the form of nylon 66,
started in Britain in 1941; another type of nylon (nylon 6) has been manu¬
factured since 1963. Total productive capacity for nylon has increased from
160 million lb. a year in 1964, to almost 250 million lb. at the end of 1968.
Terylene, a polyester fibre, was invented in Britain during the second
world war. It is resistant to fading and is particularly suited to blending with
wool. Annual manufacturing capacity totals about 115 million lb. A group
of fibres of growing importance are the acrylic fibres: Courtelle (a British
discovery) and Acrilan are examples. Synthetic elastomerics or spandex
fibres, which are man-made textile fibres having inherent properties of stretch
and recovery, are now produced commercially.
Exports of man-made fibre yarns had a value of j£5o-6 million in 1968,
and woven fabrics ^19-6 million. Switzerland, the Federal Republic of
Germany and the Republic of Ireland were the most important purchasers
of yarns.
The hosiery and knitwear industry is predominantly one of small-scale
enterprises. The industry is widely distributed, with Scotland and the east
Midlands as the two most important centres. Sales of knitted goods were
valued at £388 million in 1968 including £139 million worth of outerwear

amounted to ^11-4 million. The British Hosiery and Knitwear Export Group
co-ordinates the export activities of the industry and organises overseas
missions. The Hosiery and Allied Trades Research Association, with
laboratories at Nottingham, undertakes collective research.
The linen industry is concentrated in Northern Ireland (the greatest linen¬
manufacturing region in the world), with most of the remainder in Scotland.
Broadly speaking, the Northern Ireland industry concentrates on yarns
and the lighter types of fabrics, while in Scotland production is largely of
coarse linens and canvas, although household types are also produced.
Northern Ireland manufacturers produced 38 million linear yards of cloth
in 1968, while weavers in Great Britain delivered 23 million square yards,
including 14 million square yards of sailcloth and canvas. Exports in 1968
included £7-8 million worth of linen fabrics and ^3-3 million worth of flax
yarns and linen thread.
Jute is manufactured on a large scale in the Dundee area—the centre of the
world’s oldest jute industry—and 15,000 people are employed in all. Jute is
used in the manufacture of carpets, cordage, ropes and woven into fabrics for
a wide range of uses in the packaging, carpet, upholstery, building and motor
car industries. Research is being undertaken into new uses, for example,
plastics reinforcement. In 1968, 109,000 tons of raw jute were used, and
exports of jute fabric and yarn totalled £3 million.
Sales of finished lace goods amounted to £17 million in 1968. The most
important lace product is from the warp knitting machines, with sales valued
at £10 million. Exports were worth ^4-5 million in 1968.
In addition to the products mentioned above, British textile firms manufacture
a wide range of other goods, including many special yarns and fabrics, net,
household textiles such as blankets, tablecloths and curtains, and floor
coverings other than carpets. Sales of narrow fabrics (including elastic
machinery belting and ribbon) totalled £50 million in 1968, including export
sales of j£6-8 million. Sales of floor coverings of linoleum, vinyl and other
synthetic materials were valued at £35-7 million in 1968; just under one-sixth
were for export. The cordage industry is the largest in Europe. Exports of
ropes, cordage, nets and netting in 1968 were valued at £4 million.
In 1968 total sales of all types of carpets and rugs amounted to 136-2 million
square yards, valued at £195-7 million. Exports in 1968 had a value of £21-7
million; Australia (£4-1 million) was the largest single market.
There are over 130 enterprises engaged in the manufacture of carpets,
including several large firms. In addition to the manufacture of woven carpets
such as Axminster and Wilton, almost one-half of total sales by quantity in
1968 were of tufted carpets, a form of carpeting in which the pile, usually
containing a high proportion of artificial fibres, is inserted into a pre-woven
backing. Axminster-type carpets account for about 35 per cent of the value of
exports. The principal manufacturing centres include Kidderminster (in
Worcestershire), Halifax and Dewsbury (in the West Riding of Yorkshire),
Glasgow and Kilmarnock (in Scotland) and several towns in Northern
Ireland. About a third of the carpets produced (by quantity) are made

There are 543,000 employees in the clothing, leather and footwear industries.
Some 389,000 are in the clothing industry, 98,000 in the footwear trade and
56,000 in leather, leather goods and fur manufacture. The aggregate value of
their exports in 1968 was ^138 million.
The British clothing industry is the largest in Europe and total deliveries
of made-up clothing have increased by 35 per cent since 1958. Exports in 1968,
excluding knitted goods, were valued at £55-9 million; the United States
(^57 million) was the main purchaser. Substantial quantities of clothing are
also sent by parcel post.
Although there are some large firms employing mass-production methods
on an increasing scale, the typical firm is small. The principal manufacturing
centres are London, Leeds and Manchester, but several firms are also situated
on industrial trading estates throughout the country. Fashion is important in
the production of haute couture models and throughout the ready-to-wear
industry. The Clothing Export Council, representing over 200 companies,
organises promotions for various sectors of the industry.
Leather tanning is one of Britain’s oldest industries. In 1968, some 12,000 tons
of sole and other heavy leather and about 435 million square feet of upper,
lining and other light leathers were produced. Britain is one of the world’s
leading exporters with exports in 1968 valued at £28-2 million. The United
States is the largest single market (j£6-i million in 1968), followed by Canada
(£4-1 million) and the Federal Republic of Germany.
Tanneries are situated in most parts of Britain, but there are important
concentrations in Lancashire, Cheshire, Yorkshire, the north Midlands and
the London area. Many different types of leather are produced, ranging from
the heavy types for industrial uses, such as machinery belting, to high quality
leather for footwear, leather goods, gloves and clothing. The British Leather
Manufacturers’ Research Association is the foremost of its type in the
world.
The British footwear industry is the third largest in the world. In 1968
manufacturers’ sales of footwear totalled 201 million pairs. Exports of all
types had a value of ^26-1 million; the United States (£7-3 million), the
Soviet Union and Canada were the largest markets.
Factories are located throughout Britain. Some areas concentrate on
production of particular types; for example, the Rossendale Valley region
of Lancashire on slippers, and Leicester and Norwich on women’s and girls’
shoes. The Shoe and Allied Trades Research Association enjoys a world-wide
reputation in all matters connected with shoemaking.
The food, drink and tobacco industries employ 869,000 persons in the
production of a great variety of goods. The value of their combined exports
in 1968 was ^370 million. Exports of alcoholic and other beverages accounted
for £197 million; sugar, sugar preparations and honey for £25 million;
cereal and cereal preparations for £40 million; fruit and vegetables for
^15-8 million; and coffee, cocoa, tea and spices for 3^17-7 million.
Many of the industry’s leading firms have been involved in mergers, or
have announced merger plans.

The household consumption of bread, which has been falling, averaged about
2 lb. 6 oz. per head per week in 1968. The trend is heavily towards concen¬
trating production in large mechanical bakeries; well over two-thirds of the
bread is made in these bakeries, which specialise in sliced and wrapped loaves;
four groups have a dominant position. In the smaller bakeries production of
cake and other flour confectionery is usually allied to bread production. There
are 164,000 employees in the bread and flour confectionery industry; a further
43,000 are employed in grain-milling.
There are 53,000 employees producing biscuits, and annual output has been
over 550>00° tons in recent years. Weekly consumption of cakes and biscuits
per head in Britain was 11-9 oz. in 1968. British biscuits have gained a world¬
wide reputation, and, despite the problem of import restrictions in several
overseas markets, exports in 1968 were valued at ^11-9 million.
The chocolate and sugar confectionery industry, which has 95,000 employees,
is composed of a small number of very large manufacturers and many medium¬
sized and small firms. The main ingredients used by the industry are sugar,
cocoa beans, glucose, milk, nuts and fats. Production of chocolate and
sugar confectionery was 668,000 tons in 1968. Consumption of chocolate
and sugar confectionery in the United Kingdom is far higher than in any
other country, being equivalent to 7-7 oz. per head per week.
The value of exports in 1968 of cocoa preparations (including chocolate)
was £i4‘9 million and of sugar confectionery, ^16-1 million. The Republic
of Ireland and Canada were the main markets for cocoa preparations. About
30 per cent of total world exports of chocolate and sugar confectionery come
from Britain, the world’s largest exporter of these products.
Among the fruit and vegetable products manufactured are jam, marmalade,
sauces and vinegar. The labour force numbers 71,000. Output of jams and
marmalade, which fell from 329,000 tons in 1949 to about 215,000 tons in
1956, has since remained little changed, totalling 199,000 tons in 1968. Straw¬
berry, raspberry, apricot and blackcurrant jams are the most popular. Exports
of jams and marmalade in 1968 were valued at ^2-3 million.
In 1968, 713,000 tons of canned vegetables were produced. The British
I\avy was using canned foods in 1813, but rapid development in the industry
did not take place until after 1935. Beans in tomato sauce (270,000 tons) and
processed and fresh peas (244,000 tons) are the vegetables most in demand
as canned products. In addition, output in 1968 included 100,000 tons of
canned and bottled fruit, and 273,000 tons of canned soup. Strawberries and
rhubarb are the most important fruits used for canning, followed by prunes
and apples. Sales of prepared fruit pie fillings are increasing.
Sales of frozen foods are rising in Britain, and nearly 119,000 tons of
vegetables and 700 tons of fruit were preserved by this method in 1968; peas
accounted for 55 per cent of all home-produced quick-frozen vegetables. Sales
of dehydrated products, including accelerated freeze dried foods, are also
increasing.
The industry comprises the curing of bacon and ham, the canning and
preserving of meat and fish, the manufacture of sausages and pies and the
preparation of extracts and pastes. The labour force numbers 94,000. Output
of canned meat and meat products in 1968 rose to 128,000 tons, and the
quantity of bacon and ham cured increased to 216,000 tons. There has been a
rapid expansion of quick-frozen fish output, and some 14,000 tons wrere

The industries producing beer, spirits, wines, cider and soft drinks have a
labour force of 157,000. Exports were valued at £196-9 million in 1968.
Exports of whisky (almost all of it Scotch whisky) reached the record level of
59-2 million proof gallons with a value of £176-6 million in 1968; over half
went to the United States (£93 million or 33-3 million proof gallons). Scotch
whisky was first distilled in the fifteenth century. It is blended from 20 or
more different types, some from malted barley and some from other grains.
Whisky requires several years to mature, and the 114 million proof gallons
of Scotch whisky produced in the 1968 distilling year will not be on sale for
some years. Stocks of whisky amount to more than 610 million proof gallons,
representing 10 years’ consumption. About four-fifths of annual sales are to
overseas buyers.
Production of gin in Britain has risen steadily since the early 1950s. The main
distillers are in London and one company accounts for a large proportion of
total output. Although the larger manufacturers also own distilleries abroad,
exports had a value of £9 million in 1968.
There are 97,000 employees in the brewing and malting industry. Recent
mergers have led to the creation of a few major brewery groups, marketing
their products throughout the country. In 1968 32 million bulk barrels of
beer were produced, the highest for some years, and consumers’ expenditure
on beer amounted to £957 million. Exports in 1968 of malt beer were 340,000
bulk barrels, worth £3-2 million. Firms are experimenting with new methods,
including continuous brewing processes, and automated batch production
plants are well established.
The main raw materials used in brewing are malt, hops and some sugar.
Malt is made almost entirely from home-grown barley. Some brewers make all
or part of their own malt, others purchase it from independent maltsters who
also supply distillers, vinegar brewers, and malt extract manufacturers. British
malt is used by brewers throughout the world, and exports in 1968 amounted
to 75,000 tons, worth £3-6 million.
The soft drinks industry has expanded markedly in the last decade although
sales are liable to be affected by the weather. Output in 1968 included 60
million gallons of concentrated liquid, and 253 million gallons of unconcen¬
trated drinks. Though there has been some amalgamation in recent years,
there are still several hundred firms supplying regional markets. There are two
very large firms among about 20 producing widely advertised brands which
are marketed on a national scale. There is also some degree of specialisation by
firms in the production of various types, such as carbonated drinks, cola-based
drinks, squashes and cordials, tonic waters and ‘mixers’, and comminuted
drinks (in which the whole fruit is used).
The tobacco industry manufactures almost all the cigarettes and other
tobacco goods sold in Britain. In 1968 consumers’ expenditure on these
goods amounted to £1,585 million (of which about three-quarters was tax
revenue) and, in addition, exports worth £30 million (of which cigarettes
accounted for 88 per cent) were shipped to a large number of overseas
markets; Kuwait, Hong Kong and Southern Yemen were the most important.
The main centres of production are in and around Bristol, Liverpool, London,

The tobacco industry used 308 million lb. of unmanufactured tobacco
in 1968 (8 per cent more than in 1967), all of which was imported. In 1968
the main sources were the United States, Canada and India. Total consump¬
tion of tobacco in Britain in 1968 amounted to 253-4 million lb., including
220-2 million lb. consumed in cigarettes, 28-6 million lb. in pipe and hand
rolling tobacco and 4-1 million lb. in cigars. In 1968, 121,800 million
cigarettes were consumed, 2,700 million more than in the previous year;
71 per cent of the total were tipped compared with 16 per cent in i960.
This group comprises the manufacture of bricks, fireclay, refractory goods,
pottery, glass, cement, abrasives, asbestos and other building materials. The
industries have a combined labour force of 347,400, which includes 66,000
in the bricks, fireclay and refractory goods trades, 77,000 in the glass industry
and 61,500 in the pottery industry.
Firms in the industry manufacture such items as bricks, roofing tiles, chimney
pots, fireclay ware and heat-resisting products including furnace and kiln
linings. Brickmaking, one of Britain’s oldest industries, was introduced by
the Romans, and manufacturing methods vary from traditional hand fabri¬
cation to highly mechanised systems. In 1968 about 7,464 million building
bricks were produced in Great Britain, 45 per cent of which were of the
Fletton type, made mainly in the Bedford and Peterborough areas. Refractory
goods (firebricks, silica bricks, magnesite bricks and chrome-magnesite bricks)
are manufactured mainly for home use. Exports of refractory construction
materials in 1968 were worth ^7-2 million.
The pottery industry is a long-established and complex industry, largely
located in the Stoke-on-Trent area of Staffordshire. Much of its raw material
is indigenous, such as china clay, ball clay and china stone from Devon and
Cornwall. It supplies nearly all home needs for domestic and industrial
pottery.
The largest section of the industry, about half, makes domestic pottery,
sub-divided into china, earthenware, stoneware, jet and Rockingham; the
other main divisions are glazed tiles, sanitary ware and electrical ware, and
such specialised industrial products as acid-proof stoneware, porous ceramics
and laboratory procelain are also manufactured. Among famous makes of
British pottery are Wedgwood, Spode, Royal Worcester, Royal Doulton,
Minton, Coalport and Royal Crown Derby. Total sales of domestic pottery
were ^48-5 million in 1968 including export sales of £20-6 million, the highest
ever; the United States and Canada are important markets.
There has been considerable re-equipment; gas or electrically fired kilns
have replaced almost all the coal-fired kilns, and new decorating techniques
and automatic and semi-automatic machinery have been introduced.
Britain’s glass industry is the third largest in the world. The section of the
industry devoted to the manufacture of plate and sheet glass in their various
forms is organised for quantity production, much of it in the form of the
‘float’ glass process, which was developed in Britain and has been licensed
to glass makers throughout the world. Its use for internal decoration and as
a finish for internal and external walls has greatly increased in recent years.

Large quantities of safety glass are produced for the motor industry. Other
products include glass bricks, tubular glass (produced on a large scale),
mirrors, lamp and bulb glass, scientific and medical glassware, glass fibres,
and all types of glass containers (often made by fully automatic machinery).
A traditional product is hand-made lead crystal glassware of very high quality.
Direct exports of glass and glassware reached the record value of ^30-6
million in 1968. Those of glass were worth ^18-2 million, the most important
markets being the United States, South Africa, Australia and the Republic of
Ireland. The figures included ^4-7 million of float glass.
Collective research is undertaken by the British Glass Industry Research
Association, and much research work is also carried out by the Department
of Glass Technology of Sheffield University.
The cement industry of the United Kingdom is chiefly concerned with the
manufacture of Portland cement. Invented by Joseph Aspdin and patented
in 1824, this material and the methods of its production have been the subject
of continuous technical improvement and intensive research. The capacity
of the industry, which has 19,000 employees, has expanded substantially.
The Dartford-Gravesend district of Kent is an important producing area.
Annual output totalled 17-6 million tons in 1968.
The paper, printing and publishing industries have 629,000 employees,
including 94,000 in the manufacture of paper and board, 62,000 in the pro¬
duction of cardboard boxes and packing cases, 144,000 in the publishing of
newspapers and periodicals, and 256,500 in other types of printing and
publishing.
The manufacture of paper in Great Britain was not firmly established until
1678, but records show that some paper was produced as far back as 1492.
The British paper and board industry is the largest in Europe. Total
production in 1968 of all types of paper and board amounted to 4-6 million
tons. Of this, newsprint accounted for 724,000 tons, board for 3-7 million
tons and other paper for the remainder. Exports of paper, board and
manufactured paper items were valued at ^66-3 million in 1968. The main
purchasers were the Republic of Ireland, Australia and South Africa.
Wood pulp is the main raw material, but large and increasing quantities
of waste paper are also used. A £20 million integrated pulp and paper mill,
the first in Britain, was opened at Fort William, in the Scottish Highlands,
in 1966. Two-thirds of the timber it uses is home-grown.
There are a few very large groups in the industry and many medium-sized
and small firms. The large groups hold considerable interests abroad, includ¬
ing pulp and paper producing mills in the United States, Canada and other
parts of the Commonwealth and Europe. Sales of household paper products,
including facial tissues, have risen sharply. Sales of cardboard boxes and
cartons were valued at 18-8 million in 1968, while those of fibre board pack¬
ing cases totalled £113-7 million. Sales of manufactured stationery totalled
£102-7 in 1968. Wallpaper manufacturing is dominated by one firm;
a recent development has been the introduction of plastic and plastic-coated
wall coverings. Research is undertaken by the Research Association for the
Paper and Board, Printing and Packaging Industries.
The printing industry produces an immense range of goods, from national
newspapers and periodicals to books, catalogues and greetings cards. The

industry includes many very small enterprises. Mergers in recent years have
led to the formation of large groups in the newspaper, magazine and book

General printing, publishing, engraving and bookbinding remains essentially
an industry of small firms.
Publishers’ turnover in 1968 is estimated at £133 million, of which export
sales accounted for a record total of -£60 million, forming a higher proportion
of output than in any other country. Consumers’ expenditure on books, news¬
papers and magazines totalled almost £400 million in 1968. Book titles
published in 1968 totalled nearly 32,500, over 23,500 of them new ones.
Popularity of paper-backed books has increased rapidly in recent years.
According to the overseas trade returns, exports of printed matter, manu¬
scripts and typescripts were valued at £68-6 million in 1968, including books
(£35-5 million), and newspapers and periodicals (£11-5 million), but these
figures do not include parcel post shipments, which are possibly as large again
as the recorded totals. The United States and Australia are the most important
overseas markets. The Book Development Council was formed in 1965 to
promote the supply and use of British books overseas. Firms have introduced
the latest developments in high-speed printing equipment, including elec¬
tronic engraving machines and advanced processes of photographic repro¬
duction, and several newspapers are now set by computer.
Other manufacturing industries include the timber and furniture group, with
305,000 employees, rubber manufacture, with 129,000 employees, and a group
of miscellaneous manufactures which embrace some 209,000 employees,
including 96,000 employed in plastics moulding and fabricating.
Britain’s rubber manufacturing industry is the oldest in the world, dating
from 1819. Macintosh invented waterproof garments, and Dunlop in 1888
devised the pneumatic tyre. Tyres and tubes represent more than half the
output of the industry but firms also make a variety of other rubber manu¬
factures, the most important being rubber footwear, conveyor belting, cables,
hose, latex foam products, and other vehicle components and accessories.
The British industry is one of the largest in the world. In 1968 its consump¬
tion of rubber totalled 425,000 tons, comprising 183,000 tons of natural
rubber, 214,000 tons of synthetic rubber and 28,600 tons of reclaimed rubber;
the proportion of synthetic rubber used is increasing. In 1968, 128,000 tons
of rubber were used in the production of tyres and tyre products. Tyre
manufacturers include several subsidiaries of United States and other overseas
companies. Tyres and tubes exported were valued at ^33-4 million; this
figure excludes large indirect exports on vehicles. Direct exports of all rubber
manufactures (including tyres) in 1968 were worth £61-2 million, with
Sweden, Australia, Denmark and the United States as the main markets. In
addition, the industry exported about £4-3 million worth of rubber footwrear
and £i-y million of rubber gloves and other miscellaneous products.
London is the largest centre for furniture manufacturing, but High Wycombe,
in Buckinghamshire, is important for domestic furniture.
Deliveries of domestic furniture rose by 35 per cent in volume between 1958
and 1968, and in the latter year their value was j£i8i million. Exports of all
furniture were worth £iJ-8 million in 1968. There are numerous enterprises
manufacturing furniture in Britain (including domestic, upholstered, office,
school and other furniture) with a total labour force of 98,000. The bedding

Scientific research and technical information services are provided by the
Furniture Development Council and the Furniture Industry Research

The brush industry is located throughout Britain, and embraces highly
mechanised establishments as well as small craft unions. The value of sales in

The timber industry employs 108,000 people. Britain is mainly dependent
on imported supplies of timber (valued at ^231 million in 1968) but sawmill
output of home-grown timber together with the output of home-grown
pitwood totalled about 55 million cubic feet in 1968. Other products include
plywood and chipboard.

increased production of small-scale precision models of vehicles and toys

FUEL AND POWER
The main primary sources of energy currently used in Britain are coal,
petroleum and, to a lesser extent, nuclear energy, natural gas and water power;
secondary sources produced from these are electricity, town gas and coke.
Coal, mined within the country, still represents slightly more than half
primary energy consumption, although the amount of coal used and its share
of the total energy market has been falling. Oil, on the other hand, virtually
all imported, has expanded rapidly, its share of total energy consumption
having risen from one-fifth in 1958 to over one-quarter in 1961, and to over
two-fifths in 1968. With nuclear power and North Sea natural gas making
an increasing impact over the coming years, Britain is moving over from two
fuels to four. A programme for nuclear power stations has been in progress for
nearly 15 years and nuclear power now provides a significant and increasing
share of electricity supplies although it still represents under 5 per cent

The fuel and power industries, with the exception of petroleum, are under
public ownership. General responsibility for the effective and co-ordinated
development of fuel and power resources lies with the Minister of Power.
Research is undertaken by the fuel and fuel-using industries. The Minister
of Power also has an Advisory Council on Research and Development.
The fuel and power industries in Britain employ in total about 770,000
people, or 3^ per cent of the working population; their capital investment in
1969-70 will be in the region of ^850 million, about one-sixth of total invest¬
ment; their annual turnover is about £2,850 million; and the value of their
net output is about 5 per cent of the national product. The nationalised

borrowing from the Government (long term), the clearing banks (short term),
and, in the case of gas and electricity, from overseas (long term) sources.
The responsible ministers—the Minister of Power in England and Wales
and for Scottish electricity the Secretary of State for Scotland—are required
by statute to set up consultative councils for each of the nationalised fuel
industries to protect the interests of consumers. National Industrial and
Domestic Coal Consumers’ Councils were set up in 1947 and Area Electricity
and Gas Consultative Councils (supported by district committees) were set up
in 1948 and 1949 respectively. Each consists of a chairman and from 20 to 30
unpaid members appointed from nominations put forward by interested
bodies, mainly local authorities.
COAIj Coal has been worked in Britain for over 700 years and an organised coal¬
mining industry has been in existence for over 300 years, some 200 years
longer than in any other country. British coal exports dominated the world
market until about 1910. By 1913—the peak production year—the industry
was producing 287 million tons of coal, exporting 94 million tons and
employing over a million workers.
In 1947 the coal mines passed into public ownership by means of the Coal
Industry Nationalisation Act 1946, which set up the National Coal Board as
a statutory corporation to manage the industry.
The National The National Coal Board (NCB) consists of a chairman and between eight
Coal Board and eleven members appointed by the Minister of Power. The NCB has an
almost complete monopoly to extract coal in Great Britain, and is also
empowered to license private operators to work small pits and open-cast sites.
It has no monopoly in distribution, and retail sales remain largely in private
hands, but it has, however, some retail depots and makes bulk sales to large
industrial consumers.
The NCB is responsible for the day-to-day running and the commercial
management of the industry, but is answerable to the minister (and through
him, to Parliament) for its efficiency. The minister has power to issue
directives on matters affecting the public interest, and to authorise borrowings
to finance capital investment.
The 317 collieries in operation at the end of March 1969 were grouped into
17 areas, each controlled by a director who is responsible to the national
board. A typical area produces nearly 10 million tons of coal a year, employs
up to 20,000 men and has a turnover of about ^55 million.
Pattern and
Trends in
Supply and
Demand
Coal consumption in Britain increased by an average annual rate of nearly
4 million tons between 1947 and 1956; sales fell sharply, however, between
1956 and 1959 and large stocks of coal accumulated at pit heads. Growing
competition from oil, increasing efficiency in the use of coal and reduced
requirements of the gas, steel, railway transport, and other industries contri¬
buted to the fall in demand. Undistributed stocks at the end of 1968 were
28-1 million tons. The fall in consumption is shown in Table 17.
Over two-fifths of total output is consumed by the electricity authorities
and over one-quarter by domestic and industrial users together. Coke ovens
and the gas industry are other large users. Consumption by the electricity
industry has increased by 33 per cent since 1961 to 73 million tons in 1968,
whereas the requirements of all the other main classes of consumer have
declined. In the case of domestic users this fall has been slightly offset by
increased purchases of solid smokeless fuels.

Coal exports have declined for somewhat similar reasons and now average
about 3 million tons a year. The peak post-war figure was 19 million tons in
1949. The principal markets are in Western Europe and the Republic of
Ireland.
The fact that the British industry was developed so early has meant that many
of the best seams of coal are now worked out. There are, however, abundant
reserves of coal with which production can be maintained well into the next
century; there is also scope for opening new collieries should these be
required.
The main coal-bearing areas are: (1) the Yorkshire, Derbyshire and
Nottinghamshire field, which produces about 48 per cent of the total output,
(2) the Durham and Northumberland field, (3) the South Wales field, and
(4) the Scottish field. Other important coal-bearing areas are those of
Lancashire and the west Midlands (Staffordshire and Warwickshire).

According to forecasts by the Ministry of Power, the fall in coal consump¬
tion shown in Table 18 is likely to continue, but the Government is taking
measures to support consumption with the aim of holding the demand for
coal at around 120 million tons by 1975. The NCB plans to improve the
competitive position of coal by restricting production to the most efficient
pits (27 of which each produced over a million tons of coal in 1968-69) and
the most efficient faces. Most faces are highly mechanised and are worked
increasingly on a multi-shift basis. Productivity has risen by nearly one-half
since 1961. In 1968 output per manshift at NCB mines rose to nearly 2-1 tons,
with 51,000 fewer workers. At mechanised faces output averages 7-5 tons per
shift as compared with 4-1 tons at non-mechanised faces, the average for all
faces being 6-5 tons. Among measures contributing to higher productivity
are new techniques for obtaining information about the reserves before they
are worked, intensive training of management and men to obtain the maximum
utilisation of equipment on highly mechanised faces, the increasing use of
powered supports, the use of higher horse-power machines and improvements
in the mechanised handling of coal below ground and on the surface.
