BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
The NCB raises capital, including working capital, by borrowing from the
Exchequer. At present there is a statutory limit of £900 million on such
borrowing. Within its limit the Board may, with the permission of the
Minister of Power, borrow temporarily (by way of overdraft or otherwise).
The greater proportion of investment, however, is financed from internal
resources.
Capital expenditure by the industry totalled ^462 million from 1947 to
1955 and about £79° million in the nine years 1956 to end-March 1964. At
the end of the 1964-65 financial year the total capital debt to the Exchequer
amounted to about £960 million. In 1965 legislation was enacted to effect a
capital reconstruction involving the writing off of ^415 million of the existing
debt. As a result, the total debt to the Exchequer at the end of March 1969
amounted to £698 million.
Under the nationalisation statute, the NCB has been required to break even
on its current account (taking one year with another) after meeting all proper
charges including provision for reserves. It has made surpluses in some years
and deficits in others. In certain areas, such as Scotland, Lancashire and Wales,
deficits have been persistent, and profits from the areas of high productivity,
for instance, the Midlands, have been inadequate to cover the losses sustained.
By March 1966 the accumulated deficit on the current account had reached
£115-6 million; this was included in the £415 million written off. Interest
payments and depreciation provisions have been reduced as a result. In the
year ending March 1969 the NCB made an operating profit of £28-6 million,
and after payment of interest there was a deficit of £8-9 million.
To assist the redeployment of manpower and the elimination of uneconomic
colliery capacity, the Coal Industry Acts 1965 and 1967 authorise the Ministry
of Power to make grants equal to two-thirds of relevant expenditure up to a
maximum aggregate amount of ^45 million over the four years to 1971.
The NCB has two research organisations: a Coal Research Establishment,
at Stoke Orchard, near Cheltenham, Gloucestershire, providing facilities for
fundamental research; and a Mining Research and Development Establish¬
ment, near Bretby, Derbyshire, for the investigation of underground problems,
developing new machines and testing equipment. In 1959 the Board set up a
department concerned primarily with the further development of new
processes for making smokeless fuels.
Research associations receiving grants from the NCB and the Ministry of
Technology include the British Coal Utilisation Research Association, the
British Coke Research Association and the Coal Tar Research Association.
Much of the work of other bodies, such as the Safety in Mines Research
Establishment (SMRE), is closely related to the Board’s problems; the
SMRE carries out research on explosions and fires, pneumoconiosis, engineer¬
ing and metallurgy.
The petroleum industry in Britain dates back to 1850, when Dr. James Young,
a Glasgow chemist, succeeded in obtaining lamp oil and lubricants from
natural mineral oil occurring in the Derbyshire coal measures. The Scottish
shale deposits, yielding similar products, were first worked in 1858 and ceased
production in 1962.
Sources of crude oil within Britain meet only 1 ton in every 1,000 of total
United Kingdom requirements, the remainder being imported from overseas.
Annual production of crude oil from indigenous oilfields now totals about
INDUSTRY
International
Trade
Consumption
Refineries
285
80,000 tons. Prospecting for crude petroleum has so far led to the establish¬
ment of several small oilfields, notably in Nottinghamshire (Egmanton and
Bothamsell), in Leicestershire (Plungar), in Lincolnshire (Gainsborough)
and in Dorset (Kimmeridge). A substantial field of natural gas was also located
in 1966 in north Yorkshire, near Scarborough.
Seismic prospecting in the North Sea has been going on since 1962. Under
the Continental Shelf Act 1964, the Minister of Power, by a system of licensing
for exploration and production, controls those activities in the areas over the
shelf appertaining to the United Kingdom. Britain’s share of the North Sea
shelf amounts to about 100,000 square miles. Licences covering about 41,000
square miles were issued in 1964 and 1965 (one being in the Irish Sea).
Drilling, which started in 1964, has proved the existence of four major fields
of natural gas capable of commercial production, two of which (West Sole
and Leman Bank) are delivering to the Gas Council. In 1968 production from
these two fields averaged just under 200 million cubic feet per day.
British and British-Dutch oil companies have been responsible for developing
the oil resources of many countries to mutual advantage, especially in the
Middle East, Far East, Africa and Caribbean areas.
Today these companies produce more than one-third of all oil entering into
international trade, with a tanker fleet (partly owned by them and partly on
charter) amounting to nearly a quarter of the world’s tanker tonnage. (United
Kingdom registered tanker tonnage is about 12 per cent of the world’s total.)
In 1968 the United Kingdom imported 81-7 million tons of crude oil valued
at ^627 million, the largest single item among imported products.
Libya (26-4 per cent) replaced Kuwait as the largest supplier. Other major
suppliers were Iran, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela.
Deliveries of petroleum products for inland consumption in 1968 totalled
82-8 million tons, having almost doubled since i960. Fuel oil consumption
in 1968 constituted 30-6 per cent of the total. Demand for gas and diesel oils
(excluding those used in road vehicles) rose by a further 1 million tons to
9 million tons in 1968. Sales of motor spirit have expanded by an annual
average of 6-7 per cent since i960 and totalled 12-8 million tons in 1968.
The most important uses of gas and diesel oils in 1968 were for non¬
industrial central heating, agricultural tractors and the railways. Electricity
generation accounted for about 21 per cent of total fuel oil consumption,
excluding that used in oil refineries; the steel industry accounted for 15 per
cent; and non-industrial central heating for a further 12-5 per cent. Of the
remainder, the largest users were the cement, paper-making, general chemical,
glass, engineering, brickmaking and textile industries.
Before 1939 three-quarters of the United Kingdom’s supply of petroleum
products was refined overseas, as it was considered more economical to
refine at the source of production. Since the second world war the industry
has favoured the siting of refineries in the consuming areas.
At the end of 1968 rated refinery capacity in Britain amounted to 97-4 million
tons a year. Of the 22 refineries in operation, seven have a capacity of under
0-5 million tons. The eight largest are situated at Fawley, near Southampton
(16-5 million tons); Stanlow, in Cheshire (10-5 million tons); Isle of Grain
(10 million tons) and Shellhaven (10 million tons), both on the Thames
Estuary; Teesport, Yorkshire (6 million tons); two at Milford Haven in
Pembrokeshire (6-3 million tons and 5-9 million tons); and at Llandarcy near
286
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Oil Pipelines
Research
ELECTRICITY
SUPPLY
Swansea (8 million tons). Other important refineries are located at Belfast,
Grangemouth, Billingham (Teesside), Killingholme, Heysham (Lancs) and
Coryton (Essex). A project on Humberside is nearing completion, thus
bringing the number of important refining areas to seven. Britain’s total
capacity in mid-1969 stood at nearly 100 million tons a year.
Output of refined products (excluding refineries’ own consumption) has
risen steadily; from 4 million tons in 1948 to 25^ million tons in 1954,
40 million tons in i960 and the peak total of 76 million tons in 1968. There is a
substantial external trade in refined products which tends to follow trading
and seasonal requirements and the commercial arrangements of the major oil
companies. Exports from Britain, mainly in the form of heavier products
to European countries, were valued at £149 million in 1968; imports of
refined products (including liquefied gases) amounted to £275 million.
Three main crude oil pipelines are in operation in Britain between harbours
capable of berthing very large tankers and refineries: in west Scotland, from
Finnart to Grangemouth: in South Wales, from Angle Bay, Milford Haven,
to Llandarcy; and in north-west England, from Tranmere to Heysham.
Pipelines carry refined products from refineries to major marketing areas; for
example, from Stanlow to the Manchester area, from Fawley to Staines and
Heathrow Airport, and from the Isle of Grain to Walton-on-Thames and
Heathrow Airport. A 245-mile pipeline, opened in 1969, feeds refined products
to north London and the Midlands from refineries and installations on the
Thames and Mersey; a similar line is planned from Milford Haven to the
Midlands and Manchester. Pipelines carrying petrochemical feedstocks run
from Stanlow to Carrington, near Manchester, from Fawley to Severnside,
near Bristol, and from Teesside to Fleetwood and Runcorn. The Pipelines
Act 1962 is designed to secure the orderly development of privately owned
industrial pipelines.
Research into problems of petroleum technology is carried out mainly by the
leading oil companies, which have also endowed research at the universities
on a substantial scale. Research centres are situated at Sunbury-on-Thames
(the British Petroleum Company), Thornton, in Cheshire, and Woodstock,
in Kent (Shell), and Abingdon, in Berkshire (Esso). The first of these covers
the full range of petroleum research and development, from geology and
production to product utilisation and petroleum chemicals. In general, the
remainder are concerned with the evolution of new and improved fuels and
lubricants and the development of new uses for petroleum products and of
new products based on petroleum, especially chemicals.
A public supply of electricity was first provided in Britain in 1881, at
Godaiming, Surrey. From its earliest days a measure of public control has
been a feature of the industry. In 1919 the Electricity Commissioners were
created as a supervisory body and to promote reorganisation on a national
scale through voluntary agreement. In 1926 the Central Electricity Board
was set up to construct and operate a national grid inter-connecting individual
power stations, thus co-ordinating generation and transmission. In 1943 the
North of Scotland Hydro-Electric Board (NSHEB) was established as a
public corporation to develop the water-power resources of the Highlands.
In 1948 all municipal and private undertakings (other than those in Northern
Ireland) were acquired under the Electricity Act 1947 and vested in the
British Electricity Authority and 14 regional boards, except in the north of
INDUSTRY
Present
Structure
England and Wales
Scotland
Northern Ireland
287
Scotland where they became the responsibility of the NSHEB. Two subse¬
quent Acts (1954 and 1957) effected a measure of decentralisation and gave the
industry its present structure. Electricity supply employs about 230,000
people, including 5,700 in Northern Ireland.
In England and Wales, electricity is generated and transmitted by the Central
Electricity Generating Board (CEGB) and distributed by 12 separate Area
Electricity Boards; co-ordination is effected by the Electricity Council. In
Scotland, two boards—the NSHEB and the South of Scotland Electricity
Board (SSEB)—both generate and distribute electricity. In Northern Ireland,
the Belfast Corporation and the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland
generate and distribute electricity, and the Londonderry Corporation
distributes only.
The Electricity Council is the central body of the supply industry with a
general responsibility for promoting electricity supply and for advising the
Minister of Power; it is also responsible for a number of common services,
principally capital financing, research and industrial relations. The Council
consists of a chairman, two deputy chairmen, the chairman and two designated
members of the CEGB, the chairmen of the 12 Area Electricity Boards and
not more than three other members. The CEGB controls the operation and
maintenance of power stations and the main transmission system (the national
grid) and supplies electricity in bulk to the 12 Area Boards. The CEGB
consists of a chairman, a deputy chairman and between six and eight members.
Each of the 12 Area Electricity Boards acquires bulk supplies of electricity
from the CEGB and is responsible for distribution networks and sales of
electricity to its area consumers.
Area Consultative Councils were set up under the Electricity Act 1947 in
the area of each Board to represent the interests of consumers; their chairmen
are ex officio members of their respective Area Boards. The Minister of Power
appoints the chairmen, deputy chairmen and members of the Electricity
Council, the CEGB, the Area Boards and the Consultative Councils; approves
each Board’s capital development programmes and the industry’s research
programme; and approves, in consultation with the Treasury, the industry’s
borrowing requirements. The Electricity Act 1957 requires each Board, and
not merely the industry as a whole, to pay its way taking one year with
another.
The boundary separating the areas covered by the two Scottish Boards runs
roughly from Dumbarton on the Firth of Clyde to Newburgh on the Firth of
Tay. Members of both Boards and of the respective consumer consultative
councils are appointed by the Secretary of State for Scotland; each Board
comprises a chairman and between four and eight members, one of whom is the
chairman of the other Board. The Secretary of State’s responsibilities in
relation to the Boards are similar to those of the Minister of Powrer.
In Northern Ireland electricity is generated at power stations in Belfast and
at Ballylumford and Coolkeeragh. Those in Belfast are operated by the city
corporation and the remainder by the Electricity Board for Northern Ireland.
Generation is co-ordinated by the Northern Ireland Joint Electricity
Authority, set up by statute in 1967. The output of the stations has, since
1948, been purchased in bulk and re-sold to distributors—the Belfast
Corporation for Belfast and district, the Londonderry Corporation for the
City of Londonderry, and the Electricity Board for the rest of Northern
Ireland.

As Britain has abundant supplies of coal, together with good rail and water
transport for moving it, most of its electricity is produced by coal-fired steam
generating stations. Hydro-electric development on any scale is comparatively
recent, water-power resources being relatively small and in remote areas.
Since 1965* nuclear energy has become increasingly important.
The output capacity of the generating stations of the electricity boards in
Great Britain at the end of 1968 totalled 50,060 megawatts (MW), an increase
of one-third since 1963.
In the years 1963 to 1968 an annual average of over 2,700 MW of
generating capacity was installed, including 3,800 MW in 1967 and 4,000 MW
in 1968. About 13,270 MW of capacity will come into operation in England
and Wales in the period 1969-72 inclusive. The SSEB’s plans provide for
its total capacity of 3,837 MW at the end of 1968 to be increased to c,6oo MW
by 1970.
Sales of electricity in Northern Ireland (where, of the total installed
generating capacity of 1,020 MW, 480 MW is in oil-fired and the remainder in
coal-fired thermal stations) amounted to 3,077 million kilowatt-hours in 1968.
Generation by the public supply in Great Britain exceeded 200,000 million
kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1968; conventional steam power stations provided
86 per cent of the total and hydro-electric and nuclear stations about 2 per
cent and 12 per cent respectively. The high rate of expansion of output,
which has been a feature of the industry since its earliest years, has not been
maintained during the past four years, although the total of electricity
generated in 1968 was still nearly 60 per cent higher than in 1961.
Generation of electricity outside the public supply system is relatively
small under 20,000 million kWh in 1968. The major sources outside the
fuel industries themselves are the chemical, iron and steel and paper industries
and the nuclear power plants of the Atomic Energy Authority (AEA).
An analysis of electricity generation in Great Britain is given in Table 20.

Oil-fired stations of 2,000 MW are under construction at Fawley, on
Southampton Water, and at Pembroke, South Wales. A dual-fired station of
the same size, to burn either coal or oil, is being built at Kingsnorth, Kent.
They are mainly situated on river estuaries and thus able to be fed con¬
veniently from oil refineries.
The electricity authorities are the largest consumers of primary fuel in
Britain, and although most of their electricity generation is based on coal, oil
INDUSTRY

289
consumption rose from a negligible quantity in 1955 to 7-3 million tons in
1967; consumption in 1968 was 5-7 million tons. Average thermal efficiency
(that is, the ratio of the electrical energy output to the heat energy input of the
fuel consumed) of conventional steam stations in England and Wales rose from
20'75 Per cent in I947to 27'99 Per cent in 1968 as new plant was brought into
use. The 20 most efficient stations, containing much of the newest plant, had
an average efficiency of 33-04 per cent in 1968.
Striking advances have been made in the design of steam-generating plant.
A cross-compound generating unit with an output capacity of 550 MW came
into operation in 1963 at Thorpe Marsh, near Doncaster. Forty-seven single¬
shaft units of 500 MW are being installed in 13 stations. The first came
into operation at the Ferrybridge ‘C’ station, Yorks, in 1966. Others were
completed during 1967 and 1968 at West Burton (near Retford, Notts), Egg-
borough (Selby, Yorks), Ratcliffe-on-Soar and Cottam (Notts) and Aber-
thaw ‘B’ (Glam). In 1968 Ferrybridge ‘C’ became the first of the 2,000 MW
stations to supply electricity from all four of its generating sets. Station
capacities are also increasing. By 1971, ten stations, each with capacities of
2,000 MW, with four 500 MW single-shaft generating units, will be in service.
Three larger generating units, of 660 MW, will be installed at Drax (Yorks),
which may have a final capacity of nearly 4,000 MW. (For locations see map,
inside back cover.) In Scotland, a 1,200 MW station at Cockenzie was com¬
missioned in 1968 and one of 2,400 MW (four generating units of 600 MW)
is under construction at Longannet.
Large gas turbine units of 55 MW and 70 MW, based on aerojet engines,
have been introduced since 1965 for peak load operation. The CEGB and
SSEB have installed 919 MW of such units. Smaller gas turbines have been
introduced at new stations to safeguard the auxiliary supplies to the large new
steam units, and also to provide capacity for peak operation. Auxiliary units
of this kind in service at the end of 1968 totalled 662 MW, and by 1972 will
exceed 1,100 MW.
Hydro-electric generation is confined to Scotland and Wales, and most of the
water-power so utilised is drawn from high-level reservoirs with their own
natural catchment areas. The setting up of the NSHEB in 1943 marked the
beginning of an era of intensive water-power development in the Highlands.
In 1968-69, 2,248 million units were sent out by the NSHEB from water¬
power, compared with 322 million in 1949. At the end of March 1969 there
were 50 main hydro-electric conventional stations in operation in the north
of Scotland with a total installed capacity of 1,047 MW and the largest—the
Loch Sloy station—has a capacity of 130 MW. The Cruachan pumped
storage section of the Awe scheme, with an installed capacity of 400 MW
from four reversible-pump-turbines, came into full operation at the end of
1967. In February 1969 plans were approved for a 300 MW pumped-storage
project at Foyers, Loch Ness. It will have two 150 MW reversible-pump-
turbines and is planned for completion in 1974. In addition, there are stations
generating electricity by water-power in the south of Scotland (122 MW)
and in Wales (472 MW). The latter includes the 360 MW pumped-storage
station at Ffestiniog, which was completed in 1963. (In pumped-storage
schemes electricity generated in off-peak periods is used to pump water to
higher levels from which it descends at peak periods to operate turbo¬
generators.)
Some 12 per cent of Britain’s public supply generation was in nuclear power
stations in 1968 and the proportion is expected to rise to about 25 per cent by
290
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the mid-1970s. Britain has so far produced more electricity by this means
than the rest of the world put together.
The AEA itself has five main stations which produce electricity for the
national grid: Calder Hall, in Cumberland (198 MW electrical output);
Chapelcross, Dumfriesshire (191 MW); the Advanced Gas-Cooled Reactor
(AGR) at Windscale, Cumberland (34 MW); the experimental fast breeder
station at Dounreay, Caithness (14 MW); and the Steam Generating Heavy
Water Moderated Reactor (SGHWR) at Winfrith, Dorset (100 MW).
Others are owned and operated by the electricity authorities. Under the
first commercial programme, originally announced in 1955 but since twice
modified, eight stations with a total installed capacity of over 3,600 MW were
in operation in 1968: Berkeley, in Gloucestershire (276 MW output
capacity), and Bradwell, in Essex (300 MW), were both commissioned in
1962; Hunterston ‘A’, in Scotland (300 MW), in 1964; and in the following
year Hinkley Point ‘A’, in Somerset, Trawsfyndd, in Wales (both 500 MW),
and Dungeness ‘A’, in Kent (550 MW); Sizewell, in Suffolk (580 MW),
was commissioned in 1966; and Oldbury, in Gloucestershire (600 MW) in
1968. A ninth station, Wylfa, in Anglesey (1,180 MW), is due to be com¬
missioned in 1970. These stations, like Calder Hall and Chapelcross, are all
magnox stations—graphite-moderated, carbon-dioxide cooled, using natural
uranium metal fuel elements canned in magnesium.
Under a second programme announced in 1964 and extended in 1965, a
further 8,000 MW of nuclear capacity is planned by about 1975. The first
station in this programme, Dungeness ‘B’, due to begin operating in 1972, is
based on the AGR at Windscale, which uses slightly enriched uranium
dioxide fuel canned in stainless steel, a logical development of the magnox
system. When in full operation with a net electrical output of 1,200 MW, it
will be the most powerful in the world. Three further stations, Hinkley
Point ‘B’, Hunterston ‘B’ and Hartlepool are under construction, and will
come into service in 1972, 1973 and 1974 respectively. They will be the first
in Britain to produce electricity more cheaply on base load than the best
contemporary coal stations.
A large prototype fast reactor (PER) of 250 MW capacity is being built
at Dounreay where in October 1962 the experimental fast reactor became the
first of such type to produce electricity for public use and to operate at a high
power level. It is due for completion in 1971.
Transmission
and
Distribution
Main electricity transmission lines—the national grid—supply most of the
country. By 31st March 1968 those of the CEGB totalled 17,879 circuit miles,
of which 4,747 miles were 400,000 volt, 2,208 miles 275,000 volt, 10,383 miles
132,000 volt and the remainder were 66,000 volt and below. In Scotland there
were some 4,400 circuit miles of main transmission lines at the end of March
1968, of which 1,350 circuit miles operated at 275,000 volts and the remainder
at 132,000 volts. Energy movements on the grid in England and Wales are
controlled through the seven operational areas, set up for that purpose and
distinct from the regions in which the generating side of the industry is
organised; each area has a separate control, and the operations are
co-ordinated by a National Control in London. The grid in Scotland is
operated from the control centres at Pitlochry (NSHEB) and at Kirkintilloch
(SSEB).
To reduce the number of new transmission lines needed to meet the
country’s increasing power demands, most of the new ‘supergrid’ of main
transmission lines now operating at 275,000 volts are, since 1965, being
INDUSTRY
Capital
Investment
Research
291
uprated to operate at 400,000 volts. The development of the grid system has
made the British system the largest integrated power network in the world.
Twin cross-Channel cables laid between Dungeness and Boulogne, capable
of transmitting up to 160 MW at 200,000 volts (direct current), have been
in operation since 1961; by this means advantage is taken of the differences
between France and Britain in the timing of peak loads.
A direct current transmission link to reinforce supplies in the London area
is being installed; due for completion in 1970, the scheme—the first of its
kind in the world—will have a capacity of 640 MW.
In England and Wales the Area Electricity Boards distribute to consumers
electricity acquired mainly from the CEGB, supplemented from other
sources, such as industrial plants and the nuclear power stations of the AEA.
There are over 17-8 million consumers. Industrial concerns are the biggest
users of electricity. The principal domestic uses of electricity are for lighting,
cooking and for space and water heating, but the demand for numerous other
domestic purposes is rising steadily.
The NSHEB has about 455,000 consumers, many in remote areas. The
SSEB supplies about 1-5 million consumers.
About 9 per cent of the annual gross fixed capital formation of the United
Kingdom in 1968 was attributable to the electricity supply industry. The
industry’s plans for new capital investment are based on a growth in demand
estimated at an annual average rate of some 5 -8 per cent up to 1974—75.
Capital expenditure of the electricity supply industry has been expanding
very rapidly: from £249 million in 1956 it rose to £364 million in 1961 and
about £570 million in 1968-69, although a temporary downturn is expected
over the next few years. More than two-fifths of the industry’s capital require¬
ments have been financed from internal resources. The statutory limit to
borrowings by the industry in Great Britain is Is,200 million. The Gas and
Electricity Act 1968 empowered the industry to borrow (long term) from
overseas sources.
The Electricity Council, in consultation with the Minister of Power, is
responsible for drawing up a general programme of research, comprising:
direct research carried out by the Electricity Boards themselves, supported
by co-operative research with selected industrial research associations and by
research contracts placed with universities and other organisations. The
Council itself is empowered to conduct research. It is advised by the Elec¬
tricity Supply Research Council. Collaboration on research between the
supply industry and the plant manufacturers is co-ordinated by the Power
Engineering Research Steering Committee set up in 1966.
The main research establishments of the industry are run by the CEGB and
comprise the Central Electricity Research Laboratories at Leatherhead,
Surrey, the Berkeley Laboratories in Gloucestershire, concerned with
nuclear problems, and the Engineering Laboratories at Marchwood, on
Southampton Water. In 1965 the Electricity Council established a research
centre at Capenhurst, Cheshire, at which intensive research is being under¬
taken on distribution problems (to supplement the work undertaken at the
Central Electricity Research Laboratories) and on appliances and methods of
electricity utilisation.
Both Scottish electricity boards carry out research and experimental work
either on their own or in co-operation with other electricity authorities. The
NSHEB undertakes a wide range of research and development work, both

The SSEB has recently extended its own research activities and, with the
NSHEB, is associated with those of the Electricity Council and CEGB.
Public supply of gas in Britain dates from 1807, when Pall Mall, London,
was first lighted with gas. In 1812 the London and Westminster Gas Light
and Coke Company received a Royal Charter to supply gaslight in London.
In the early years of the industry gas was used almost exclusively for lighting,
provided by a growing number of company and municipal undertakings.
The gas industry in its present form developed in the main during the
period between the two world wars when increasing competition from
electricity had to be met, and by 1939 the industry had become mainly a
supplier of heating rather than lighting.
The Gas Act of 1948 brought the industry in Great Britain, in which about
123,000 persons are at present employed, under public ownership and control
on 1st May 1949. The assets of 991 undertakings, of which 269 belonged to
local authorities, were vested in 12 Area Gas Boards. The central body is
the Gas Council, appointed by the Minister of Power. It is both a co¬
ordinating council and, since the enactment of the Gas Act 1965, a trading
body. It consists of a full-time chairman and deputy chairman, the 12 chair¬
men of the area boards and up to five other members. Its general duties are to
advise the Minister on questions affecting the industry and promote the
efficient performance of their duties by the area boards. It also has specific
duties relating to finance, labour relations and research.
The Area Gas Boards, which have a large measure of financial and opera¬
tional responsibility and are similar in most respects to the central bodies
of the other publicly owned corporations, are responsible for the local
manufacture of gas and its distribution to consumers. Each of the Area Gas
Boards, appointed by the Minister of Power, consists of a full-time chairman
and deputy chairman, in some cases one or more full-time members, and
usually five or six part-time members, including the chairman of the Area
Consultative Council. There is no common pattern of organisation; each
board is fully independent and has devised its own subordinate structure.
Each is required to pay its way, taking one year with another. The operations
of the area boards have resulted, in the 20 years up to 31st March 1969, in an
aggregate disposable surplus of approximately £80 million before taxation.
In Northern Ireland the gas supply industry remains in the hands of a
number of municipal undertakings and statutory and non-statutory companies.
The chief method of gas production in Britain used to be by carbonising coal
but oil-based production is now the main method. More than 40 per cent of
total gas available in 1968 was derived from oil, and 5-4 million tons were
used. The gas industry used only about 11 million tons of coal. Gas made
from coal accounted for less than 13 per cent of all gas available during the
year.
About one-third of the output of gas from coke ovens is sold to gas under¬
takings for general distribution; the remainder is mainly consumed at the
ovens or at steelworks. There are about 13 million consumers, the total having
shown no significant change since 1955. Manufactured gas and gas acquired
from coke ovens and other sources for distribution is about 4,500 million
therms1 annually.

In 1968 the quantity of gas produced in Northern Ireland was about
3 -4 million therms, most of it for household use.
Three-fifths of all gas sold by gas boards is for household use and the remainder
for industrial and commercial purposes. Total consumption has been rising
steadily since 1961, after a period when growth was almost negligible. For
the last two years consumption has risen by about 10 per cent. Sales reached
a level of over 5,000 million therms in 1968.
About 40 per cent of the domestic load is used for cooking and space heating
and water heating account for the largest part of the remainder. Most homes
in Britain are supplied with gas, except in some rural areas where, owing to
difficulties in storage and transmission, mains gas is not economic, and bottled
gas, derived from petroleum, is widely used.
Gas is used extensively in industries which require the control of temperatures
to a fine degree of accuracy, for example, in the pottery industry and in
certain processes in the manufacture of iron and steel products. In 1968-69
sales of gas to industry totalled 976 million therms.
Production of coke at gas works in 1967-68 was 5-8 million tons (a fall of
one-fifth in two years) and at coke ovens 16-3 million tons, reflecting the
increasing use of oil and natural gas. The gas industry and coke ovens jointly
produce about 2 million tons of crude coal tar and about 80 million gallons of
crude benzole a year. These latter by-products yield materials widely employed
in the newer branches of the chemical industry.
Under the Gas Act 1948, borrowing by the Gas Council and the Area Gas
Boards was limited to £250 million. In 1954 the industry’s borrowing powers
were increased to ^450 million, in i960 to £525 million, in 1963 to £650
million, in 1965 to ,£1,200 million and in 1968 to an interim limit of ,£1,600
million with provision for a further increase to ,£2,400 million. The Gas and
Electricity Act 1968 empowered the industry to borrow from overseas (long
term) sources.
The industry had been spending about ,£50 million a year on capital
investment in the period 1955 to 1961 but since 1961-62 expenditure has
increased sharply; in 1968-69 it reached ,£225 million and £234 million is
planned for 1969-70. Between vesting day (1st May 1949) and the end of
March 1969 about ,£1,700 million had been invested in fixed assets.
Considerable integration, by the linking of works for the transmission of gas
through gas grids and long-distance mains, has enabled production to be
concentrated in the most efficient units.
To maintain its competitive position, the gas industry has investigated
new and more economic methods of production and new sources of gas
supply. There have been significant developments in the gasification of oil.
The introduction of processes using light distillates in large units producing
gas at high pressure has permitted savings in both capital and running
costs.
Much of the gas industry’s current research and development effort is
concentrated on transforming the industry from one based on town gas
manufactured from coal or oil to one based almost entirely on indigenous
natural gas. The Gas Council has stated that it is switching over entirely to
natural gas within the next ten years.
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
A phased programme of converting the 30 million gas appliances in Britain
is in progress. Investigations are being made into projects involving various
methods of storage of natural gas to meet peak load conditions. Further
storage facilities for natural gas are under construction at Ambergate,
Derbyshire, and near Coatbridge, Scotland.
Since 1964 deliveries of natural gas from the Sahara have been made in liquid
form to Britain. A pipeline system distributes the gas from a terminal on
Canvey Island to 8 of the 12 Area Gas Boards.
The first productive well in the North Sea was discovered in 1965. Four
major gasfields have now been located as well as a number of smaller struc¬
tures. The Ministry of Power has estimated that production could exceed
3,000 million cubic feet per day by 1975.
The first pipeline to pump natural gas to the shore, at Easington in
Yorkshire, was put on flow early in 1967. The second pipeline, which comes
ashore at Bacton in Norfolk, came on flow in August 1968.
The Gas Council expects gas consumption to increase by some 12 per
cent a year up to 1972 and therefore substantial expansion is required. The
need to provide additional storage capacity, and the strengthening of the
distribution system will also give rise to substantial investment.
The Gas Council has a research committee which advises on research policy
at the four research centres. The engineering research station at Killingworth,
Northumberland, has concentrated on distribution problems. Research is
also carried out on behalf of the Gas Council at a number of universities and
colleges.
Efficiency in the use of fuel, among both industrial and domestic users, has
been assisted by various bodies representing producers and consumers and
by the technical advisory services of the fuel and power industries.
The Coal Utilisation Council consists of representatives of the National
Coal Board, solid fuel distributors and appliance manufacturers and distri¬
butors. Originally formed in 1932, it informs and advises domestic users
on the best use of solid fuel, including the choice of installation and the
operation of solid fuel appliances.
A non-profit-making company, the National Industrial Fuel Efficiency
Service, was formed in 1954 and sponsored by the fuel and power industries
to promote fuel saving in industry. In addition to consultancy work, it provides
advice and services to all non-domestic fuel users in a variety of forms, from
‘spot’ inspection to full-scale surveys and regular visits on a contract basis.
Sponsoring by the fuel and power industries ceased on 1st April 1969 but the
Government is providing a measure of financial support until April 1972,
when it is hoped that the service will have become fully self-supporting.
WATER SUPPLY
Britain’s water resources are, with progressive development, sufficient for
domestic and industrial requirements. The sources of water are often distant
from the areas where supplies are needed, however, and water undertakings
are therefore mainly concerned with abstraction, storage, treatment and
distribution. Supplies are obtained partly from surface sources such as
mountain lakes, streams impounded in upland gathering grounds and river
intakes, and partly from underground sources by means of wells, adits and
England and
Wales
Organisation
Present Supplies
industry 295
boreholes. Unlike other public services in Great Britain, such as electricity and
gas, water supply remains in the hands of a large number of undertakings.
Ministerial responsibility in England and Wales is shared by the Minister of
Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of State for Wales; in
Scotland it lies with the Secretary of State for Scotland; and in Northern
Ireland with the Minister of Development.
It was not until the nineteenth century that the provision of water supplies
became a general public service, largely due to the efforts of Edwin Chadwick
and his colleagues who demonstrated the dangers arising from inadequate
water supply and sanitation. The Public Health Act 1848 laid the basis for
a long series of statutes dealing with public health. From the middle of the
nineteenth century onwards a number of water undertakings were set up
to provide water to the expanding urban population, and the water supply
system developed rapidly, although in piecemeal fashion and with some
overlapping and waste.
Local authorities have a duty as sanitary authorities to ensure that water
supplies are adequate for the needs of their areas, and they may do this
either by operating water undertakings themselves or by ensuring that other
bodies are providing adequate supplies. Over one-fifth of the water consumed
is supplied by statutory water companies. The householder receives his
domestic water supply at a comparatively small charge, varying in different
areas, which he usually pays by way of a water rate levied, like other rates,
on the value of his house. Industrial users are charged in most cases according
to actual metered consumption.
The Minister of Housing and Local Government and the Secretary of
State for Wales have a duty to promote the conservation and proper use of
water supplies in England and Wales and are advised by the Central Advisory
Water Committee on general questions relating to water and organisation of
supplies. Since the passing of the Water Act 1945, over 800 smaller water
authorities in England and Wales have been absorbed by larger authorities or
by the creation of joint boards in order to improve the efficiency of the water
supply industry. There are now some 234 statutory water undertakings of
which about two-fifths are local authorities. A number of private proprietors
without statutory powers also provide small supplies.
The largest undertaking in Britain is the Metropolitan Water Board, which
supplies over 360 million gallons daily to 6£ million people in the London
area. It consists of 39 part-time members who are the elected representatives
of the various local authorities within the Board’s area of operations, together
with one representative each from the Thames and Lee Conservancies.
Public water supplies in England and Wales—reaching over 99 per cent of
the total population—now total some 2,696 million gallons a day, out of a total
estimated abstraction of 5,000 million gallons a day (excluding water used for
cooling in connection with electricity generation). Capital expenditure by
water undertakings, which averaged about ^58 million a year in the period
1961-65, has risen to over ^75 million a year. Interest and running costs
are largely met from annual income.
The provision of piped supplies for rural districts has been assisted by
grants under the Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Acts 1944 to 1965. By
March 1969 schemes costing over ^109 million had been completed or were
in progress with the aid of grants under these Acts.
The Water Resources Acts 1963 (which came into full operation in April
1965) and 1968 created a new administrative structure consisting of 27 river

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
authorities and a central Water Resources Board to meet the growing domestic,
industrial and farm irrigation needs. The river authorities, the Thames
Conservancy and the Lee Conservancy Catchment Board have a majority of
members appointed by the county and county borough councils in their areas.
The remainder are appointed by ministers mainly for their knowledge of land
drainage, fisheries, the public water supply, and water in use in industry and
in agriculture. The authorities manage the water resources of river basins
and carry out other functions in respect of land drainage, flood control,
administration of fisheries and prevention of pollution. They are responsible
for assessing water resources and requirements, controlling and developing
resources and securing regulation by a system of licensing. Special arrange¬
ments exist for the Greater London area, where the full range of river authority
control is not necessary. The work of the river authorities is co-ordinated by
the Water Resources Board, an expert advisory body which reports to the
Ministry of Housing and Local Government. Its duties include the review of
national water resources and requirements, the encouragement of the transfer
of water between areas according to need, the co-ordination of proposals of
river authorities for capital investment and the initiation of research. Since
April 1969 water conservation has been financed from charges levied by river
authorities on the licensed abstractors and users of water.
The administrative arrangements for water supply and distribution in
Scotland were reorganised by the Water (Scotland) Act 1967 under which
the functions of 200 local water authorities were transferred to 13 regional
water boards in May 1968. The Act also established the Central Scotland
Water Development Board which supplies water in bulk to its seven constituent
regional water boards; it does not supply direct to individual consumers.
All the members of these boards are members of town or county councils.
The water problem in Scotland is broadly similar to that in England and
Wales except that there is not the same need to allocate water between
competing interests and less reliance needs to be placed on underground
sources. The Secretary of State for Scotland is responsible for general
oversight and co-ordination and has a general duty to promote the conservation
of water resources in Scotland; and to require regional water boards to
provide supplies of wholesome water everywhere in their districts, where
this can be done at reasonable cost; at present, they supply about 97 per cent
of the total population. The Scottish Water Advisory Committee advises the
Secretary of State on general questions relating to resources and supplies.
The Rural Water Supplies and Sewerage Act 1944, as amended, makes available
to Scottish local authorities grant assistance up to a maximum of ^45 million
towards the cost of water supplies and sewerage schemes in rural areas.
Northern Ireland has abundant supplies of water for both domestic and
industrial consumption. Distribution is mainly the responsibility of local
authorities, some of which have combined to form joint boards. Some 85 per
cent of the population has a piped supply and nearly 100 million gallons are
supplied daily. Under the Water Supplies and Sewerage Act (Northern
Ireland) 1945 the Ministry of Development may pay grants towards the cost
of water schemes. Since 1945 almost £40 million have been invested, of which
^19-5 million were government grants.
Information on the yield, behaviour and quantity of the nation’s surface
water resources is provided in the Surface Water Year Book of Great Britain,

INDUSTRY 297
published annually by Her Majesty’s Stationery Office. This publication
contains particulars of the run-off and related rainfall from a large number of
rivers, streams and reservoired areas. The Water Resources Board is respon¬
sible for the collation and publication of hydrological information: the field¬
work of surface water measurement is done by river authorities, water
undertakings and other bodies. Detailed studies of the resources and use of
water in specified areas have been published in the series of hydrological
surveys which cover approximately half of England and Wales. General
information on rainfall, published annually in British Rainfall, is the
responsibility of the Meteorological Office, while advice on ground water is the
responsibility of the Water Resources Board. The Hydraulics Research Station
of the Ministry of Technology at Wallingford and the Water Research
Association’s station at Medmenham carry out research into problems of the
design and calibration of gauging weirs and flumes for the measurement of
surface water, and into other hydraulic problems.
Full-scale feasibility studies are being made of barrages across Morecambe
Bay and the Dee estuary. A preliminary ‘desk study’ has also been carried out
at Solway Firth, and one is in progress for the Wash. Barrage projects involve
dams across or within tidal estuaries to form a lake of fresh water.
Each river authority is responsible for the control of pollution of rivers
and certain tidal waters in its area and its approval must be sought before
polluting effluents are discharged. Control of pollution in the tidal Thames
is exercised by the Port of London Authority. In Scotland nine river purifica¬
tion boards have been set up. The Secretary of State for Scotland is advised
by the Scottish River Purification Advisory Committee on questions affecting
the cleanliness of Scottish rivers. In several ports the petroleum companies
co-operate in the prevention of oil pollution from tankers and refineries.
The Water Pollution Research Laboratory at Stevenage investigates
problems connected with the treatment of polluted water, the treatment
and disposal of sewage and industrial waste water, and the effects and
prevention of pollution of surface water and underground water. Research is
carried out with general supervision and advice from the Water Pollution
Research Board.
CONSTRUCTION
The construction industry includes firms engaged on the construction,
alteration, repair and maintenance of buildings, highways, airfields, drainage
and sewerage systems, waterworks, docks, harbours and canals, sea defence
works, electrical wiring, heating and other installation work, open-cast coal
prospecting and mining, and structural work connected with thermal and
hydro-electric power stations and telecommunications. About i-6 million
people are engaged on construction in both the public and private sectors.
They represent about 7 per cent of the total labour force and their net
output provides about 7 per cent of the gross national product.
The construction industry is gradually adopting metric in place of Imperial
weights and measures; the change is due to be completed in 1972. Designers
have used metric terms for new projects since January 1969; contractors will
start working in metric terms on some projects in January 1970.
Constructional work is carried out both by private contractors and by public
authorities which employ their own labour. Over five-sixths of the work is

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
done by private firms. Although there are over 80,000 firms in the industry,
more than a fifth of them are one-man businesses. At the other end of the
scale are about 220 firms each with more than 600 employees.
Public authorities as a whole employ about 350,000 operatives but a very
large proportion of these are engaged on repair and maintenance work which
local authorities, for example, carry out with their own labour.
Over 40 per cent of operatives are occupied on building maintenance, valued
at over £1,100 million annually. The total labour force includes about 800,000
skilled craftsmen, who have been trained for four or five years under the indus¬
try s apprenticeship schemes. A further 115,000 are employed as apprentices.
Some firms are vertically integrated, owning quarries and workshops,
mechanised plant and standard builders’ equipment; some undertake respon¬
sibility for projects from initial design to finished building. All but the
smallest projects are generally carried out under professional direction, either
by architects or, in the case of the more complicated civil engineering projects,
by consulting engineers. The functions of the latter, acting on behalf of a
client, embrace advice on the feasibility of projects, the drawing up of plans
and the supervision of the constructional work by the contractor.
The Ministry of Public Building and Works (see p. 55) is responsible for
the construction programmes undertaken directly by the Government
(except for roads and health and education projects), including work for the
armed services, both at home and overseas. It is also responsible for
co-ordinating research and development throughout the government service and
seeks to influence methods and techniques in the building industry as a whole.
The output of the industry has been rising steadily over many years. The
value of work done in 1968 amounted to £4,520 million, of which £640
million represented work carried out by the labour employed directly by
public authorities. Private contractors carried out the remaining £3,880
million (£3>09° miHion on new work and £790 million on repair work).
About 394,000 houses were started in 1968 and some 414,000 were completed,
of which 222,000 were for private owners. Of the £1,255 million of new
housing carried out by private contractors, £622 million, or just under half,
was for private owners and the remainder for public authorities. Increasing
use is being made of industrialised building methods employing prefabricated
components.
The National Building Agency, which was set up by the Government in
1964, is an independent advisory body, managed by a board of directors
appointed by the Minister of Housing and Local Government and the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and financed by a government
grant and the fees which it earns. Its main function is to encourage the
adoption of advanced methods of housebuilding, especially industrialised
building methods, as well as to provide technical advice and services, in
particular to local authorities.
Britain was the first country to develop civil engineering as a large-scale
modern industry and the first to provide techniques, finance and equipment
to carry out major civil engineering projects throughout the world. Prominent
figures in the early development of civil engineering included John McAdam,
pioneer in road construction; Thomas Telford, builder of roads, bridges,
canals, docks and railways; George and Robert Stephenson and Isambard
Kingdom Brunei, pioneers of railway building.

299
Among important construction projects in hand in the United Kingdom in
1969 were several major conventional power stations and nuclear power
stations (see p. 289), dams and reservoirs, including a £3 -5 million dam on the
River Towy in Wales, hospitals, large-scale housing developments, such as
the Thamesmead (London) project to house 60,000 people, and the new town
being built at Craigavon, Northern Ireland. Projects for road construction,
bridges and tunnels included about 100 miles of motorways under construction
(see p. 338) a ^6 million high-level bridge over the Clyde, and the £20 million
second Mersey Tunnel. The main section of the 14-mile Victoria under¬
ground railway in London was completed early in 1969; a 3|-mile extension
is under construction.
British constructional firms have been as active overseas as in the United
Kingdom. British consulting engineers, in particular, have built up a tradition
of knowledge and integrity which has caused their standards to become
international practice and their services to be in world-wide demand.
A British firm acts as consultant to the World Bank on the Indus Basin
irrigation scheme, the largest in the world, and several firms were involved in
the design of the Mangla Dam, Pakistan, which forms part of it. Other projects
included a new port at Dammam, to cost between £10 million and £12 million,
for the Saudi Arabian Government, and a £14-6 million university for the
Government of Libya.
Among important construction projects by British contractors in hand in
overseas countries during 1969 were: a £14 million gas treatment complex in
southern Iran, a £24 million deep-water harbour and a ^4 million air terminal
at Dubai in the Persian Gulf; bridges in Uganda and Zambia; a new capital
for British Honduras; and a £6-7 million hospital building scheme in Uganda.
It has been estimated that the total value of work carried out during the
year ending in March 1969 by over 100 British contractors, operating in 106
countries, was £204 million, compared with ^182 million in the previous
year, and that the value of new contracts obtained was £234 million, compared
with £232 million in the previous year. Members of the Association of
Consulting Engineers had projects worth about £1,638 million in hand on
1st January 1969.
The Directorate-General of Research and Development in the Ministry of
Public Building and Works is responsible for co-ordinating research and
information services to increase efficiency in the building industry. The
Building Research Station was originally set up in 1921, thus making Britain
the pioneer of organised building research, and is concerned with research
into all aspects of building. It became part of the Ministry in 1967.
The Construction Industry Research and Information Association was
formed in 1967 to extend to the whole industry the research activities
previously undertaken by the Civil Engineering Research Association and to
provide an information and advisory service. Its future is at present under
review.
The Heating and Ventilating Research Association, an industrial research
organisation, deals with problems of heating and ventilation of large buildings.
The major construction firms have research departments working on plant,
materials and methods. Other bodies concerned with research include the
universities and colleges of technology. Most of the producers of primary
building materials have trade associations which maintain research institutions
chiefly devoted to seeking new and more efficient use for their materials.

AGRICULTURE
Although Britain is a densely populated, industrialised country relying on
imports for half its food supply, agriculture remains one of its largest and
most important industries. It occupies 724,000 people or somewhat over
2 per cent of those in civil employment, provides about 3 per cent of the
gross national product, and uses 48 million of the 60 million acres of land.
In Northern Ireland 2-7 million of the 3-3 million acres of land are in
agricultural use, and the corresponding proportions for employment and
gross output are 10 per cent and 13 per cent.
THE LAND AND The soils of the country are extremely varied. Many of those in the west
and north, overlying hard rocks, are poor and thin. The lowlands and river
valleys are usually fertile, varying in texture from clay through silt to sandy
loam. There is also some peat. Clay soils everywhere necessitate under¬
drainage. Land used for farming is conventionally divided into improved land
suitable for cultivation (crops and grass) and rough grazing. In hill country
the area of improved land is often small, but is usually supplemented by
grazing on a comparatively large area of hill land.
In the United Kingdom as a whole there are 30 million acres under crops
and grass. Improved land and rough grazing together represent 81 per cent
of the land area. The rest is mountain and forest, or put to urban and kindred
uses. The area available for farming is gradually decreasing to meet the needs
of housing and industry; however, the loss is more than outweighed by the
increase in output from what remains. Rough grazing, nearly all of which is
hill or mountain land with a native herbage of coarse grasses, rushes, bracken,
heather or scrub trees, has a low potential output—usually assessed at about
one-sixth of that of agricultural land—but is valuable for sheep. In England
and Wales only about one-seventh of farming land is classified as rough
grazing. In Northern Ireland the proportion is about one-quarter, but in
Scotland it is about three-quarters.
Size and
Ownership
of Farms
For many centuries the bulk of land in Britain lay in estates ranging in size
from a few hundred acres upwards, comprising farms of varying sizes let to
tenants. Social changes of the past half-century have completely changed the
pattern of rural life in England and Scotland. Estate duties have been a
principal factor in the breaking up of estates. Most surviving estates are still
owned by private individuals or family trusts, but the Crown, local authorities,
and other corporate bodies hold considerable areas. Of the farms sold, many
have been bought by the tenants already in occupation. About half the farms
in Great Britain today are owner-occupied.
There are about 422,000 agricultural holdings in the United Kingdom.
Slightly over half are part-time holdings, the occupiers generally having
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY
301
another source of livelihood besides farming. A recent survey has shown that
there are about 220,000 full-time holdings, and about half the industry’s
total output comes from the 42,000 holdings classified as large ‘commercial’
farm businesses. A further 66,000 fall within the category of small ‘commer¬
cial’ businesses, which are able to operate as viable enterprises. Of the
remaining 112,000 full-time holdings, farming is in general on too restricted
a scale for commercial viability, and amalgamations are being encouraged.
The average size of full-time holdings in England and Wales is between
155 and 160 acres of crops and grass. In Scotland the crops and grass area of
the 22,600 full-time farms averages 167 acres although the average for the
32,900 part-time and other holdings is only 15 acres.
In Northern Ireland the land is divided into about 64,000 holdings, almost
all of which are owner-occupied. About 40 per cent of these holdings are
either very small or let in conacre (seasonal lettings for crops or grazing), so
that the number of effective farm businesses is about 38,000, of which half
provide a full-time occupation for the owner. The typical farm size is between
40 and 70 acres of crops and grass.
Most British farms produce a variety of products; the pattern varies from
farm to farm. Dairy farming is widespread throughout Britain. In England
the farms devoted primarily to arable crops are in the eastern part of the
country—in East Anglia, Kent, Lincolnshire and the East Riding of Yorkshire.
Potato and vegetable growing on a substantial scale marks the farming of the
Fens (south Lincolnshire and Cambridgeshire), the alluvial areas around the
rivers Thames and Humber and the peaty lands in south Lancashire. Else¬
where, horticultural crops are widely dispersed amongst agricultural crops.
In Scotland the rich lowlands of the east coast are also primarily arable.
Interspersed between these arable areas, and also in the Midlands, the
south-east of England and the north-east of Scotland, there are large tracts
where much of the land is under grass and the rearing and fattening of cattle
is an important enterprise. In the south-west of Scotland dairying is
extensively practised, but most of the north-west is devoted to rearing sheep
on rough hill land. The parts of England bordering the Pennine hills and most
of Wales are also sheep-rearing areas, though a good deal of dairying, based
on purchased feedingstuffs, is also done there. In Northern Ireland mixed
farming is practised, the most important products being milk, fat and store
cattle, pigs and eggs, with sheep and stock raising in the hill areas. Oats and
barley are widely grown, mainly for livestock feeding, and the only important
cash crop is potatoes, both ware and seed.
There are three main categories of grassland in the United Kingdom—
temporary grass, permanent grass and rough grazing. Temporary grass may
be part of an arable rotation, providing a break of from one to seven years
between tillage crops, or it may be part of an all-grass system where its
advantages over permanent grass are that it can provide early and late season
grazing and often heavier crops.
Since the end of the second wrorld war there has been an increase of well
over half a million acres in the area of temporary grass and the total arable
area is about 5^ million acres more than it was pre-war. In England and
Wales nearly one-half of the 24 million acres of crops and grass (excluding
over 3 million acres of rough grazing) is under permanent grass, one-third
under cereals and one-sixth under temporary grass. About three-quarters of
all agricultural land in Scotland is in rough grazing and of the 4-3 million

acres of crops and grass about one-quarter is in permanent and two-fifths in
temporary grass. Excluding about 636,000 acres of rough grazing the crops
and grass area of Northern Ireland is about 2 million acres, of which over half
is under permanent and over one-quarter under temporary grass.
Farmers everywhere are exposed to the vagaries of the weather, of pests and
diseases, and of the market; but over the past 30 years much has been done
in Britain to mitigate these risks. This has been partly due to the advance of
science, partly to self-help by farmers’ organisations, but largely to govern¬
ment action. The role of the Government as guarantor and provider of
technical and advisory services, is described on pp. 309-18.
The steady expansion in productivity which has taken place over the last 25
years is summarised in Table 21. Apart from a slight decline between 1961
and 1964 total cattle stocks have risen steadily each year since 1963. The milk-
producing herd reached its peak level in 1962, thereafter suffering a two-year
decline. Since 1964 the herd has increased each year despite heavy losses in
the foot-and-mouth epidemic of 1967-68. Numbers of sheep and lambs
reached their highest level in 1966 but declined slightly in 1967 and 1968,
while those of pigs and poultry have expanded considerably over the past
decade, though pig numbers showed a temporary reduction in 1966-67.
Production of wheat at over 3! million tons a year has almost doubled since
the end of the second world war, while barley production at over 8 million
tons a year is now more than four times the 1946 figure. There has been a
marked fall in the production of oats. Potato production is very susceptible
to weather conditions but on average adequate supplies are being maintained
from a steadily declining acreage. Between i960 and 1968 output of pigmeat
increased by over one-quarter, and eggs by just over one-fifth and these,
together with the increase in beef and milk output, resulted in higher con¬
sumption of feedingstuffs, mostly from home resources. Imports of concen¬
trated feeds have fallen slightly over the same period, from 6-i million tons
in 1960-61 to 5-8 million tons in 1968-69.
The index of agricultural net output (all holdings) at constant prices has
risen steadily. By 1953-54 it was about 56 per cent above the immediate
pre-war average. Based on the average of 1954-55 to 1956-57= 100, it was
112 in 1959-60 and 143 in 1967-68; 138 is forecast for 1968-69.
Since 1939 the population of the United Kingdom has increased by 7^ million,
or nearly 16 per cent. In spite of this growth Britain now produces about half
of its total food requirements or two-thirds of all that can be grown in
temperate climates; this latter figure comparing with about one-half before
the second world war. Home production of the principal foods is shown as a
percentage by weight of total supplies in Table 22.
Table 23 shows how the level of the main food supplies passing into
consumption has changed since before the second world war and within the
last decade. The main trends reflected in the table are that consumption of
bulky foods (carbohydrates), such as flour, has tended to decline, while that of
high-protein foods, such as meat and eggs, continues to increase with greater
availability and rising living standards.
Wheat growing is mainly confined to the East Anglia area of England.
Although there was an increase in the acreage under wheat in 1968 the bad
weather during the summer resulted in a sharp decrease in the yield per acre.

About 3-5 million tons were harvested in 1968, with average yields estimated
at 29-1 cwt per acre. Just under a half of the wheat crop is used for flour
milling, the remainder going mainly for animal feed.
Since i960 the acreage under barley has increased by nearly 80 per cent
and production has almost doubled due to improved yields. The important
malting and distilling market currently absorbs about one-sixth of the crop,
most of the remainder being used for animal feeding purposes.
The widespread use of combine harvesters has necessitated the installation
of drying and storage facilities on many farms. Such equipment is also widely
used on a co-operative basis.
In England and Wales the total acreage of fodder crops is rising slowly,
although in many cases farmers can provide winter feed more economically
Sugar Beet
Potatoes
Dairy Farming
Livestock
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 305
by increased grass production and improved methods of conservation. In
Scotland the acreage of fodder crops is declining but the acreage of turnips
and swedes is greater than in England.
Beet is grown mainly in East Anglia and Lincolnshire where most of the beet
sugar factories are situated. The crop is grown under contract to the British
Sugar Corporation, which takes the entire output at guaranteed prices and also
provides technical advice and assistance. Precision drilling is the usual method
of sowing and more than three-quarters of the crop is mechanically harvested.
Potatoes are grown in most parts of Britain. Early potatoes are cultivated
mainly in the south and on the west coast for immediate summer marketing.
The production of main crop potatoes (which may be stored until the
following spring) is centred on the eastern side of the country and in Northern
Ireland, which sends about one-sixth of its crop to Great Britain. Seed potato
requirements are met mainly from Scotland and Northern Ireland. Both areas
also export seed potatoes. The long-term trend is for the area planted with
potatoes to diminish and for yields to increase but Britain remains self-
sufficient in main crop potatoes except in years of unusually low yield. The
acreage has declined from 829,000 acres in i960 to an estimated 691,000 acres
in 1968. The yield in 1968 was 9-8 tons per acre, the record being io-i tons
per acre in 1965. Although the planting, cultivation, harvesting and grading
of the potato crop are becoming increasingly mechanised, much hand labour
is still needed.
Milk is much more valuable when sold on the liquid milk market than when
converted into cheese, butter or other milk products. In Great Britain milk
is produced primarily for liquid consumption, but in Northern Ireland the
greater part of the milk is used for manufactured products. Average
consumption per head is nearly five pints per week.
Average yields per dairy cow have increased during the last decade by more
than 11 per cent and now average over 800 gallons a year. Freedom from
tuberculosis has reduced herd wastage, and through the artificial insemination
(AI) centres, operated by the Milk Marketing Boards and other organisations,
the influence of a relatively small number of high-potential bulls is widely
disseminated. It is estimated that about two-thirds of Britain’s total cattle
are bred by AI. The Friesian breed is dominant in the dairy herds of England,
Wales and Northern Ireland, but in Scotland the Ayrshire breed is the most
numerous. Milk production has also been stimulated by advances in grassland
management, intensive grazing techniques and new methods of making high
quality hay; new methods of conversion into silage are being exploited. Most
dairy farmers practise some degree of intensive grass management, but hay of
the traditional type remains the basic winter feed; it is supplemented with
purchased concentrates.
Clean dairy farming methods and hygienic standards for equipment and
buildings used in milk production are prescribed by regulations made and
enforced by the appropriate ministers.
A great number of specialised breeds of livestock have been developed over
the centuries in Britain. It has been found that they meet the needs of breeders
in most countries and substantial export sales are made to buyers seeking
to replenish and improve their herds with British animals.
In the hill regions hardy herds of beef cattle are kept, especially of the Galloway
and Welsh Black breeds and their crosses; in marginal land and lower areas
Beef Cattle
3°6
Sheep
Pigs
Poultry
Horticultural
Crops
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the sires used are predominantly of the Aberdeen Angus and Hereford breeds.
About two-thirds of home-fed beef production derives from the dairy herds,
some females being mated to beef sires, the majority by AI. There is a large
and complex trade in store cattle (increased by animals imported from the
Irish Republic), a typical movement being from the upland west to grazing
areas in the Midlands.
Britain has outstandingly good pastures for sheep. Moreover, veterinary
research has provided vaccine and sera protection against nearly all the
epidemic diseases to which sheep are subject. More than 30 breeds and
innumerable crosses are to be found in Britain, each breed having originated
within a circumscribed area.
In the hills, and especially in the Highlands, winter conditions are usually
severe. Draft ewes and lambs are brought from the hill areas every autumn
to swell the lowland flocks, usually in two stages: first, to farms at inter¬
mediate altitudes, where they are mated with rams of a larger and more
rapidly maturing breed; then, the cross-bred progeny pass on in due course
to the more genial lowland conditions and especially to the Midlands and the
south and east of England, where they become crossed again with Down
rams for fat lamb production. The hill breeds bring in hardiness and the
lowland sires fecundity and early maturity.
Although wool is of considerable importance to the sheep farmer the main
object is the production of fat lambs; this reflects the change in the preference
of consumers away from mature sheep.
Pig production is carried on in most parts of Britain but is particularly
important in the eastern counties of England. In the past pigs were found on
the majority of farms but there is now an increasing concentration into
specialist units and larger herds. The most frequently used breeds are the
Large White and the Landrace though considerable cross-breeding takes place.
Pig improvements are fostered by the Meat and Livestock Commission and
by leading commercial firms through schemes for progeny and performance
testing, litter recording and other development work. Attention is focused
on utility qualities, such as size and weight of litters, and on food consumed
per pound of liveweight gain. AI is available as a nationwide service.
Carcases are used for curing as bacon, for sale as fresh pork and for manu¬
facturing into sausages and other processed forms. In terms of pig meat,
about 30 per cent is used for bacon and 70 per cent for pork and manufacturing.
Specialist techniques and intensive husbandry have been introduced over a
large part of the poultry industry and considerable concentration has occurred.
There are now several flocks of over 100,000 birds and only a small pro¬
portion of total production is in the hands of the smallest producers. Nearly
80 per cent of the laying birds on farms are in flocks of 1,000 or more. With the
rise in the poultry population and in the yield of eggs per bird (now averaging
over 200 eggs a year), the estimated production of eggs has more than doubled
the 1938 level and for several years nearly all eggs consumed in Britain have
been home-produced. About 274 million broilers and other special table
chickens were produced in 1968.
Horticultural crops occupy only a small fraction of the cultivated land of
the country—about 2| per cent of the area under crops and grass—but
their value in terms of output per acre is very high. The total value of
horticultural crops sold in 1968-69 is estimated at about £201 million,
compared with some ^1,970 million for total agricultural output in the United
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 307
Kingdom. About 440,000 acres are under vegetables, about 220,000 acres
under fruit, and 35,000 acres under flowers and nursery stocks.
Market gardening has grown up around all the large centres of population,
notably in the Lea Valley, near London, and in more rural areas with favour¬
able soil or climatic conditions—in Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire, Lincoln¬
shire, Hampshire and Kent, and in a concentration of smallholdings in the
Vale of Evesham. Districts with mild climates, such as the Penzance region of
Cornwall, have been favoured for the production of selected early crops. More
recently, selected vegetable crops, particularly peas, have been grown in
rapidly increasing quantities for quick-freezing.
Specialised horticultural holdings range from a few acres up to about
300 acres, and many have glasshouses, frames or forcing houses. Use of
fertilisers, particularly of an organic nature, is very heavy, and much of the
field work is mechanised. The larger holdings normally have specialised
packing sheds, with washing and grading machinery, and irrigation plants.
Growers, however, often join together in co-operatives for marketing their
produce and many of these provide grading and packing facilities.
Britain has over 4,000 acres of glasshouses, about half of the area being
used primarily for the cultivation of tomatoes, the main centres of which
are the Lea Valley in Essex and Hertfordshire, Lancashire, the East Riding
of Yorkshire, the rest of Essex, and Sussex. In the Lea Valley, on a narrow
belt of gravel and brick earth, about 500 acres are covered with glass. Produc¬
tion of tomatoes is estimated at about 80,000 to 85,000 tons annually and the
value of all glasshouse crops (including flowers) at some £40 million per year.
Hard fruits are grown in many parts of England and Wales, the chief risk
associated with their culture being late frosts. The main centres are in the
south, south-west and east of England, and Kent in particular. The acreage
of Cox’s Orange Pippin has increased in recent years but that of other dessert
varieties and of cooking apples has declined. About 23,000 acres of varieties of
cider apple are grown mainly in Devon, Herefordshire and Somerset for the
cider-making industry. In Northern Ireland there are 7,000 acres of cooking
apples—Bramley Seedlings—mostly concentrated in County Armagh. Plums
and soft fruits are grown in many counties; concentrations of plums and
cherries are found in Kent and Worcestershire, of blackcurrants in Norfolk,
Kent, Herefordshire and Worcestershire; and of strawberries in the Wisbech
area and in Kent. Raspberries are exceptional in that of some 8,800 acres
grown in Britain over four-fifths are in Scotland, mainly in the Blairgowrie
district of Perthshire and in Angus.
Hop-growing for the brewing industry is confined to two main areas, in Kent
and Sussex and in Herefordshire and Worcestershire. Capital outlay and
cultivation costs are very high, but crops per acre average about 12 cwt.,
worth some ^460. The total annual value of the crop is about ^7 million.
Estimates of farm expenses and sales and the aggregate net income of agri¬
cultural producers are prepared annually by the agricultural departments
(see Table 24). They show that Britain’s farming is based on livestock; two-
thirds of farmers’ income is derived from the sale of animals or their products.
The aggregate net income of farmers rose from £393 million in 1960-61 to
£477 million in 1968-69. The annual cost of direct support to agriculture
from public funds has averaged ^255 million during the past five years.
Of farm expenses, machinery and equipment amount to about one-sixth,
feedingstuffs about one-third and wages about one-fifth. Since i960
