agricultural earnings have risen by nearly 55 per cent, offsetting the manpower
economies made possible by mechanisation.
Until 1958 rents tended to lag behind other costs. This was due partly to
the reluctance of landlords to put up the rents of satisfactory tenants, and
partly to the terms of reference given to arbitrators. These terms were
modified in the Agriculture Act 1958 and since i960 rents in England and
Wales have gone up by nearly 90 per cent.
The capital required for land and buildings may be provided by the farmer,
if he is an owner-occupier, or by the landlord, if the farm is let to a tenant.
In 1968 ‘fixed capital’ totalling about ^85 million was added to the value of
land and buildings (annual gross investment in fixed assets exceeds £200
million). The bulk of the capital required to stock and run the farms is
provided by the occupiers. Bank advances are an important source of outside
capital, both fixed and working; about half the total bank advances to agri¬
culture are believed to be for short-term purposes. Agricultural merchants are
also an important source of short-term credit. Mortgage loans form the chief
source of long-term credit and are provided by building societies, insurance
companies, private sources, and specialised financial institutions (see p. 313).
Accounts of some 2,000 farms in England and Wales, collected by university
agricultural economists in 1967-68, show average valuations of occupiers’
capital ranging from over £10 to more than £65 per acre. In Scotland a similar
sample of 800 accounts shows a wide range in valuations per acre, from about
£2 on hill sheep farms with extensive rough grazings to between £50 and
£60 per acre on lowland farms. In Northern Ireland average valuations of
occupiers’ capital range from over £100 on the smaller, more intensive farms
to £50 per acre on the larger farms. On all types of farms investment in
machinery is a heavy item: on dairy farms it averages £17 per acre and on
Mechanisation
Net Incomes
THE ROLE
OF THE
GOVERNMENT
Government
Policy
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 309
arable farms nearly £20 per acre; on stock-rearing farms it may amount to
£6 per acre.
Britain has one of the heaviest tractor densities in the world, with over half a
million tractors in 1968, or one to every 35 acres of arable land. Power-take-off
implements now characterise arable farming; and some 70,000 combine
harvesters were in use in 1968. A wide variety of machines for harvesting
and preservation of grass are employed. Milking machines are installed
on all except the smallest farms, many with mechanical means of handling
milk.
Over 90 per cent of the farms in Great Britain have an electricity supply
and accompanying equipment. There are about 1,100 farmers’ machinery
syndicates through which farmers have the use of expensive equipment
without tying up their own capital.
Research, development and testing of farm machinery are carried out by
the National Institute of Agricultural Engineering.
The range of net incomes between individual farms is very wide, varying
with the type and size of farm, quality of land, and managerial ability of the
occupier. The average net income for farms of different types is mostly within
the range of £5 to ^16 per acre with the exception of pig and poultry farms
and horticultural holdings, which are more intensive in their use of land. Net
income per acre on dairy and arable farms has nearly always been higher than
on stock-rearing farms, which are generally larger than the other types and
are situated on poorer land.
By the beginning of the 1930s the need for some form of State assistance
to agriculture had become pressing: it was during this time that the
Government initiated the various forms of protection and financial assistance
for agriculture.
During the second world war and the immediate post-war years, agri¬
cultural production was closely controlled by the State, with County War
Agricultural Executive Committees, composed of landowners, farmers and
farm workers, acting as the Government’s local agents.
Government policy today is founded on the Agriculture Act 1947. The
main objective, as set out in Section 1 of the Act, continues to be ‘a stable
and efficient agricultural industry capable of producing such part of the
nation’s food and other agricultural produce as in the national interest it is
desirable to produce in the United Kingdom, and of producing it at minimum
prices consistent with proper remuneration and living conditions for farmers
and workers in agriculture and an adequate return on capital invested in
the industry’. To this end, the Government is empowered to provide, for
the main agricultural products, guaranteed prices determined in the light of
annual reviews (see p. 310).
The Agriculture Act of 1957 assured farmers that the prices guaranteed
under the 1947 Act would not be steeply reduced, and at the same time
provided grants towards the cost of bringing fixed equipment up to date.
The Agriculture and Horticulture Act 1964 gave the Government powers
to introduce minimum import prices for agricultural and horticultural
products. These powers have been used in the case of cereals. In the same
year an understanding with overseas suppliers on the sharing of the bacon
market became effective. This was renewed in 1969.

Machinery of
Government
CURRENT
SUPPORT POLICY
Annual Review
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In 1968 the selective expansion programme, announced in 1965, was
extended to 1973. The agricultural industry is expected to increase production 1
to produce substantial import savings on temperate foodstuffs.
The functions of government in relation to agriculture are mostly exercised
by the agricultural ministers, that is to say, for England and Wales the ^
Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food and the Secretary of State for
Wales, for Scotland the Secretary of State for Scotland, and for Northern !
Ireland the Home Secretary, who is the minister responsible for United
Kingdom aspects of Northern Ireland agriculture, local aspects being the
responsibility of the Northern Ireland Minister of Agriculture. The agri¬
cultural ministers are assisted by advisory committees composed of general
agriculturists, scientists and other specialists.
The headquarters of the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food is
divided functionally, each division being responsible for a particular subject
or service. Its relations with individual farmers are conducted mainly through
its local offices, grouped in England in regions, each administered by a
regional controller working in close collaboration with the regional heads of the
technical services. Local offices in Wales are grouped under a Welsh Secretary
with similar functions and with special responsibility for Welsh affairs.
In Scotland most of the agricultural functions of the Secretary of State are
discharged through the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries. The
Secretary of State for Scotland also appoints the members of the Crofters
Commission (see p. 314) and the Red Deer Commission, which deals with the
conservation and control of red deer.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture is responsible for imple- ,
menting agricultural policy inaugurated by the Northern Ireland Government.
It is organised on similar lines to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and
Food, for which it acts as agent in the administration in Northern Ireland
of United Kingdom agricultural schemes.
In November 1966 an Economic Development Committee (see p. 237) f°r
agriculture was established, comprising representatives of farmers, workers
and landowners, as well as official members.
In February each year, in accordance with the 1947 Act, the agricultural
ministers review the economic condition and prospects of the industry.
Between annual reviews, a special review may be held if the ministers consider
it warranted, but this has seldom been necessary. In holding reviews, the
ministers are required to consult with representatives of agricultural pro¬
ducers—in practice, the three farmers’ unions in the United Kingdom. The
ministers consider such factors as production trends and market requirements,
world market prospects, the cost of subsidies, the trend of profits in the
industry as a whole, the increasing efficiency of the industry and changes in
production costs, trading relations (especially with the Commonwealth) and
the national economic situation. In the light of their conclusions, they
determine guaranteed prices for fat cattle, fat sheep, fat pigs, eggs, wool,
milk, cereals, potatoes and sugar beet. These guarantees apply to livestock
and livestock products for the ensuing 12 months, and to crops to be
harvested in the current year. Various grants in aid of particular kinds of
production or farming practice (known as ‘production grants’) are also
considered. Any changes in ‘relevant’ production grants (broadly, those
payable to occupiers rather than landowners) are taken into account. The

RETAILING
Price
Guarantees
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 3H
Government’s conclusions and its decisions on changes in guaranteed prices
and relevant production grants are published as a White Paper.
The Agriculture Act 1957 gave statutory effect to long-term assurances that
set minimum limits to the price determinations that may be made after an
Annual Review. The cost of government support to the industry in 1968-69
was about £281 million; the estimate for 1969-70, adjusted for the effect of
the 1969 review decisions, forecast an increase to about ^3million.
The general policy of the Government is to use methods of agricultural
support that allow the ordinary channels of trade to flow freely. The form of
guarantee most generally used is the deficiency payment, which means that
the Government makes payments to producers, related to the differences
between the average market price realised and the guaranteed price, for
output eligible for the guarantee.
The deficiency payments scheme for cereals is administered directly by the
agricultural departments, and storage incentives are paid to growers who sell
their wheat and barley after the harvest period. ‘Standard quantity’1 arrange¬
ments for wheat and barley were introduced for the 1964 crop but were
abolished in 1968 and 1969 respectively. Deficiency payments for fatstock
are made weekly to producers on certified sales on a liveweight or deadweight
basis. For cattle and sheep there may also be a balancing payment at the end
of the year if the average return to producers falls short of the annual
guaranteed price.
For most of the remaining commodities and for fat pigs in Northern
Ireland, the Government operates the guarantee through the appropriate
marketing board, which takes account of any payments from or to the
Government in deciding what to pay producers for their produce. In the case
of milk there are five boards, and the full guaranteed price is paid only on a
‘standard quantity’ relating to the volume of liquid milk sales plus a reasonable
reserve. Milk produced in excess of the standard quantity is sold for manu¬
facturing considerably below the full guaranteed price. The retail price of
liquid milk is determined by the Government so as to cover the full cost of
the guarantee and, taking one year with another, there is no Exchequer
subsidy. For eggs, a subsidy is paid to the British Egg Marketing Board on all
first-quality eggs sold to the Board through packing stations. The Govern¬
ment intends to phase out the subsidy and remove eggs from the guarantee
by the end of March 1974. A deficiency payment is made for potatoes in years
in which the growers’ average price for potatoes for human consumption
(excluding new potatoes) is less than the guaranteed price; payment for the
benefit of growers is made to the Potato Marketing Board in Great Britain
and to the Ministry of Agriculture, Northern Ireland. Surpluses are purchased
by these authorities for stockfeed.
For wool a fixed price is guaranteed to the British Wool Marketing Board
for every pound of fleece wool it buys from producers. This enables it to
fix in advance a schedule of producers’ prices, based on types and quality,
after making allowance for the Board’s marketing costs.
1 The Agriculture Act 1947 postulates that the guarantees should be related to the
volume of agricultural produce which, in the national interest, it is desirable to produce
domestically (see p. 309). This is effected by including standard quantities in the
guarantee arrangements for milk, pigs, potatoes and sugar beet. Standard quantity
arrangements vary in form but, in general, the basic guaranteed price determined in
the Annual Review is related to a specific quantity of produce marketed annually on a
national basis; if this quantity is exceeded, the producers’ average unit return falls.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Under the Sugar Act 1956 and the Agriculture Act 1957 the British
Sugar Corporation contracts to buy the whole of the sugar beet crop pro¬
duced from a specified acreage (at present 443,000 acres) at a scale of fixed
prices, determined as a result of the annual review and related to sugar
content. Refined sugar produced by the Corporation is sold, under market¬
sharing agreements with the refiners, at a price based on the world price.
The Sugar Board buys Commonwealth sugar under the Commonwealth
Sugar Agreement and sells it commercially. The deficits or surpluses which
result from the transactions of both the Corporation and the Board are
ultimately reflected in the Board’s accounts. When these accounts show a
deficit a levy is charged on all sugar, imported or home-produced, entering
the British market, including the sugar content of composite sugar imports,
and when there is a surplus a distribution payment is made correspondingly,
so that taking one year with another the Board balances its accounts.
The price supports outlined above relate only to current production. To
increase productivity, however, the Government offers to farmers a wide
range of inducements, known as production grants, for improvements to land,
crops, livestock and equipment. In 1968-69 the Exchequer’s contribution in
the form of production grants was ^’130 million. The form taken by these
schemes varies considerably but they fall into three main categories. Firstly,
improvements to land fertility, which include a subsidy on fertilisers and
lime and grants for field drainage, farm water supply and for ploughing certain
kinds of land; the Exchequer cost of these improvements currently runs at
over £45 million a year. The second type of inducement is aimed at main¬
taining breeding herds of cattle and flocks of sheep (particularly in upland
areas) and includes a calf subsidy on animals suitable for beef production;
the total cost is nearly £55 million a year. The third type consists of a
contribution towards farm improvements generally but with particular
reference to farm buildings, silage, roads, fences and other equipment. A
special business management scheme exists to help small farmers improve
the efficiency of their holdings. A grant is also available to farmers and
growers to encourage the keeping of farm business records as an aid to sound
management decisions. Under the Agriculture Act 1967 a hill land improve¬
ment scheme was introduced which provides for 50 per cent grants for various
improvements designed to increase the productivity of hill land.
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government is empowered to make
grants to meet 50 per cent of the approved costs of voluntary amalgamations
of small farms with other land to form commercial units; and to pay lump
sums or annuities to farmers who give up such holdings for amalgamation.
Where an owner wishes to dispose of an uncommercial holding the Govern¬
ment may buy it outright for this purpose.
Horticultural produce, because it is perishable and liable to seasonal variation
in quantity and quality, does not lend itself to a system of guaranteed prices.
Hitherto the principal means of support has been tariffs on imports, but
greater emphasis has now been placed on the need to strengthen the com¬
petitive efficiency of the industry so as to reduce its dependence upon tariffs.
To this end grants of one-third are available to meet the capital cost of a wide
range of buildings, plant and equipment used in the production, storage, pre¬
paration for market and transport of horticultural produce. Additionally, small-
scale horticulturists who are prepared to undertake a three-year programme for

OTHER

ASSISTANCE
AND ACTION
Agricultural

Smallholdings
313
improving the efficiency of their businesses may qualify for a grant of up to
£500. The cost to the Exchequer of these schemes is over £4 million a year.
Special arrangements for the agricultural and horticultural industries have
been made under the investment incentives procedure which replaced invest¬
ment allowances in 1966. Broadly speaking, the Minister of Agriculture in
England, Wales and Northern Ireland and the Secretary of State in Scotland
are empowered to pay grants of 10 per cent of approved expenditure on fixed
equipment, plant and machinery, agricultural tractors and self-propelled
harvesters, and 5 per cent supplements to other improvement grants with a
basic rate of 45 per cent or less. For expenditure incurred between January
1967 and December 1968 grants have been paid at 15 per cent for tractors and
self-propelled harvesters, and at I2| per cent for fixed equipment.
A number of facilities for specific purposes enjoy government encouragement
and support.
In England and Wales finance for the purchase or improvement of agri¬
cultural property is available from the Agricultural Mortgage Corporation
Ltd. (see p. 375). The Corporation’s funds are derived mainly from public
issues of stock, but it receives a measure of government support. Similarly
in Scotland, loans for agricultural purposes secured on agricultural land in
Scotland are granted by the Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd.
Improvement loans for carrying out improvements to agricultural land and
buildings are also available to landowners from the Lands Improvement
Company, whose funds are provided privately.
In Northern Ireland loans are available to farmers from the Agricultural
Loans Fund, administered by the Ministry of Agriculture and financed out
of public funds. Half of the loans issued are short-term for agricultural
machinery and the remainder are medium- or long-term loans for such
purposes as the purchase of livestock, the erection and improvement of farm
buildings and farm dwellings, and the purchase of land for amalgamation and
subsequent restructuring.
Under the Agriculture Act 1967 the Government can make loans in Great
Britain to help finance the purchase of land acquired for approved amalgam¬
ations of small farms (see p. 312), and approved remodelling expenditure.
These loans may be granted up to 90 per cent (100 per cent for certain small
amalgamations) of the valuation of the combined unit determined by the
Agricultural Mortgage Corporation Ltd. in England and Wales and the
Scottish Agricultural Securities Corporation Ltd. in Scotland, which act as
the Government’s agents.
Since 1892 county councils and county borough councils in England and
Wales have had powers to provide land for smallholdings. County councils are
obliged by statute to provide smallholdings and the Minister of Agriculture
is empowered to contribute towards their losses. In England and Wales,
about 13,250 smallholdings are provided by local authorities and about
950 by the Ministry. The Minister may also make loans for working capital
to tenants of statutory smallholdings. In this way they can be helped to
obtain livestock, machinery, implements and other necessary items; tenants
must, however, have available at least 25 per cent of the capital required.
Land settlement in Scotland has always been carried out by the central
Government, which now owns and maintains about 420,000 acres of land
settlement estates, comprising some 3,450 crofts and holdings.

Crofting
Arterial

Land Tenure
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In the seven Scottish crofting counties—Argyll, Caithness, Inverness,
Orkney, Ross and Cromarty, Sutherland, and Shetland—much of the land is
farmed by crofters, tenant farmers whose holdings are generally either
rented at a cost of not more than £50 a year or have an area not exceeding
75 acres.
In these counties there are about 19,000 crofts, which produce about
one-quarter of the total agricultural output of the area. The special problems
of the crofting counties, which had for some time been suffering from a
declining population, led to the setting up, in 1955, of a Crofters Commission
whose functions are to reorganise, develop and regulate crofting in the
crofting counties, to promote the interests of crofters and to keep under review
matters relating to crofting. The Commission’s statutory powers include
supervising the letting of crofts and (if the crofters agree) the reallocation of
land to form viable and self-contained communities; it also acts as the
Secretary of State’s agent in administering development grants and loans.
Land drainage (including flood protection) in England and Wales is the
responsibility of 27 river authorities (see p. 295), two catchment and 372
internal drainage boards. Local authorities also have general drainage powers.
There are no comparable authorities in Scotland, where arterial drainage of
agricultural land is the owners’ responsibility. River authorities have powers
to maintain and improve watercourses scheduled as main rivers. Their work
is concerned with the improvement of land drainage by increasing the capacity
and efficiency of rivers and erecting pumping stations, the prevention of
inland flooding and the erection of defences to protect low-lying areas from
coastal flooding. River authorities also have powers relating to water resources
generally, freshwater fisheries and river pollution.
Internal drainage boards are concerned with very much smaller areas and
their work is chiefly in low-lying agricultural districts. Their main function is
to keep the land drained in their area by improving the main drains and,
where necessary, by pumping from low-lying land.
Drainage authorities derive their income directly or indirectly from local
authority funds. The Government pays grants towards the cost of the
improvement schemes. Grants to river authorities vary from 10 per cent to
80 per cent according to the financial position of the authority, with an
additional premium for sea defence works. Internal drainage boards receive
grants at a flat rate of 50 per cent. Local authorities receive grants varying
from 20 per cent to 50 per cent. In Scotland 50 per cent grants are available
to owners or occupiers of agricultural land.
In Northern Ireland the Ministry of Agriculture is the drainage authority
in respect of watercourses designated by the Drainage Council as main or
minor watercourses.
In Great Britain about half, and in Northern Ireland almost all, farms are
owner-occupied. The traditional form of tenancy in England and Wales runs
from year to year; in Scotland longer leases for terms of 10 to 14 years are
more common, although most tenants farm on a year-to-year basis. The
tenancy agreement may be either written or verbal (in Scotland it must be
written if the period of the lease exceeds one year) and may (but need not)
include provisions about such matters as rights of cropping, liability for repair
and maintenance, and compensation for tenant’s improvements.
In order to protect the respective interests of landlords and tenants and to
eliminate uncertainty as to their rights and liabilities, a code of landlord and
MARKETING
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 315
tenant relationships has been written into legislation. The Agriculture Acts
1947 (England and Wales) and 1948 (Scotland) lay down the basic rules of
good estate management and good husbandry for owners and occupiers
respectively. The Agricultural Holdings Acts 1948 (England and Wales)
and 1949 (Scotland) as amended by the Agriculture Act 1958 and the Agri¬
culture (Miscellaneous Provisions) Acts of 1963 and 1968 contain more detailed
provisions concerning the rights and obligations of landlords and tenants.
The Acts provide for any tenancy of agricultural land, with the exception
of certain short-term lettings to which exemption can be given by the Minister
or Secretary of State, to continue in force from year to year until terminated
by a valid notice to quit. With certain exceptions the tenant can contest it
by serving a counter-notice; the notice to quit then becomes inoperative
unless the landlord can satisfy an independent body (in England and Wales
the Agricultural Land Tribunal and in Scotland the Scottish Land Court) that
his claim for possession is in the interests of sound estate management or good
husbandry or that the land is required for certain purposes specified in the
Acts.
The Acts lay down a code of compensation to which the tenant is entitled
on termination of the tenancy. Rent is a matter for negotiation between
landlord and tenant and may be varied by agreement at any time or, failing
agreement, by arbitration at intervals of not less than three years in England
and Wales and five years in Scotland.
Agricultural products are marketed mainly through private trade channels
such as corn merchants, livestock auctions and markets, and bacon factories;
or through producers’ co-operative organisations. For certain commodities,
however, marketing arrangements are influenced by boards operating under
the Agricultural Marketing Act 1958 (which consolidated earlier legislation).
These marketing boards are producers’ organisations with statutory powers
to regulate the marketing of particular products. The schemes under which
they are constituted and operate must be approved by Parliament and
confirmed by a poll of the producers. Most of the members of the boards are
elected by the producers but a minority are appointed by the minister or
ministers concerned. Further safeguards serve to protect consumers and other
interests affected by schemes and the public interest generally.
Marketing boards fall into two broad categories: first, those which are
sole buyers of the regulated product from all producers not specially exempted
or, alternatively, those exercising a comparable influence by controlling all
contracts between producers and first buyers; and, secondly, boards which
maintain only a broad control over marketing conditions, leaving producers free
otherwise to deal individually with buyers. The boards for eggs, hops, milk
and wool fall into the first category and the potato board into the second.
Northern Ireland has its own marketing boards, based on local legislation,
for milk, pigs and seed potatoes.
The Home-Grown Cereals Authority, established to improve the marketing
of home-grown cereals, operates a scheme of bonuses and provides market
intelligence. It has reserve trading powers.
The Meat and Livestock Commission, established under the Agriculture
Act 1967, is charged with improving the production, marketing and distribu¬
tion of livestock and meat in Great Britain. It has a range of executive
functions extending from breeding to retail distribution, one of the most
important of which is to evolve a general scheme of carcase classification. It is
not empowered to trade in either livestock or meat.

Grants of up to one-third are available for the modernisation of major
wholesale horticultural markets; Covent Garden market is being moved to a
new site in south London, which should be in use in the early 1970s.
National statutory grades are being introduced to improve the competitive
position of home produce as against imported supplies and to speed its transit
through distributive channels. By May 1968 grades had been introduced for
apples, pears, tomatoes, cucumbers and cauliflowers.
The Apple and Pear Development Council publicises home-grown apples
and pears to increase sales.
In 1962 the Government earmarked million to assist the financing of
research and development in the marketing of agricultural and horticultural
produce. By March 1969 grants totalling about ^1-25 million had been
approved. The grant ceiling has been raised to £2 million and the scheme
extended to March 1971 to assist marketing developments other than those of
a co-operative nature.
The Central Council for Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation was
established under the provisions of the Agriculture Act 1967 to promote and
develop co-operation in agriculture and horticulture and to administer a
scheme of grants. The Agricultural and Horticultural Co-operation Scheme
1967 incorporates and extends grants for co-operative production and
marketing of agricultural and horticultural produce.
The day-to-day work of treating animal disease is the responsibility of the
veterinary profession in private practice. The State veterinary service,
inaugurated in 1865 and covering Great Britain, deals with situations beyond
the control of the individual veterinary surgeon. Centred on London and
Edinburgh, it is able to deal promptly with outbreaks of notifiable diseases.
For many years Britain has been free from many serious animal diseases,
including rinderpest, sheep scab, glanders and rabies. The campaign to
eradicate swine fever has been successful. A major epidemic of foot-and-
mouth disease was experienced towards the end of 1967 but was eradicated
successfully by a stringent slaughter policy supported by other vigorous
control measures; the last case of the disease occurred in June 1968. In i960
the whole of the United Kingdom became a bovine tuberculosis attested area.
The incidence of bovine tuberculosis is now very low; all cattle are tuberculin
tested at regular intervals and reactors to the test are slaughtered, compensa¬
tion being paid to the owners. In 1967 the Brucellosis (Accredited Herds)
scheme was introduced as a first stage towards eradication of the disease.
The work of the service is backed by the extensive facilities of the Central
Veterinary Laboratory at Weybridge, Surrey, and those of its subsidiary
laboratory at Lasswade, near Edinburgh. In addition, there are 21 investiga¬
tion centres with well-equipped laboratories in England and Wales. These
centres perform work requiring specialist knowledge and give advice on
disease problems to private practitioners. In Scotland a similar service is
provided by the investigation centres of the three Scottish agricultural
colleges.
In Northern Ireland the veterinary services are organised similarly to those
in Great Britain but are administered separately by the Northern Ireland
Government. Animal Health Control policies and the geographical situation
have kept the country free from nearly all the major epizootic diseases. A
scheme for the eradication of brucellosis was almost complete by the end of

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 317
1969. The full-time veterinary service is supplemented by the central
veterinary laboratory at Stormont, Belfast.
The State plant health service is responsible for statutory controls designed
to limit the spread of plant pests and diseases present in Britain and prevent
the introduction of new ones from abroad. It also issues the health certificates
required by other countries to accompany plant material imported from
Britain. Voluntary certification schemes are operated to encourage the develop¬
ment of healthy, vigorous and true-to-type planting stocks, particularly of
crops subject to degenerative diseases. The Plant Pathology Laboratory at
Harpenden, Hertfordshire, provides the information on which statutory
controls and certification schemes are based.
The problems of controlling mammalian pests and birds are studied at the
Ministry of Agriculture’s Infestation Control Laboratory at Tolworth, Surrey,
and its Land Pests Department at Worplesdon, Surrey. The laboratories
provide information to and liaise closely with Regional Pest Officers who in
turn advise local authorities, farmers and others concerned with these problems.
Safeguards against the dangers which could arise from uncontrolled use of
pesticides have been devised and are operating successfully. Regulations made
under the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 provide protection
for workers using the more toxic chemicals. The voluntary Pesticides Safety
Precautions Scheme, operated by the Government with the full backing of
the industry, ensures that new pesticides for use in agriculture and food
storage, or new methods of using existing pesticides, are not introduced until
enough experimental work has been done on their attendant hazards (including
contamination of food and harm to wild life) to allow the Government to make
recommendations for their safe use. Products approved for safety may then
be submitted through the Agricultural Chemicals Approval Scheme for
efficiency approval. There is also a voluntary Veterinary Products Safety
Precautions Scheme on similar lines.
A key role in the administration of both these schemes is played by the
Government’s Advisory Committee on Pesticides and Other Toxic Chemicals.
Reports of this Committee, published in 1964, concluded that there was no
evidence that the use of the persistent organochlorine pesticides presented any
immediate hazard to human beings and animals, apart from certain species of
predatory birds. In 1967 the Committee recommended that the voluntary safety
precautions schemes should be replaced by compulsory licensing arrangements.
In England and Wales free technical advice on all agricultural and horticultural
matters, other than veterinary, is available through the Ministry’s National
Agricultural Advisory Service (NAAS), which is organised on a regional and
county basis. Every county has a county agricultural adviser and is divided
into districts, in each of which there is a district agricultural adviser who can
call on an extensive system of specialist advisers. In Northern Ireland
advisory work is organised by the Ministry of Agriculture, with a county
organisation similar to the NAAS. In Scotland the advisory services, also
similar in scope to the NAAS, are based on the three agricultural colleges.
The Agricultural Land Service, through its qualified land agents, surveyors
and architects, provides a service without charge to owners and occupiers of
both agricultural and horticultural land needing advice on problems arising
RESEARCH AND
EDUCATION

and Market

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
from the ownership of land, and investment connected with it. The services
include general advice on the design, layout and construction or improvement
of all types of farm and horticultural buildings as well as roads, fences, shelter
belts and effluent disposal. The Service also provides professional advice and
services to the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food.
Basic agricultural research in Britain is described on p. 198. In England and
Wales, research and advice on farm economics are combined in the Provincial
Agricultural Economics Service, which comprise ten university Departments
of Agricultural Economics and which is co-ordinated by the Ministry of
Agriculture, Fisheries and Food. In Scotland, agricultural economists are
on the staff of the three agricultural colleges. The agricultural departments
in England and Wales and Scotland have economics and statistics units.
The Northern Ireland Ministry of Agriculture also has an Economics and
Statistics Division and nine other Research Divisions dealing with different
aspects of agricultural research and development.
There are four types of institution which provide full-time education in
agricultural subjects: universities; non-maintained agricultural colleges; in
England and Wales, county agricultural colleges and institutes; and in
Scotland, farm schools. Twelve universities in Britain provide degree and
postgraduate training in agriculture. A National College of Agricultural
Engineering was established in i960 at Silsoe, Bedfordshire, and it offers
degree and postgraduate courses in agricultural engineering. In Northern
Ireland there are three agricultural colleges and two more are planned.
A new pattern of three-year sandwich courses leading to diplomas has
been introduced at three of the four non-maintained agricultural colleges and
at 12 of the county agricultural colleges and institutes in England and Wales.
The older two-year courses will be phased out in a year or two as the new
pattern becomes established. The 31 county colleges and institutes in England
and the five in Wales also provide one-year residential courses in general
agriculture or horticulture with supplementary courses covering the various
specialisms in greater depth. Local education authorities also provide short
courses, block-release, day-release and other part-time classes for farmers,
farm workers and horticulturists, as well as an advisory service for domestic
producers.
There are eight farm schools in Scotland, run by local education authorities,
providing courses—mainly residential—of from one to three years’ duration
for boys and girls of from 12 to 16 years. There is one residential agricultural
school in Northern Ireland, which provides short courses for boys over
15 years of age.
Courses in land management are available at the Universities of Cambridge
and London and at the Royal Agricultural College, Cirencester.
FISHERIES
The sea fishing industry is of especial importance to the economy of Scotland.
In the rest of the United Kingdom it is an important source of employment in
the major fishing ports. The industry falls into three main divisions, concerned
respectively with white fish, herring and shellfish. The major element of the
catch (about 85 per cent by weight) is white fish: the catches of herring and
shellfish, although important, are relatively small. White fish are demersal fish
Fishing Ports
Methods of
Sea Fishing
The Fishing
Fleet
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 319
(such as cod, haddock, plaice, turbot and sole) which live on or near the sea
bed, and also pelagic fish (such as pilchard, mackerel and sprats) which live
mainly in intermediate waters or near the surface. Herring is a pelagic species
and constitutes a separate fishery. Shellfish include Crustacea (such as
lobsters, nephrops and crabs) and molluscs (such as escallops, mussels, cockles
and oysters).
The white fish section of the industry is made up of three main groups:
the distant water, the near and middle water, and the inshore fisheries. The
distant waters are those round Iceland and in the west Atlantic, Greenland,
Bear Island and the north coast of Norway, and the Barents Sea; the middle
water grounds lie around the Faroe Islands; and the near water grounds are
those in the North Sea, the Irish Sea and in the coastal areas around Britain.
The herring fishing grounds are mainly within 60 miles of land. The inshore
waters also yield considerable quantities of shellfish.
The principal fishing ports in England and Wales are Hull, Grimsby, Fleet-
wood, Milford Haven, North Shields and Lowestoft. In Scotland the chief
centres for white fish are Aberdeen, Granton, Fraserburgh, the Moray Firth,
the west coast and Shetland Islands; herring landings are made mainly at
the east coast ports of Aberdeen, Fraserburgh and Peterhead, the west coast
ports of Ullapool, Mallaig, Oban, Tarbert and Ayr, and in Shetland Islands.
In Northern Ireland the fishing ports are Ardglass, Portavogie and Kilkeel.
The chief methods of catching fish are by trawling, seining, lining, and ring
and drift netting. Trawling is carried out throughout the year in the distant
and near waters for all species of demersal fish. Seining is also used for
catching demersal fish all the year round, mainly in the North Sea, the
Minches, the Firth of Clyde, and the Irish Sea. There are about 600 Scottish
and Northern Ireland seiners, and about 155 operating from English ports.
The pelagic fisheries are seasonal. There is summer fishing for herring
based on the Shetlands, the east coast ports of Scotland, and the north-east
coast ports of England. Other seasonal fisheries take place off the west coast
of Scotland, in the Isle of Man area and off southern Ireland.
The inshore fisheries comprise a great diversity of types of vessels and
methods of capture; in addition, there are extensive fisheries for crabs,
lobsters, shrimps, mussels, escallops, cockles and oysters, and, off Scotland,
north-east England and in the Irish Sea there are valuable catches of
‘Norway lobsters’ (nephrops or Dublin Bay prawns).
Distant water vessels, which operate mainly from Hull, Grimsby and
Fleetwood, numbered 165 at the end of 1968. They are mostly over 140 feet in
length and most of them make voyages of 17 to 23 days to fishing grounds in
the Arctic Circle. Partly due to the introduction of freezer trawlers and
factory vessels, there has been an increasing tendency to fish the waters
bordering Newfoundland, Labrador and Greenland. These vessels spend
from one to three months at sea and freeze, in some cases as fillets, much or
all of their catch immediately it is taken. At the same date, near and middle
water vessels numbered 383; they are between 80 and 140 feet long and most
of them work nearer home, making voyages of from a few days up to more
than two weeks, although some of the larger vessels fish regularly off the
Faroes and seasonally as far afield as Iceland. Included in the near water group
are vessels engaged in drift net fishing for herring; these vessels usually make
daily voyages. The inshore group consists mainly of vessels of under 80 feet
320
Supplies
Sea Fish
Processing
Freshwater
Fisheries
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
which, except for seiners, are seldom at sea for longer than two or three days
and more usually make daily landings, often fishing within sight of land.
In the British fishing industry in 1968 there were about 18,000 fishermen
in regular employment and some 5,000 occasionally employed; about two-
fifths of the former and one-third of the latter were from Scottish ports. In
Northern Ireland there are about 500 regular fishermen.
In 1968 landings of all types of fish by British fishing vessels totalled 900,000
tons (720,000 tons of demersal fish, 140,000 tons of pelagic and 40,000 tons
of shellfish), valued at about ^60 million. Imports totalled about 141,000 tons
of fresh and frozen fish (including 65,000 tons brought direct from the fishing
grounds), valued at about £24 million. Cod accounted for 44 per cent of the
total value of demersal and pelagic fish landed by British vessels; haddock
(19 per cent) and plaice (10 per cent) were the other most important sources of
earnings to the industry.
Imports of all types of fish (fresh, frozen, salted, canned or otherwise
preserved) in 1968 amounted to about 240,000 tons valued at £76 million,
including 44,000 tons of canned salmon to the value of ^33 million and other
canned fish worth £14 million.
Weekly disposals of fresh, frozen and cured fish (excluding shellfish and
imported canned fish) in Britain averaged about 15,500 tons landed weight
in 1968. Although consumption had been declining slightly, on an edible
(fillet) weight basis, it was 16-6 lb. per head in 1968 in comparison with a peak
total of 28-7 lb. in 1948 (see Table 23).
Processing and packaging of fish—curing, kippering, canning and quick-
freezing for consumer packs—are the subject of continuing research and
development. The growth of quick-frozen fish production has altered
radically the structure of the industry. With the increase in quick-freezing
(which now processes over a quarter of all white fish landings), new export
outlets have opened up for white fish, which in 1968 accounted for just under
half the total exports of fish and fish preparations, valued at ^12-3 million.
Exports of shellfish and other fresh, frozen and cured fish increased in 1968,
while exports of canned and preserved fish were somewhat reduced.
A valuable by-product of the industry is the manufacture of fish meal for
animal food and, to a much lesser extent, for fertilisers. Home production of
white fish meal and herring meal in 1968 was 87,000 tons.
The most valuable freshwater fish are salmon and sea-trout, being worth far
more when caught by rod and line than similar fish netted at sea. Drift netting
for salmon is prohibited off the coast of Scotland and is strictly controlled
around England, Wales and Northern Ireland to protect the valuable sport
fisheries in the game rivers. A limited amount of estuary and river netting
for salmon is permitted under licence by river authorities. In England and
Wales the value of the salmon catch is approximately £370,000 a year, in
Scotland it amounts to over £2 million, and in Northern Ireland to some
£200,000. In Northern Ireland, eels worth about £300,000 a year are captured
by long lines and by eel nets placed in river weirs.
The principal inland wholesale distributing centre for fish is Billingsgate
Market in London, which handles about 300 tons a day, but other large
cities also have central fish markets. The principal method of distribution is
through wholesalers, located at the ports, who buy at the auctions and sell

to inland wholesalers; the port wholesalers prepare the fish for onward ship¬
ment. Fish lorries, including insulated and refrigerated vehicles, transport
the catch daily from the ports to inland centres, although rail transport is still
used from some ports. Retail sales are handled by some 25,000 to 30,000 fish¬
mongers and fish friers; the latter use about a third of the landings of white fish.
Trawler-owning companies have entered into the marketing and distribu¬
tive system. This process has been encouraged by the growing popularity of
quick-frozen consumer packs, which are sold by other retail outlets, such as
grocers, as well as by fishmongers.
The government departments mainly responsible for the administration of
legislation concerning the fishing industry are the Ministry of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries for Scotland
and the Ministry of Agriculture for Northern Ireland. The safety and
welfare of crews of fishing vessels are provided for under the Merchant
Shipping Acts administered by the Board of Trade, under whose aegis a
committee of enquiry into deep-sea trawler safety was set up in 1968.
The Herring Industry Board was set up under the Herring Industry Act
z935 to reorganise, develop and regulate the herring industry; subsequent
amending Acts have also been passed. The Board consists of a chairman and
three other members, all part-time and independent of the industry, who are
appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, the
Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales, and the Home Secretary. The
Board, whose activities are financed partly by levies and licence fees and
partly by government grants and loans, is advised by the Herring Industry
Advisory Council, consisting of 32 members representing all sections of the
industry and consumers.
The functions of the Board include the promotion of sales of herring, both
at home and abroad, and the application of the benefits of technical progress
to the industry, including the adoption of new methods of catching, processing
and distributing herring. The Board administers the government grant and
loan schemes which provide for assistance towards the purchase of new fishing
vessels, and the improvement of existing vessels. Fishermen may also obtain
loans from the Board towards the purchase of second-hand vessels under
80 feet in length and towards the cost of new nets and gear. Up to 31st March
1969, £2,021,000 in loans and £1,468,000 in grants had been advanced.
The White Fish Authority and the Committee for Scotland and Northern
Ireland of the Authority were set up under the Sea Fish Industry Act 1951.
The function of the Authority is to reorganise, develop and regulate the white
fish industry, and that of the Committee to advise the Authority about the
exercise and performance of its functions in Scotland and Northern Ireland.
The Authority is composed of a chairman and six members, and the Scottish
Committee of five members and a chairman who is a member of the
Authority. They are appointed jointly by the Minister of Agriculture,
Fisheries and Food, the Secretary of State for Scotland, the Home Secretary
and (in the case of the Authority) the Secretary of State for Wales. The White
Fish Industry Advisory Council was also set up under the 1951 Act to advise
the Authority about the exercise and performance of its functions. It consists
of 53 members representing the various interests of the fishing industry.
The White Fish Authority administers government grant and loan
schemes for the purchase of new fishing vessels and engines and the improve¬
ment of existing vessels. It also administers loans for the purchase of nets and

Operating

BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
gear and processing plants. Up to 31st March 1969, £34 million in loans and
^24 million in grants were approved for these purposes by the Authority. Its
other activities are financed by a levy on first-hand sales of fish, and a
government grant towards research and development.
The system which has been in force for some years is that subsidies have been
authorised which vary according to the class of vessel used; they are paid at
the rate of so much per day at sea according to the length of the vessel or at
so much per stone of fish landed, which varies according to the kind of fish,
from certain vessels under 60 feet in length. No subsidy is paid for shellfish.
Subsidies for white fish cost £3,897 million in 1968-69 and those for herring
£207,000.
Under the Sea Fisheries Act 1968 a new scheme of government financial
assistance to the deep-sea fishing industry has been approved by Parliament.
It is proposed to introduce the new form of subsidy for three years initially.
There will be a basic subsidy of £2 million adjusted by reference to operating
profits in the preceding year. The total annual subsidy will be limited to
£4 million, and payment will be related to the operating efficiency of vessels,
not as at present to their classification.
FORESTRY
The estimated total area of productive woodland in Great Britain is 3-28
million acres, or about 6 per cent of the total land area. If account is taken of
areas of scrub and old felled areas, including those cut down in the second
world war, the total rises to 4-35 million acres, or yf per cent of the land area;
about half of the area is in England, two-fifths in Scotland, the remainder in
Wales. The high proportion of unproductive woodland is largely a legacy of
two wars and, while rehabilitation of these areas continues to proceed, it is
unlikely that all areas (for instance, because of remoteness and poor site
conditions) will be replanted. A measure of the extent of rehabilitation is
provided by the fact that the area of unproductive woodland has been reduced
by 300,000 acres since 1945.
The area of productive forest managed by the Forestry Commission, at
1-65 million acres, represents 50 per cent of the total. The annual rate of
productive forest expansion is currently about 52,400 acres by the Commission
and about 35,000 acres by private woodland owners. The Commission’s
programme includes considerable planting in upland areas, especially in
Scotland, and consists mainly of conifers because of the difficult site conditions
encountered. The major species used are Sitka spruce, Lodgepole pine,
Scots pine and Norway spruce. In the older woodlands and taking the country
as a whole, the most common coniferous trees are Scots pine, Sitka spruce,
Norway spruce and the larches, while, among the broadleaved, beech and
oak occur widely.
Except for the period of the two world wars, when much over-felling took
place, home woodlands have until recent years made only a limited contribu¬
tion to the nation’s total requirements of wood and wood products. Britain
imports 90 per cent of its needs by volume and a higher proportion still by
value, the total import cost of wood and wood products being £640 million
in 1968.
The Forestry
Commission
and Forestry
Policy
Finance
Private
Forestry
AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 323
The Forestry Acts 1919 to 1945 established the Forestry Commission as the
national forestry authority charged with promoting the interests of forestry,
the development of afforestation and the production and supply of timber in
Great Britain (the Forestry Acts 1919 to 1963 were consolidated in the
Forestry Act 1967). As more and more of its coniferous woods reach the
production stage the Commission has assumed an increasingly important role
as a timber seller. The Commission consists of a part-time chairman, a full¬
time director general, three full-time executive commissioners and five part-
time commissioners. The Commissioners comply with directions given by the
forestry ministers, who are the Minister of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food
and the Secretaries of State for Scotland and Wales. Northern Ireland has its
own separate organisation (see p. 325).
The Commission’s total estate covers some 2-8 million acres and includes
1-96 million acres of forest land, of which about 1-64 million are under trees
in nearly 400 forests distributed throughout England, Scotland and Wales. All
these forests are covered by management plans, which provide for such work
as planting, road construction, thinning, fire protection, and timber
production.
As already stated, a substantial amount of the Forestry Commission’s new
planting is carried out in Scotland, much of it in the Highland counties. The
poorer types of land are being used, such as sour, peaty soil which is unsuitable
for agricultural purposes, but has become suitable for forestry as a result of
advances in the technique of deep ploughing.
Production of coniferous timber from Commission woodlands, mainly by
way of thinnings, is expected to rise from about 1-3 million tons in 1968 to
about 2-7 million tons by 1980. Some of this kind of produce is meeting
traditional requirements of the coal mines but much is taken by the paper
pulp industry and by factories established to make chipboard, fibreboard and
wood wool.
The Forestry Fund was constituted under the 1919 Forestry Act; from it is
paid all the expenditure of the Forestry Commissioners and into it are paid
amounts voted annually by Parliament, together with the Commission’s
receipts from sales of produce, rentals and other sources. In 1967 drawings
from funds voted by Parliament amounted to £15-3 million, and receipts were
£6 million.
Privately owned woods comprise nearly two-thirds of the total forest area in
Great Britain and contain most of the mature and semi-mature timber. The
size of woodlands in individual ownership ranges from a few acres to several
thousand acres, and a high proportion of the private woodland area is in small
ownership (that is, owners of up to about 250 acres).
Impetus was given to the effective management of private woodlands
by the introduction of the Dedication of Woodlands Scheme, initiated in
1947. Under this scheme, owners are invited to put their land permanently
to timber production and to manage their woods in accordance with a plan
agreed with the Forestry Commission, in return for the provision of planting
and management grants and technical advice. By September 1967 the total
area dedicated was 875,000 acres. In addition, there are woodlands covered
by the Approved Woodlands Scheme and the Small Woods Scheme under
which a planting grant, but no management grant, is paid. More than 1 million
acres are managed under the first two schemes. Woodland owners are
represented, in their relations with the Forestry Commission, by the Forestry
324 BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Committee of Great Britain, which co-ordinates the work of two associations of
woodland owners: the Timber Growers’ Organisation (for owners in England
and Wales) and the Scottish Woodland Owners’ Association.
There are a number of forestry co-operative societies providing for
landowners and farmers the services of skilled staff, centralised purchasing
facilities, and a central agency for the disposal of forest produce. The Forestry
Commission also co-operates with the principal forestry societies, such as the
Royal Forestry Society of England and Wales and the Royal Scottish Forestry
Society, in disseminating technical knowledge.
In 1959 the Home Grown Timber Marketing Corporation was established
by timber merchants to promote the use of home grown timber.
Under the Forestry Act 1967 the Commissioners maintain national com¬
mittees for England, Scotland and Wales, composed partly of Forestry
Commissioners and partly of persons outside the Commission. These
committees act in an advisory capacity, particularly as to the social, recreational
and amenity aspects of the Commissioners’ activities and relationships with
other land users. The Commissioners also maintain a regional advisory
committee for each Conservancy.
Advisory
Bodies
Consultative Other bodies have been set up to provide for consultation on the marketing
Machinery and utilisation of home grown timber. The Home Grown Timber Advisory
Committee (HGTAC) is a statutory body and includes representatives of
associations of landowners, timber merchants and processors and the trade
unions under an independent chairman. In 1949 the Forestry Commissioners
set up the Advisory Committee on Utilisation of Home Grown Timber (now
a sub-committee of the HGTAC) to advise on measures designed to promote
utilisation of produce from British woodlands.
A voluntary scheme was agreed upon in 1961 for consultation on proposals
for afforestation of land within National Parks (see p. 174). The Timber
Growers’ Organisation and the Country Landowners’ Association undertook
to advise their members to notify the park planning authorities about their
planting proposals.
Forestry The Forestry Commission maintains three forester training schools: in
Education and England, at Parkend in the Forest of Dean, Gloucestershire; in Wales, near
Research Betws-y-Coed in Caernarvonshire; and in Scotland at Faskally, near Pitlochry
in Perthshire. All three will be closed by 1972 as the responsibility for forester
training is being assumed by the Department of Education and Science.
Northerwood House in the New Forest, Hampshire, is the Commission’s
educational centre, and is used for practical courses for Commission staff and
for university students, landowners and agents, planning officers, school
teachers and others.
An Agricultural, Horticultural and Forestry Industry Training Board and a
Furniture and Timber Industry Training Board have been set up to provide
for training in forestry for employees of private woodland owners and in the
home-grown timber trade.
Higher education in forestry is provided at several universities; a propor¬
tion of graduates is recruited by the Commission as forest officers.
The Commission’s Forest Research Station at Alice Holt Lodge, near
Farnham, Surrey, was opened in 1946. Expenditure on research work at this
station and in experimental areas in many forests in Great Britain amounted
to £717,000 in 1967. This sum included grants for special forestry research

AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY 325
work to various institutions and to university departments including the
Commonwealth Forestry Institute at Oxford, which is also financed by the
university, the Foreign and Commonwealth Office and overseas governments.
Research into the qualities of home-grown timber is carried out by the Forest
Products Research Laboratory at Princes Risborough, Bucks, and also by
grant-aided research associations.
When the Government of Northern Ireland was formed in 1922, the new
Ministry of Agriculture became the forest authority working with similar
powers and duties to those conferred on the Forestry Commission by the
Forestry Act 1919. At that time the Ministry took over some 4,000 acres
for afforestation, of which 700 acres had been planted.
Forest policy is carried out under the authority of the Forestry Act
(Northern Ireland) 1953, which replaced earlier legislation. This Act pro¬
vides the Ministry with powers to acquire and manage land, and to give
financial and technical assistance for private planting. It introduced measures
for the protection of all woodlands, whether owned by the State or privately
owned, against destruction by over-cutting, fire or depredation by animals.
The State forest area has grown steadily and at a greatly accelerated pace
since the end of the second world war. By 1969 over 150,000 acres had been
acquired, of which about 95,000 acres had been planted. The present
afforestation programme provides for the creation, as soon as possible, of an
area of 150,000 acres of productive forest.
Financial provision is made by sums voted annually by Parliament and
from receipts from forest produce and other sources. About 1,000 people are
employed in field labour and ancillary work. The area of exploitable private
woodlands is at present about 35,000 acres, and private planting, which is
gaining impetus, is assisted by schemes for the supply at a low cost of young
trees from the Ministry’s nurseries, by grants towards the cost of the estab¬
lishment of new plantations, and by free technical advice.
Pomeroy Forestry School at Pomeroy House, Co. Tyrone, provides
training and refresher courses for forestry workers, school teachers and
others interested in trees and forestry.
13 TRANSPORT AND
COMMUNICATIONS
Technical
Trends
Inland and overseas transport and communications employed 6-4 per cent
of the total labour force in the United Kingdom in June 1968. Of the i-6
million persons so occupied, 31 per cent were engaged in road passenger
transport and road haulage contracting, 18 per cent in railways and 27 per
cent in postal services and telecommunications; sea and air transport absorbed
respectively 6 per cent and 4 per cent; port and inland water transport
and miscellaneous transport services and storage absorbed 14 per cent.
Transport and communications contribute about 8 per cent of the gross
national product and are responsible for the same proportion of the nation’s
gross fixed capital formation.
SHIPPING
Of the world’s active sea-going tonnage of 100 gross tons1 and over 11 per
cent is registered in Britain, making the British merchant fleet one of the
largest in active employment. The British shipping industry is, however,
exposed to severe international competition. The position has been made
more difficult by the prevalence among competitors of such practices as
flag discrimination and the use of ‘flags of convenience’. While from 1958 to
1968 Britain’s merchant fleet increased by 8 per cent from 20-3 million to
21-9 million gross tons, the total tonnage of all other countries, excluding the
US Reserve Fleet, increased by 98 per cent, from 84 million to 165 million
gross tons. After being positive until about 1959 the balance of payments
for shipping services remained adverse until 1965, but showed an estimated
surplus of j£6i million in 1968. Shipping’s net contribution to Britain’s
foreign exchange earnings was estimated at some £260 million in 1968.
By 1968 over 60 per cent of all tonnage was diesel-driven. In a variety of ways
technological change has been proceeding more rapidly under current
conditions. Vessels are becoming obsolete over a shorter period and as they
do so are being replaced by larger ships, with generally lower building costs per
ton; labour-saving devices, greater speeds and faster turn-round facilities
are reducing operating costs. The tendency to greater average size has
been the most marked in tankers and dry bulk cargo ships. Vessels are
specially built to carry ore, vegetable oils, cement, wine and various kinds of
chemicals. Many ships have been designed to carry fully loaded road vehicles,
pallets and containers. In particular the use of containers on long door-to-
door journeys can result in speedier, safer and cheaper carriage of a wide
range of goods. Two consortia of British shipping companies are operating
specially designed deep-sea cellular container ships on services to Australia,
and another company is operating a similar service to Canada.
1 One gross ton (g.t.)= 100 cubic feet. One deadweight ton (d.w.t.)= 1 long ton
(2,240 lb.). Gross tonnage indicates the total capacity of the enclosed spaces on a ship.
Deadweight tonnage denotes the maximum load which a vessel can carry before
submerging the load-line.

The Queen Elizabeth 2 (66,000 g.t.), the most advanced and one of the largest
passenger liners ever built, designed for the transatlantic route and for cruising,
went into service in 1969. Two other large British-built liners, the Oriana
(42,000 g.t.) and the Canberra (46,000 g.t.), have been in service since i960
and 1961 respectively.
Of the 21-9 million gross tons of merchant shipping of 100 gross tons and
over registered, but not all owned, in the United Kingdom on 30th June 1968
tankers accounted for 8-4 million gross tons and 12 per cent of the world’s
sea-going tonnage.
In June 1968, 17-8 million gross tons of trading vessels of 100 gross tons and
over were both owned and registered in Britain.1 The usual employment of
this fleet has been analysed by the United Kingdom Chamber of Shipping as
follows: 6-7 million gross tons were employed as foreign-going passenger and
cargo liners; 3-5 million gross tons as foreign-going tramps; 6-8 million gross
tons as foreign-going tankers; and o-8 million gross tons in coasting and trade
with ports between the Elbe and Brest (home trades).
Over one-third of British-owned shipping registered in the United Kingdom
consists of ocean-going passenger-cargo and cargo liners, mostly the latter.
Practically all these ships are owned by large liner companies. Many operate
wide networks of scheduled cargo and passenger services which, between
them, cover every ocean. The 3-5 million gross tons of ocean-going tramp
ships are operated by a large number of private owners, some having only a
small number of ships and some only one ship.
Examples of major British liner shipping companies operating scheduled
services from the United Kingdom are: the Cunard, to North America; the
Royal Mail, to South America; the Blue Funnel, to Australia and the Far
East; the Peninsular and Oriental (P. & O.) and the British India lines, to
India, Australia and the Far East; the Union Castle, to South and East Africa;
Elder Dempster, to West Africa; Furness Withy, to North America and the
West Indies; the New Zealand line, to Australia and New Zealand; and Shaw
Savill and Albion, to Australia and New Zealand. These and the other major
liner companies have for the most part amalgamated to form a small number
of major groups, of which the largest and best known are the P. & O., the
Furness Withy, the Ocean S.S., and the British and Commonwealth groups.
Over two-thirds of the total tanker fleet belong to the oil companies,
although there are a few important independent United Kingdom tanker¬
owning companies.
A government guaranteed loan scheme to benefit British shipowners
ordering from British shipyards was introduced in 1967.
The main organisations concerned with the activities, interests and common
problems of the industry are as follows:
Lloyd’s Register is an organisation (distinct from the Society of Lloyd’s, see
p. 377) which surveys and classifies ships with particular regard to their
safety and operational efficiency. It will accept responsibility for surveying
and giving technical advice on vessels of all flags from the initial stages of

building, at regular intervals during their service, and after casualties. A
satisfactory Lloyd’s classification is a guarantee to an underwriter that he may
accept the risk of a vessel, and this forms a strong link between the Register
and the Society of Lloyd’s.
The representative body speaking for shipowners generally (excluding, for
the most part, owners of fishing vessels) is the Chamber of Shipping. There
are a number of local associations of shipowners centred around the main port
areas. Other organisations represent companies specialising in a particular
trade or type of cargo.
The British Shippers’ Council, formed in 1955, represents the shipping
interests of exporters and importers in matters of both national and inter¬
national concern.
The British Shipping Federation Limited is the employers’ organisation
concerned with labour relations and the regulation of employment throughout
the Merchant Navy. It is responsible for the administration of the Merchant
Navy Established Service Scheme, under which shipowners engaging crews
for ships of 200 gross tons and above engage them through the Merchant Navy
Establishment Administration unless they are prepared to offer two-year
company service contracts.
The National Maritime Board is composed of equal numbers of representa¬
tives of the shipowners and seafarers and is responsible for all negotiations of
wages and conditions of service in the Merchant Navy.
British shipping companies operating liners have associated with each other
and with the companies of other countries operating on the same routes in a
series of ‘conferences’ designed to secure standardisation and stability of rates,
and to maintain frequency and regularity of services. The essential principle
of a conference is the establishment of a common tariff of freight rates or
passenger fares from each port of departure. Each conference meets from
time to time to review and revise existing rates, or to compile new ones. Some
of the conferences are connected by rate agreements, or have joined together
to form wider groupings. There are over 60 conferences dealing with trade to
and from the United Kingdom.
The Baltic Mercantile and Shipping Exchange, which originated in one of
London’s seventeenth-century coffee houses, is the world’s largest market
for the chartering of ships of all nationalities. Shipbrokers and merchants’
representatives meet here to arrange the chartering of dry-cargo tramp ships
for the carriage of goods to and from all parts of the world.
The Board of Trade is the government department responsible for most
matters connected with merchant shipping. Under the Merchant Shipping
Act 1894 and subsequent legislation, it administers many regulations for
marine safety and welfare, for instance: certifying the load-line (or Plimsoll
line) that shows that a ship is not overloaded; ensuring that standards of
safety are observed in ship construction; ensuring the provision of adequate
life-saving, fire-fighting and radio equipment; and dealing with the discipline,
professional standards, health and accommodation of seamen. Most of the
work which these responsibilities entail is carried out by the officers of the
Marine Survey and Mercantile Marine at the ports. There is also a Registrar-

Control
Lighthouses,

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 329
General of Shipping and Seamen, in whose office at Cardiff a complete record
of all British ships and seamen is kept.
Abroad, certain parts of the Merchant Shipping Acts, in particular those
provisions dealing with the engagement and discharge of crews outside the
United Kingdom, are administered by H.M. Consuls and by officers of
Commonwealth Governments.
The discharge of oil into British territorial waters was first restricted in 1922.
Britain is a party to the 1954 International Convention for the Prevention of
the Pollution of the Sea by Oil which came into force in 1958. The nations
ratifying this convention (now numbering over 30) agree to prohibit their
national fleets from discharging persistent oil within a certain distance of
any coast (originally 50 miles but under amendments in 1962 extended in
many areas to 100 miles or more) and also in extensive areas of the north-east
Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean, the whole of the North Sea, and around
Australia. The provisions were given legal effect for British ships under the
Oil in Navigable Waters Act 1955 which also prohibits the discharge of any
kind of oil from British and foreign vessels into British territorial waters.
Amendments to the 1954 Convention were agreed in 1962 and came into
force on 18th May 1967; the Oil in Navigable Waters Act 1963, applying the
amendments to British ships, became effective on the same date. The
Convention as amended prohibits ships of 20,000 gross tons and over, built
after 18th May 1967, from discharging persistent oil anywhere at sea.
Over 300,000 vessels pass through the Dover Strait every year. Recommended
one-way routes were marked in 1967 by navigational aids provided by the
French and British lighthouse authorities—a scheme worked out by the joint
Institutes of Navigation of France, the Federal Republic of Germany and
Britain and agreed by the Inter-Governmental Maritime Consultative
Organisation, a United Nations agency with headquarters in London.
Additional traffic-separation schemes in areas around British and other coasts
have since been adopted, and others are under consideration.
The Board of Trade administers the Coastguard Service. This is primarily a
life-saving organisation which keeps watch at danger points around the coast
for vessels in distress and renders assistance either by coastguard rescue
equipment or by informing other authorities who may be able to give help.
There are some 550 regular coastguards and about 7,000 part-time auxiliary
coastguards. During the year ended 31st March 1969 life-saving action was
taken on 2,444 occasions. There is close liaison between the Coastguard
Service and the Royal National Life-boat Institution. The latter maintains
lifeboats and fast inshore rescue boats around the coast of the United Kingdom;
it is supported entirely by voluntary contributions, and depends largely for its
operation on voluntary workers. From its foundation in 1824 to the end of
1968 the Royal National Life-boat Institution saved 90,357 lives. Lifeboats
and inshore rescue boats were launched 2,295 ti™68 in !968 and rescued
1,008 people.
The general lighthouse authority for England and Wales, the Channel
Islands and Gibraltar is the Corporation of Trinity House, which received its
first Royal Charter in the sixteenth century and is administered by a Board
of ten Elder Brethren, elected from the Royal Navy and the Merchant Navy.
Lighthouses in Scotland and Ireland are the responsibility respectively of the
Commissioners of Northern Lighthouses and the Commissioners of Irish
