Lights. Trinity House controls about 60 lighthouses, many minor lights and
buoys, and a number of lightships, some of which are to be replaced by
unattended sea marks or by light towers; in 1969 a £600,000 concrete light
tower replaced the Royal Sovereign lightship off the Sussex coast.
Trinity House is also the chief pilotage authority, licensing some 700 pilots
in 41 districts in England and Wales, including London, Southampton and
Milford Haven. In some cases the harbour authority or local council is the
pilotage authority. In Britain there are 48 pilotage authorities for the 92
pilotage districts and over 1,600 licensed pilots. The Board of Trade also has
certain responsibilities in connection with lighthouses and pilotage.
About 86,000 United Kingdom personnel and a considerably smaller number
of aliens are employed by the merchant fleet.
The Board of Trade holds examinations for, and issues certificates of
competency to, ships’ officers as master, first mate and second mate of
foreign-going ships, or master and mate of home trade ships and as first-class
engineer and second-class engineer. Officers may not normally serve on board
ships in these grades unless they hold the appropriate, or a higher, certificate.
Radio officers are required to hold certificates of competency in radio¬
telegraphy issued by the Minister of Post and Telecommunications on the
results of an open examination.
A seaman may not be rated as A.B. (Able Seaman) in United Kingdom
registered ships unless he holds a certificate of competency as A.B. granted
by the Board of Trade, or an equivalent certificate. To obtain this certificate
a seaman must, among other qualifications, have served three years at sea on
deck, have obtained a certificate of efficiency as lifeboatman and have passed
a qualifying examination.
Seamen qualify by seniority for promotion to the rating of petty officer.
Service as a deck rating qualifies for the purpose of admission to the examina¬
tion for a second mate’s certificate.
The Merchant Navy Training Board promotes the instruction and studies
of apprentices, cadets and ratings who are preparing for their examinations
for the various certificates of competency.
Wages and conditions of employment are negotiated by the National Maritime
Board. Minimum wages and holidays with pay are guaranteed for both officers
and ratings. Moreover, the Merchant Navy Established Service Scheme,
introduced by the Board in 1947, has removed a great deal of the uncertainty
formerly associated with a seafaring life. Officers and men can now take
two-year contracts, not only with individual shipping companies but with
the industry as a whole, and get special benefits between voyages in addition
to the normal unemployment insurance benefit.
There are over 300 sea ports in Britain. In 1968, 176 million tons of imports,
including 105 million tons of petroleum and petroleum products, passed
through the ports and 40 million tons of exports and re-exports, including
4 million tons of coal. Coastal traffic amounted to 106 million tons, principally
petroleum and coal.
As a result both of the anticipated increase in the country’s trade and of
technological changes affecting sea-going traffic (such as the shift to larger
tankers and bulk carriers implying a need for more deep-water berths,
demand for the development of mechanical handling methods, packaging of
Principal
Ports
Development
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 331
general cargo in standard sizes and container and ‘roll-on, roll-off’ services)
large-scale modernisation of the ports system became necessary. Con¬
sequently capital investment in ports has risen from about £18 million
a year in the early 1960s to some £50 million in 1969.
The Port of London, with 92 miles of waterway and about 4,000 acres of
dock estate, including 36 miles of quayage, is the largest port in the Common¬
wealth and, with New York and Rotterdam, is one of the three largest ports
in the world. The Port of London Authority operates four main groups of
docks. A further group of older up-river docks was closed in 1968, and
facilities down-river, notably at Tilbury, are being extensively developed.
About 60 million tons of cargo were handled in 1968. Among the chief
commodities handled are petroleum, coal, timber and grain. Other imports
include textile fibres, scrap, sugar and meat. Vehicles, machinery and food¬
stuffs predominate among exports.
Liverpool is the second largest port in Britain. It handles a large proportion
of Britain’s exports to the Far East. There are extensive facilities for dealing
with imports of grain, sugar, wool and other specialist cargoes. In 1968 over
29 million tons of cargo passed through the port.
Other major ports are Hull and Immingham on the Humber, the port of
Clyde (or Clydeport) which includes the docks at Glasgow and at Greenock
(now being developed as a container port), Manchester (an inland port reached
from the Mersey via the Manchester Ship Canal), Bristol on the Bristol
Channel, and Southampton on Southampton Water. Other estuaries impor¬
tant for shipping are the Firth of Forth on the east coast of Scotland (Grange¬
mouth and Leith), the Tyne (Newcastle), the Tees (Middlesbrough and the
Hartlepools), and the Stour and Orwell on the East Anglian coast (Harwich,
Felixstowe and Ipswich). Among the smaller ports which have been growing
rapidly are Felixstowe, Grangemouth, and Shoreham on the south coast. The
major oil importing centres are London, the Medway, Milford Haven,
Southampton, Liverpool, Manchester, and Finnart on the Clyde; Port
Talbot and Newport in South Wales, the Tees, the port of Clyde and Liver¬
pool are the main ore handling ports; London, Liverpool, Bristol and Hull are
among the chief grain importers; and London, Hull, Liverpool and Garston
are the main timber ports. Dover is Britain’s most important port for short-sea
voyage passengers, and Southampton for travellers by ocean liner. Grimbsy,
Hull and Aberdeen are the largest fishing ports.
A development scheme costing over £30 million has been carried out at
Tilbury, London. In addition to a grain terminal, freightliner terminal, and
a riverside impounding station, a dock extension project, finished in 1969,
has provided 13 new deep-water berths, six of them for container traffic.
Another major scheme, costing over ^33 million and including deep-sea
container berths, is under construction at Seaforth, Liverpool. Container
facilities have also been provided at Southampton (where a completely new
container berth came into operation in 1969 and another is under construction),
Harwich, Greenock (port of Clyde), Felixstowe, Manchester, Newport and
Grangemouth. At Hull a £7 million extension to King George Dock was
brought into operation in 1969, and a new deep-sea coal terminal is being
provided at Immingham. A ^17 million deep-water harbour was completed
at Port Talbot in 1969, and serves as an ore terminal for the British Steel
Corporation.

The Minister of Transport makes grants of 20 per cent of approved capital
expenditure to statutory and other harbour authorities and persons carrying
out harbour operations.
Since 1948 ports handling about a fifth of the national sea-borne trade have
been government owned; the British Transport Docks Board (see p. 334)
owns the majority of such ports, which include Southampton, Hull, Imming-
ham, Newport, Cardiff and Swansea. The Government has proposed that
the major ports should be reorganised on the basis of public ownership.1
In 1968 shipping arrivals and departures at BTDB docks totalled over
no million net registered tons (including fishing vessels), and the total cargo
handled was about 75 million tons. Certain ports and docks used largely in
conjunction with railway services are administered by the British Railways
Board: examples are Folkestone, Holyhead, Heysham, Stranraer and
Parkeston Quay (at Harwich).
Other ports are controlled by public trusts on which are represented users
of the port, by local authorities and other interested bodies or by companies.
Examples of ports under public trusts are London (Port of London Authority),
Liverpool (Mersey Docks and Harbour Board), and Belfast (Belfast Harbour
Commissioners). Several new estuarial authorities have been set up by
means of harbour reorganisation schemes under the 1964 Harbours Act.
The powers and responsibilities of the port authorities are, in the main, set
down in private Acts of Parliament, other local legislation, and orders made
under the Harbours Act 1964.
The National Ports Council, set up in 1964 as a statutory body under the
Harbours Act of that year, is financed by a levy on harbour authorities and is
primarily an advisory body. It advises the minister on major port develop¬
ments, and has various responsibilities in relation to research, training and
charges, its main task being the supervision of long-term national planning
for the ports as a whole.
About 120,000 people are employed in the operation of ports in the United
Kingdom. At the end of 1968 there were 55,000 dock workers registered with
the National Dock Labour Board, concerned primarily with loading and
unloading cargo. The remainder included administrative, clerical and
technical staff, and pilots, lightermen and customs officials.
Because arrivals and departures of ships are liable to occur at irregular
intervals without conforming to set schedules a system of largely casual
labour existed at the docks in the past. However, a start was made on
‘decasualisation’ in 1941 when war-time controls were imposed. In 1947 the
National Dock Labour Board was established, with members appointed by
the Minister of Labour and representing both employers and workpeople, to
administer a scheme under which registered workers received a guaranteed
minimum wage for attendance even when no work was available. Under the
new government proposals the functions of the Dock Labour Board would be
transferred to the subsidiaries of the National Ports Authority and to Dock
Labour Committees.
In September 1967 each registered dockworker was placed in employment
with a licensed employer on a permanent basis in accordance with the

Work is proceeding on rationalisation of the industry’s pay structure and

Most of the oil tankers coming to the United Kingdom to discharge crude oil
are berthed at special tanker terminals which are near the oil refineries and are
owned and operated by the oil companies. The maximum deadweight tonnage
of fully laden tankers that some of the most important terminals can accom¬
modate at present is: Finnart (Clyde) 100,000; Isle of Grain (Thames estuary)
65,000; Coryton (London) 85,000; Tilbury Reach (London) 47,000; Thames
Haven (London) 100,000; Tranmere (Liverpool) 100,000; Milford Haven
(Pembroke) 100,000; and Fawley (Southampton) 100,000. Long pipelines
connect Finnart with the refinery at Grangemouth on the Firth of Forth,
Angle Bay (Milford Haven) with the refinery at Llandarcy (near Swansea)
and Stanlow (Merseyside) with the refinery at Heysham (Lancashire).
Facilities are being extended to accommodate larger vessels; Finnart and
Coryton will be able to accept tankers of 200,000 tons (partly laden). Follow¬
ing dredging Milford Haven will be able to take 255,000-ton vessels.
A deep-water oil terminal, costing £5 million, and serving two new oil
refineries, was brought into operation at Immingham (Humberside) in 1969.
INLAND TRANSPORT
The dense passenger and freight traffic of Great Britain1 is carried mainly
by road and rail, although coastal shipping and, to a lesser extent, inland
waterways and pipelines are important in carrying certain types of freight,
particularly bulk cargoes. A small but increasing proportion goes by air.
Part of the inland transport system of Great Britain is nationalised; namely,
the railways, passenger transport in the London area, a large proportion of
road passenger and some road haulage services, most of the inland waterways
and some of the vessels on them. Road haulage is largely, and coastal shipping
almost entirely, in the hands of private enterprise.
In the third quarter of 1968 there were about 14-5 million vehicles licensed for
use on the roads. Of these, nearly 11 million were motor cars and 1-3 million
motor cycles, 2 per cent of the i-6 million road goods vehicles and 60 percent
of the public road passenger vehicles (excluding taxis) were publicly owned.
In 1968, 59 per cent of freight, in terms of ton-mileage,2 travelled by road,
20 per cent by rail, 20 per cent by coastal shipping, and 1 per cent by pipeline.
Since 1945 the rapid growth of private and commercial motor traffic, causing
congestion problems of increasing severity, especially in cities and towns, and
and the changing pattern of demand for transport services have led successive
Governments to undertake or commission fundamental studies of probable
trends in transport and problems which may arise therefrom. Over the
period 1966-75 an increase of over 50 per cent is forecast for total passenger
mileage, with demand for public transport diminishing and travel by private
transport still rising fast. Freight ton-mileage may rise by over 10 per cent,
fuel and steel traffic fall by 15 per cent as a result of structural and technological
change, while other freight traffic is expected to grow by some 30 per cent.
1 For an account of inland transport in Northern Ireland, see p. 346.
2 Ton-mileage is calculated by multiplying the tonnage carried by the actual distance
it was transported.

Statutory Boards
The Buchanan report, published in November 1963, was the result of a
study group set up to examine the problems of traffic in urban areas. It
estimated that Britain would have 40 million vehicles on its roads by a.d. 2010
and proposed radical measures to rebuild and adapt cities and roads to handle
the growth of traffic. It is now expected that the number of vehicles on the
roads will double by 1990.
The railway network has been reduced by nearly a third in recent years,
but it was decided in 1967 to fix a basic network of some 11,000 route-miles
for modernisation and development.
The present role and structure of the nationalised transport undertakings are
the result of a series of legislative measures, starting with the 1947 Transport
Act under which they were taken into public ownership. In accordance with
this Act the British Transport Commission (BTC) was established on
1 st January 1948 and assumed control of Britain’s railways, all railway-owned
steamships, docks, hotels and road transport interests, most of the country’s
canals (including all those owned by the railways), certain rivers (as navigation
authority) and the whole of the London passenger transport system. It was
also to arrange for the gradual acquisition of privately owned long-distance
road haulage firms.
Changes of policy following the coming into power of a Conservative
Government in 1951 were put into effect under the Transport Act 1953 which
modified the functions of the BTC. The Transport (Disposal of Road Haulage
Property) Act 1956 provided for the completion of the denationalisation of
road haulage, a process begun under the 1953 Act.
Over the next few years it became apparent that the activities of the BTC were
so large and diverse that they could not be run effectively as a single under¬
taking. The Transport Act 1962 therefore dissolved the BTC and set up four
boards, for British Railways, London Transport, British Transport Docks
and British Waterways. Each of these was responsible to the Minister of
Transport, who appointed the members.
The shipping services operated by British Railways and certain ports and
docks used for them passed to the British Railways Board.
The hotel property of the BTC was transferred to British Transport Hotels
Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary, first of the BTC and later of the British
Railways Board.
Road passenger, haulage and other undertakings, such as British Road
Services, the Tilling Bus Group, the Scottish Omnibuses Group, Thomas
Cook and Son, were operated as companies incorporated under the Companies
Act, with their own boards; they were grouped under a Transport Holding
Company, responsible to the Minister of Transport.
The Government’s plans to integrate and modernise the national transport
system are being put into effect under the provisions of the 1968 Transport
Act which has considerably altered the transport pattern laid down by the
1962 Act. The Act provided for a capital reconstruction and reorganisation of
British Railways; the setting up of Passenger Transport Authorities to control
and co-ordinate local transport arrangements; three new nationalised bodies—
a National Bus Company, a Scottish Transport Group and a National Freight
Corporation; a new licensing system and safety provisions for road haulage
operators; and new grants for public transport. Most of the functions of
the Transport Holding Company have been distributed among the new
bodies.

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 335
Britain was the pioneer of railways. The opening of the Stockton to Darlington
Railway in 1825, and of the Liverpool and Manchester line in 1830, when
George Stephenson’s famous ‘Rocket’ locomotive was used, began a century
of widespread railway development. The great period of railway building
was from 1840 to 1875.
The railways first came under centralised government direction during the
first world war, and afterwards some 130 private companies were amalgamated
into four large regional groups under the Railways Act 1921. Thereafter they
suffered from the prolonged industrial depression and growing competition
from road transport, and following the second world war the Transport Act
1947 brought the railways under public ownership as a single enterprise,
British Railways, operated under the overall management of a Railway
Executive established as the agent of the BTC. Under the Transport Act 1962
the British Railways Board was set up and came into existence on 1st January
1963 with sole responsibility for managing railway affairs.
In spite of technical and operational advances the Board’s financial position
remained unsatisfactory and, following a detailed review of railway policy,
the 1968 Transport Act made far-reaching changes. Capital debt was written
down from ^1,562 million (of which j£7°5 miHkm had already been suspended
under the 1962 Act) to ^300 million. Grants for rail passenger services which
are unremunerative but which are regarded as socially necessary were
introduced; £62 million was so paid in 1969. Grants not exceeding a total of
^50 million may be paid to the Railways Board on a gradually diminishing
scale during the years 1969 to 1973 towards the cost of maintaining surplus
track and signalling equipment pending their elimination; ^15 million was
paid in 1969. Deficit financing, which had been in operation since 1963,
ceased in 1968 and the Board is now expected to pay its way; the working
deficit for 1968 was £76 million. Other provisions of the Act removed certain
restrictions on the Board’s powers to manufacture and to run hotels, and
reduced the size of the Board.
The process of rationalisation arising from changing public transport require¬
ments is reflected in the reduction of over 5>000 ufil65 standard-gauge route
since 1961. A total of 830 million passenger journeys was made and 207 million
tons of freight traffic conveyed on British Railways in 1968; total receipts
amounted to £457 million. The railway operating deficit in 1968 was £91
million, while there was an overall surplus of ^8 million on other activities
ships, harbours, hotels and letting of land. At the end of 1968, 296,000 people
were employed by the railways, a reduction of 103,000 in four years.
In 1968 a subsidiary, British Transport Hotels Ltd., managed 34 (in¬
cluding one opened in 1968) hotels and the catering facilities on trains
(including Pullman trains); it also owned refreshment rooms at 197 stations,
managing 155 of them.
British Railways’ subsidiary, British Rail Hovercraft Ltd., set up in 1966,
runs regular hovercraft services across the Solent to the Isle of Wight, and
across the Channel between Dover and Boulogne. The 165-ton Mountbatten
(SRN-4) hovercraft, the largest in the world, is used for cross-channel
journeys.
The Railways Board and the shipping subsidiaries of the National Freight
Corporation have between them a fleet of about 100 vessels, providing
passenger and freight services on most of the important routes between
Great Britain and the Continent and the Republic of Ireland, as well as on
336 BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
many domestic routes. Ownership of domestic services in Scotland was
transferred to the Scottish Transport Group under the Transport Act 1968.
Development In 1955 the BTC produced a modernisation plan designed to transform
virtually all the services offered by the railways. The plan has since been
modified in the light of ensuing economic and technical developments,
but capital expenditure has been substantial over the past few years and in
1968 amounted to £87 million.
The most important developments have been the replacement of steam by
diesel and electric traction completed in 1968; the improvement of inter-city
passenger services with the emphasis on speed, reliability and comfort;
the introduction of express freight services (‘freightliners’) enabling freight
to be handled throughout transit in standard containers (now the responsi¬
bility of Freightliners Ltd., see p. 337); and increased mechanisation in the
carrying of coal.
On main lines in 1955 there were about 18,000 steam, 7 mainline diesel
and 71 electric locomotives. At the end of 1968 there were 4,326 diesel
and 329 electric locomotives. In addition there were 3,810 diesel passenger¬
carrying multiple units and 7,348 electric multiple units.
The Board’s current programme includes the replacement of old passenger
coaches by new stock with improved amenities, and the construction of
new electric multiple unit stock to replace old vehicles. On certain sections
of the London—Bristol—South Wales line and of the London—Edinburgh
line passenger trains are permitted to run up to 100 mph. Similar speeds are
also in operation on the London Midland Region’s services on the electrified
line between London, Birmingham, Manchester and Liverpool. This electri¬
fication scheme, costing some jf 160 million, was the largest individual
capital investment project ever undertaken by British Railways and included
station reconstruction, bridgeworks, a new colour-light signalling system
and new rolling stock. Work on the scheme was finally completed in 1967.
Other projects have involved the electrification of the London-South-
ampton-Bournemouth line, the extension of modern signalling facilities and
the rebuilding of various stations, notably at Euston (London) at an estimated
cost of ^15 million and in Birmingham.
Motorail services (carrying both passengers and cars) have developed
fast and have a current capacity of 100,000 cars. The world’s first car-train
terminal was opened in London in 1966.
The efficiency of freight services is being improved as new vehicles come
into service and as facilities for concentrating traffic at fewer and better
equipped and sited marshalling yards and terminals are completed. The
freightliner services, now the responsibility of Freightliners Ltd. (see p. 337),
are to be developed further to bring the number of main terminals in operation
to 21. Services are operated throughout the country and to the Continent.
Traffic trebled in 1968. The first freightliner ran in November 1965.
The London International Freight Terminal, opened in 1967, links the
British Railways container port of Harwich with the main freightliner network.
The first fully cellular container ships built in a British yard are being used in
British Railways container services between Harwich and Zeebrugge, opened
in 1968.
Bulk products traffic is increasing. Oil is being moved from refineries
under long-term contracts, while coal is being fed direct from collieries to
power stations in ‘merry-go-round’ trains, on which coal is loaded and dis¬
charged automatically from a new type of high-capacity wagon. Long-term

contracts are in operation for the carriage of cars, china clay, milk, grain and

British Railways’ workshops have been reorganised and modernised
into 15 main works, employing some 38,000 people, mostly on repairs and
construction of rolling stock.
The Railway Technical Centre at Derby covers 20 acres and will eventually
employ about 1,500 people. Work is proceeding on a large number of projects,
a major one being the development of a 150 mph gas turbine powered
passenger train to run over existing tracks. With the associated train control
system it is being given government financial help.
The National Freight Corporation was set up under the 1968 Transport
Act to provide or promote the provision of integrated road and rail freight
services, making the maximum economic use of rail. The Corporation took
over all the road haulage and most of the shipping interests of the Transport
Holding Company, and from the Railways Board the depots, vehicles,
warehouses, containers and other equipment, though not the actual trains
used, in the freightliners and sundries services, and also the Board’s road
haulage vehicles.
Freightliners Ltd., a company jointly owned by the Freight Corporation
and the Railways Board (with 51 per cent and 49 per cent of the shares
respectively), is responsible for the marketing and management of freightliner
services. The Railways Board makes a charge for providing and hauling the
trains, and profits are divided between the Board and the Corporation in
proportion to their holdings.
A Freight Integration Council was set up under the 1968 Act to advise
the Minister of Transport and the Secretary of State for Scotland on the
provision of integrated freight services by publicly owned bodies. It consists
of several independent members with an independent chairman, the chairmen
of the Freight Corporation and the Railways Board, and members representing
union interests.
The British and French Governments have agreed to the construction of a
rail Channel Tunnel (either a bored tunnel or an immersed tube) provided
that finance can be raised on acceptable terms in the private sector. The
construction cost is estimated at about £200 million. It is expected that the
Tunnel will be open in the 1970s.
The advent of the motor vehicle made it necessary for the Government to
set up a central road authority; accordingly, the Road Board was established
by the Development and Road Improvement Funds Act 1909. In 1919 the
Board’s responsibilities were taken over by the newly established Ministry of
Transport.
In April 1968 Great Britain had 197,430 miles of public highway. There
were 8,379 miles of all-purpose trunk roads and 540 miles of motorways,
20,216 miles of principal roads, and 168,295 m^es °f other roads. Roads
are classified according to their traffic value, those of purely local traffic
importance remaining unclassified. Under the Local Government Act 1966
the classification of important roads other than trunk roads into classes I, II
and III (still retained for certain purposes) has been superseded, as far as the
making of grants for road building is concerned, by two categories of ‘principal’
roads, roughly equivalent in mileage to the Class I roads, and others. On maps
and signposts the trunk and principal roads can usually be identified by the
338
Development
Motorways
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL FIANDBOOK
letter ‘A’ (or, in the case of motorways, ‘M’) in front of a route number. Trunk
roads are the main arteries of national traffic and the whole cost of their
upkeep is met from Exchequer funds. The Minister of Transport is the
highway authority for trunk roads in England and on these roads he
administers expenditure, which is provided wholly from central government
sources, although for many purposes he employs local authorities as his
agents. Work on major trunk road schemes, including motorways, is controlled
by regional road construction units, manned jointly by Ministry of Transport
and county council staff. The highway authority for principal roads is, in
general, the council of the county or county borough in whose area the roads
lie. The Minister makes specific grants towards approved expenditure on
construction and major improvement of these roads and contributions from
public funds towards maintenance and other expenditure is made through
grants to local authorities. The Secretary of State for Scotland has corres¬
ponding responsibilities for roads in Scotland and the Secretary of State for
Wales for roads in Wales. Roads other than trunk and principal roads are
entirely the responsibility of the local authority in whose area they lie.
A large and steadily expanding road-building programme has been in progress
since 1955. Public expenditure on new and improved roads in Great Britain
is estimated at over £2°° million in 1969-70. The current programme includes
a considerable mileage of motorways constructed for the use of limited classes
of traffic under powers granted by the Special Roads Act 1949 (consolidated in
the Highways Act 1959).
The motorways form part of a programme designed to provide a national
network of modern through routes. At the same time, work done under this
programme is eliminating some of the worst bottlenecks in urban areas and
thus helping to give free outlets from the big cities and from other main
sources of traffic to the trunk routes. Urban motorways are being built or are
already open in London, Birmingham, Glasgow, Bristol, Manchester, Leeds
and Newcastle.
Proposals for an inter-urban road plan, to be carried out in England over
the ten to 15 years following the completion of the current programme in the
early 1970s and with improvements to other trunk roads to cost about £2,250
million, were put forward by the Government early in 1969.
It is planned that 1,000 miles of motorways should be completed by the
early 1970s. At the end of May 1969 in England and Wales, 570 miles had
been opened for traffic and construction had started or tenders had been
invited for a further 294 miles. The lines of an additional 221 miles had been
fixed and draft schemes published for 96 miles. It is expected that some 720
miles of motorways will be in use by 1970- Among the motorways in England
and Wales open to traffic or under construction in May 1969 were:

Yorkshire, the last section (outside London) being brought into use in
1968.
M2 Medway motorway, London to Dover. The 25 miles of this motorway

M4—London to South Wales. The projected length of this road, which
will link London with Newport, is 140 miles. In the east, 24 miles are in
use from Chiswick to Maidenhead, including a one-mile spur to London
Airport; a section of 38 J miles of road from Newport (Monmouthshire) to
Tormarton (Gloucestershire) including the bridge over the Severn was
completed in 1967. The route has been fixed for the 78 miles still
to be built, between the Maidenhead bypass and Tormarton, and
construction work is in progress.
M5—Birmingham to Bristol. Of this 114-mile motorway eventually reaching
to Edithmead (22 miles beyond Bristol), the first 26 miles running south
from Birmingham were opened in July 1962, followed by a further 6 miles
of the northward link with the M6 in 1965. There will be a connection
with the M4 north of Bristol. The 21-mile Ross Spur (M50), opened in
i960, links the M5 with the existing road system leading from Ross-on-
Wye (Herefordshire) to South Wales.
M6—Birmingham to Carlisle. The projected length of this road is 230 miles
including the Midland Link motorways connecting with the Mi and
the M5, due for completion in 1970-71; the 125! miles linking Darlaston
with Lancaster are open to traffic. It includes the 8-mile Preston bypass,
the first section of motorway in Britain, opened in 1958. The Penrith
bypass was opened in November 1968, and the remaining sections
between Lancaster and Carlisle are under construction.
M62—Lancashire to Yorkshire. A 6-mile stretch from Stretford to Eccles
bypass was finished in i960, and the remaining 70 miles are under
construction.
Draft schemes have been published for 38 miles of the Mu from London
towards Cambridge, the 26-mile M23 from London to Crawley, and 28 miles
of the South Coast motorway between Portsmouth and Southampton (M27).
In Scotland about 115 miles of motorways are planned including motorways
between Glasgow and Edinburgh, Edinburgh and Stirling, Edinburgh and
Perth, and a 16-mile section between Glasgow and Carlisle (of which 13^ miles
are in use). Altogether about 37 miles of motorway are now open. Following
the completion of the current programme about £500 million is to be spent on
trunk and principal roads over the period 1971-72 to 1980-81.
Notable schemes for improving existing trunk roads include that for the
A19 from the recently improved Ai (Great North Road) through Teesside
to the Tyne, the A38 from Exeter to Plymouth and the A12 from London to
Ipswich. Improvements on the A40 route, linking London with Gloucester and
South Wales via Oxford, include a 131-mile bypass around High Wycombe, in
Buckinghamshire, built to motorway standards and completed in 1968. It will
eventually form part of the London to Oxford motorway (M40). Several
major projects are under construction or planned for the industrialised areas
of South Wales.
A large programme of bridge and tunnel building has been undertaken in
recent years. The £2-3 million Medway Bridge, which is part of the M2 and
one of the largest prestressed concrete structures of its kind in the world, was
completed in 1963 and the suspension bridge across the Firth of Forth, one of
the longest bridges in the world, was opened in 1964. The Severn Bridge,
incorporating major advances in suspension bridge design, and the 7,000-ft.
bridge across the Firth of Tay, were opened in 1966. Tinsley Viaduct, near

Sheffield, a two-level viaduct over 3,000 feet long, was opened in two stages in
1968. A high-level bridge over the Clyde at Erskine is under construction.
The second Blackwall Tunnel (under the Thames) costing £8 million and
the £13 million Tyne Tunnel between Wallsend (Northumberland) and
Jarrow (Durham) were opened in 1967. The £11 million Dartford-Purfleet
tunnel (under the Thames) has been open to traffic since the end of 1963.
Work on the £20 million second Mersey Tunnel began in 1967 and is due for
completion in 1970. A tunnel to carry a London motorway under the Thames
is to be built at the new town of Thamesmead.
Research on roads is carried out at the Road Research Laboratory (see p. 191).
Its aims are to find more economical ways of designing, constructing and
maintaining roads and of facilitating the flow of traffic on them and to reduce
road accidents. The layout of roads, their traffic, the safety features of road
vehicles and the behaviour of road users are investigated, and new methods,
materials and processes are developed for building roads and providing
them with a smooth, safe and durable surface. The Laboratory has a Tropical
Section, which undertakes research and advises on road problems overseas.
In 1968 there were about 14-5 million motor vehicles licensed to use Great
Britain’s roads. Of these, i-6 million were goods vehicles and 100,000 were
public road passenger vehicles (that is, buses and taxicabs).
The first world war greatly stimulated the development of motor vehicles,
which became serious competitors of the railways. Government regulation of
public road transport began with the passing of the London Traffic Act 1924,
which gave the Minister of Transport power to control the number of buses
and their journeys in London; this was followed in 1933 by the setting up of
the London Passenger Transport Board (see p. 345).
The Road Traffic Act 1930 ended the licensing of public service vehicles
(that is, buses and coaches) by local authorities and set up instead traffic areas
under the control of three traffic commissioners (except for the London
metropolitan area, which has one1) appointed by the Minister. The com¬
missioners regulate, by means of a licensing system, all public road passenger
transport services, and they sanction routes and time-tables in order to
secure proper co-ordination of services and eliminate unnecessary competi¬
tion; they may also control fares. Once the Passenger Transport Executives
(see p. 345) are operating ordinary bus services within their areas, these
services will no longer be subject to control by the traffic commissioners.
The Road and Rail Traffic Act 1933 established a system of licensing for
road haulage vehicles designed to restrict vehicle operations to proved needs
and to eliminate wasteful competition which will remain in partial operation
until the new licensing system proposed in the 1968 Transport Act is fully
operational. A licence has to be secured from the licensing authority (the
chairman of the appropriate body of traffic commissioners) before a goods
vehicle can be used on the road. There are three types of licence: the ‘A’
licence for general public haulage; the ‘B’ licence for public haulage limited to
certain goods or certain areas and covering also the carriage of the licensee’s
own goods; and the ‘C’ licence for the carriage by traders solely of their own
goods. Applications for ‘A’ and ‘B’ licences are examined by the licensing
authorities to see if they are necessary in view of existing transport services,
1 Under the Transport (London) Act 1969, three commissioners will eventually operate
in the metropolitan traffic area (excluding the London Transport area).
to
TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS
341
and competitors may raise objections. The ‘C’ licence is granted on application,
as of right. Regulations concerning the fitness and loading of vehicles, the
keeping of records, and driving hours and rest periods of employees have
been made more severe under recent legislation.
Under the 1968 Transport Act a new licensing system, with the aims of
improving safety and promoting a fuller use of rail transport where this does
not impose higher costs on industry, will eventually replace the system
described above. Over 900,000 goods vehicles not exceeding 3^ tons gross
loaded weight (30 cwt. unladen), formerly mostly holding ‘C’ licences, have
already been exempted from licensing. Operators of goods vehicles of over 3!
tons will need to hold a ‘quality* licence, certifying that they can and will
provide or receive adequate maintenance facilities, and control loading and
the hours worked by their drivers; that they have adequate financial resources
to enable them to maintain vehicles properly; and that they or an employee
hold a ‘transport manager’s licence’ entitling them to manage the vehicles of
a transport undertaking. A new form of ‘quantitative’ control will apply to all
goods vehicles of over 16 tons gross weight engaged in hauls of over 100 miles
or carrying certain bulk materials, such as coal, in loads of over 11 tons over
any distance. The British Railways Board and the National Freight Corpora¬
tion will eventually have the right to object to the granting of any quanti¬
tative licence on the grounds that they can offer a rail service at least as good
in terms of speed, reliability and cost.

From September 1956 to January 1963 the nationalised road haulage services
were controlled by British Road Services (BRS), a division of the British
Transport Commission, and operated through five companies, which together
owned about 16,000 vehicles. Under the Transport Act 1962, these organi¬
sations operated companies incorporated under the Companies Act, with
their own boards, and were grouped together under the Transport Holding
Company, responsible to the Minister of Transport. The road haulage
interests of the Holding Company have been transferred to the National
Freight Corporation (see p. 337).
The number of licensed vehicles in the road goods transport industry has
shown only a relatively slow growth, from 1-4 million in i960 to i-6 million
in 1968, when 1 -2 million were on ‘C’ licence. Of the other 240,000 vehicles,
with ‘A’ and ‘B’ licences, about 18,000 were operated by British Transport
Holding Company subsidiaries. There are only a few operators with large
fleets of vehicles in any of the licence categories. ‘C’ licence vehicles include a
large number of small vehicles used locally in the delivery of groceries and
other goods. Other vehicles in this class are engaged in long-distance carriage
of traders’ own goods.
Public
Passenger
Transport
by Road
The 1968 Transport Act enables Passenger Transport Authorities (PTAs)
to be set up to control and co-ordinate the different forms of transport in
any particular area. The first PTAs were set up in April 1969 in Greater
Manchester, Merseyside, the West Midlands and Tyneside. The relevant
local authorities appoint most of the members, but up to one-seventh may be
appointed by the Minister of Transport (or by the Secretaries of State for
Scotland and Wales). Each appoints its own chairman, with the Minister’s
approval. The PTAs control policy and finance, and appoint professional
executives—Passenger Transport Executives—to be responsible to them
for day-to-day operations. The Executives may operate services themselves
and enter into agreements with other bodies, such as British Railways or
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the National Bus Company, to operate others; they will take over all the present
municipal bus undertakings in their areas.
The National Bus Company has been formed to take over the former bus
operating and manufacturing subsidiaries of the Transport Holding Company
in England and Wales, and operates through locally based subsidiaries.
A separate Scottish Transport Group has been set up to control bus and
some shipping services in Scotland, and has taken over the relevant interests
of the Transport Holding Company, operating through subsidiaries.
The National Bus Company and the Scottish Transport Group operate
about 21,100 and 4,700 vehicles respectively. The PTAs will take over
control of 6,300 vehicles now operated by 21 municipal undertakings.
The remainder of the industry, excluding London Transport, comprises
4,800 operators owning 34,000 vehicles; 71 of these operators are local
authorities outside PTA areas operating 10,000 vehicles, and 3,500 are small
concerns operating not more than five vehicles.
Capital grants are made by the Government towards the cost of invest¬
ment in public transport, at rates of up to 75 per cent of approved cost.
Eligible schemes include improvements or extensions of railway lines, new
fixed track rail and bus systems, interchanges, stations, and car parks. Grants
at the rate of 25 per cent are available towards the cost of newr types of buses
approved by the Ministry of Transport. Grants may also be paid through a
new rural bus grants scheme, and for a time to PTA executives towards the
cost of rail services covered by agreement with the Railways Board.
Britain has one of the highest densities of road traffic in the world. Road
accident statistics are compiled and published by the Ministry of Transport,
the Scottish Development Department and the Welsh Office from reports
made by the police. In 1968, 6,810 people were killed on the roads and about
342,000 injured. The fatal accident rate per vehicle is lower than that in
most other European countries, but slightly higher than in the United States.
Modern roads, designed for present-day traffic and segregating pedestrians
from vehicles, are safer than the roads they replace and surveys have shown
they result in a marked fall in casualties. The more important measures
directed primarily towards road safety include speed limits of 30 and 40 m.p.h.
in built-up areas and 50 m.p.h. on certain trunk and important classified
roads in rural areas; a 70 m.p.h. speed limit on all motorways and on ordinary
main roads where no lower limit applies; the provision of pedestrian cross¬
ings—usually illuminated by flashing beacons and marked with conspicuous
white stripes (‘zebra’ crossings); and the system of road markings and traffic
signs which are being replaced by greatly improved signs in accordance
with general European practice. The Road Safety Act 1967 made it an offence
to drive with more than a prescribed level of alcohol in the blood.
The design of vehicles, their use on the roads, and the maintenance of their
mechanical condition are controlled by regulations. Private cars and light
vans which are three or more years old must be tested annually at private
garages authorised as test stations. Heavy goods vehicles are tested annually
at government test stations. Public service vehicles must be specially approved
before being licensed to carry passengers, and are tested at regular intervals.
Any vehicle may be stopped on the road at any time by the police and
examined. Fitting of seat belts in cars registered in or after 1965 is compulsory,
and a high standard of tyre safety is enforced.
All drivers of motor vehicles, unless they have either held a full British
licence or passed the driving test in the last ten years, are required to pass the

must obtain a ‘provisional’ licence which necessitates their displaying ‘L’
(Learner) plates on their vehicle, and in all cases where vehicles are constructed
to carry passengers, other than pillion passengers, learner drivers must be

A scheme for special licensing and testing of drivers of heavy goods vehicles,
which lapsed in 1939, is to be brought up to date and reintroduced in February

The Road Traffic Acts, which embody the law relating to road users, are
enforced by the police and the courts. A person convicted of any of the 30
most serious offences is liable to be disqualified from driving for a period. The
standard of conduct for all road users and a summary of the requirements of
the law is set out in easily understandable form in the Highway Code, which
was revised in 1968. A failure to observe the code does not of itself render a
person liable to criminal proceedings but may be taken into account in any
such proceedings.
National campaigns to persuade people to take greater care on the roads
are conducted by the Ministry of Transport and the Royal Society for the
Prevention of Accidents, acting as the Government’s agent and with the
participation of the local authorities. The police and education authorities
also help by arranging courses of instruction, especially courses for children.
In a White Paper published in 1967 (see Bibliography, p. 483) the Govern¬
ment announced further proposals for reducing accidents. These include
the setting up of a central road safety unit within the Ministry of Transport,
extension of local authority activity in safety matters, publicity and training
campaigns, and a review of pedestrian safety.
The Road Traffic Regulation Act 1967 empowers traffic authorities to make
orders regulating traffic and imposing parking control. With the exception of
trunk roads, which are the concern of the central Government, traffic is the
responsibility of local authorities. Several extensive schemes for the improve¬
ment of road safety and the relief of traffic congestion are being undertaken:
these include ‘fly-overs’ at road junctions; new outlet roads from cities; and
traffic management measures, including comprehensive control of street
parking, one-way’ systems, peak hour ‘clearways’ prohibiting waiting on
busy roads, and ‘tidal flow’ arrangements. A traffic Advisory Unit set up in
1965 in the Ministry of Transport advises local authorities. In most town
centres street parking is permitted for limited periods only, and in London
and some other towns on payment at parking meters usually under the
supervision of traffic wardens. Disc schemes providing free but limited
parking facilities are in operation at Cheltenham, Devizes, Harrogate and
Ripon. More off-street facilities are being provided. A computer-controlled
system to regulate traffic was installed in west London in 1968. Computer-
controlled systems are also operating in Glasgow and Liverpool.
In 1761 James Brindley completed the Bridgewater Canal to take coal from
the collieries owned by the Duke of Bridgewater at Worsley to Manchester.
This marked the beginning of canal building in modern Britain, with which
the names of Brindley, Telford, Rennie, Jessop and other great engineers are
associated. Canals played an important part in promoting industrial and
commercial expansion in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries.
The whole canal system was practically complete by 1830. As a result of
developing competition from the railways, however, about one-third of the
344
The System
Development
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
canal mileage had passed to the control of the railway companies by the middle
of the nineteenth century. During the two world wars government control of
railways included railway-owned canals. Under the Transport Act 1947, most
of the country’s canals passed to the British Transport Commission in
January 1948. From 1955 the canals were managed separately by the water¬
ways division of the Commission, known as British Waterways; under the
Transport Act 1962, control has been vested in the British Waterways Board
since January 1963. This control has been confirmed by the Transport Act
1968, under which a substantial grant-in-aid is to be paid to enable the Board
to maintain an extensive network of amenity waterways.
There are about 2,500 miles of navigable inland waterways in Great Britain,1
some 2,000 miles of which belong to the British Waterways Board; the
remainder are mainly still in the hands of local authorities or private com¬
panies. Many of the Board’s canals are narrow waterways which can generally
be used only by boats not exceeding 7 feet in width, capable of carrying a load
varying from 25 to 30 tons; the remainder are broad waterways and canalised
rivers, some of which can be used by craft of up to about 750 tons capacity.
The Caledonian and Crinan Canals in Scotland are broad waterways. Of the
2,000 miles of inland waterways under the control of the British Waterways
Board some 340 miles are commercial waterways. A substantial additional
mileage (1,100 miles, known as ‘cruiseways’) is to be maintained mainly for
recreational purposes; a statutory council has been set up to advise the
Minister of Transport and the Board.
Engineering, commercial and estate work is directed from the Board’s
headquarters at London, and through regional offices at Leeds and Gloucester.
In Scotland the canals (other than the Caledonian, which is run by a manager)
are, for engineering purposes, under the control of the engineer-in-charge at
Glasgow; estates work is supervised centrally from London.
In 1968 traffic on the Board’s waterways amounted to just over 7 million
tons, of which 3 million tons were coal, 1^ million tons liquids in bulk
and 2^ million tons general cargo. Some 97 per cent of the traffic is carried
on about 300 miles of broad waterways, which are mainly canalised river
navigations.
Although the British Waterways Board is the largest single carrying
operator, most of the traffic is handled by independent carriers or by traders
in their own craft. The Board at the end of 1968 owned 13 tugs and 646
carrying craft, with a carrying capacity of 29,350 tons, including 53 power-
driven craft with a carrying capacity of 4,379 tons. It operates 3 docks and
25 warehouses.
The Board continues to improve facilities on its commercial waterways, most
of which link important industrial districts with ports. These waterways are
the main navigations and broad canals in the Yorkshire-Humberside area,
together with the Trent and Weaver Navigations, and the Weston Canal in
Cheshire, the Lee Navigation, part of the river Severn, including the Glouces¬
ter and Sharpness Canal, and the Caledonian and Crinan Canals.
The total revenue of the British Waterways Board in 1968 amounted to
^5-1 million, of which j£o-6 million arose from the Board’s own freight¬
carrying activities, £1 million from warehousing and terminal services, and
j£i'i million from the docks. The sale of water for industrial and agricultural

London is, with Tokyo and New York, one of the world’s three largest cities.
The area known as Greater London, within a radius of about 15 miles from
Charing Cross, contains about 7-8 million people.
London’s passenger transport system, in its modern sense, began in 1829
when the first omnibus, horse-drawn, appeared on the London streets. The
first regular tram service, also horse-drawn, began in 1870. In 1863 the first
underground steam railway, the Metropolitan, was built by digging a great
trench for the line and roofing it over. In 1870 the world’s first tube railway,
the Tower Subway, was constructed under the river Thames; it was cable-
operated and ran for only a few months. The first electric tube railway in the
world, the City and South London Railway, was opened in 1890, and this was
followed in 1900 by the opening of the Central London Railway. Shortly
afterwards the original steam-operated underground lines were electrified.
Meanwhile horse-drawn buses and trams were being replaced by motor buses
and electric trams.
Until 1933 there were many separate undertakings providing passenger
transport facilities in London, but in that year they were all vested in a single
public corporation, the London Passenger Transport Board. In 1948, with
the establishment of the British Transport Commission, the London Trans¬
port Executive took over control as an agency of the Commission.
Under the Transport Act 1962 the London Transport Executive was
replaced by a financially independent board, the London Transport Board.
Exchequer loans have financed the Board’s external capital needs. From 1965
the Board has been running a deficit (£10 million in 1968), due mainly to
competition from the private car and to increasing congestion. The deficit has
been met by government grants.
A basic reorganisation of transport in London is to take place, involving a
reconstruction of the Board’s capital, and the transfer of responsibility for
central bus and railway services’ activities to the Greater London Council.
The Council is to become the statutory transport planning authority for
London, and is to appoint the members of a new statutory body, to be respon¬
sible for the day-to-day management of transport services within the Greater
London area.
The London Transport undertaking operates all road and rail passenger
transport services in the London area with the exception of the London lines
of British Railways and the taxicabs. (Some 7,600 taxicabs that ply for hire
in the streets are privately operated by companies or owner-drivers and are
licensed annually by the Metropolitan Police. There are about 12,200 licensed
cab drivers.) London Transport’s operations at present extend beyond Greater
London to cover an area of 2,000 square miles (known as the London Passenger
Transport Area) within a radius of about 25 miles from Charing Cross and
with a population of over 10 million. In the ten years from 1959 to 1968 the
number of passenger journeys made annually on the London Transport
system fell from 3,425 million to 2,601 million, the fall being almost entirely
confined to bus and coach services, affected by increased private motoring
and changes in leisure habits.
London Transport’s railway network stretches 18 miles from north to south
and 32 miles from east to west. In March 1969 the total length of the railway
over which London Transport trains operated was 254 miles, of which 98
346

miles were underground. London Transport trains served 277 stations and
in 1968 its buses and coaches travelled over 3,239 miles of roads. To carry
traffic over all this area London Transport owned 4,240 railway cars and
7,894 buses and coaches. The total staff employed was 68,911.
Improvements carried out by London Transport have included complete
renewal of the bus and coach fleet, replacement of trams and trolleybuses by
diesel buses, extension and modernisation of parts of the Underground
system, and the introduction of automatic fare collection and automatic
trains. One-man operation of buses is being steadily extended over a period
of years.
Work on a new 14-mile underground railway, to cost about £89 million,
has been in progess since 1962. The main lo^-mile section from Walthamstow
in north-east London to Victoria Station is now in use, and an extension
to Brixton in south London should be in operation by the end of 1971. There
are plans to extend the underground system farther.
Reorganisation of public transport in Northern Ireland was completed in
1968. Under the Transport Act (Northern Ireland) 1967 the Ulster Transport
Authority was wound up and its assets and liabilities transferred to a new
company, the Northern Ireland Transport Holding Company. Responsibility
for operating services on the 203 miles of railway track was given to the
Northern Ireland Railways Company Ltd., a subsidiary of the Holding
Company. The Act also provides for a licensing system for road passenger
operators in certain areas.
Ulsterbus Ltd., another subsidiary of the Holding Company, has taken over
the road passenger operations of the Authority, which formerly provided all
public road passenger services, apart from those of the City of Belfast. A
number of privately owned bus companies now operate in addition.
In 1966 the Authority’s monopoly of road carriage of freight was replaced
by a licensing system. About 1,500 operators and 3,600 vehicles have been
licensed, the biggest single operator being Northern Ireland Carriers Ltd.,
owned jointly by the Northern Ireland Holding Company and the British
National Freight Corporation.
On 31st March 1969, there were 14,016 miles of public roads in Northern
Ireland, comprising 382 miles of trunk roads, 999 miles of Class I roads,
1,727 miles of Class II roads, 2,874 miles °f Class III roads and 8,034 miles °f
unclassified roads.
The Ministry of Development is directly responsible for the trunk road
system and bears the entire cost of maintenance and reconstruction work on
these roads. In addition to major reconstruction schemes on trunk roads, an
extensive system of motorways is planned including an urban motorway
system in Belfast. About 46 miles of motorw'ay were in use by the middle of
1969.
The Ministry of Development administers the Road Fund (the proceeds of
motor vehicle taxation, driving licence fees, etc.), from which grants are paid
to the local authorities (county, county borough, borough and urban district
councils) which are responsible for the other roads. The rates of grant range
from 90 per cent for major improvement works on Class I roads to 25 per cent
for maintenance work on the unclassified roads.
Gross capital expenditure on all roads in the financial year to 31st March
1969 was j£i2-8 million, and expenditure on maintenance and minor improve¬
ments was about £5-8 million. Gross capital expenditure in the five-year

CIVIL AVIATION
British airmen were among the first to carry mails (at the time of the
Coronation of King George V in 1911) and among the first to operate regular
mail and passenger services, which were inaugurated on 25th August 1919,
when a daily passenger service was opened between London (Hounslow)
and Paris (Le Bourget).
In April 1924 four small British companies merged to form Imperial Airways
Limited and this company pioneered the commercial development of inter¬
continental air routes. By 1929 there was a through service from England to
India. The first passenger service to Australia started in 1935.
The British Overseas Airways Corporation, a public corporation, took over
the undertakings of Imperial Airways Limited and British Airways Limited in
1940. British European Airways was established under the Civil Aviation
Act 1946 as a separate public corporation to cover the United Kingdom
and Europe. In addition to the two nationalised corporations, there are
between 20 and 30 independent air transport operators.
General responsibility for the development of United Kingdom civil aviation
was transferred in 1966 from the Ministry of Aviation to the Board of Trade.
Under the post-war nationalisation legislation the air corporations had a
statutory monopoly of British scheduled services, and independent operators
were confined, broadly, to charter work. From 1949, and increasingly from
1952, the independants were allowed to develop new scheduled services,
provided they secured ministerial approval and operated, technically, as
associates of the corporations. The Civil Aviation (Licensing) Act i960
abolished the corporations’ monopoly and provided for a licensing system,
administered by an Air Transport Licensing Board, to which the nationalised
and independent operators could apply on an equal footing for licences for
scheduled or charter services, or for revocation or variation of existing licences.
The ATLB is an independent body of six to ten members appointed by the
Board of Trade. Its main function is to consider and decide on applications for
licences (or their revocation or variation). The ATLB must have regard to an
applicant’s financial resources, staffing, organisation, the need for the proposed
services, the adequacy of, and possible effect on, existing services, and any
objections or representations made by interested parties. It also has the
general duty of furthering the development of British aviation.
There is provision for appeals on ATLB decisions to the Board of Trade,
which appoints independent commissioners to hear appeals publicly and report
with recommendations upon them. A committee set up to enquire into the
affairs of the civil air transport industry reported in May 1969. Its proposals
included the establishment of a Civil Aviation Authority to take over general
control of the industry, of a National Air Holdings Board to control the
state-owned airlines, of a privately owned ‘second force’ airline formed from
among the independent operators, and of a group of regional airlines owned
by both public and private interests.

The constitution and functions of BOAC and BE A are laid down in the Air
Corporations Act 1967, which consolidates, with certain exceptions, the
provisions of the Air Corporations Acts 1949 and 1966, and in the Air
Corporation Act 1969. Each corporation consists of 5 to 11 members, including
the chairman. The chairman of each board is a member of the other.
As a result of BOAC’s capital reconstruction in 1966, £35 million ‘Exchequer
Dividend Capital’ on which a variable dividend, related to each year’s earnings,
is payable, was created, together with a reconstruction reserve of some £30
million and appropriate loan capital. The introduction of Exchequer Divi¬
dend Capital (now £50 million and known as Public Dividend Capital)
is experimental. The statutory limit on BOAC’s total borrowings is ^90
million, which can be increased by Order to £120 million. BEA’s borrowing
limit is £200 million, which can be increased by Order to £230 million.
The Board of Trade has certain statutory powers and duties in respect of the
air corporations, including the power, very seldom used, to give directions
of a general character as to the exercise and performance of their functions
in relation to matters affecting the national interest. With the approval of the
Treasury, the Board has power to make Exchequer advances within the limits
laid down by Parliament. The Board of Trade is responsible for approving
the lines of the corporations’ capital expenditure. The Board also sets, after
consultation with the corporations, their financial targets and, in BOAC’s
case, approves the amount payable annually as dividend. There is also close
consultation on overseas traffic rights and air safety. Day-to-day matters
concerning the corporations’ activities are the responsibility of the commercial
management of BOAC and BEA.
Total capacity-ton-miles offered on all services has more than trebled since
1959, and had risen to 2,896 million capacity-ton-miles in 1968. In 1955,
2-5 million passengers entered or left the United Kingdom by air, compared
with 5-7 million who arrived or departed by sea; in 1962 there were for the
first time more air than sea passengers, and by 1968 the figures had risen to
15-7 million by air and 9-2 million by sea.
BOAC is engaged on long-haul airline operations. Its scheduled services link
Britain with Europe, the Middle East, the Far East, Australasia, Africa and
North and South America, and it also provides complete round-the-world
services. It co-operates closely with airlines of several other Commonwealth
countries; it also has financial interests in eight companies operating local and
regional services in the Far and Middle East and in the Caribbean in areas
adjacent to BOAC’s main routes; and in a number of hotel companies in areas
attractive to business and holiday travellers.
The capacity offered on BOAC’s own scheduled services reached 1,531 million
capacity-ton-miles in the year ended March 1969, having risen by 5-1 per cent
over the previous year. Over half of this capacity was on the western routes
to North and South America. The overall load factor in 1968-69 was 51-4 per
cent; the break-even load factor (the figure at which operating costs are
covered) was 43-6 per cent. The Corporation’s fleet, made up entirely of pure
jets, consists (June 1969) of Super VC 10s (17), VC 10s (12), Boeing 707-4365
(18) and Boeing 707-3365 (6 with a further 2 on order). Twelve Boeing 747s
are also on order; the first are due to enter service in 1970.
The VC 10, introduced into service in 1964, operates on African, Middle
East and Far East routes. The Super VC 10 (a larger and more powerful

atlantic routes. The Boeing 707-336C took over the transatlantic all-freighter
operation in January 1966. BO AC has reserved delivery positions on eight of
the Anglo-French Concorde aircraft and on six of the projected US Boeing
SSTs (supersonic transports).
BOAC’s own passenger terminal at Kennedy International Airport,
New York, is due to come into use in 1970. The Corporation is making a
substantial investment over a period of ten years on the installation of an
advanced airline computer system to control a wide variety of international
activities, including accounting and flight planning. The first stages, con¬
trolling seat reservations, came into operation in 1968.
BO AC had another profitable year in 1968-69 when it earned an operating
surplus of £21-9 million and net profits of £21-7 million after interest on
borrowings and taxation. Of its gross traffic revenue (£170 million)
million was earned in foreign currencies.
BEA operates a network of services to over 80 places in Britain, Europe,
North Africa and the Middle East. Its services in Britain include a number
which cannot be operated on a commercial basis but which meet a vital
social need, mainly the services to the Highlands and Islands of Scotland.
BEA also co-operates with other airlines in order to create ‘through travel’
facilities. It has a financial interest in several associated companies, most of
which collaborate with BEA in providing a network of services.
For the year ended 31st March 1969, the increases in capacity offered, and
passenger-miles and freight-ton-miles flown on scheduled services were 5-3
per cent, 7 • 1 per cent and 10-2 per cent respectively over the previous year: in the
same year some 7-7 million passengers were carried, an increase of 5 -3 per cent.
BEA’s fleet consists (March 1969) of BAG One-Elevens (10, out of 18
on order), Trident Twos (11, out of 15 on order), Trident Ones (22), Comet 4BS
(12), Viscount 802s (20), Viscount 806s (15), Argosys (4), Vanguard 951s (5),
Vanguard 953s (14), and Herons (2). Twenty-six Trident Threes, enlarged
versions of the Trident One, have been ordered at a total cost of £80 million.
In 1968-69 the corporation earned over ^108 million in revenue and made
a net profit of ^3-5 million. Recent difficulties have included the effects
of financial restrictions in Britain, particularly the reduced currency allowance
for travel abroad, and political upheavals elsewhere.
Although the two State corporations had a statutory monopoly up to 1961
there has been a significant expansion in recent years not only of the number
of passengers and volume of freight carried but also in the diversity of services
operated by the independent operators. As well as a wide network of domestic
and international services they provide vehicle ferry services; specialised air
cargo facilities; and enable travel agents to offer low-cost all-in holidays abroad.
The independent companies compete with BEA over several domestic
routes, including the busiest internal route in Europe, from London to
Glasgow. In 1968 they carried some 6-9 million passengers. A large programme
of aircraft re-equipment has been carried out. Jet airliners on domestic
routes in Britain were first introduced by British United Airways in 1966.
In addition to the public transport operators there are a large number of
companies engaged in miscellaneous aviation activities such as crop-spraying,
aerial survey and photography, and flying instruction. About 30 companies
carry out air-taxi operations.

The proportion of Britain’s overseas trade carried by air is increasing steadily.
In 1956, 1-7 per cent of imports and 2-9 per cent of exports (by value) were
carried by air. In 1968 the corresponding percentages were 11 -8 and 12-2, and
the total value of exports, imports and re-exports by air was £1,753 million.
The chief export items are expensive machinery and parts, aircraft and vehicle
parts, and electrical and electronic products; furs and skins account for a large
proportion of the total value of re-exports.
At Heathrow, London, freight traffic is increasing at an annual rate of over
19 per cent and totalled 291,000 metric tons in 1968. Scheduled services of
British airlines carried about 304,000 tons of freight in 1968, compared with
196,000 tons in 1959.
The estimated number of aircraft on the United Kingdom register used for
business and private purposes is over 800, while approximately 600 are
owned by clubs, groups and training schools. About 16,000 student and
private pilots hold licences. About 130 companies use private aircraft and
some 80 companies are members of the Business Aircraft Users’ Association.
The Board of Trade has a general responsibility for civil aerodromes. It may
itself establish and maintain airports, and local authorities may also do so
subject to its approval. Aerodromes which are municipally or privately owned
and wffiich are used for the public transport of passengers and/or flying
instruction are subject to government licensing, inspection and regulation.
The Board of Trade is also responsible for navigation facilities at a number
of main municipal airports.
The British Airports Authority, an independent statutory body operating
on a commercial basis, took over on 1st April 1966 the ownership and manage¬
ment of London’s two major airports (Heathrow and Gatwick), Prestwick in
Scotland, and Stansted in Essex. At these airports the Board of Trade is
responsible for the provision of navigation services and may direct the
Authority to take measures to control noise and vibration.
There are approximately 135 civil aerodromes in the United Kingdom;
in addition, 52 Service aerodromes are available for civil use. Those under
civil control include 13 directly controlled by the Board of Trade, 3 in the
Channel Islands and 1 in the Isle of Man administered by the local island
governments, and 40 aerodromes licensed for public use, of which 24 are
owned by municipalities. Two of the Board of Trade’s aerodromes and 28
others are designated Customs airports; limited customs facilities are available
at a further eight aerodromes.
Aircraft and passenger movements at the principal airports have risen very
markedly in the last five years, and in 1968 United Kingdom civil airports
handled 25-6 million passengers. The number of movements of aircraft
engaged on commercial transport operations was 560,000.
For international scheduled services Heathrow and Gatwick are the main
airports, and Heathrow is the largest and busiest airport in Western Europe.
The number of passengers handled at Heathrow has increased from 5-4
million in i960 to 13-4 million in 1968. The British Airports Authority is at
present spending some £25 million on improvements to Heathrow and its
other airports. The shorter of the two Heathrow runways is being extended to
12,800 ft. An £11 million passenger terminal for British short-haul airlines
and Aer Lingus was completed in 1969, and extensions are being made to
several other buildings. To accommodate the rapid expansion expected in

freight movements, £25 million has been invested in a new cargo terminal and
associated developments, which came into use in 1969. New facilities costing
some £12-5 million are planned for handling Boeing J47 (jumbo jet) aircraft
from 1970 onwards. There are plans to build a rail link between Heathrow and
central London (Victoria) to include a large station underneath the airport’s
central area.
The airport at Gatwick, 28 miles south of London, was opened in June
1958 as the second airport for the London area. Built alongside the main
London to Brighton railway and the A23 road, Gatwick airport was the first
in the world to contain road, rail and air transport in one unit. In 1968 it
handled over 2 million passengers. It is planned to extend the existing runway
and construct a second runway.
A privately owned helicopter terminal (or ‘heliport’) is in operation at
Battersea on the south bank of the Thames.
Prestwick airport in Scotland has been developed to accommodate large
jet aircraft. The freight facilities have been extended and further improve¬
ments are planned. A ^4^ million airport at Abbotsinch, owned and run by
the Glasgow Corporation, is expected to handle over 2 million passengers a
year in 1970. The main runway at Manchester has been extended.
Both Manchester (Ringway) and Glasgow (Abbotsinch) handled over a
million passengers in 1968; Belfast (Aldergrove), Luton, Edinburgh (Turn-
house), Birmingham and Prestwick each handled over 500,000.
The role of the Government in promoting air safety7 lies in research and in
setting up and supervising standards for both aircraft and personnel.
Research on aircraft design and construction is done at the Royal Aircraft
Establishments at Farnborough and Bedford, which are exceptionally well
equipped with testing facilities.
The Board of Trade determines the policy and legislative requirements for
the safe operation of civil aircraft, analyses accidents and initiates preventive
measures and research in flight safety.
All aircraft registered in the United Kingdom must have a valid certificate
of airworthiness issued (or rendered valid) by the Board of Trade on the
recommendation of the Air Registration Board, which was set up in 1937 and
consists of 18 members, two of whom are appointed by the Board of Trade—
one as an independent and one as an experienced professional pilot, the others
being representatives of constructors, operators and insurers of aircraft. No
aircraft built in Britain is granted a certificate of airworthiness unless it has
been constructed in accordance with British Civil Airworthiness Require¬
ments, a code compiled and frequently reviewed by the Board. Continued
airworthiness is ensured by regular inspection and by requiring aircraft to be
maintained in accordance with a schedule approved by the Board.
Every operator of aircraft above a certain weight used for public transport
must possess an Air Operator’s Certificate which is granted by the Director of
Aviation Safety when he is satisfied that the operator is competent to secure
the safe operation of his aircraft. The Director is advised by the Board of
Trade’s flight operations inspectors (who are experienced airline pilots) on
all matters affecting the operation of aircraft, except aircraft maintenance,
which is the responsibility of the Air Registration Board.
Each member of a flight crew must hold the appropriate official licence. Flight
operations inspectors check the standards maintained by the operators, which
must be adequate for purposes of the Air Operator’s Certificate.
