In order to supplement the diminishing supply of well-trained pilots for civil
airlines from the Royal Air Force, the College of Air Training was set up at
Hamble in i960. It is sponsored and financed by the Government and the
two airways corporations. Commercial pilots must attend a course of training
approved by the Board of Trade. Such courses have been approved at the
training schools at Carlisle, Elstree (near London), Oxford and Perth, in
addition to Hamble.
Responsibility for policy, planning and execution of both civil and military
air traffic control over the United Kingdom and the surrounding seas rests
with the National Air Traffic Control Services organisation, under the joint
control of the Board of Trade and the Secretary of State for Defence.
In 1950 a system of airways covering the main traffic routes with control zones
around the major airports was introduced. Subsequently, the airway system
has been revised and extended to meet traffic requirements. There are three
main air traffic control centres: at London for southern England, at Preston
for the north of England and Wales, and at Prestwick for Scotland and the
Atlantic Ocean to 30°W.
A variety of radar installations and other equipment provide the means by
which the system can accept the increasingly heavy load of air traffic. Britain
was the first country to use radar for the control of civil air traffic, and the
Instrument Landing System (ILS) is installed at all its major airports. During
the next few years virtually the whole of the airspace over Britain above
5,000 feet will be brought under surveillance by the latest types of primary and
secondary radar equipment, which will provide data to be used in two air
traffic control centres, located at West Drayton (near London) and
Prestwick. A subsidiary centre will be located at Manchester to deal with
traffic in the Manchester terminal control area. Extensive use will be made in
these centres of automatic data processing and other advanced electronic
techniques.
The Board of Trade provides radio navigational aids to help pilots navigate
in all weather conditions. In addition, the Board of Trade supports the Decca
Air and Marine Navigator System now operating over a wide area of Britain
and northern Europe, which can be used, by arrangement with the Decca
Company, by any aircraft fitted with the appropriate receiving equipment.
Britain has pioneered in the development of all-weather landing systems.
The Blind Landing Experimental Unit of the Royal Aircraft Establishment
at Bedford and private industry have worked towards fully automatic blind
landing, which has now been achieved with passenger-carrying aircraft.
Britain is a member of Eurocontrol, a European international agency con¬
cerned with the traffic control problems arising from the increasing use of
high-flying, high-speed jet aircraft. Set up in 1963 it provides control at the
higher flight levels for civil aircraft and for military aircraft operating
according to civil procedures.
The hovercraft, a vehicle which rides on a cushion of air over both land and
water surfaces, has been in regular public passenger service around the coasts
of Britain since 1965. Large-capacity passenger and car ferry craft (165 tons)
were introduced in 1968 as an extension to the present cross-channel services
to France, making an all-year-round service possible. A hovercraft terminal
at Pegwell Bay, near Ramsgate, came into use in 1969.

THE POST OFFICE
The Post Office, founded in 1657, provides the postal and public telecom¬
munications services of the United Kingdom. Although it has been a government
department run by civil servants, it became in effect a nationalised industry and
was formally set up as a public authority under the Post Office Act 1969.
The Post Office, previously controlled by a Minister, the Postmaster General,
is now headed by a chairman and board, appointed by and responsible to the
Minister of Posts and Telecommunications. In March 1969 the Post Office
had 417,000 employees and 24,820 post offices.
The Post Office has authority to borrow up to £2,300 million. At 31st March
1969 it had borrowed £1,681 million. Over 90 per cent of total expenditure
on fixed assets is accounted for by telecommunications. The postal, tele¬
communications and data processing services are now managed separately.
Recent figures of financial results are shown in Table 24.
The development of postal communications in Britain can be traced from
the time when horsemen carried dispatches to the Tudor Court up to modern
airmail transport. The first dispatch of mails by train was made in 1830
between Liverpool and Manchester. The inauguration of the penny post
(the uniform charge for any inland distance being prepaid by means of
postage stamps, which originated in Britain) in 1840 was followed by a rapid
extension of the scope of the postal services. The registered post, ensuring
additional safety for valuable mail, was introduced in 1841. The money order
system, which had operated as a private venture from 1792 to 1838, was
supplemented in 1881 by the issue of postal orders for fixed amounts.
Letterboxes had been instituted in London in 1855, and in 1883 the parcel
post was introduced. In 1919 the Post Office inaugurated its own motor
transport fleet and the first mail was carried by air in Britain in 1911.
Table 24 gives statistics of items of inland and overseas mail carried. Each
year about 7,500 tons of mail are carried by air within the United Kingdom.
Out of the 559 million items of overseas mail carried in 1968-69,67-5 per cent was
carried by air, compared with 51 per cent in 1955-56. The air parcel service now
operates to all countries in Europe and to over 190 countries outside Europe.
Several new highly mechanised sorting office buildings were opened in
1969. Over the next ten years £50 million is to be spent on conveyance and
sorting equipment and research into new techniques. About half of this
sum will be spent on letter coding and automatic letter-sorting machines.
Letter segregating and facing machines are being installed at over 60 centres.
Postal address coding is being continuously extended, and is expected to
cover over 10 million addresses by March 1970. A two-tier letter service was
introduced in 1968 consisting of a more highly priced service for first-class
mail and a cheaper one for less urgent items; it has succeeded in reducing
pressure at peak periods.
A Postal Consultancy Service offers facilities to overseas countries to aid
them in the planning and mechanisation of their services.
At the post office counter, besides making use of its postal and telegraph
facilities, the citizen can draw his pension and his family allowance, buy a
licence for his dog, sound radio or television receiving set, renew his car
licence and buy national insurance stamps. He can also use the wide range of
facilities for savings and investments (see p. 372) offered by the National
Department for Savings, and the money transmission services of the National

All private telegraph systems in Britain were transferred to the control of
the Postmaster General in 1870. Teleprinter-working for the transmission
of inland telegrams was introduced generally in 1928 and conversion to the
present automatic switching system was completed in mid-1954. It is now
one of the most up-to-date systems in the world and gives direct connection
between any of the 350 or so larger telegraph offices. The overseas telegraph
services were shared until 1950 between the Post Office and Cable and
Wireless Ltd. This company was brought into public ownership in 1947.
The Post Office, which acquired the British services, operates all overseas
telegraph services from the United Kingdom, except those offered by foreign

TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS 355
telegraph companies. Cable and Wireless Ltd. continues to operate its cable
and wireless services in many dependencies and foreign countries.
Telegraph services to overseas countries are operated from Electra House in
London, the world’s largest overseas telegraph office, and from nine other
London and provincial area telegraph offices. Direct connection via the Centex
system between these British offices and the larger towns in Belgium, France,
Germany, Holland, Luxembourg, Italy and Norway minimises delivery delay.
In addition, the Post Office is well to the fore in the development of telegraph
message relay techniques for services beyond Europe.
The Telex Service (opened in England in 1932) combines the speed of the
telephone with the accuracy of the printed word. Calls may be made direct
between the rapidly increasing number of telex users in Britain (about 25,000
by the end of 1968) and also to well over 300,000 subscribers throughout the
world. Britain is linked to over 130 countries by telex. For call charging
purposes Britain is divided into 50 charging areas, each with its own telex
centre. The United Kingdom telex service is fully automatic and immediate
connection is made by direct dialling to any subscriber in this country, and to
many subscribers in Europe, New Zealand, the United States and Canada.
Other overseas calls are connected by operators at the International Telex
Exchange in London which provides a teleprinter service to over 120 countries
abroad. Inland and overseas telex traffic is growing annually by about 20 per
cent; the Post Office is planning for a system of about 140,000 United
Kingdom subscribers by 1980. A new radioteleprinter service extends the use
of telex to ships at sea (see p. 357).
The demand for facilities enabling digital data for computers to be trans¬
mitted over telephone and telegraph lines has greatly increased; to meet it
the Post Office has developed a range of datel services providing for trans¬
mission at speeds of up to 50 bits per second over telegraph-type circuits
and up to to 2,400 bits per second over speech-type circuits. Datel facilities
are available to a number of European countries and over speech-type
circuits to the United States. In the year ending March 1969 the number of
British datel terminals rose by 130 per cent to about 4,400.
When the Post Office bought the property of the National Telephone Com¬
pany in 1912 it became the owner of almost the whole telephone service.
Hull Corporation was the only municipality to exercise its option of operating
its own service under licence from the Postmaster General; this service (and
the service in the Channel Islands, also operated under licence) is connected
to the Post Office trunk network.
At the end of March 1969 there were 6,125 local telephone exchanges and
just under 13 million telephones. On that date, only 150 exchanges remained
to be changed to automatic working. Trunk dialling by subscribers began in
Bristol in December 1958; by March 1969 the facility had been extended to
2,176 exchanges, serving 81 per cent of all subscribers; by 1970 it will be
available on over 90 per cent of all telephones. The introduction of group
routing and charging equipment brings the advantages of quicker service,
automatic accounting and cheap long-distance calls of short duration, and
constitutes the most radical reform of the telephone service since the Post
Office assumed national responsibility for it. Telephones in London and five
other large cities have been given all-figure numbers in which exchange names
are replaced by figures, to facilitate handling of rapidly expanding domestic
and international traffic.
356 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Electronic exchanges are now being ordered for all new exchanges with
from 200 to 2,000 lines. The first operational electronic exchange in Europe
was opened at Ambergate, Derbyshire, in December 1966. Similar equipment
for larger exchanges is being tested.
Pulse code modulation systems are being used to increase the circuit
capacity of lines on short-distance routes between exchanges. Over 900 should
be installed by the end of 1969. A new time-division electronic switching
system for interconnecting routes equipped with pulse code modulation
systems has been used experimentally.
International subscriber dialling operates between London, Edinburgh,
Birmingham, Glasgow, Liverpool, Manchester and most of Western Europe;
it is planned to extend it to Italy and other European countries.
Operator-connected calls are handled at the London Continental Exchange,
from which well over 2,000 direct telephone circuits give service to European
countries and at the London International Exchange, which is linked by
transatlantic cables to the US and to the Commonwealth cable network. High
frequency radio is used for calls to other destinations and communications
satellites carry an increasing proportion of intercontinental telephone calls.
The various overseas circuits are also used to send and receive pictures, and
special circuits are used for broadcast transmissions.
A radio tower, 620 feet high, in London provides microwave radio links for
carrying long-distance telephone and television circuits. There are over 100
Post Office communications masts and towers in use, including a tower of
500 feet in Birmingham.
Special Telephone Several specialised services are available by telephone, including the ‘999’
Services emergency dialling service enabling subscribers to be connected as quickly
as possible, and free of charge, to the police, ambulance or fire brigade
services; the speaking clock; and a recorded weather forecast, motoring
information, recipe, cricket, and ‘Dial a Disc’ services. In London a recorded
service provides details in English, French, Spanish and German of important
events taking place in and around the capital on the day of the call and a
similar service (in English only) is provided in Edinburgh during the summer.
A public radiotelephone service, introduced in 1959, enables the users of
vehicles fitted with suitable radio equipment to make calls to, or receive them
from, any telephone in the United Kingdom network.

In March 1969 there were 107,000 private circuit stations not connected with
the public exchange networks. These are associated with circuits rented for
private use for telephone conversations, teleprinter connections, photo¬
telegraphy, television, music, or for the transmission of signals which
represent data for computers or operate other devices.
The first transatlantic telephone cable, TAT 1, connecting Britain with Canada
and the United States, was laid in 1956. Many submarine telephone cables
have been laid in succeeding years. Cable and Wireless Ltd., in co-operation
wdth the Post Office, carried out a comprehensive Commonwealth telephone
cable plan. The plan was agreed upon in 1958, and covered the construction
of three long-distance telephone cable systems: CANTAT (2,100 nautical
miles), from Scotland to Canada, was opened in 1961; COMPAC (8,130
nautical miles), connecting Canada, Hawaii, Fiji, New Zealand and Australia,
opened in 1963; and SEACOM (7,070 nautical miles), connecting Australia,
New Guinea, Guam, Hong Kong, Malaysia and Singapore, was completed in
stages from 1965 to 1967 and opened as a complete system in March 1967. All

three can provide 80 telephone circuits throughout, apart from the heavily
used section of SEACOM between Guam and Australia, which can provide
160. The submarine cables are linked overland across Canada and Australia by
radio microwave systems. CANTAT was the first single-cable ocean telephone
system to use the new lightweight cable and rigid two-way repeaters, both
developed by the Post Office.
Submarine cable systems using transistors in place of thermionic valves
have been developed by British manufacturers in consultation with the Post
Office Research Station. Three such systems providing 480 telephone circuits
were opened for service in 1968, and another, providing 640 between Britain
and Portugal, in 1969. Three new cables with a capacity of 1,260 circuits are
to be laid between Britain and Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands. The
long-life transistors used were developed and manufactured by the Post Office
Research Station.
The Goonhilly satellite communication earth station in Cornwall was brought
into operation in 1962, and took part in the first experiments in satellite
communications using the Telstar and Relay satellites. After major extensions
and improvements, including the installation of a second large aerial, the
station now provides commercial telephone and television circuits via high-
capacity, geo-stationary satellites positioned over the Atlantic and Indian
Oceans. By the end of 1970 over 20 countries will have direct satellite links
with Britain. The satellites used in the global communications systems are
provided by INTELSAT (International Communications Satellite Con¬
sortium) of which Britain is the second largest shareholder.
In addition to the radio stations for overseas telecommunications, the Post
Office has 11 coast radio stations in the United Kingdom. These stations
provide radiotelegraph and radiotelephone communications with ships at sea
at ranges of up to some 500 and 250 miles respectively. There is also the
long-distance radiotelegraph station, Portishead Radio, which communicates
with ships in all parts of the world.
These coast stations play an important part in the services concerned with
safety of life at sea. They keep continuous watch on the international radio¬
telegraph and radiotelephone frequencies for distress calls from ships or
aircraft and take immediate action to obtain assistance for any vessel in
distress. During 1968-69 the stations handled 504 urgent and SOS calls
from ships and aircraft.
In addition to the services for safety of life at sea, the stations exchange
radiotelegrams with ships and connect radiotelephone calls between telephone
subscribers ashore and suitably equipped ships; they also broadcast naviga¬
tional warnings and weather bulletins.
The stations operate a free medical advice service whereby the master of a
ship of any nationality may obtain advice from appropriate medical authorities
on the treatment to be given in cases of sickness or injury aboard ship. During
1968-69, 440 medical enquiries were dealt with in this service.
An Act passed in 1967 enabled the Post Office to offer its data processing
facilities developed for its own use to commerce and industry. The National
Data Processing Service has already attracted a considerable volume of
commercial work. It has 14 operational computers situated at centres in
London (3), Edinburgh, Portsmouth, Derby and Leeds. Other machines are
on order and additional centres planned.
14 FINANCE
PUBLIC FINANCE
Public finance is concerned with the way public authorities (that is, the
central Government and local authorities) finance their activities—how their
expenditure is decided upon and how their revenue is obtained.
Money administered by public authorities1 can be roughly divided into:
1. The funds of the central Government raised mainly by taxation which are
paid into and out of the Consolidated Fund in accordance with the
proposals of the Government as approved by Parliament (principally the
House of Commons). Additional central Government funds are raised by
borrowing and are paid into the National Loans Fund set up under the
National Loans Fund Act 1968.2
There are also funds administered for special purposes by central
government departments and wholly or partially maintained by receipts
which do not pass through the Consolidated Fund. The most important
one is the National Insurance Fund, administered by the Minister of
Social Security and used for the payment of benefits under the National
Insurance Scheme.
2. The funds of local authorities, obtained partly from rates (local taxes on
dwelling-houses and other real estate) and income from property and
trading receipts, partly from grants and loans from the central Government
and partly from loans raised in the open market (see p. 73).
The following broad account of government finance is concerned mainly
with central Government taxation and borrowing and only incidentally with
local government and other public funds.
Financial control, as exercised by the House of Commons, is based on law,
parliamentary rights and custom.
As the power of Parliament grew in late medieval and Tudor times, the
principle that taxation by the Crown required parliamentary consent was
gradually evolved. The principle was established, at the end of the constitu¬
tional struggles of the Stuart period, by the Bill of Rights 1689.
In medieval, Tudor and Stuart times, it is broadly true to say that once the
king was granted the right to raise a given sum by taxation, he was free to
spend it as he chose. In the eighteenth and nineteenth centuries, the House of
Commons gradually developed the modern system of controlling expenditure
through the device of Appropriation which was embodied in the Exchequer
and Audit Departments Act 1866. But by a Standing Order of the House of
Commons dating from the early eighteenth century the Crown’s consent is
required for all proposals involving new spending from the Consolidated Fund.
The House of Commons cannot, therefore, initiate expenditure which must be
proposed by a Minister.
1 For an account of public finance in Northern Ireland and its relationship to that of the
United Kingdom, see pp. 368-9.
2 Prior to April 1968 the funds from both these sources were paid into the Exchequer.
The term ‘Exchequer’ took its name from the ‘chess-board’, or table with chequered
cloth, round which the King’s financial officials sat for accounting purposes in the
twelfth century.
FINANCE
ESTIMATES AND
EXPENDITURE
Classification of
Expenditure
359
From the very early days of Parliament it had been established that such
financial control as Parliament possessed should be exercised by the House of
Commons. This control became effective, as regards taxation, in the seven¬
teenth century, but as regards expenditure it was not effective until the
nineteenth century. The controlling power of the House of Commons is
acknowledged today in the Speech from the Throne at the opening of a new
session of Parliament, which is addressed to both Houses but contains a
special paragraph on expenditure addressed to the Commons alone.
The Commons have traditionally claimed that the Lords have no power to
modify financial provisions, though they may reject such provisions; thus,
to minimise the chance of rejection, the practice was started in 1861 of
embodying the main financial provisions for the ensuing year in a single Bill.
Since the passing of the Parliament Act 1911, however, if the Finance Bill is
certified by the Speaker to be a Money Bill, it may be presented to the Queen
for the Royal Assent and become law without the consent of the House of
Lords if it has not been passed by them within one month (see p. 36).
Today, the authority of the House of Commons has to be obtained for all
expenditure by the central Government itself and for the raising of revenue
by taxation or borrowing. All government revenue, other than the proceeds of
borrowing and sums received by government departments in the course of
their normal activities (known as appropriations-in-aid), is paid into an
account with the Bank of England (known as the Exchequer Account) which
forms the Consolidated Fund. With certain exceptions (the main ones being
government loans and national insurance benefits), all payments by the
Government come out of this account.
The following sections outline the machinery by which expenditure and
revenue are authorised and controlled, the purposes on which public money
is spent and the sources from which revenue is obtained.
Central government expenditure falls into three main groups:
1. The main part of government expenditure which is authorised by annual
Appropriation Acts and includes, broadly, expenditure on defence, on the
social services and on the general administration of the country. These are
called Supply Services because the House of Commons, when voting
money, is granting to the Crown ‘such aids or supplies as are required to
satisfy ... the pecuniary necessities of the Government’. It should be
noted that some of this expenditure may also depend on legislation, such
as the National Health Service Acts, which relates to a specific object of
expenditure.
2. Expenditure which is specifically authorised by Acts of Parliament other
than annual Appropriation Acts. These are the Consolidated Fund
Standing Services which represent a direct charge on the Consolidated
Fund, covering the residual cost of servicing the National Debt,1 the
financial provision made for members of the royal family, and salaries and
pensions of judges and certain high officers, such as the Speaker of the
House of Commons and the Leader of the Opposition, whose indepen¬
dence of the Government is thought to be better guaranteed by permanent
grant than by annual vote. This group also includes expenditure from the
National Insurance and similar special funds.
1 The servicing of the National Debt is charged in the first instance to the National
Loans Fund. After taking account of certain receipts by the Fund, including interest
received on loans to nationalised industries and local authorities, the residue is charged
to the Consolidated Fund.
36°
Authorisation
of Expenditure
Scrutiny of
Expenditure
The Treasury
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
3. Government lending and debt, which under the National Loans Act 1968
are channelled through the National Loans Fund. These include most of
the Government’s domestic lending to the nationalised industries, local
authorities and public corporations as well as the principal repayments and
the servicing (that is, interest and expenses) of the National Debt.
The Estimates for the Supply Services are considered by the House of
Commons during the 29 days (known as Supply days) which are allotted by
Standing Order of the House to consideration of Supply business in each
session. The choice of subject for debate on these days rests with the
Opposition. The House usually discusses general questions of policy relevant
to the Estimates, though any Estimate may be examined in detail if members
wish and if time allows (see p. 39).
Estimates for Supply Services in the financial year beginning on 1st April
are submitted to the Treasury by each department in the preceding December.
Estimated expenditure is grouped under main headings called ‘Votes’ which
are further broken down into subheads and items. If the House of Commons
approves the Estimates, the sums asked for are voted and later confirmed in
the Appropriation Act; this Act appropriates the money to specific Votes.
No civil department may spend money granted on one Vote for the purposes
of another; but Service departments may do so providing they get Treasury
sanction, which, in turn, requires the retrospective authorisation of Parliament.
Within each Vote, ‘virement’, that is, the spending of money on one subhead
instead of on another, is permissible so far as Parliament is concerned, but
only with Treasury consent.
An insufficient Estimate, or a new service not covered by the Vote, or
virement of a magnitude or character which the Treasury considers should be
brought to the attention of Parliament, requires a Supplementary Estimate.
The Treasury exercises the same power of scrutiny over this as over the
ordinary Estimates.
Control of expenditure is maintained by the Treasury, by the Comptroller
and Auditor General, and by the Public Accounts and Estimates Committees
of the House of Commons.
The power of the Treasury to control expenditure derives from the responsi¬
bility of the Chancellor of the Exchequer for financial policy.
A central function of the Treasury is to present the Civil Estimates to the
House of Commons. In considering the Estimates submitted by departments,
the Treasury has to look at the proposals for expenditure in relation to
the results of the public expenditure surveys (see below); and to eliminate
any overlapping, uneconomic or wasteful expenditure where this has escaped
the net of departmental financial control. Apart from the scrutiny of Estimates,
throughout the year the Treasury exercises a general supervision over all
departmental expenditure. The Treasury also lays down general rules of
financial and accounting procedure for departments and prescribes the
principles on which departmental contracts shall be made and the limits
within which certain classes of losses may be written off.
In 1961 the Plowden Committee on the Control of Public Expenditure
recommended in its Report (Cmnd. 1432) that regular surveys should be
made of public expenditure as a whole over a period of years ahead and in
relation to prospective resources, and that decisions involving future expendi¬
ture should be taken in the light of these surveys. Surveys, therefore, are now
made annually and have become an established part of the Government’s
FINANCE
The Comptroller
and Auditor
General
The Public Accounts
Committee
The Estimates
Committee
361
machinery for the planning and control of expenditure (see p. 234). Changes
in the presentation of the Estimates and in the procedures for consideration
by Parliament of expenditure were proposed in a White Paper Public Expendi¬
ture: A New Presentation (Cmnd 4017), published in April 1969.
Control over issues of money to departments and the audit of accounts is
exercised by the Comptroller and Auditor General, which is a permanent
Crown appointment. Since 1866 he has had two functions: as Comptroller he
controls receipts and issues of public money to and from the Exchequer
Account and the National Loans Fund; and as Auditor General he audits
departmental accounts and submits his report on the Appropriation Accounts
and other accounts, as required by statute, to Parliament. His statutory
function is to ensure that all expenditure is properly incurred, for example,
that no payments are made which go beyond any relevant statutory authority,
and that Treasury sanction has been obtained wherever necessary. In addition,
however, he has been encouraged by successive Public Accounts Committees
(see the next paragraph) to examine departmental expenditure with a view to
drawing attention to any cases of apparent waste or extravagance.
The accounts of each department and the reports on the accounts made by
the Comptroller and Auditor General are considered by a select committee
called the Public Accounts Committee. This was first set up in 1861, on the
motion of Mr. Gladstone, for the purpose of ensuring that expenditure was
properly incurred in accordance with the purpose for which it was voted and
with any relevant Acts of Parliament. The terms of reference of the committee
are to examine the accounts and these terms have been widely interpreted by
successive committees which have investigated whether full value has been
obtained for the sums spent by departments and have examined cases in which
the administration appears to have been faulty or negligent. The committee
has therefore become a powerful instrument for the exposure of waste and
inefficiency. It embodies its findings in reports which may be debated in the
House of Commons. Its recommendations are considered by the Treasury
in consultation with departments and put into effect, so far as they are
accepted, according to Treasury instructions. A reply to each report is
submitted by the Treasury to the committee of the following session and
where the recommendations have been unacceptable to the Treasury the
committee may either accept the objections or return to the charge in sub¬
sequent reports.
This committee was originally set up in 1912 and has been reappointed
annually except during the war years. In i960 it was made a select committee
set up each session under standing orders. The committee’s functions are
to examine the Estimates, to report how, if at all, the policy implied in the
Estimates can be carried out more economically and to consider the principal
variations between the Estimates of the current year and those of the previous
year and the form in which the Estimates should be presented. Usually, the
committee selects each year a few Votes for review.
Through the medium of a number of sub-committees, the committee carries
out extensive investigations into the departments or subjects under considera¬
tion. In practice the Estimates for the current year are not affected, but the
committee’s recommendations produce changes in future Estimates and
strengthen Treasury control. One of these sub-committees examines the
winter and spring Supplementary Estimates and the principal variations
between the Estimates presented and those of the previous year. The other
sub-committees are organised on functional lines, each sub-committee being
362
THE BUDGET
Budget Policy
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
allocated a different sphere of government policy and administration. Addi¬
tional parliamentary time has been allocated for discussion of the reports of
the Estimates and the Public Accounts Committees.
‘Budget’ is an old word meaning a bag containing papers or accounts. The
use of the word in public finance originated in the expression ‘The Chancellor
of the Exchequer opened his Budget’, which is applied in Parliament to the
annual speech of the Chancellor of the Exchequer explaining his proposals for
balancing revenue and expenditure.
The annual Budget speech is normally the main occasion of the year for
reviewing the central Government’s finances and the economic state of the
nation, and its formal basis is the Chancellor’s proposals for raising money by
taxation. In recent years it has become the practice for Chancellors to discuss
in the Budget speech the prospects for the economy in the period ahead in
some detail. By the time the Budget is introduced (usually in April) the
Estimates of expenditure under various headings will have been presented to
Parliament and published, and the expected total of government expenditure
for the year will be known. The Chancellor estimates the yield of the revenue
on the basis of existing taxation and proposes such changes in taxation as he
considers desirable on economic grounds. These proposals are later embodied
in detail in a Finance Bill. The interval between the Budget Statement and the
Royal Assent to the Finance Bill (usually given in July) is covered by legisla¬
tion (mainly the Provisional Collection of Taxes Act 1968), whereby changes
in income tax, corporation tax, purchase tax, selective employment tax and
customs and excise duties have statutory effect before the passing of the
Finance Bill if adopted by Resolution of the House of Commons.
The Budget also takes into account the finance needed to cover government
lending. Details for the current year were given in a White Paper, Loans from
the National Loan Fund 1969-jo, issued on Budget day. For 1969-70 it is
estimated that rather more than half of the net issues from this Fund would
be loans to nationalised industries; just under one-third would be loans to
local authorities; and the remainder loans to public corporations, private
industry, and certain advances within the central Government.
The original purpose of the Budget was purely financial—to provide money
for government expenditure. From an early stage, however, it was appreciated
that taxation would affect the distribution of income and property and the
level of expenditure on particular goods and services. At a later period it was
realised that taxation also affected the nation’s total expenditure and therefore
the general level of economic activity. Since the second world war, Budgets
have been consciously designed in greater or lesser degree to bring the total
demand for goods and services into balance with total national output.
The Budget affects the general level of expenditure and, therefore, the total
demand for goods and services in the following way: if there is an increase in
government expenditure without an increase in taxation then total demand for
goods and services will tend to rise; the same thing will happen if there is a
decrease in taxation without a decrease in government spending. In this way
the Budget can be used to counter unemployment. On the other hand, if
there is an increase in taxation without an increase in government expenditure,
or a decrease in government expenditure without a decrease in taxation then
the total demand for goods and services will tend to fall. Particular taxes may
be used with the intention of bringing about certain desired effects. For
example, taxes on income and capital affect the distribution of wealth because
Sources of
Revenue
Income Tax
FINANCE 363
the rates vary according to the size of the income or capital, the proportion of
a high income or capital taken in tax being much greater than the proportion
of a small one; while taxes on expenditure may influence the allocation of
resources and the pattern of trade by discouraging or encouraging the con¬
sumption of particular goods.
The main objectives of British budgetary policy in recent years have been
the achievement and maintenance of a strong balance of payments together
with a high rate of economic growth and a high level of employment. In order
to regulate demand more closely, successive governments have adopted a
much more flexible attitude towards fiscal policy and have not hesitated to use
budgetary measures between annual Budgets. At the same time consideration
is given to the long-term strategy for taxation and to ways in which the
existing system of taxation can be improved by ensuring that its incidence
is fair and by closing loopholes. The Budgets of 1968 and 1969 were used to
reduce the level of domestic demand so as to obtain the maximum benefit
from the devaluation of the pound sterling in 1967.
In the United Kingdom the principal taxes fall into three main categories.
First, taxes on income, which include income tax, surtax and corporation tax;
second, taxes on capital, which include estate duty, capital gains tax and the
tax on short-term gains; and third, taxes on expenditure (including taxes
on the ownership or use of certain assets)—these include not only customs and
excise duties and the purchase tax, but also the selective employment tax (in
service and construction industries), local rates, stamp duties and licence duties
(for example, on motor vehicles and dogs). Taxes on individual (though not
corporate) incomes are progressive taxes, that is, larger incomes and estates
bear a proportionately higher rate of tax. The Board of Inland Revenue
collects the taxes on income and capital and the stamp duties, the Board of
Customs and Excise collects the most important taxes on expenditure, the
customs and excise taxes and the purchase tax, while a variety of authorities
are responsible for the collection of the remainder, including the Ministry of
Social Security for the selective employment tax.
Income tax is imposed at a standard rate for the year of assessment beginning
on 6th April, which is at present 41-25 per cent (8s. 3d. in the £). The tax
imposed on an individual is graduated by means of personal allowances and
reliefs, by a reduced rate of tax on the first section of taxable income1 and by
the surtax. In the case of a married couple the incomes of husband and wife are
aggregated and are treated as one income, but higher allowances are given
than for a single person. A special allowance is given against any earnings of
a married women. Earned income bears less tax than other income as certain
fractional deductions (‘earned income relief’) are allowable.
A single person earning £1,000 a year pays £186 in income tax, while a
married man with the same earned income pays £137; if he has two children
under the age of 11, his tax (after taking into account the receipt of family
allowances) falls to £75; when the children are between the ages of 11 and 16,
the tax is £60; if the children are over 16 and receiving full-time education,
only j£45 18 paid. The range of tax payable by a single person varies from, for
example, £40 on an earned income of £$00 a year to ^I>515 on an earned
income of £5,000; if the income is unearned, tax liability on £500 will be £53
and on £5,000 will be £2,441.
1 The balance of income remaining after deduction of the personal allowances and
reliefs is taxable income. For 1969-70 there is one reduced rate of 30 per cent (6s. in
the j0 on the first £260 of taxable income. The remainder is charged at the standard rate.

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Most wage and salary earners pay their income tax under a PAYE (‘Pay-as-
you-earn’) scheme, under which tax is deducted at source, thus enabling them
to keep up to date on tax payments.
In general, income tax is charged on all income which originates in the
United Kingdom and on all income arising abroad of persons (including
companies) resident in the United Kingdom. The main exceptions are that
interest on certain United Kingdom government securities belonging to
persons not ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom is exempt; and
income from certain classes of possessions abroad is chargeable not on the
amount of income arising but on the amount of income remitted to the United
Kingdom. The United Kingdom has entered into agreements with many
countries providing for relief from double taxation; where such agreements
are not in force unilateral relief is allowed.
The surtax, which is essentially an income tax at higher rates, is charged on
personal incomes exceeding £2,000 a year after deducting certain personal
allowances in excess of the single person’s basic allowance. In addition, the
same earned income relief as for income tax and a special earnings allowance
(not exceeding £2,000) are deductible from earned income only. Surtax is
imposed at rates which increase progressively until, on the portion of taxable
income above £15,000, the combined rate of income tax and surtax payable
in 1969-70 (being income tax for 1969-70 and surtax for 1968-69) reaches
91-25 per cent (18s. 3d. in the £).
Companies are liable to corporation tax on both their profits and their capital
gains. In addition, a company now deducts income tax from dividends and
other distributions and pays it over to the Inland Revenue as a separate matter
from its own liability. The rate of corporation tax is fixed retrospectively in the
Budget for the past financial year; for 1968-69 it is 45 per cent. The tax is
assessed on the profits of accounting periods, the rate of tax being the rate for
the financial year in which the accounting period falls. The basic rule for the
calculation of income for corporation tax purposes is that, except for special
provisions, it is computed in accordance with income tax principles.
Estate duty is chargeable on the value of all property which passes at death.
The charge to duty is not limited to property owned by the deceased but may
extend to other property, for example, to trust funds from which the deceased
received income in his lifetime and to gifts made by the deceased within
seven years of his death (one year in the case of a gift for public or charitable
purposes). Since the 1969 Budget estates not over £10,000 are exempt from
duty; but on estates of a higher value duty is chargeable by reference to rates
ranging from 25 per cent to 85 per cent applied to successive slices of the
estate.
Capital gains accruing on the disposal of assets are liable to capital gains tax
or, in the cases of companies, to corporation tax. Where assets were acquired
before 6th April 1965, the charge is restricted to the part of any gain attribut¬
able to the period since 6th April 1965. The rate of tax for persons other than
companies is 30 per cent, but in the case of individuals may be less, depending
on their circumstances. Certain assets are exempt from tax including the
principal private residence, chattels worth less than £1,000 (and any chattels,
except those used for the purpose of a trade, with a predictable life of less than
50 years), private motor cars, National savings certificates and (from 15th
April 1969) British Government and Government-guaranteed securities. The
gains of an individual for a year are exempt if, after deducting losses, they do
not exceed £50. Gains arising to individuals from the disposal of assets
Customs and
Excise Duties
Purchase Tax
Betting Duties
Motor Vehicle
Licence Taxes
Selective
Employment Tax
FINANCE 365
within 12 months of their acquisition are in general liable as short-term gains
to income tax (and surtax) and not to capital gains tax.
The largest group of taxes on expenditure are those administered by the
Customs and Excise Department, namely, the duties on tobacco, hydrocarbon
oil, alcoholic drinks, purchase tax, protective duties, betting and certain
miscellaneous items. In British usage the distinction between customs and
excise depends on whether the goods are imported (customs duties) or British
produced (excise duties). These taxes are sometimes known as indirect taxes
since they are normally paid by the importer, manufacturer, or wholesaler,
who adjusts the prices charged to customers accordingly. In 1969 the tax
burden was equivalent to about 4s. 6d. on a gallon of petrol, 4s. qd. on a
packet of 20 standard plain cigarettes, £2 4s. on a bottle of whisky, and nd. on
a pint of beer of average strength.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer has power to vary by Order by up to 10
per cent the rates of purchase tax and any of the other main groups of customs
and excise duties (that is, tobacco, alcoholic drinks, oil, and the minor revenue
duties). This power known as the ‘regulator’, requires annual renewal.
Purchase tax is charged on a wide range of goods, nearly all of them consumer
goods, at four rates, which are currently 13! per cent, 22 per cent, 36! per cent
and 55 per cent of the wholesale value. Articles subject to revenue duties of
customs and excise are in general exempt from this tax; other goods free
of purchase tax include food (other than confectionery, soft drinks, ice cream,
crisps and pet foods), fuel, books and newspapers, young children’s clothing
and footwear, certain non-proprietary drugs and medicines, and some house¬
hold appliances.
The principal betting duties are: the pool betting duty (which applies to
football pools and betting by coupon at fixed odds) charged at a rate of 33^ per
cent of the stake money; and the general betting duty, which is charged on
most other kinds of betting at the rate of 5 per cent of stake money. An annual
licence duty equivalent to three times the rateable value of the premises where
off-course betting is carried on was imposed in the 1969 Finance Act. Gaming
is taxed at different rates mainly by licence fees.
Taxes on motor vehicles are collected by the local taxation authorities (the
county or county borough councils in England and Wales and the correspond¬
ing councils in Scotland); the proceeds are paid by the local authorities into
the Exchequer. The licence duty on a private motor car is £25 a year; motor
cycles and three-wheel vehicles, etc., pay £2 10s., £5 or £10 a year according
to engine capacity.
The selective employment tax is designed, among other things, to encourage
economy in the use of labour in the service industries. It is paid by all employers
throughout the United Kingdom at a rate per week of 48s. for men, 24s. for
women and boys and 16s. for girls. Employers, however, are affected in
various ways. Employers in manufacturing industries in the development areas
receive a refund of tax and additional sums, made up of a selective employment
premium and a regional employment premium (see p. 254). Employers in
manufacturing industries not in the development areas and employers in
transport and communications, public service, including the nationalised
industries, agriculture, extractive industries and charities have the tax refunded
but receive no premium. Employers in service industries and construction pay
the tax without refund, but schemes have now been introduced for the refund
of the tax in respect of certain part-time and elderly workers, employees working
overseas and employees in hotels in certain rural parts of development areas.

After allowing for the Budget changes, total expenditure for the financial year
ending 31st March 1970 is estimated to reach £12,551 million, including £751
million for Consolidated Fund Standing Services and £11,800 million for
Supply Services. The estimate for total revenue is £15,008 million of which
£14,464 million is receipts from taxation. A surplus of £2,457 million for
transfer to the National Loans Fund is therefore expected. Net lending from
the National Loans Fund (see p. 360) is estimated to reach £1,631 million.
Thus in 1969-70, after special transactions, there is likely to be a net
repayment of debt by the central Government of some £826 million.

PUBLIC FINANCE

BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Capital expenditure consists chiefly of loans to the nationalised industries, the
local authorities and other public corporations, such as the New Towns
Development Corporations. These loans, less repayments, are financed
from the National Loans Fund by the surplus of revenue over expenditure
(if any), by the proceeds of government borrowing including borrowing
from extra-budgetary funds, such as the National Insurance Fund, and
by the sterling receipts (if any) accruing to the Exchange Equalisation
Account.
Exchequer borrowing may be in the form of borrowing from the public
either through the National Savings Movement (see p. 372) or by borrowing
on the market by means of new issues of securities. New issues of government
securities are made from time to time for the purpose of refinancing maturing
issues (conversion issues) or to raise new money (issues for cash). The
capital requirements of the nationalised industries are met by the central
Government while those of the local authorities are met partly through the
Public Works Loan Board (see p. 73) and partly by borrowing direct from
the public, although both may also now borrow, with Treasury consent, in
foreign currencies.
The National Debt increased particularly rapidly during and immediately
after the first and second world wars. It rose from £650 million in 1914 to
£7,435 million at the end of the first world war, and from £7,131 million in
I939 t0 £23>637 million in 1946. On 31st March 1969 the total National Debt
(provisional) was £33,991 million, of which £2,253 million was repayable
in currencies other than sterling, mainly to the United States and Canadian
Governments. Of the £31,738 million of internal debt, £6,078 million was
short-term debt, mainly in the form of 91-day Treasury bills, while the long¬
term loans included a variety of stocks, bonds, loans, and certificates carrying
fixed rates of interest (ranging from 2^ to 8f per cent) and with fixed or
indeterminate dates of repayment.
The general system of public finance in Northern Ireland is, in its main
features, similar to that operating in the United Kingdom as a whole, under
which public revenues, with a few minor exceptions, are paid into the
Exchequer Account, from which no money can be withdrawn except on the
authority of Parliament. That authority is expressed in the case of Consolidated
Fund charges in permanent legislative form, and in the case of Supply Services
by annual Appropriation Acts based on estimates prepared by departments
and sanctioned by the Ministry of Finance.
The major sources of revenue flowing into the Northern Ireland Exchequer
are the main national taxes imposed by the United Kingdom Parliament over
the whole country and paid, in the first instance, into the United Kingdom
Consolidated Fund. These taxes, which are referred to in the Government of
Ireland Act 1920 as ‘reserved’ taxes (that is, reserved to the United Kingdom
Parliament), comprise the Inland Revenue group (income tax, surtax,
corporation tax and capital gains tax) and customs and excise duties on goods.
After the cost of collecting these taxes in Northern Ireland (and the cost of
some other reserved services) and an Imperial Contribution have been
retained in the United Kingdom Consolidated Fund, the balance, termed the
‘Residuary Share of Reserved Taxes’, is paid to the Northern Ireland Ex¬
chequer where it joins up with the ‘transferred’ taxes (that is, where taxation
powers have been transferred to the Northern Ireland Parliament) to form the
public income. Among items of Transferred Tax Revenue are estate duties,
lie Bank of
Ingland
FINANCE 369
stamp duties, betting duties, various excise licence duties, motor vehicle
duties and selective employment tax.
A joint Exchequer Board, representative of the Treasury and the Ministry
of Finance for Northern Ireland, constituted in accordance with the Govern¬
ment of Ireland Act 1920, determines the amount of Reserved Revenue and
the cost of Reserved Services attributable to Northern Ireland for each year,
the amount of the Imperial Contribution, and such other questions affecting
the financial relations of the two Governments as may be referred to it.
In the Northern Ireland Budget for 1969-70 (year ending 31st March),
total revenues were forecast at ^339 million and expenditure at £337 million.
After allowing for the Imperial Contribution, provisionally estimated at £2
million, there was a Budget surplus of £67,380.
The Public Debt of Northern Ireland, totalling £281 million on 31st
March 1969, is covered by repayable advances and investments held by the
Ministry of Finance.
Outside the Exchequer system in Northern Ireland, various funds have been
established, in addition to statutory Reserve and Sinking Funds, for specific
purposes. In general, these funds follow the United Kingdom pattern, the
principal funds being those relating to National Insurance and government
loans. The latter constitutes a pool of capital money available mainly for local
and public authority borrowings; on 31st March 1969, a sum of approximately
£222 million was outstanding against such borrowers.
BANKING AND PRIVATE FINANCE
The British banking system is long established and well integrated. It
comprises a central bank; commercial banks which carry on the usual main
banking services; the United Kingdom offices of banks whose main business
is in other countries; merchant banks and other specialised institutions.
The Bank of England was established in 1694 by Act of Parliament and Royal
Charter as a corporate body; the entire capital stock was acquired by the
Government under the Bank of England Act 1946.
As the central bank, the Bank acts as banker to the Government, to
overseas central banks and to commercial banks; it is the note-issuing
authority and the registrar for some 200 government, nationalised industry,
local authority, public board and Commonwealth government stocks. As
agent for the Government the Bank administers exchange control and the
voluntary arrangements to limit investment in the more developed countries
of the sterling area. On behalf of the Treasury it manages the Exchange
Equalisation Account (EEA), which holds Britain’s official reserves of gold
and foreign exchange; using the resources of the EEA the Bank designs its
interventions in the foreign exchange market both to prevent undue fluctua¬
tions in the exchange value of sterling and to conserve the means of making
payments abroad.
As banker to the Government in the widest sense, among other things,
the Bank examines and seeks to anticipate banking and financial problems
and to undertake the appropriate operations in the money, capital and the
foreign exchange markets; consequently the Bank has a major responsibility
for advising the Government on the formulation of monetary policy and for
its subsequent execution.
The
Deposit
Baraks
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
In implementing monetary policy the Bank acts almost daily in the money
market, by buying or selling Treasury bills, and similarly in the market for
government stocks. A prime concern is to maintain orderly conditions and,
when necessary, the Bank also exerts influence on interest rates; an important
instrument in this context is Bank Rate, which is the minimum rate at which
the Bank will discount approved bills of exchange for the members of the
London Discount Market or will normally lend to them; virtually all other
short-term interest rates are related to it.
As the recognised channel of communication between the commercial
banks and other financial institutions of the City of London on the one hand,
and the Government on the other, the Bank has been called on in recent
years to administer direct control of credit. This has been achieved by means
of ‘special deposits’ which the London clearing banks and Scottish banks are
called upon to make with the Bank; through requests to the banks and other
financial institutions not to extend credit beyond stipulated quantitative
ceilings; and by general guidance to them on lending policy.
The Bank of England has the sole right in England and Wales of issuing
bank notes. Notes thus issued need a 100 per cent cover in gold, securities
and coin. Very little gold is now held by the Issue Department of the Bank,
by far the major part of the note issue being covered by securities and coin;
this part is the fiduciary issue, the level of which is subject to parliamentary
control. (The Scottish and Northern Ireland banks have limited rights to
issue notes; these issues, apart from an amount specified by legislation for
each bank, must be fully covered by Bank of England notes and by coin.)
The provision of coin for circulation is the responsibility of the Royal Mint,
a government department.
The primary business of the deposit banks is the receipt, transfer and
encashment of deposits. The principal deposit banks are the 11 London
clearing banks, 4 Scottish banks and 3 Northern Ireland banks. Recent
mergers have resulted in the formation of six banking groups, four based in
London and two in Scotland. When they have been completed there will be
only six London clearing banks and three Scottish banks. The three Northern
Ireland banks are owned by London clearing banks, but two groups of banks
based in the Republic of Ireland also operate in Northern Ireland.
At the end of 1968 current and deposit accounts with the deposit banks
operating in Britain amounted to over £11,600 million, and accounted for
just over half of the total deposits of the banking sector, which also includes
the National Giro, the accepting houses, overseas banks, other banks and the
discount market. The deposit banks provide full banking services throughout
Britain, operating through over 14,000 branches at the end of 1968; several
have interests in British overseas and Commonwealth banks, and in other
banks which have been formed specially to compete in international markets.
They have also acquired substantial interests in hire-purchase finance houses,
and some have set up their own unit trusts.
Together with the Bank of England the London clearing banks make up
the membership of the London Bankers’ Clearing House. In 1968 cheques,
drafts, bills and bankers’ effects passing through the clearing system averaged
in value £50,021 million monthly, while the average monthly value of the
credit transfer clearing was £970 million.
Current account balances with the deposit banks are repayable on demand
and no interest is paid on them, but on deposit account balances interest is
paid at a rate generally 2 per cent below Bank Rate. The London clearing
FINANCE

The Merchant

banks maintain a ratio of about 8 per cent between cash reserves and total
deposits. It is also a convention among the London clearing banks that at
least 28 per cent of deposits should be held in the form of liquid assets.
The banks’ profits are largely earned through their advances to customers
partly in the form of overdrafts and partly in the form of loans (with or
without collateral security); these are normally for a short term only unless
renewed. The ratio of London clearing bank advances to total deposits
declined from about 43 per cent in 1938 to 17 per cent at the end of the
second world war but it has since risen and in June 1969 it was around 50 per
cent. In recent years the banks have several times been asked to restrain the
growth of their lending and to ensure that, within the total, priority is given
to finance for exports and for productive investment in manufacturing industry
and agriculture: this has involved the restriction of advances to the personal
sector. (In November 1968 they were asked to reduce their advances by
2 per cent of the level of November 1967.) The banks’ ‘liquid’ assets, that is,
those that are quickly realisable, are their loans to discount houses (money
at call), and their holdings of Treasury and commercial bills and certain export
and shipbuilding credits refinanceable with the Bank of England: they also
hold a proportion of their assets as portfolio (mainly British Government
securities) or trade investments.
The bank giro, originally introduced as the credit transfer scheme, and the
direct debiting system, by which a creditor with the prior approval of the
debtor may claim money due to him direct from the latter’s banking account,
have helped to improve the money transmission services. Another fairly
recent banking innovation has been the introduction by some banks of
automatic cash dispensing machines, which allow customers to obtain cash
at any time. Credit cards have become increasingly popular for the settlement
of accounts in retail shops.
There are also some 35 British overseas and Commonwealth banks, many of
them having their headquarters in London. They provide a comprehensive
banking service in many parts of the world and engage in the financing of
trade not only between Britain and other countries but also between third
countries. There are also currently in London about 25 United States banks,
10 Japanese banks and over 50 other foreign banks.
The National Giro came into operation in October 1968. It provides a postal
cheque service for all customers with a current account, but no overdraft
facilities. Payments and withdrawals may be made through any post office in
Britain, but the records of all transactions and all the accounts are maintained
at a single central office at Bootle, near Liverpool.
The merchant banks have helped to give London an international reputation
as a world financial centre for short-term and long-term borrowing. They
are of two kinds, and are known as accepting houses and issuing houses
according to whether they specialise predominantly in the work of acceptance
credit1 or in transactions involving the sponsoring of capital issues on behalf
of their customers. They arrange to issue and themselves underwrite long-
and short-term loans to governments of, or enterprises in, overseas countries
1 Acceptance credit has been defined as fundamentally a three-month operation
financing exports from and imports to Britain and to other markets. The expression is
derived from the method of financing trade by which commercial bills are ‘accepted’
or guaranteed by a merchant bank against documents, after which they may be
discounted for cash by a discount house.
372 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
in sterling (where permitted by exchange control regulations) or in other
currencies which have been deposited with them; this latter type of transac¬
tion, in what are called the euro-dollar markets, has increased considerably in
recent years. They are also engaged in the work of the gold and foreign
exchange markets, and they have many other functions in connection with the
financing of trade, investment management, and insurance.
The Discount The London discount or money market is a distinctive part of the British
Market banking system. It consists of 12 discount houses and its principal function
is to marry the needs of lenders of money for short periods with those of the
borrowers of such money.
The discount houses borrow ‘at call’ from banks and other financial
institutions at a relatively low rate of interest. To them the Bank of England
acts as a lender of last resort. The clearing banks do not borrow money
directly from the Bank of England; if they need to add to their cash resources
they call in part of their loans to the discount market. If, as a result, any
particular discount house is unable to cover its needs for cash elsewhere, it is
obliged to borrow from the Bank of England, normally at Bank Rate for
seven days, but the Bank may charge a higher rate and has also at times lent
overnight, or for short periods, at the rates of interest prevailing in the
market.
An important part of the money borrowed by the discount houses is
invested in British Government Treasury bills. The discount houses accept as
an informal responsibility that they should cover the Government’s need to
borrow on Treasury bills, which are offered on tender each week. The
clearing banks do not buy Treasury bills at the weekly tenders except on
behalf of customers, but they purchase, from the discount market, bills which
are of a maturity required by them.
The discount houses provide a specialised market in commercial bills and
in short-dated Government bonds (that is, those with not more than five years
to run before repayment), local authority bonds, and certain other negotiable
instruments.

Savings
Movement
National Savings
Securities
The National Savings Movement started in 1916 to help finance the war by
promoting savings. The present movement encourages the widespread
investment of savings in Trustee Savings Banks and the National Savings
Bank (see p. 374), formerly known as the Post Office Savings Bank, and in
National Savings securities. The movement is led by the National Savings
Committee for England and Wales and similar committees for Scotland and
Northern Ireland.1 The committees are bodies of independent persons
representing regional savings organisations and various national institutions
connected with such matters as finance, industry and education. They are
assisted by a salaried staff of civil servants. Voluntary local savings com¬
mittees, often assisted or promoted by local authorities, co-ordinate the work
of voluntary local savings groups.
The administration of the National Savings Bank and all forms of national
savings is carried out by the Department for National Savings. Three forms
of National Savings securities are currently on sale: the National Savings
1 The Northern Ireland Ministry of Finance is responsible for the administration of
Ulster Savings, but the furtherance and organisation of the savings movement in
Northern Ireland is the concern of a central voluntary committee, which is voluntarily
assisted by county and local committees and district groups.

National Savings Certificates, in units of j£i, are encashable at par at any
time; interest, which is free of income tax and surtax, is only paid on encash¬
ment; the limit on individual holdings is 1,500 units of the current issue.
British Savings Bonds, sold in units of £5 with a maximum holding of
£10,000, bear interest at 7 per cent and are repayable at par on one month’s
notice. Premium Savings Bonds are in units of £1 and individual holdings
are limited to £1,250. After a qualifying period of three months the bonds
give investors a chance to win tax-free prizes instead of receiving interest.
There is now a weekly draw for a prize of £25,000 and a monthly draw for
prizes ranging from £25 to £5,000. At the end of June 1969, £726 million
was invested in this form of savings. Nearly all British Government securities
are held on the Post Office Register and can also be bought or sold at most
post offices.
A contractual savings scheme was announced in the 1969 Budget for
introduction in October 1969. Known as ‘Save as You Earn’ (SAYE), it
enables savings to be made in regular monthly amounts within a minimum
of £1 and a maximum of £10 in deposits with the Department for National
Savings by means of deductions from pay or by other regular payments. At
the end of five years, savings will qualify for a bonus equivalent to one year’s
savings free of tax. Completed savings which are not withdrawn will qualify
for a double bonus at the end of seven years, that is, two years’ savings.
For example, contributions totalling £60 payable over five years at a rate of
£1 per month will qualify for a bonus of £12 at the end of that period, or
£24 if left on deposit for a further two years. Savers who wish to stop pay¬
ments will be able to withdraw the total sum saved (but there cannot be
partial withdrawals). Tax-free compound interest will be paid at the rate of
2^ per cent on amounts withdrawn after the first but before the end of the
fifth year, or at 4^ per cent where the contributions cease but the savings
are left invested for the remainder of the five years or where the saver dies
1 These bonds, which were introduced in 1968, are similar to the earlier National
Development Bonds and the Defence Bonds.

before the contributions are completed. A ‘Save as You Earn’ scheme (with
the same ^10 limit) will be operated by the trustee savings banks and a
similar but separate scheme will be operated by building societies.
The National Savings Bank, formerly known as the Post Office Savings Bank
which was set up in 1861, is the largest organisation of its kind in the world.
It provides a countrywide system for depositing and withdrawing small
savings and has over 23 million active accounts. Ordinary Accounts bear
interest at 2^ per cent and the first £15 of interest is tax-free. Up to £10 can
be withdrawn on demand at any post office, but a few days’ notice is required
for larger amounts. The moneys are lodged with the National Debt Office
and are invested in government securities. Deposits up to a limit of £10,000
bearing a higher rate of interest may be made in Investment Accounts where
investors have a qualifying deposit of £50 in an Ordinary Account. All
deposits carry a government guarantee; in June 1969 they totalled £1,770
million.
The Trustee Savings Banks, many of which also started in the nineteenth
century, operate under their own trustees but are subject to statutory provi¬
sions and National Debt Office surveillance. There are 77 individual banks
with 1,427 Trustee Offices and over 12 million accounts. Deposits can be
made either in the Ordinary Departments, the Special Investment Depart¬
ments or the Current Account Departments. The terms for deposits in the
Ordinary Departments are similar to those in the National Savings Bank.
Withdrawals can usually be made on demand though notice is required for
large sums. Deposits are invested with the National Debt Commissioners and
both capital and interest are guaranteed by the Government. The Special
Investment Departments offer a higher rate of return, which is taxable.
Deposits are limited to £10,000, but are not government guaranteed. At
the end of June 1969 total sums in the Ordinary Departments of the Trustee
Savings Banks were £1,070 million and in the Special Investment Depart-
ments £1,349 million. Most Trustee Savings Banks operate cheque services
on deposits in the Current Account Departments. In January 1968 the
Trustee Savings Banks set up their own unit trust (see p. 376).
At end-June 1969 National Savings totalled £8,546 million, about a
quarter of the National Debt. The diagram on p. 373 shows the distribution
of National Savings between the different outlets in 1958 and 1968.
The Co-operative Wholesale Society formed a deposit and loan department
about the year 1870, and the right of a co-operative society to engage in
banking was recognised in the Industrial and Provident Societies Act of 1876.
The primary purpose of the Co-operative Wholesale Society Bank was to
serve the co-operative movement, whose financial centre it has become, but
its clients include trade unions and other mutual societies, local authorities
and individual depositors. The bank’s headquarters are in Manchester. The
Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society, which has its headquarters in
Glasgow, has similarly engaged in banking since 1948.
It has been the policy of the commercial banks to leave the provision of many
special financial facilities to other financial institutions. These facilities,
which are supplementary to the credit facilities of the banking system, are
mainly provided through the savings banks, finance corporations, hire-
purchase finance companies, the stock exchanges, investment trusts, building
societies and the insurance market. The firms engaged in such activities are

in the main highly specialised, for example, discount and other finance houses,
