Two corporations, the Finance Corporation for Industry Limited (FCI) and
the Industrial and Commercial Finance Corporation Limited (ICFC), were
set up in 1945 to assist in dealing with the problems of post-war reconstruction
and development. The corporations are ordinary limited companies with no
official representation on their boards and having no recourse to public funds.
Another corporation, the Commonwealth Development Finance Company
Limited (CDFC), was established in 1953 to assist development projects in
the Commonwealth. Among other financial corporations are the Agricultural
Mortgage Corporation Limited and the Scottish Agricultural Securities
Corporation Limited.
The FCI was formed to assist in the provision of capital (in amounts of
£200,000 and upwards) for the re-equipment and development of industry.
The FCI has an authorised and issued capital of £25 million and may
borrow up to four times this amount, making a possible total of resources of
j£i25 million. The share capital is held as follows: 40 per cent by insurance
companies, 30 per cent by investment trust companies and 30 per cent by the
Bank of England. At 31st March 1969 the capital called and paid up was
10 per cent (£2-5 million); the Bank of England paid £5 million in advance
of call in 1959. The liability of the shareholders in respect of the uncalled
capital represents security to the banks providing loans for the corporation’s
working capital. The value of its investments at that date was £38-4 million.
The ICFC has as its main object the provision of credit and finance by means
of loan and share capital for small and medium-sized industrial and commer¬
cial concerns in Great Britain, particularly in cases where the existing
facilities provided by banking institutions and the Stock Exchange are not
readily or easily available. It has a number of subsidiaries including Technical
Development Capital Ltd. and others which own ships which are chartered
to responsible shipowners.
The authorised and issued share capital of the ICFC at 31st March 1969
was £40 million fully paid up. In addition, public debenture issues have been
made to a total of £yo million. The current resources of the ICFC group,
including reserves shown in the balance sheet, total about £144 million.
The Commonwealth Development Finance Company is a private enterprise
institution. Established in 1953, CDFC is not now necessarily confined to the
Commonwealth. It aims to support business enterprise overseas by providing
finance in the form of share capital and loans on mutually acceptable terms.
Its authorised share capital is .£30 million, of which about 14J million ‘A’
ordinary shares of £1 (2s. paid) are held by industrial, shipping, mining and
banking interests in the United Kingdom, and nf million ‘B’ ordinary shares
of £1 (10s. paid) are held by the Bank of England and certain central banks
in the Commonwealth. Up to the end of March 1969 CDFC had investments
in nearly 100 undertakings. They were spread over a wide range of industry
in 27 countries and had a book value of £28 million.
There are 8 stock exchanges in the British Isles. In addition the Provincial
Brokers’ Stock Exchange operates in no cities and towns throughout Britain
and the Irish Republic. The Federation of Stock Exchanges in Great
Britain and Ireland, comprising with one exception all these organisations,
N
376 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
was set up in July 1965 to co-ordinate their work. Four Scottish stock
exchanges are linked, as are also those in the north of England and in the
Midlands and west of England.
The London Stock Exchange is by far the most important of these stock
exchanges and is one of the world’s two foremost free markets in securities.
Some 9,000 securities are quoted on the London Stock Exchange; at the
end of March 1969 these had a total market value of £131,679 million. About
8,100 securities of companies are quoted, including a number of leading over¬
seas companies. Companies issues represented 45 per cent of the securities at
nominal values, and the remainder were British and overseas government and
corporation stocks; at market values the proportion was over four-fifths.
The London Stock Exchange is linked by cable or telephone with stock
exchanges all over the world. Therefore, a quoted company, subject to any
limitations imposed by the exchange control regulations, has a world-wide
market for its issues. This is an important factor in the raising of new capital
by government and commercial borrowers. Arbitrage transactions by brokers
—the buying or selling of a particular security on one stock exchange with the
intention of reversing it on another—play an important part in equating
price differentials between different markets and maintaining a continual
flow of business between centres.
The stock exchanges do not fix dealing prices; the terms on which bargains
are made between members reflect the interaction of supply and demand
for the securities concerned. All the stock exchanges operate under strict
rules of conduct which they formulate themselves.
In recent years there has been a constantly rising demand, except for short
periods, for ordinary (equity) shares, partly in expectation that such shares
will maintain their real value or grow in value in periods of rising prices.
Insurance companies and pension funds invest a larger proportion than
formerly of their assets in these shares, and the Trustee Investments Act 1961
permits trustees, under certain conditions, to invest up to half the funds they
hold in trust in equity shares.
The ownership of securities on the London Stock Exchange is much more
widespread than formerly: it is estimated that there are about 2% million
shareholders in the United Kingdom and that their shareholdings are widely
distributed. The largest public company in Britain has nearly 600,000
shareholders and there are several others with more than 100,000.
Investment Through investment trusts and unit trusts, investors may spread their risks
Trusts and and obtain the benefit of skilled management.
Unit Trusts The ordinary type of investment trust is constituted as a public company
registered under the Companies Acts with limited liability; its business is
to invest its capital in a range of stocks and shares. Like other companies,
it may issue several types of stocks or shares and may retain part of its profits
to build up reserves. Investment trusts grew to importance in the latter half
of the nineteenth century and have been prominent in directing capital
towards overseas investment.
Unit trusts are constituted by trust deed between a management company
and a trustee company which holds the securities. Normally, the managers
sell units to the public and invest the proceeds in a fairly wide range of
Stock Exchange securities. The costs of running the trust are defrayed partly
by an initial charge which forms part of the price of a unit, and partly by a
semi-annual service charge which is taken usually out of the income of the
trust. The level of both charges is controlled by the Board of Trade, whose
FINANCE
377
authorisation is required before units can be offered to the public; this is
only granted if the trust deed is satisfactory to them.
The first British unit trust was formed in 1931 and by 1939 there were
98 trusts, with assets estimated at £80 million. This medium of saving
has grown considerably since 1957. At the end of June 1969 there were nearly
2 million unit holdings. The value of the funds invested in authorised trusts,
numbering some 180, has risen from £60 million in 1958 to £1,315 million
in June 1969; it has more than doubled since the end of 1966. There are now
a wide variety of trusts, both as to the range of investments covered and the
ways in which they cater for the differing needs of investors.
The Insurance
Market
Insurance
Companies
Lloyd's
Although a certain amount of insurance is provided by friendly societies and
trade unions, most insurance services in Britain are in the hands of either
mutual or joint stock companies or Lloyd’s underwriters.
Table 28 shows the distribution of business in terms of net premium
income in 1967, the latest year for which figures are available.
There are about 400 insurance companies incorporated in the United Kingdom
but most of the business is in the hands of about 100 companies. Most
British insurers write several of the main classes of business although some
specialise in one class, particularly in life assurance, where about 60 companies
write only that type of business. A few specialise in re-insurance.
In addition about 170 overseas companies carry on business (and even more
companies are represented) in the United Kingdom, thus emphasising the
international nature of the London market. Some of the large British com¬
panies, however, have their administrative headquarters in the provinces.
In 1968 the total insurance funds of the British insurance companies and
collecting societies amounted to about £13,000 million, the bulk of which is in
respect of life assurance business. The accumulation of life funds has
increased greatly with the growth of group pension schemes.
There is no government control over the investment policy of insurance
funds at home and these represent one of the most important sources of funds
for investment in commerce and industry. Almost a half of the total assets
of British insurance companies is now invested in equity shares and debentures.
Lloyd’s is an incorporated society of private insurers in London. The name
‘Lloyd’s’ is derived from Edward Lloyd’s coffee house, established in the late

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
seventeenth century, where merchants with maritime and other interests
gathered to transact business. By the middle of the eighteenth century,
Lloyd’s coffee house had become the principal centre of underwriting business
and intelligence of shipping movements. Although in its earlier history
the activities of Lloyd’s were confined to the conduct of marine insurance
business, there has also been built up at Lloyd’s a very considerable world¬
wide market for the transaction of other classes of insurance business in its
non-marine, aviation and motor markets.
Lloyd’s is now regulated by a series of special Acts of Parliament starting
in 1871; the affairs of the Society of Lloyd’s in its corporate capacity are
administered by the Committee of Lloyd’s, which does not itself transact
insurance business.
Lloyd’s is not a company but a market for insurance, where business
is transacted by individual underwriters for their own account and risk and
in competition with each other. Insurance may only be placed through
Lloyd’s brokers, who negotiate with Lloyd’s underwriters on behalf of the
insured. Only elected underwriting members of Lloyd’s, who must transact
insurance with unlimited liability and who have met the most stringent
financial regulations laid down by the Committee of Lloyd’s, are permitted to
transact business at Lloyd’s; these financial safeguards give a security behind
the Lloyd’s policy which is second to none. Since 1968 non-Commonwealth
underwriters have been admitted to membership of Lloyd’s, if they satisfy
the requirements.
Today there are over 6,000 underwriting members of Lloyd’s grouped into
some 300 syndicates and represented at Lloyd’s by underwriting agents who
accept risks on behalf of the members of their syndicates.
In conjunction with its marine insurance business Lloyd’s has built up a
world-wide organisation for the collection and diffusion of shipping
intelligence.
The insurance market is completed by the insurance brokers, acting on
behalf of the insured; brokers are an essential part of the Lloyd’s market and
a valuable part of the company market. Many brokers specialise in re-insurance
business, acting as intermediaries in the exchange of contracts between
companies, both British and overseas, and often acting as London repre¬
sentatives of the latter.
Over two-thirds of the fire, accident and marine insurance business is
carried on overseas, partly by re-insurance on the London market and partly
through branches and agencies established in over 100 countries. The basic
principle of this international business is that resources capable of meeting
any potential loss are instantly available for use in any part of the world.
Behind this large and international volume of business stand the very
substantial assets of the companies, in addition to substantial reserves of
uncalled capital, and the whole of the deposits, underwriting trust funds and
personal fortunes of Lloyd’s underwriters.
The principal function of building societies is to supply long-term loans on
the security of private dwelling-houses purchased for owner-occupation,
though loans are occasionally made on the security of commercial and
industrial premises and farms. The funds of building societies are derived
mainly from the general public who invest in shares or deposits. The amount
of share capital is not fixed; shares, which have a fixed value, are not dealt
with on the Stock Exchange but may be withdrawn in cash if notice is given.
FINANCE
379
The Building Societies Act 1962, which consolidated a number of earlier Acts,
prescribes the general way in which societies must conduct their business.
The Chief Registrar of Friendly Societies has discretionary powers to stop
a society either advertising or accepting money from investors if he considers
that the way in which the society’s business is conducted is jeopardising
investors’ money. The rapid expansion of building society activity in the
twentieth century has been accompanied by a concentration of most of
the business in the hands of a few large societies. At the end of 1968,
525 societies were in operation, with total assets of £8,298 million. Seven of
the largest societies, however, each with assets of over £250 million, account
for w ell over half of the total funds. The amount advanced on mortgage in
1968 wras £1,590 million.

OVERSEAS TRADE
Although relatively small in area and accounting for less than 2 per cent of
the world’s population, the United Kingdom is the world’s third largest
trading nation, conducting about 11 per cent of international trade in manu¬
factured goods in 1968.
For well over a century international trade has been of vital importance to
Britain’s economy. Britain relies upon imports for about half its total con¬
sumption of foodstuffs and nearly all the raw materials needed for its industries.
Its exports of goods and services together represent about a fifth of the gross
national product. It is a major supplier of machinery, vehicles, aircraft, metal
manufactures, electrical apparatus, chemicals and textiles. It is the world’s
largest market for foodstuffs, and among the largest for metals and ores,
textile raw materials, petroleum and many other products.
Changes in value, volume, composition and geographical distribution of
imports and exports are outlined in the following paragraphs.
The value of imports (including cost, insurance and freight) during the 1950s
fluctuated between £3,000 million and £4,000 million a year. Since i960
imports have risen in all years except 1961 and 1962. There was a particularly
rapid expansion in 1964 (of 14 per cent) and again in 1968 (of 21 per cent),
when they were valued at £7,754 million (excluding purchases of US military
aircraft, see note “ to Table 29). The increase in exports (valued free-on-board)
during the 1950s and 1960s has been at a steadier rate, increasing at an
average annual rate of 5 per cent from the i960 total of £3,648 million until
1968, when they rose by 23 per cent over the previous year, to reach £6,176
million.
Between 1961 and 1968 the volume of exports rose by 36 per cent and
that of imports by 43 per cent. Since 1956 the terms of trade, that is, the ratio
between the general level of export prices and that of import prices, has
tended to move progressively in Britain’s favour except for a small adverse
movement in 1963 and 1964, and a slightly larger one in 1968.
The value and volume of exports and imports in selected years from 1959
to 1968 are shown in Table 29.
The expansion of domestic agricultural production has reduced Britain’s
dependence on imported food supplies and the proportion of imported food¬
stuffs to total imports has fallen from 39 per cent in 1954 to 24 per cent in
1968 when imports of foodstuffs (including beverages and tobacco) were
£1,904 million. There has been a similar downward trend in the proportion
accounted for by basic materials—from 30 per cent in 1954 to 15 per cent in
1968. This reflects a growing economy in industrialised countries in materials
consumption per unit of output, with the gradual switch from the pro¬
duction of goods with a high material content to those with a relatively low
material content plus the increasing use of synthetic materials.

Imports of crude petroleum and lubricants are by far the biggest single
item by value among Britain’s imports: they have accounted for about 11 per
cent of the total value of imports during the past ten years, and amounted to
£905 million in 1968.
The most marked change in recent years has been the rise in the proportion
of imports of finished manufactures, from nearly 7 per cent of total imports in
1957 to 21 per cent in 1968. Strong growth in these imports is a common
feature in the trade of industrial countries. Most of the rise in recent years
has been in capital goods which account for nearly three-quarters of the
value of imports of finished manufactures. Imports of semi-manufactures
have also been increasing steadily and since 1962 have accounted for a
greater proportion of the total import bill than basic materials. This trend is
due partly to the tendency for countries producing the basic materials to
embark upon the subsequent stages of manufacture themselves. Imports of
semi-manufactured (excluding chemicals) and manufactured goods amounted
to £1,705 million and £1,653 million respectively in 1968, accounting for
22 per cent and 21 per cent of Britain’s total imports.
More than five-sixths of Britain’s exports consist of manufactured goods.
By far the most important group are engineering products, which in 1968
accounted for 44 per cent of total exports. Within this group, exports of many
types of machinery, electrical equipment, road vehicles, tractors and scientific
instruments have expanded markedly over this period. The share represented
by chemicals has grown fairly steadily, reaching 9-7 per cent of total exports in

The growth of trade between Britain and Western Europe has been a notable
feature of the area distribution of trade in recent years, and conversely there
has been a decline in the proportion of Britain’s exports going to primary
producing countries. In 1958, 27 per cent of exports went to Western Europe,
but in 1962, for the first time, these exports began to exceed those to the
sterling area and by 1968 they formed 37 per cent of the total (a fall 1 per¬
centage point over the previous year). Exports to Western Europe increased
by 19 per cent in 1968, compared with a o-6 per cent increase in 1967. Exports
to the European Economic Community (EEC) increased by 24 per cent in
1968, compared with 0-7 per cent in 1967, and to the European Free Trade
Association (EFTA) they increased by 13 per cent compared with 3 per cent
in 1967. Both rates of increase were significantly higher than the average over
the past decade.

Imports from Western Europe increased by 24 per cent in 1968, almost
twice the increase in 1967, and formed 37 per cent of total imports.
Relatively, trade with other members of the Commonwealth and with the
sterling area as a whole has tended to decline. Exports to the sterling area
increased by 15 per cent in 1968 but as a proportion of total exports dropped
to 28 per cent, compared with 30 per cent in 1967 and with 43 per cent in 1958.

There has been a similar relative fall in respect of imports, although these
recorded an increase of 28 per cent in 1968. Canada, Australia, South Africa
and the Republic of Ireland, however, are among Britain’s most important
trading partners. The United States has been both Britain’s largest single
market and source of supply since 1957. The proportion of total exports going
to North America in 1968 was 18 per cent, the highest ever, and reflected an
increase in the value of deliveries of 37 per cent in 1968 over 1967. Exports
to Latin America increased by 35 per cent in 1968 compared with 5 per cent
in 1967- Britain’s trade with the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe has been
growing rapidly over the past decade though it is still small in relation to
trade with other parts of the world. Exports to the Soviet Union rose by
61 per cent in 1968. Trade with Japan continues to grow, with increases of
15 per cent in exports and 26 per cent in imports in 1968.
Re-exports are goods which are exported (1) in the condition in which they
were imported or (2) after having undergone minor operations—such as
simple blending, cleaning, husking, repacking—which leaves them essentially
unchanged. Traditionally, the greater part of United Kingdom re-export trade
has been in raw materials and foodstuffs, for example, wool, rubber, tea, non-
ferrous metals and fur-skins. Commodities imported from Commonwealth
countries and sent on to countries in Europe, particularly traditional re-exports
such as tea and wool, account for a considerable proportion of the total value.
In recent years a considerable re-export trade has developed in manufactured
goods, part of which is accounted for by machinery, for example, aircraft and
aero-engines which have been repaired or have been overhauled in the United
Kingdom.
In 1968 the value of re-exports was £218 million, easily the highest annual
total. The principal items were: fur-skins, non-ferrous metals, electrical
and other machinery and tea. Over half of the re-exports went to countries in
Western Europe.
As previously mentioned, the United Kingdom has traditionally imported
more goods than it exports; however, the gap has been covered in the long¬
term by net earnings from ‘invisible’ transactions. These are defined as
earnings from the provision of services to overseas persons or from the
ownership of overseas assets.
Invisible transactions are divided for statistical purposes into six main
groups: government, transport (shipping and civil aviation); travel; other
services (which covers a variety of items including royalties, films and tele¬
vision transactions, financial services, and other commercial and miscellaneous
services); interest, profits and dividends; and private transfers (migrants’
funds, legacies and private gifts). Some of these figures are precise (for
instance, for government transactions), others are estimates. Table 31 shows
the breakdown of the figures from 1963 to 1968. The total invisible balance
in 1968 was a record ^412 million (in the previous five years the annual surplus
averaged £190 million). Excluding government transactions, the net balance
on private transactions was a surplus of £874 million. Private invisible receipts
in 1968 rose to ^3,653 million (second only to the United States). Earnings
from invisibles amounted to slightly more than half the total from visible
exports.
As shown in Table 31, in recent years there has been a considerable net
surplus on ‘other services’ and on interest, profits and dividends. Over half
of Britain’s receipts under this heading comes from investments in the sterling
area. There has also been a surplus on civil aviation services. Shipping

transactions have been moving into surplus since 1966. Travel credits exceeded
debits for the first time in 1968. Over half the net deficit in respect of govern¬
ment expenditure relates to military expenditure overseas; other substantial
items of expenditure are grants to developing countries and subscriptions to
international organisations.
Tourism yields a substantial income from overseas; in the ten years 1959-68
overseas visitors spent around £2,000 million in Britain. For 1968 these travel
and tourist receipts, excluding fares, are estimated at about £282 million.
United Kingdom residents on holiday, or travelling for business or other
purposes overseas, spent about £2ji million (excluding fares) in the same
year. The continuing increase in both the average expenditure per visitor
and in the number of travellers visiting Britain coupled with the fall since
1966 in the expenditure by British travellers abroad caused travel credits to
exceed debits in 1968. The total number of visitors to the United Kingdom
in 1968, including visitors from the Republic of Ireland, is estimated at some
5 million—an 11 per cent increase over the 1967 figure, and more than twice
the number in 1956.
Britain’s national tourist organisation is the British Travel Association, a
voluntary body deriving the major part of its income from a government
grant-in-aid. The Association undertakes publicity overseas aimed at
attracting visitors to Britain and works towards the improvement in Britain
of hotel accommodation, catering, transport, entertainment and other
386 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
amenities for the tourist. It maintains offices in 16 overseas countries. The
Association works in close collaboration with the Scottish Tourist Board and
the Wales Tourist Board (contributing to their information and publicity
services), as well as the Northern Ireland Tourist Board, which is a statutory
body receiving a grant from the Government of Northern Ireland.
The Development of Tourism Act 1969 provides for the establishment of a
statutory tourist organisation which will take over the British Travel Associa¬
tion’s responsibility for promoting tourism. The new organisation has powers
to give financial assistance towards hotel development and the development of
other tourist facilities and amenities. In addition it will be responsible for any
scheme for the classification or grading of tourist accommodation.
COMMERCIAL Britain’s prosperity depends on the prosperity of those who buy her exports
POLICY an(j theij-g wip depend on how they sell their exports elsewhere. Thus Britain
is a strong advocate of the removal of artificial barriers to trade and to this end
has taken a leading part in the setting up and subsequent activities of such
organisations as the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) and the Organisation for Economic
Co-operation and Development (OECD). It has also played a full part at the
two plenary sessions of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Develop¬
ment held in 1964 and 1968 and is a member of the Trade and Development
Board which acts on behalf of the Conference between sessions.
Customs duties on imports into Britain are divided into two broad cate¬
gories: revenue duties (to which there correspond excise revenue duties on
comparable British-produced goods) and protective duties. Purchase tax is
chargeable on imported as well as home-produced goods but in the main the
charge on imports is deferred until the goods are sold by a registered to a
non-registered trader. In the financial year 1968-69 revenue duties charged
on imported goods yielded about £2,355 million, by far the greater part of
which came from tobacco and hydrocarbon oils (petroleum products). The
yield from protective duties was £218 million, or about 3 per cent of the value
of all imports.
At the beginning of the twentieth century the only customs duties were
those imposed for revenue purposes on a small range of products. Certain
duties were imposed during the first world war (the McKenna Duties), in
1921 (for strategic reasons) and in 1925 (initially for revenue purposes) but it
was not until the Import Duties Act 1932 that any serious departure was made
from the principle of free trade. This measure provided a degree of protection
for British industry and, at the same time, a basis for negotiations with foreign
countries already in possession of a tariff structure. A series of bilateral trade
negotiations between 1932 and 1939 led to some modification in the level of
protection but in the next ten years, because of government purchase and
import controls introduced during and immediately after the second world
war, the tariff lost much of its importance. The substantial relaxation of
quantitative import controls from 1949 onwards re-established the tariff as
the main instrument of protection.
The Import Duties Act 1958 replaced existing legislation relating to the
protective tariff and brought it up to date in a single measure. The tariff was
recast into an internationally agreed form (the Brussels Nomenclature), which
came into use from 1st January 1959. Under the Customs Duties (Dumping
and Subsidies) Act 1969, the Board of Trade is empowered to impose duties
on imported goods of any description which have been dumped or subsidised
if it is satisfied that these are causing or threatening material injury to a
General Agree¬
ment on Tariffs
and Trade
Commonwealth
Preference
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 387
particular industry and that such action would be in the national interest.
The Act also empowers the Board of Trade to take provisional action where a
prima facie case of dumping or subsidisation and consequent material injury
has been made out.
An import deposit scheme was introduced for a one-year period in
November 1968 as part of measures taken to assist in bringing the balance of
payments into surplus. Importers of those classes of goods subject to the
scheme (these exclude, for example, foodstuffs and raw materials) are required
to deposit 50 per cent of the value of the goods for six months with Customs
and Excise.
The United Kingdom’s protective tariff has been considerably modified in
recent years as a result of a series of international tariff negotiations held under
the auspices of the GATT, which seeks to increase the volume of world trade
by reducing tariffs and other barriers to trade, and by eliminating discrimina¬
tion in international commerce. Tariff reductions, and bindings against
increase, negotiated between countries under the GATT are applied equally
to all other GATT countries under the ‘most favoured nation’ clause.
As a result of the latest series of GATT tariff negotiations, the ‘Kennedy
Round’ (May 1964-June 1967), average reductions of over 30 per cent are to
be made by the major trading countries in their tariffs on industrial goods.
The reduction to be made in the British tariffs on dutiable industrial goods
imported from the EEC, the United States and Japan will amount to about
37 per cent, 40 per cent and 34 per cent respectively. This is closely in line
with the reductions which these countries are making, which will affect well
over 70 per cent of British exports of dutiable industrial goods to these coun¬
tries. Some reductions in the tariffs on agricultural goods are also being made.
The implementation of the British tariff reductions will be spread over
1968-72; the first cuts were made on the 1st July 1968 and subsequent
reductions are due to be made on the 1st January 1970, 1971 and 1972
respectively.
The principle of Imperial Preference was introduced into the United Kingdom
customs duties in 19tQ and at the Ottawa Conference in 1932 agreements
were concluded with independent Commonwealth countries providing for
reciprocal preferential tariff treatment over a wide range of goods. The
Import Duties Act 1932 had already provided for the duty-free entry of goods
from the United Kingdom dependencies.
Most imports into Britain from the Commonwealth preference area (which
includes the Republic of South Africa and the Republic of Ireland) enter free
of duty. Some two-thirds of them enjoy a tariff preference of about 11 per cent
(defined as the difference between the full duty rate and the preferential rate-
in this case generally nil—expressed as a percentage of the import value).
It is estimated that approximately half of Britain’s exports to the Common¬
wealth preference area enter free of duty and about the same proportion enjoy
an average tariff preference of 12 per cent.
In 1964 the first United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
(UNCTAD) in Geneva, Britain declared itself prepared to extend tariff
preferences on a non-reciprocal and non-discriminatory basis to all the
developing countries if other major industrialised countries would do the
same, if the Commonwealth countries concerned would agree and provided
that preferences were not given in such a way as to impede the continuing
reduction of tariffs on a most-favoured-nation basis. The establishment of a
388 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
system of generalised preferences for manufactures and semi-manufactures
exported by developing countries was agreed in principle at the second
UNCTAD conference in New Delhi in 1968, the detailed arrangements to be
worked out during the course of 1969.
European
Economic
Integration
Methods of
Trading
The European Free Trade Association (EFTA) was set up under the Stock¬
holm Convention of January i960 by Austria, Denmark, Norway, Portugal,
Sweden, Switzerland and Britain, with the object of creating an industrial free
trade area between the members and of working towards a wider European
settlement. Under the Convention, protective tariffs and quotas on trade in
industrial products between members of EFTA were to be eliminated by
1st January 1970. The first tariff cuts were made in July i960, and duties were
finally removed (with certain minor exceptions) on 31st December 1966, three
years earlier than originally planned. Finland, which joined EFTA in 1961 as
an associate member, made its final cuts in December 1967. EFTA was the
first completed free trade area in the world and forms a single market of almost
100 million people. Since 1959 intra-EFTA trade has more than doubled and
has increased more than twice as fast as trade between the group and non¬
member countries.
A free trade agreement between the United Kingdom and the Republic of
Ireland came into operation on 1st July 1966. On that date the United
Kingdom removed all protective import duties on goods of Republic of
Ireland origin imported from that country. After 1st July 1975, with certain
exceptions, the Republic of Ireland will not apply any protective duties on
goods of United Kingdom origin.
In August 1961 the British Government applied formally to join the EEC
but negotiations were suspended in January 1963- A renewed application for
membership was made in May 1967. At the meeting of the EEC Council of
Ministers in December 1967 five of the member states favoured the opening
of negotiations with Britain, but the French Government did not agree, and
the request for accession remains on the Council’s agenda.
The export trade and virtually all the import trade of the United Kingdom are
conducted by private firms.
Methods of export trading vary considerably, according to the firm, the
industry, the product and the market. A good deal of United Kingdom export
trade, especially of the smaller manufacturing firms, is conducted through
exports merchants in the United Kingdom; many firms, however, sell to
importers and consumers abroad through their own agents or resident repre¬
sentatives in the countries concerned; in other cases, sales are made through
a firm’s own branch offices, distributing organisations or subsidiary sales
companies established in overseas markets.
Similarly, in import trade, many large firms engaged in manufacture or
domestic trade buy directly from overseas suppliers, while smaller firms may
find it more convenient to buy through intermediaries such as import/export
houses, commission agents, and the representatives of overseas firms.
CONTROLS ON
TRADE AND
PAYMENTS
Most of the restrictions imposed on the movement of goods and services
during and immediately after the second world war have been progressively
abolished.
Exchange Exchange control is confined mainly to transactions between residents of the
Control United Kingdom and residents of countries outside the sterling area. The
Overseas
Travel
Import and
Export Control
Import Licensing
Export Controls
TRADE AND PAYMENTS
latter may settle transactions between themselves in sterling, and any sterling
held on an external account is freely convertible into other currencies,
including dollars.
The remaining important restrictions relate to the movement of capital
from the United Kingdom to non-sterling area countries. Because of the
balance of payments deficits, exchange control requirements for investments
outside the sterling area have, since 1961, been revised and made more
stringent. Exports of goods to destinations outside the sterling area are
subject to exchange control and, in general, have to be paid for within six
months in any foreign currency (except Rhodesian pounds) or by sterling
from an external account. Control is also exercised over imports to ensure that
currency authorised for their payment is used for that purpose.
There are also certain restrictions on the release of gold for manufacturing
and industrial purposes, and on the buying, selling and holding of gold coins.
Exchange control policy is the responsibility of the Treasury, but most of
the administration is, in practice, carried out by the Bank of England as agent
of the Treasury; and, in turn, the Bank of England has delegated to the
commercial banks a wide variety of powers to deal with applications.
Residents of Britain visiting countries outside the sterling area for pleasure
are at present restricted to a basic foreign exchange allowance of ^50 a year.
The purpose of this restriction is to assist the balance of payments. This
allowance covers all foreign exchange expenditure taken in the form of cash
or travellers cheques, and also the cost of hotel and other travel services,
except fares paid in sterling to travel agents in the United Kingdom. The
amount of steiling notes that a traveller may take out of the country is
restricted to £15 a journey.
Under the Import, Export and Customs Powers (Defence) Act 1939 the
Board of Trade is empowered to prohibit or regulate the import or export
of goods.
In accordance with its international obligations under the GATT and the
IMF, the United Kingdom Government has progressively removed quanti¬
tative restrictions from almost all its imports from the countries of the free
world. The very short list of goods on which controls remain includes some
items of special difficulty and a few where restrictions are recognised inter¬
nationally, such as arms, ammunition and radioactive materials. They require
a specific import licence and quotas have been set up for most of them. Some
quotas refer specifically to individual countries and are usually shared out
among exporters by the authorities of the countries concerned. Others are
accorded on an overall or global basis, and are generally allocated by the United
Kingdom authorities to United Kingdom importers, usually on the basis of
their share of the trade in the commodity in the past. Apart from these
quantitative controls, some further restrictions or prohibitions are applied
on health grounds (for example, on animals, plants and drugs). There is also
a temporary general import restriction on goods from Rhodesia.
Except for the control necessary to ensure that exports to destinations outside
the sterling area are paid for in the proper manner, United Kingdom exports
are not, except in a very minor way, subject to any government control or
direction. The few controls that are in operation are imposed to supervise
exports of military and strategic importance; to conserve materials which may
be in inadequate supply; to assist exchange control operations in preventing
39°
GOVERNMENT
ASSISTANCE
TO OVERSEAS
TRADE
Information
and Advice to
Exporters
Support for
Marketing
Organisations
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
the export of capital in the form of valuable goods; to ensure the humane
treatment of horses, cattle, sheep and pigs; and to prevent the export of works
of art classed as national treasures. Normally, individual licences are required
for specific consignments of goods subject to export licensing control. Goods
controlled for strategic reasons, not included in the category of atomic energy
materials and appliances, arms and ammunition, may, with certain exceptions,
be exported to the Commonwealth, the Irish Republic, the Republic of South
Africa and the United States of America without licence. There is also a
temporary general export restriction on goods to Rhodesia.
The British Government1 assists exporters by its efforts to create conditions
favourable to the export trade and by providing credit insurance facilities and
information and advice about opportunities for trade in other countries.
Facilities exist for the repayment of protective duties paid on goods which
have been imported for export trade purposes.
Exporters wanting assistance and advice can consult Board of Trade offices
throughout Britain and, through these offices, the commercial posts of Her
Majesty’s Diplomatic Service overseas. There are over 200 posts located in all
the principal cities and trade centres abroad and they supply the Board of
Trade with information of every kind affecting trade with their territories.
Overseas officers regularly report on local economic and commercial
conditions, pay special attention to local demand for particular commodities,
and generally assist the exporter to overcome any difficulties he encounters
in trade with the country in question, particularly those arising out of govern¬
mental regulations. These officers investigate potential markets for British
products, advise about methods of trading with particular areas, and seek out
and pass on opportunities for export business and enquiries for British goods.
Assistance is also given to United Kingdom exporters in appointing agents
and locating potential importers. From records kept up to date in London by
reports from its overseas commercial officers, the Export Services Branch of
the Board of Trade can provide information concerning any country on the
prospects for exports and requirements of particular markets, government
regulations affecting trade (including import restrictions and tariffs and duties
on particular commodities), methods of trading, local tastes and preferences
in design, and the commercial standing of firms with which an exporter
contemplates business relations.
The Government’s official information services overseas are used exten¬
sively to promote Britain’s export trade.
The Overseas Marketing Corporation, financed partly by private equity
capital and partly by loan capital made available by the Board of Trade, was
set up in November 1967 to promote exports from British firms which
encounter difficulties in selling abroad because of their size or structure. It
seeks out new export opportunities overseas and ensures an adequate marketing
effort to fulfil them. The Board of Trade also supports, by a three-year grant
commenced in July 1967, the Export Marketing Partnerships scheme
operated by the Institute of Marketing to enable smaller manufacturers to
reach profit-sharing agreements with established exporters.
1 Export promotion is also assisted by the Scottish Council (Development and Industry)
and the Development Corporation for Wales. In Northern Ireland, the Ministry of
Commerce provides a liaison service with the Board of Trade Export Services Branch
and the overseas posts.

391
The Export Credits Guarantee Department (ECGD) is a government
department, responsible to the President of the Board of Trade, which
provides insurance for exporters against the main risks in selling overseas,
and guarantees to banks providing finance for export credit. It covers more
than a third of the country’s export trade. The ECGD is required to carry
on its business on a self-supporting basis; it does not provide subsidies to
exporters, nor is it a charge on the taxpayer.
The risks covered include insolvency or protracted default of the buyer,
governmental action which blocks or delays transfer of payment to the
United Kingdom exporter, imposition of new import licensing restrictions
in the buyer’s country, war between the buyer’s country and the United
Kingdom, cancellation or non-renewal of a United Kingdom export licence,
additional handling, transport or insurance charges incurred after shipment
through interruption or diversion of voyage or ‘any other cause of loss
occurring outside the United Kingdom and not within the control of the
exporter or the buyer, and not normally insurable with commercial insurers’.
Cover may commence from the date of contract or (at lower premiums) from
the date of shipment.
Policies may be comprehensive, covering all export business in all markets
(or in an agreed group of markets) on goods sold on six months’ to five years’
credit, or specific, covering large, single capital transactions sold on credit
terms of five years or more.
Some 300 exhibitions, of which about 200 were trade fairs, wrere held in
Britain in 1968. Some of the specialised fairs, such as the Motor Show and
the Royal Agricultural Show, attract large numbers of the public, as well as
many trade buyers from home and overseas, and provide an important means
of advertising and selling British goods.
United Kingdom products are shown at most of the large international
trade fairs throughout the world and United Kingdom manufacturers have
been prominent at the many specialised fairs held in Europe and North
America. Special displays of British consumer goods have also been presented
in hotels in North America and elsewhere.
Participation in trade fairs, ‘British weeks’ and store promotions overseas is
a form of export promotion for which the Government provides information,
financial assistance and, in certain cases, free facilities. (‘British weeks’ dilfer
from trade fairs and exhibitions in that they are primarily designed to promote
sales of consumer goods in shops overseas.) The amount allocated to the
Board of Trade for these purposes has risen from £60,000 in 1955-56 to nearly
£4 million in 1968-69. In 1968 the Board of Trade assisted some 5,300 British
firms to participate in 239 specialised and general trade fairs in 39 countries;
and provided practical help to one major and seven minor ‘British weeks’,
and to some 84 overseas store promotions, including 3,000 stores and shops.
The British National Export Council (BNEC), a promotional body formed in
July 1964, is sponsored by the Government and by representatives of industry,
trade, finance, and organised labour in Britain. Associated with it are 12 Area
Committees with the primary responsibility for developing British exports
to a particular market or group of markets: Africa, Asia, Australia, the
Caribbean, Israel, Latin America, the Middle East, New Zealand, Europe,
Canada, southern Africa and the United States.
The tasks of the BNEC are to keep all British export activity under constant
review: to stimulate exports in all markets; to advise on organisations relating
392
FINANCING OF

TRADE

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
to particular markets; to provide a central point for the export effort; and
services for this purpose such as the sending overseas of export missions.
There is an annual scheme for royal recognition of outstanding export and
technological achievement by industry, namely, the Queen’s Award to
Industry; the first awards were made in 1966.
In the nineteenth century, the rapid growth of British industry, commerce
and shipping under the stimulus of the industrial revolution made Britain
the market as well as the workshop of the world. It became the site for the
chief world markets in raw materials (see below), freight, insurance, and
precious metals. A sound commercial banking system and a flexible system
of central bank control have been built up, while specialised institutions such
as discount houses, merchant banks, accepting houses, the stock exchanges,
investment trusts and finance corporations have evolved to satisfy particular
needs for short-term or long-term finance. The facilities provided by merchant
banks and accepting houses, for example, have long been used to finance
shipments of goods not only to and from Britain, but also between other
overseas countries. (Exchange control no longer allows the financing of trade
between two non-sterling area countries.)
At the same time, the banks which were already engaged in financing trade
were able to assist in raising finance for longer-term ventures. British capital
invested in overseas countries has furthered their development, increased
their output and exports, and provided markets for manufactured goods. A
number of specialised institutions help in providing financial services for
overseas countries.
Britain is the traditional centre for marketing many of the world’s basic
commodities. Among the more important are the Baltic Exchange (the market
for shipping and air transport, grain, seeds and vegetable oils), the London
Commodity Exchange (cocoa, coffee, copra, hides and skins, rubber and
sugar), the London Wool Exchange, the London Metal Exchange, the
Liverpool Cotton Exchange and the Liverpool Corn Exchange. A soya bean
oil futures market opened in London in July 1967 and a coconut oil futures
market in June 1969. These markets not only cater for the import of goods
for home consumption but do much business in effecting transactions between
buyers and sellers in other countries. In addition to these formal markets,
there is scarcely any product which cannot be traded through an intermediary
in Britain. For example, London is the world’s most important philatelic
market and also the leading international centre for the sale of works
of art.
The market consists of over 180 authorised banks and nine firms of brokers,
all linked together by telephone in the United Kingdom, and by telephone,
telex and cable with overseas centres. The turnover of the market has
increased progressively since the introduction in December 1958 of external
convertibility for the principal European currencies. The Foreign Exchange
Market is subject to United Kingdom exchange control regulations governing
the purchase and sale of foreign currencies in the sterling area.
The London Gold Market, which had remained closed from the outbreak of
war in I939> was reopened in March 1954, under the general supervision
of the Bank of England. All authorised banks may deal in gold but, in
practice, dealings are largely concentrated in the hands of the five members
The Sterling
System
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 393
of the gold market. The five members meet twice daily to fix a price for all
transactions which customers ask to have executed at the fixing.
A gold pool was set up in i960 to co-ordinate the gold operations in London
(including supplying gold to private buyers) of certain European central banks
and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Following heavy world-wide
speculation in gold at the end of 1967 and the beginning of 1968, the gold pool
was terminated in March 1968. Officially held gold is now used only to effect
transfers between monetary authorities where these are not replacing gold
sold in private markets.
As a result of Britain’s early lead in international trade and finance, several
countries tended not only to use sterling as their natural currency for inter¬
national transactions, but also to maintain central currency reserves in
Britain. When Britain abandoned the gold standard in 1931 these countries,
which came to be known as the ‘sterling bloc’ and later as the ‘sterling area’,
did likewise, and pegged their currency exchange rates to the pound sterling.
In 1939, after the outbreak of war, the pound sterling was no longer freely
convertible into other currencies and the sterling area became more formally
defined as a currency area for exchange control purposes. The United
Kingdom imposes no exchange control on transactions with residents of other
sterling area countries. Sterling became convertible again in December 1958
but there is still exchange control against the non-sterling area.
All the Commonwealth countries (except Canada and Rhodesia), together
with Iceland, the Irish Republic, Jordan, Kuwait, Libya, the Republic of
South Africa, South West Africa, the Republic of Southern Yemen, the
British Protected States in the Persian Gulf, and Western Samoa, are members
of the sterling area. The main features of the sterling area are that the greater
part of the overseas trade of member countries is financed in sterling, while
much of their foreign reserves are held in sterling. Member countries sell their
foreign currency earnings in London in exchange for sterling and purchase for
sterling the foreign currency they require. Britain’s reserves of gold and
foreign currencies are held in the Exchange Equalisation Account. These
arrangements are voluntary; there are no strict or centralised rules of conduct.
Consultations were held during 1968 between Britain and sterling area
countries to devise means of stabilising their sterling balances. As a result
12 central banks outside the sterling area agreed to make available via the
Bank for International Settlements a $2,000 million medium-term credit
facility, to enable Britain, in return for certain assurances, to offer dollar-
value guarantee on the bulk of each sterling area country’s official sterling
reserves.
THE BALANCE OF PAYMENTS
A summary of Britain’s balance of payments position between 1966 and 1968
is given in Table 32, p. 395. It will be seen that the various items are subject
to considerable fluctuation.
The transactions fall into three main groups—current account, long-term
capital account and monetary movements. The balance on current account is
composed of the balance of visible trade (that is, the difference between mer¬
chandise imports and exports and re-exports) and the balance of invisibles.
394
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
On long-term capital account, the main groups of items are intergovernmental
loans (including amortisation) and other identified net long-term investment
abroad by United Kingdom residents, or in the United Kingdom by non¬
residents. The third heading, monetary movements, reflects in part the
United Kingdom’s position as an international banker. It includes miscel¬
laneous capital transactions, generally of a short-term character, changes in
external assets and liabilities of the banking system and changes in the United
Kingdom reserves of gold and convertible currencies.
Between 1952 and 1963 there were surpluses in the balance of payments on
current account in all years except for 1955, i960 and 1961. In 1964 there was
a substantial deficit of £381 million, which turned to a surplus of £64 million
in 1966. This improvement was not maintained in 1967 and 1968, when
deficits of £283 million and £265 million were recorded. These resulted from
the increased deficit in the visible trade balance. The invisible balance, which
benefited from the deferment of interest payments on the North American
loans, increased by almost 50 per cent over 1967 to a net surplus of ^412
million, see p. 385. The deterioration in the trade balance was largely due to
the initial adverse impact of devaluation upon the terms of trade. However,
the second half of 1968 saw a marked improvement in the visible trade
balance, with exports rising at a faster rate than imports.
The net outward flow of long-term capital, which reached a peak of £363
million in 1964, was £142 million in 1968. The balance on official account
(see Table 32) moved into surplus in 1968. This resulted partly from certain
debt repayments and also from the deferment of the North American loan
repayment. Gross drawings and repayments on the United States Export/
Import Bank—the credit to finance the purchases of American military
aircraft—increased by similar amounts and net lending under the aid pro¬
gramme was unchanged. There were exceptionally large increases of £279
million in outward private investment and of .£193 million in inward private
investment in 1968, giving an increase of .£86 million in the net outward flow,
to £163 million. A large part of the increased outward flow represented
increased portfolio investment in Australia and South Africa; increases in
reinvested profits and in investment by foreign oil companies in Britain largely
accounted for the higher inward flow of private investment.
The balance on current and long-term capital transactions combined was in
surplus in 1961 and 1962 but moved into a considerable deficit of £744
million in 1964. By 1966 this deficit had been substantially reduced to £48
million but it increased in 1967 and dropped slightly in 1968 to £407 million.
Movements of short-term capital may mean that changes in the balance on
current and long-term capital accounts are not necessarily reflected in the
reserves of gold and convertible currencies.
The general level of the reserves has not changed greatly since the early
1950s and has usually been in the region of £1,000 million. In 1964, when
there was a very large deficit in the balance of payments, they fell to £827
million. Subsequently, they have regained their £1,000 million level though
this has been maintained in part by transfer from the dollar portfolio in 1966
and 1967 of £520 million. At the end of 1968 the reserves amounted to
£1,009 million. They were made up of £614 million in gold and £395 million
in convertible currencies. Britain’s net external liabilities in sterling (excluding
liabilities to the IMF) amounted to £4,077 million at the end of 1968. Over
half of these were towards countries in the overseas sterling area. In addition,
net external liabilities in non-sterling currencies amounted to £233
million.

In addition to its reserves of gold and convertible currencies, Britain has
drawing rights on the IMF based on its quota, which was raised to $2,440
million (£871 million) in March 1966. (The sterling equivalent of the British
quota after devaluation in November 1967 is £1,017 million.) Britain has had
recourse to the IMF on several occasions. Three drawings are either wholly
or partly outstanding. A drawing of $1,400 million in 1965 has been partly
repaid and the remainder is due to be repaid by May 1970. A further $1,400
million agreed in 1967 was used to repay short-term debts to central banks;
and a stand-by facility for $1,000 million (£417 million) agreed in June
1969 is being drawn in instalments ($500 million immediately and the

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
remainder in three equal instalments up to May 1970). Part of this drawing is
being used to repay the amounts due to the IMF under the 1965 drawing.
With each request to the IMF for a stand-by facility, a Letter of Intent is
sent by the British Government setting out its policy and intentions for the
domestic economy.
Britain has also taken part since 1961 in the international network of
reciprocal credit (‘swap’) facilities arranged between central banks. These
facilities (full details of which have not been published) include one of
$2,000 million with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Under these
arrangements each central bank is able to exchange on request its own
currency for the currency of another country up to a maximum agreed for a
limited period. It agrees to reverse the transaction at a specified date at the
same rate of exchange. The currencies so obtained can be retained in the
reserves or used in exchange operations.
In the estimates of Britain’s external assets and liabilities,1 it should be
emphasised that the various elements are fundamentally different in kind and
are subject to different methods of valuation, hence the totals are of limited
significance. However, they do illustrate two features of basic importance in
Britain’s external situation. It has a very large excess of long-term assets over
long-term liabilities and a considerable excess of short-term liabilities
over short-term assets. At the end of 1968 net long-term assets amounted to
about £5,590 million while net short-term liabilities amounted to about
£3,615 million.
Britain’s official long-term liabilities have mostly arisen from the second world
war and its aftermath. At the end of 1968 about £2,997 million was still out¬
standing, of which £2,24.2 million was owed to other Governments, the greater
part to the United States and Canada. Devaluation had increased the amount
outstanding by about one-sixth.
The largest item among official external long-term claims is British
Government aid in the form of loans (see p. 399).
Overseas investors in Britain are allowed to repatriate the proceeds of the
sale of their investments, including any capital gains that may have accrued.
Earned profits and dividends can be transferred, irrespective of the amount;
transfers of this kind have never been restricted. In 1968 the net inward flow
of private investment amounted to £573 million (^193 million more than in
the previous year). Of this, £245 million represented direct investment and
£87 million portfolio investment; the rest was largely investment by the oil
industry.
Overseas long-term liabilities arising from investment in the private sector
of the British economy have increased steadily since the war. The market value
of overseas portfolio holdings of British company securities at the end of 1968
was of the order of £2,220 million. The book value of direct investments held
in Britain by companies incorporated abroad (except banks, oil and insurance
companies) was £2,570 million, of which some four-fifths was in the manu¬
facturing industry.
Nearly two-thirds of this direct investment came from the United States.
The book value of the net assets in Britain of United States and European oil
companies was some £1,150 million.
1 Published in the annual United Kingdom Balance of Payments.

BRITISH

Private investment abroad may take several forms: portfolio investment,
that is, investment in overseas securities including the loans raised by overseas
countries on the London capital market; or direct investment by the estab¬
lishment of subsidiary companies abroad, by ploughing back profits earned
overseas, or by acquiring an interest in an overseas enterprise.
Apart from the voluntary programme introduced early in 1966 to restrain
the flow of British capital to Australia, South Africa, New Zealand and the
Irish Republic, the United Kingdom imposes no restriction on investment in
the sterling area by United Kingdom residents. Direct investment is frequently
made from a firm’s existing resources. However, borrowers outside the United
Kingdom must in certain circumstances obtain the consent of the Treasury
if the amount borrowed exceeds £50,000 in any one year. Borrowing by
Commonwealth Governments in the London capital market has fallen in
recent years, but averaged about £50 million a year in the 1950s.
Direct investment outside the sterling area is normally permitted provided
that it is financed by foreign currency borrowing or by the reinvestment of an
appropriate portion of profits. Other means of finance (including the use of
official exchange in a limited category of cases) are allowed only when invest¬
ment promises a benefit to the United Kingdom balance of payments in the
short-term. The Board of Trade estimated that the flow of private direct
investment abroad by British companies (excluding oil) was about £267
million in 1967 (the latest survey available); 53 per cent went to the sterling
area. The figures include long-term and short-term investment and reinvested
profits.
Britain’s private long-term capital assets abroad include portfolio invest¬
ments which, at the end of 1968, had a total estimated market value of some
£5,8°° million. In addition, the book value of British direct investments
abroad (except oil, insurance and banking) was £6,105 million at the end of
1968. Roughly half of this was invested in manufacturing industries. The
approximate book value of oil companies’ assets at the end of 1968 was some
£1,650 million. The total value of the overseas interests of British insurance
companies is not known but the value of their direct investments in the United
States alone amounted to £500 million at the end of 1967. The British insur¬
ance industry also operates extensively in other foreign countries and
throughout the Commonwealth.
Owing to the increase in recent years in British aid to developing countries,
intergovernmental loans form the largest item among official external long¬
term claims. The total of such loans outstanding at the end of 1968 was
£739 million. New government loans (less repayments) totalled £60 million
in 1968. Other official lending included an £11 million investment by the
Commonwealth Development Corporation (see p. 399).
In addition, there are the official subscriptions to, and shareholdings in,
international financial organisations (see below). The Government also owns
real estate overseas, such as embassy buildings and military installations.
Britain’s aid programme to the developing countries consists of loans and
grants for economic and social development, technical assistance, budget
support and contributions to multilateral agencies providing financial aid and
technical assistance to these countries. (In addition to this official aid pro¬
gramme, an important contribution is made to economic development by
private investment and by private voluntary organisations engaged in relief,
development and educational work.)

The net flow of British resources to developing countries, private capital
as well as official aid, exceeded the target of 1 per cent of national income as
set by the first United Nations Conference on Trade and Development
(UNCTAD) in 1964 in each of the nine years to 1966. In 1967 the percentage
was 0-97. The second UNCTAD in 1968 revised the target to 1 per cent of
gross national product which represented, in Britain’s case, an increase of
about one-quarter. The provisional percentage figure for 1969 in terms of
the revised target was 0-83.
Historically, Britain’s aid programme began as part of the discharge of its
responsibilities towards the dependent territories and the main emphasis
remains on territories which are, or were until recent years, a British
responsibility. In 1968 nearly £171 million (89 per cent) of the bilateral pro¬
gramme was disbursed to Commonwealth countries both dependent and
independent.
Economic difficulties have made it necessary to restrain public expenditure
including expenditure overseas. The target for the basic aid programme in
1969-70 is being maintained, however, at the 1968-69 level of £205 million;
in addition, there will be an expenditure of some £22 million on other aid
commitments, for example, a contribution of £6 million to the Food Aid
Convention as part of the Kennedy Round (see p. 387), economic assistance
to Singapore and Malaysia in connection with the withdrawal of British
forces, and a payment to the World Bank to maintain the dollar value of
Britain’s capital subscription after devaluation.

Of the total of bilateral financial aid of ^150 million in 1968, 35 per cent was
in grant form and 65 per cent in loans. Budgetary aid is provided in grant
form. Development aid is in either grant or loan form depending on the
economic circumstances of the recipient countries, but is mainly in loan form.
The terms of new development loans from Britain have been progressively
softened since 1958 and a policy of interest-free loans for the poorest
developing countries was introduced in June 1965. In 1968, the total value of
loan commitments entered into, excluding investments by the Common¬
wealth Development Corporation (CDC) (see below), was ^116 million and
of this over 91 per cent was on interest-free terms. The recipients included
India, Malaysia and Singapore.
Where loans are made on interest-bearing terms waivers of interest for a
period of years are granted in appropriate cases, and both kinds of loan may
carry grace periods during which repayments of capital are not made. Of all
loans committed in 1968, 89 per cent of value carried grace periods for capital
repayments averaging just over five and a half years, while the weighted
average maturity of loans was about 24 years.
Loans and grants are used mainly for the purchase of goods, equipment and
services from Britain, although there may be a substantial element for local
costs in appropriate cases. Between 1958 and the end of 1968, 204 loans were
negotiated involving a commitment of ^719 million, of which £576 million
has been disbursed. The largest recipients have been India and Pakistan.
During the same period bilateral grants amounted to around ^802 million.
Aid to dependent territories includes budgetary assistance, development
grants and loans under the Colonial Development and Welfare (CD & W)
Acts, technical assistance, and investments by the CDC. Grants account for
the predominant share of this assistance. Economic aid to the dependent
territories increased to a peak of j£ioo million in 1961, but has declined to
£15 million in 1968 as colonies have become independent.
Although Britain’s formal responsibility to a dependent territory ceases when
it attains independence, its continuing needs have been recognised by offering
aid in appropriate forms. Almost all independent Commonwealth developing
countries have received help towards their development by way of loans. In
1968 independent Commonwealth countries received £149 million in bilateral
financial aid and technical assistance (80 per cent of the bilateral programme).
The CDC was set up in 1948 to provide finance and management for
development projects in Commonwealth countries, and acts on a commercial
basis, often in partnership with private enterprise or territorial governments.
Most of its finance has been provided by loans from the British Government
(^9-4 million in 1968). By the end of 1968, a total of £120 million had been
invested out of a total commitment of j/,’150 million. Of the latter, £26 million
was in the Far East, £28 million in the Caribbean and virtually all of the
remainder was in Africa.
Expenditure on technical assistance (the provision of skilled personnel, advice
and training) has increased to form 20 per cent of the total aid programme in
1968. The largest component of expenditure (£27-3 million in 1968) is that of
sending or maintaining experts, including volunteers; the next largest is for
students and trainees in Britain (£6-6 million).
Under the Overseas Service Aid Scheme (OSAS) and associated schemes
Britain meets the additional costs of employing experienced expatriate British
400
Multilateral
Contributions
WHOLESALE
TRADES
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
personnel in the public services. The schemes cost ^19-1 million in 1968 and
covered over 9,000 expatriate officers in 39 Commonwealth countries,
principally in East and Central Africa. Britain receives large numbers of
students and trainees from developing countries. Over 10,000 were financed in
Britain in 1968 under regional programmes of technical assistance, by awards
under the Commonwealth Education Co-operation Scholarships and Bursary
Schemes, and under the various schemes of the British Council. At the end of
1968, of the 13,430 British persons other than volunteers who were working
in developing countries and financed by the British Government, almost
10,000 were engaged in the maintenance and improvement of education, public
administration and communications.
In addition, the British Volunteer Programme has been expanding (the
first volunteers were sent overseas in 1958-59) until in 1968 there were 1,787
volunteers in developing countries. These included graduates and school-
leavers, whose recruitment, training and placing overseas is undertaken by a
number of voluntary bodies; 75 per cent of the British costs (^0-7 million
in 1968) are met by the British Government.
Britain is the second largest contributor (after the United States) to the
World Bank group of institutions including the International Development
Association, to which Britain has undertaken to provide ^65 million in the
three years 1968-70. Britain has contributed ^40 million to the United
Nations Development Programme since its inception in 1950 and has provided
more experts and training places under multilateral schemes than any other
country—1,200 experts and 1,135 training places in 1968. Other contributions
are to the regional development banks, the World Food Programme, the
United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees (UNRWA),
and the United Nations Children’s Fund (UNICEF).
INTERNAL TRADE
Britain’s internal trade can be divided into two broad categories: trade in raw
materials, capital goods and intermediate products (for example, vehicle
components) and trade in consumer goods, involving the network of distribu¬
tive trades by which home produced or imported goods reach the consumer.
(For the pattern of consumers’ expenditure see p. 231.)
There have been a number of official statistical enquiries into the distributive
trades. The latest censuses taken in Great Britain refer to the wholesale trades
in 1965 and the retail trades and certain service trades in 1966. Sample
monthly and annual enquiries are also undertaken, covering such aspects of
the distributive trades as turnover, stocks and capital expenditure. Most of the
figures given in the following pages derive from either the last published
censuses or the sample enquiries.
The first census of retail distribution and other services to be taken in
Northern Ireland relates to 1965.
Only a proportion of the trade in consumer goods passes through wholesalers:
sales are also made to consumers through producers’ own selling organisations
(including their own retail outlets and mail order businesses); and other sales
are made directly by producers to retailers. Wholesale channels are particularly
in evidence in the distribution of textiles, agricultural produce and foodstuffs.
The 1965 enquiry showed that out of a total of 23,643 business units engaged
TRADE AND PAYMENTS 40I
in wholesale distribution in Great Britain, 3,435 dealt in clothing, footwear
and textiles, 2,007 in grocery and provisions, 2,630 in vegetables and fruit,
and 3,469 in other food and in drink. In addition, there were 8,282 dealers
(wholesale or retail) in coal, builders’ materials, grain or agricultural supplies,
and 9,117 dealers in other industrial materials and machinery. The value of
stocks held by wholesalers and dealers at the end of 1968 is estimated at
£1,431 million; expenditure on capital assets during the year was about
£159 million.
Methods of wholesale distribution vary according to the type of merchandise
handled. Fish, for example, is auctioned at the ports to port wholesalers (who
sell to inland wholesalers at the main distribution centres) or, increasingly, is
sold by contract to fryers and processors, or direct to retailers. Fruit and
vegetables may be sold by growers to commission agents (who dispose of the
produce either to wholesalers or direct to retailers) or the grower may deal
only with wholesale firms. The sale of some agricultural products is regulated
by statutory marketing boards (see p. 311).
London’s wholesale markets play a leading part in the distribution of
foodstuffs, particularly imported supplies. Every year Covent Garden1 handles
about 1 -2 million tons of fruit and vegetables, and over 340,000 tons of meat
and poultry pass through Smithfield market; Billingsgate is the principal
distributing centre in Britain for fish. Others in London include Leadenhall
Market (poultry) and Spitalfields Market (fruit and vegetables).
The co-operative movement in Britain has established its own wholesale
societies, the two largest being the Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd.
(CWS) and the Scottish Co-operative Wholesale Society Ltd. (SCWS), to
serve the needs of retail societies, membership being restricted to incorporated
co-operative organisations. The CWS had sales of £510 million in 1968 and
the SCWS had sales of some £90 million.
Since 1954, many wholesalers have joined, either singly or in groups, with
groups of retailers to form voluntary chains to help to preserve the existence
of retail outlets for the wholesaler and to give to retailers the advantages of
the lower costs of large-scale trading without significant loss of independence.
The 1961 Census of Distribution showed that about 27 per cent (or 40 per
cent in terms of turnover) of smaller grocers—mostly medium-sized inde¬
pendents and small multiples with not more than nine branches—then
belonged to these chains and in 1969 the proportion is believed to be
considerably higher. A more recent development is the growth of ‘cash and
carry’ warehouses from which retailers themselves collect their purchases.
RETAIL TRADE
Types of
Retailers
Retail businesses in Britain may be classified under three main headings:
(1) multiple traders, that is, organisations other than co-operative societies
with ten or more branches; (2) retail co-operative societies (see p. 402); and
(3) independent retail businesses, including for this purpose the small
multiple stores (that is, chains of stores with nine or fewer branches). Busi¬
nesses in each of these categories may own department stores. Other retail
outlets include gas and electricity showrooms owned by the area gas and
electricity boards, and mail order houses (see p. 405).
The findings of the 1966 Census of Distribution (Table 34) show that, in
comparison with 1961, a larger volume of trade had been handled by rather
fewer shops. A notable feature is the continuing expansion of large multiple
1 It is planned to move the market from Co vent Garden, in the heart of London, to a
