firms relative to other types of shop. Independent shops, however, still account
for over half of Britain’s retail trade.
A very wide range is covered in the size of retailing establishments. Ten
shops (nine of them department stores) had sales in 1961 exceeding £5 million
or takings of more than £2,000 an hour; at the other extreme there were more
than 70,000 establishments taking less than £2,000 a year. Some of these were
market and street traders, whose volume of business may be very small.
According to the Census of Distribution there wrere nearly 74,000 shops
owned by multiples (including multiple department stores) in 1966 with
a total turnover of £3,858 million. This form of organisation showed the
largest rise in numbers between 1961 and 1966 and their share in total sales
went up from 29 per cent to 35 per cent. Their turnover increased faster than
that of independent businesses between 1966 and 1968.
The share in total retail trade of co-operative stores dropped from 11 to 9 per cent
between 1961 and 1966 which was rather less than the relative decrease in the
number of stores. However, their turnover did not increase between 1966 and
1968.
The retail co-operative societies are voluntary organisations controlled
by their members. Membership is open to anyone paying a small deposit
on a minimum share, which entitles the member to an equal voice with other
members in determining the policy of the society. Share investment by
individual members is limited to £1,000 (less in some societies) and only a
low rate of interest is normally paid on the shares.
In the past the trading surplus, after allocation to reserves and other
payments, has been paid out periodically to members in the form of a dividend
in proportion to their purchases. Most recently some societies have favoured
reducing prices (especially on foodstuffs) to consumers in preference to
dividends, or have introduced gift stamps redeemable for cash or available
for buying other goods.
At the end of 1968 there were 539 retail co-operative societies registered
under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act. Amalgamations are slowly
diminishing the number of societies (the total in 1958 was 1,015). The

Independent shops have been giving ground gradually in the face of increased
competition from the larger undertakings. The proprietors of many of the
smaller shops often have other means of livelihood. Average turnover per shop
has continued to increase, though by less than for the retail trade as a whole.
None the less, even allowing for a 15 per cent increase in prices, the average
independent shop sold more goods in 1966 than in 1961.
There were 778 department stores in Britain in 1968 with a turnover of
over £662 million—about 6 per cent of the total turnover of all retail establish¬
ments. Between 1966 and 1968 their turnover increased by 12 per cent.
Department stores were defined for the purposes of the census as having 25 or
more persons engaged in selling a wide range of commodities notably clothing
and household goods. Co-operative societies owned 238 department stores
in 1966 and 213 were owned by multiples.

Though the total value of retail trade in Great Britain (inclusive of
electricity and gas showrooms and mail order business) rose by a quarter
between 1961 and 1966, rates of growth (measured in turnover) varied
appreciably between different types of trade. The slowest growth was in
general stores, in the food sector, and department stores. The fastest growth
was in radio and television hire, mail order business, gas and electricity
showroom sales of durable goods, sports and leisure equipment, and chemists’
and photographic goods. However, the actual trends are blurred by the
introduction into specialised shops of other specialities, for example, clothing
multiples opening food sections, and vice versa. Though gas and electricity
showroom business was buoyant between 1961 and 1966, their combined
turnover is relatively small, amounting in 1966 to just over £185 million.
The real expansion in the volume of sales in Great Britain between 1961 and
1966, taking into account the exclusion of market traders (included in the 1961
Census) and a general increase in prices of 15 per cent, was about 7 per cent,
or an average of 1 - 6 per cent a year.
Sales by all kinds of retail business increased again by 9 per cent between
1966 and 1968, while retail prices increased by 8-5 per cent.
The Northern Ireland 1965 Census of Retail Distribution and Other
Services shows total spending of £385 million through 22,000 establishments.
The value increased by 9 per cent between 1965 and 1968.
The development of self-service trading has been a feature of the last two
decades. At the end of 1967 there were some 23,000 stores operating wholly
or partly on self-service lines, compared with about 9,500 towards the end of
1961 and less than 500 in 1950. This development has mainly been associated
with multiple stores and has been accompanied by a trend to larger shops in
terms of both staff and floor space.
Supermarkets may be defined as self-service shops with a minimum selling
area of 2,000 square feet. There were about 870 supermarkets in 1961, accord¬
ing to the Census of Distribution, of which 524 were owned by multiples,
308 by co-operative societies and 38 by independents. It has been estimated
that by the end of 1968 over 3,000 had been opened.
Automatic Vending New forms of automatic vending machines have come to the fore since 1955.
Machines Possibly some 300,000 machines are in use. Machines now sell not only
cigarettes, sweets and stamps but also hot and cold beverages, prepared
foodstuffs, stockings, paper-back books and other commodities, including
various types of fuel. Another form is the self-service petrol pump. Organisa¬
tions specialising in automatic vending machines (not otherwise engaged in
retail trade) numbered 56 in 1966, with sales of over ^11 million.
Mobile Shops Some 11,700 mobile shops1 were reported in the Census of Distribution for
1961, with sales amounting to £93 million. Nearly a quarter of this turnover
was concentrated in Scotland (where the density of population is lower than
in England) compared with a tenth of all retail sales. Co-operative societies
accounted for 39 per cent of sales through mobile food shops, against 16 per
cent in ordinary food shops. For the most part, mobile shops were concerned
with food sales; about 42 per cent were travelling grocers, and over 28 per cent
and 21 per cent respectively were greengrocers and butchers. Only a very

An increasing number of ‘out of town’ stores are being opened, providing a
range of goods under one roof, associated with extensive car parking facilities,
away from established central shopping areas.
All forms of consumer sales promotion have been expanding, including
reduced price offers, gift schemes, and stamp trading. The stamps, by law,
have to be marked with their cash value and redeemed for cash on request.
It has been estimated that manufacturers spent some £200 million on
promotions in 1967 compared with £117 million in 1965.
A facility which is spreading in Britain is the ‘credit card’. Users are issued
with a card on production of which their signature is accepted on bills in
participating shops, hotels and restaurants. The issuers then meet the bills and
recover from the card-holder through a single account presented periodically.
Users of certain cards are also required to pay a regular subscription.
Mail order trading has been one of the most rapidly growing forms of selling
in Britain in recent years. The 1966 Census of Distribution showed that the
sales of specialist retail mail order businesses had almost doubled in five years
from £227 million to £431 million; an increase of just under ten times since
1950, when they amounted to ^46 million. Turnover continued to rise steadily
between 1966 and 1968.
Sales by manufacturers direct to the public totalled £144 million in 1961,
compared with £70 million in 1950. Mail order sales accounted for 24 per
cent of the former total, sales to employees for 11 per cent, and charges for
work done for 9 per cent. Other direct sales, including sales by door-to-door
salesmen, accounted for the balance. Included in these sales were items as
various as carpets, washing machines, brushes, books and soft drinks.
Closely connected with the distributive trades are those which offer a service
directly to the public, notably catering and hotel trades, laundries and dry
cleaners, garage and motor repair trades, hairdressers and boot and shoe
repairers.
In 1964 there were 151,000 establishments primarily concerned with catering
(defined to cover public houses, canteens, and fish and chip shops, as well as
licensed hotels and restaurants, etc.) with a total turnover in that year of
£2,036 million. Hotels and holiday camps (excluding boarding houses and
unlicensed hotels) had receipts of about £286 million, of which £124 million
was from residential accommodation. Nearly half the total turnover of the
catering trades was from the sale of alcoholic drinks. Between 1964 and 1968
the catering trades’ turnover increased by 17 per cent. In addition coin-
operated machines are widely being installed in factories—some 60,000
beverage and snack machines are estimated to have been provided in industrial
sites—and in commercial premises as well as in normal retail outlets.
There were about 6,000 commercial laundry, launderette and dry cleaning
businesses with an annual turnover of about ^182 million in 1966. Between
1961 and 1966 it increased by 61-7 per cent, but in the following two years
turnover of this group, other than launderettes and coin-operated dry cleaning
establishments, showed little change.
There were nearly 47,000 businesses in the motor trades in Britain in 1962,
with nearly 58,000 establishments. Total turnover amounted to £2,979
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
million, including transactions between traders amounting to £800 million or
less. Traders classified as new vehicle dealers had nearly 14,700 establishments
and accounted for over two-thirds of total turnover. Over 14,000 establish¬
ments were classified as being primarily petrol stations, and 12,600 were also
general repairers. Between 1962 and 1968 the motor trades turnover has
increased by about 55 per cent.
Takings in hairdressing establishments increased very rapidly between 1950
(£38 million) and 1961 (£97 million), and between 1961 and 1966 to £136
million. Between 1966 and 1968 they rose by only 4 per cent. There are about
48,000 hairdressing establishments.
There are some 8,700 establishments specialising in boot and shoe repairs
(excluding repairs handled through footwear shops); they had takings of £26
million in 1966.
Other establishments found in shopping areas and offering a service to the
public include those of radio and television rental companies (over 3,800
shops), licensed betting offices (over 15,700 in 1968) and over 3,500 funeral
undertaking businesses.
Packaging British industry’s current annual expenditure on packaging has been estimated
at £800 million. The expansion of self-service shops, the spread of branded
and standardised products, and developments in partly prepared foods, for
example, ready-washed vegetables and ready-made cake mixes, have been
major factors in the great changes which have taken place in packaging
methods. Paper packaging, including cartons and boxes, remains the most
extensively used (turnover of some £370 million a year), the fastest growing
sector being paper sacks. New uses are being found for tinplate (output,
^130 million a year), especially in sales of soft drinks and beer. Glass and
plastics packaging account for about £65 million and £70 million a year
respectively. The use of plastics continues to develop; output of polythene
bags reached some 35,000 tons in 1968, and that of bags made of poly¬
propylene, and other film, about 6,500 tons.

Shoe Repairs
Other
Hire-purchase The rapid growth of sales of household and durable consumer goods, such
Sales as cars, furniture, washing machines, television sets, refrigerators and cookers,
has been greatly helped by instalment purchase. Instalment credit debt
outstanding to the main providers amounted to £1,027 mdlion at the end of
March 19691; nearly three-quarters was owed to finance companies and the
remainder to durable goods shops and department stores. A few finance
companies which operate on a national scale account for a high proportion of
the total business.
The Board of Trade has powers to regulate the terms of hire-purchase and
credit sales agreements in order to restrain the expansion of consumer credit.
The current terms are: a minimum deposit of 33^ per cent on most durable
consumer goods except cookers and water-heaters (10 per cent), mattresses
and furniture (20 per cent), and cars (40 per cent). There is usually a maxi¬
mum repayment period of 24 months for most goods except cookers and
water-heaters (4 years).
Hire-purchase in Northern Ireland directly financed by the major finance
houses operating from offices in Northern Ireland amounted in 1968 to nearly

About £494 million is estimated to have been spent on all forms of advertising
in 1968; as a proportion of the gross national product (1-4 per cent) and of
consumer expenditure (i-8 per cent), it has remained almost unchanged
over the last ten years. About £320 million was expended on press advertising
and £i32 million (including tax) was spent on television advertising. The re¬
mainder was divided between outdoor signs, posters, films, and radio. Most of
the advertising is carried out by advertising agencies, which, in some cases,
also provide marketing, consumer research and other services; their rep¬
resentative organisation is the Institute of Practitioners in Advertising. The
trade association for the industry as a whole, including agencies, advertisers and
owners of advertising media, is the Advertising Association. It was responsible
for the setting up of the Advertising Standards Authority, an independent
body whose objective is the promotion and enforcement of the highest
standards of advertising, in particular through the British Code of Advertising
Practice.
Various legislative measures exist in the United Kingdom to protect the
consumer against specific abuses. Non-statutory organisations also exist to
further the consumer’s interests. Weights and measures legislation, one of the
earliest forms of consumer protection, was brought up to date and extended
in scope by the Weights and Measures Act 1963; it is strictly enforced by
qualified inspectors of local weights and measures authorities. The Trade
Descriptions Act 1968 deals with misdescriptions of goods and services and
provides for positive enforcement by the same authorities. The purity,
hygiene and description of food are controlled by the Food and Drugs Acts
1955 and 1956. The Consumer Protection Act 1961 gives the Home Office
power to make regulations to ensure the safety of any class of goods.
The Hire-Purchase Act 1965 and the Hire-Purchase (Scotland) Act 1965
provide safeguards to the consumer who buys goods on hire-purchase or
credit sale terms. The protection extends to agreements up to £2,000 although
most of the safeguards do not apply to credit sale agreements for less than £30.
Similar legislation operates in Northern Ireland. As a precaution against
fraud, virtually every hire-purchase agreement on a car is registered with
H.P. Information Ltd., a non-profit-making company whose members are car
dealers or finance companies concerned with car sales; dealers and finance
houses can check with it in confidence.
The British Standards Institution (see p. 251) has established a number of
standards for consumer goods, and the Council of Industrial Design (see
p. 218) helps to foster improvements in the design of consumer goods.
The Consumer Council, financed by grant-in-aid from the Board of Trade,
was set up in 1963 to concern itself with and promote the consumer’s interests.
Within the limits of its finance and terms of reference it is fully independent
and so free to criticise government departments and to exert pressure on
other bodies. It undertakes research into consumer reactions to, and experience
of, goods and services, publishes reports, advisory booklets and leaflets,
promotes consumer education in schools, produces a monthly magazine,
Focus, and has introduced an informative labelling (Teltag) scheme. (It is
debarred from engaging in comparative testing of products, law enforcement
action or taking up complaints on behalf of individual consumers.) A general

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
advisory service dealing with individual consumers’ problems is provided by
the Citizens’ Advice Bureaux (see p. 122).
Advice to its members on the merits of consumer goods is provided by the
Consumers’ Association (CA), a private body financed by the subscriptions of
members. It arranges tests and makes reports on the quality of goods bought
on the open market and its findings are published in its monthly bulletin
Which?, issued to subscribers. The Research Institute for Consumer Affairs,
established with a grant from the CA, undertakes research into consumer
goods and services, and publishes reports. There are also a number of local
independent consumer groups, which in 1963 formed themselves into a
national Federation of Consumer Groups. Assistance with certain aspects of
consumer guidance is also given by a number of other private bodies and by
certain government departments and local authorities. Individual trades and
industries have also taken measures to raise standards of quality.
The practice of resale price maintenance and its enforcement by cutting off
supplies was made unlawful under the Resale Prices Act 1964; some limited
exemptions for certain classes of goods have been granted by the Restrictive
Practices Court (see p. 242).
16 LABOUR
Less than 200 years ago, government concern with all aspects of employment
was at a minimum. State intervention came first in the sphere of safety, health
and welfare. The first factory legislation was enacted in 1802. The first
effective Factory Act was that of 1833 which set up a national system of
inspection to enforce its provisions. Trade unions—forbidden in the eighteenth
and early nineteenth centuries as a threat to civil peace and individual liberty—
ceased in 1824to be ‘actionable conspiracies in restraint of trade’. During the
nineteenth century new unions of skilled and semi-skilled workers grew up,
more soundly organised than their forerunners and more acceptable to the
public because their ambitions were more restricted. A number of employers’
associations, mainly local, were formed; unions and employers learned to
bargain together; and procedures for conciliation and arbitration began to be
agreed. Legislation passed in the 1870s clarified and regularised the legal
status of trade unions. In 1910, the first employment exchanges were intro¬
duced to provide a national service for putting employers in touch with
workers and vice versa. In 1917 the exchanges were transferred to the newly
created Ministry of Labour. The factory inspectorate was added to its
responsibilities in 1940. This department became the principal instrument of
the Government’s labour policies in Great Britain; it was re-named Depart¬
ment of Employment and Productivity (DEP) in 1968 and took over
responsibility for productivity and prices and incomes policy. In Northern
Ireland employment matters are among the responsibilities of the Ministry of
Health and Social Services.
MANPOWER
The total working population of Great Britain at the middle of June 1968 was
about 25 million, some 47 per cent of the total population, and included
about 73 per cent of persons of normal working age (15 to 59 years for
women, 15 to 64 years for men). About 92 per cent of the men of working
age are today in or seeking gainful work. The remaining 8 per cent consist
mainly of those continuing their education, of the severely disabled and of
some persons of private means. The proportion of women of working age in or
seeking gainful work is much lower, about 53 per cent, as many housewives
either do not wish or cannot manage to take employment outside the home.
Just over half of the women at work are married. Besides those of normal
working age, there are over a million older men and women still at work. The
great majority of the working population work for a wage or salary, but about
1 -7 million are employers or self-employed.
Northern Ireland, which has 27 per cent of the total population of the
United Kingdom, has 2-3 per cent of its working population. The ratio of
working to total population in Northern Ireland is about 40 per cent, and
farmers and smallholders working their own holdings account for about
one-twelfth of the working population.

For demographic reasons the size of the working population increased slowly
between 1959 and 1966 but has since fallen (see Table 36). The reasons
include a tendency for young people to stay longer in full-time education,
a higher proportion of women marrying and interrupting their working life
(many re-enter the working population later on when their family responsibili¬
ties permit), and a reduction in immigration resulting in a change from a net
inflow to a net outflow.
Because of the effect of the lower birth rates in the early 1950s and of the
change in migration patterns, no net growth in the working population
between 1967 and 1973 is expected, and because of the raising of the minimum
school-leaving age in 1973 it is expected to be lower between 1974 and 1976
than it was in 1967. After 1976 the working population is expected to increase
again, so as to show a total increase of some 3 per cent in the period 1967 to
1981, compared with an increase of some 5 per cent between 1956 and 1967.
Though successful development policies in the less-prosperous regions may
raise the numbers above the levels forecast, it is clear that increasing demand
for labour must be met by better deployment of manpower and improved
productivity. Married women form the only substantial reserve and the
Government is studying the nature of the obstacles to employing those who
are willing to work and how they may be overcome.
The industrial distribution of employees in civil employment is shown in
Table 37. Of all employees about 40 per cent are employed in the mining and
manufacturing industries and only about 2 per cent in agriculture and
fisheries, even during the harvest season. Over 55 per cent of those in manu¬
facturing are in the metal, engineering, vehicles and chemicals groups of
industries.
Most industries employ women as well as men though not always for the
same types of work, for example, few women are managers and few personal
secretaries are men. It is illegal to employ women in certain jobs, such as
underground work in coal mines. The industrial groups in which women are

The general unemployment rate in Britain as a whole in the last 25 years has
been among the lowest in the world—usually between 1 and 2 per cent—but
has been somewhat higher since 1966. It has been particularly low in the south¬
east and Midlands of England, and consistently higher in those parts of the
country which have the greatest dependence on shipbuilding, coalmining, and
certain branches of the heavy engineering and metal manufacturing industries,
notably parts of Scotland and Wales, and north-east England and Merseyside.
These areas have been the subject of a series of measures of selective
assistance to stimulate industrial expansion; and, more recently, counter¬
measures have been taken to limit expansion in areas of manpower shortage
(see p. 253). The general unemployment rate in Great Britain in August 1969
was 2-5 per cent; the areas with the highest rates were northern England,
Wales and Scotland.
The total working population of Northern Ireland—including employers and
self-employed but excluding certain unpaid helpers—was about 592,000 in
June 1968 (394,000 males and 198,000 females). The number of insured
employees was 515,000. The largest productive industries are agriculture,
engineering, textiles and clothing. Most of the agricultural work in Northern
Ireland is done without hired help.
The unemployment rate in Northern Ireland has remained higher than in
other parts of the United Kingdom. In July 1969 it was 7-2 per cent of
insured employees. The Ministry of Commerce of the Northern Ireland
Government has wide powers (similar to those in Great Britain) to assist the
development and diversification of industry. It is using these powers
vigorously in an attempt to improve the situation.
EMPLOYMENT, TRAINING AND PRODUCTIVITY SERVICES
The main government employment services are provided in Great Britain
through the country-wide network of over 900 offices of the Department of
Employment and Productivity, which act as employment exchanges. The
services in Northern Ireland are run on similar lines by the Ministry of Health
and Social Services but there are some variations related to the much smaller
area of administration.
The employment exchanges provide a free and confidential service for
employers needing staff and for workpeople, whether or not already in
employment, seeking jobs. Information and advice on any employment
problem is available to all. Employers and employees alike remain free to use
general or specialised fee-charging private employment agencies and direct
recruitment by advertisement or personal introduction. Exchanges, including
the specialist placing services described below, handle the full range of
occupations and deal with full-time, part-time and temporary vacancies.
Details of unfilled vacancies (or of people seeking jobs) can be circulated
quickly in the ‘travel to work’ area, or more widely if necessary. Local employ¬
ment committees, on which employers, workers and other local interests are
represented, are attached to certain employment exchanges as advisory bodies
to secure the full benefit of local knowledge and the close co-operation of
employers and workers.
LABOUR 413
The employment exchanges offer a selective service to certain groups of
employers and employees through specialised registers. All exchanges hold
a Commercial Register of situations vacant and wanted in the distributive
trades, clerical and typing posts, and catering and other services. Over 40 of
the larger exchanges hold a Professional and Executive Register concerned
with senior posts in industry, commerce and the professions both at home
and overseas. There are nearly 30 offices, in places where there are large
groups of hospitals, which have officers specially trained to deal with the
employment problems of nurses, midwives and those in related occupations.
Elsewhere nurses and their employers are dealt with at the local employment
exchange. In view of the increasing number of older persons in the population,
employment exchanges have instructions to make special efforts to find them
employment and to encourage employers to consider older workers on their
merits.
Vocational guidance services for young people and the Disablement
Resettlement Service are described below as is the selection of candidates
for the government vocational training scheme (see p. 416). An Occupational
Guidance Service for adults is available through about 30 units in the main
centres of population. Expert advice is given by specially trained staff to any
persons over the age of 18 in doubt about the kind of work or career for which
they are best fitted.
Employment exchanges holding the Professional and Executive Register
are also ready to give information about the professions and allied occupations
to young men and women considering a career and to older people seeking a
new one, for example, ex-Regular officers of the armed forces.
The DEP’s Regular Forces Resettlement Service helps Regular officers
and other ranks returning to civilian life to find suitable employment. Nearly
all those leaving the Services are successful in securing satisfactory
resettlement.
Youth
Employment
Service
The Youth Employment Service in Great Britain is the responsibility of the
Department of Employment and Productivity and is under the general
direction of the Central Youth Employment Executive (CYEE) composed of
senior officers of the DEP and the education departments. It is operated in
most areas through offices known as Youth Employment Offices or Career
Offices (COs) established by local education authorities in accordance with
schemes approved by the Secretary of State for Employment and Productivity
and 75 per cent of the relevant expenditure of local education authorities is
reimbursed by the DEP.
The service has four main activities: (a) the CYEE produces and circulates
careers literature to schools and careers offices. Careers employment officers
work with teachers in schools to give pupils background knowledge about
careers; (b) COs give vocational guidance in individual interviews; (c)
school leavers are helped to find employment. Career offices also provide
an employment service for any young person seeking work, or employer
seeking young workers; (d) COs follow up the progress of the young people
and give any necessary further advice. In many areas there are specialist
officers to advise the more able young people and the handicapped.
In Northern Ireland the functions of the Youth Employment Service are
similar to those in Great Britain but its organisation is different in that
parliamentary responsibility rests with the Minister of Education and the
service is operated by a statutory board composed of representatives of local
education authorities and other educational and industrial interests. Of the

The Disablement Resettlement Service is designed to help disabled persons
to get and keep suitable work. It is available to anyone over school-leaving age
who is substantially handicapped as a result of injury, disease or congenital
deformity in obtaining or keeping employment. The DEP is responsible for
the administration of the Service and is assisted by the National Advisory
Council on the Employment of the Disabled.
The help given falls under five main headings:
Vocational guidance is given at local offices by specialised disablement
resettlement officers (DROs) in consultation, as necessary, with the local
disablement advisory committees, hospital resettlement clinics and medical
interviewing committees, and also in the industrial rehabilitation units.
Having regard to a disabled person’s qualifications and aptitude and to medical
guidance, the DRO endeavours to find the work most suited to him, with
or without an intervening period of industrial rehabilitation or vocational
training. A Register of Disabled Persons is maintained, and in mid-April
1969 the number registered was nearly 645,000; registration is voluntary. All
employers of 20 or more persons are required to employ a quota (at present
3 per cent for all industries, except shipping, in respect of the manning of
ships) of registered disabled persons. The number of registered disabled
persons unemployed in mid-April 1969 was 68,600.
There are 30 specialised Blind Persons Resettlement Officers (BPROs)
attached to offices of the DEP.
Industrial rehabilitation is provided at 22 units (including one combined
medical/industrial rehabilitation unit) run by the DEP. Their aim is to
provide the final link between sickness and employment by enabling men
and women to adjust themselves gradually to normal working conditions
and to receive vocational guidance based on skilled assessment of their
aptitudes in a practical workshop situation. Attendance at a unit is voluntary
and maintenance allowances are paid. They also provide special short
assessment courses for young people finding it difficult to enter suitable
employment and at some there are work preparation classes for handicapped
school leavers (run in co-operation with local education authorities). The
staff includes a doctor, occupational psychologist, social worker, DRO,
industrially experienced workshop supervisors, and usually a remedial
gymnast, all under the general leadership of a rehabilitation officer.
The Department of Employment and Productivity gives financial assistance
to two centres conducted by voluntary organisations which provide similar
facilities for the blind, to four schemes by other bodies for the rehabilitation
of patients with mental handicaps, and to two centres for spastics.
There are vocational training facilities for the disabled at Government
Training Centres (see p. 416), educational institutions and employers’ estab¬
lishments. For the more seriously disabled there are special residential
training colleges run by voluntary organisations with the financial assistance
and technical help of the DEP. There are also arrangements for the training
of special categories such as the blind, and for providing grants to disabled
persons qualified to undertake study or training for professional or comparable
employment.
Remploy Ltd., a non-profit-making company, provides sheltered employment
for registered severely disabled people who are unlikely to obtain work except

under special conditions. In April 1969 it employed 7,550 severely disabled
men and women in 86 factories. Some 140 home workers were supplied with
work from 8 centres. The directors are appointed by the Secretary of State;
loans and grants for capital development and to meet operational costs are
provided from public funds.
The DEP also gives financial assistance to local authorities and voluntary
organisations towards the cost of providing facilities for sheltered employment
for 2,400 severely disabled sighted workers and for 3,000 blind workers.
The Manpower and Productivity Service of the DEP, set up in 1968, seeks
to bring about the effective use of productive resources and to encourage the
adoption and spread of good management practices. It consists of some 80
manpower advisers, organised on a regional basis, with a central consultancy
service. The Service’s facilities are available free of charge, and one of its
particular interests is in helping industry to improve collective bargaining and
to draw up productivity agreements.
As part of the policy of encouraging geographical mobility of labour within
Britain to balance resources and demands, the Department of Employment
and Productivity makes grants and allowances to help with costs of fares,
temporary lodging and acquisition of and removal to the new home, in
specified instances. They are available to unemployed workers moving to new
employment, and therefore settling, in another area, to key workers transferred
by a firm into a development area to inaugurate a new plant, and unemployed
workers recruited to new plants in development areas and sent to the parent
works for preliminary training.
Commonwealth citizens from overseas are subject to control under the
Commonwealth Immigrants Acts 1962 and 1968 which apply, broadly, to all
Commonwealth citizens1 (except for those who were born in Britain or have
close family links, see p. 12). If they wish to enter Britain to take or seek
full-time employment, they must first obtain a voucher issued by the DEP.
They can apply themselves if they have certain special skills and qualifications
(mainly of professional or graduate standard), or an employer can apply on
behalf of a particular individual. The issue of vouchers to citizens of
independent countries is mainly restricted to those with offers of employment
in manufacturing industries (these restrictions do not apply to citizens of
Malta or of dependent territories). Commonwealth citizens who wish to
work in Northern Ireland, and who are not ‘Northern Ireland workers’,2
need special Northern Ireland employment permits, which are issued only
in respect of definite jobs. (For immigration and community and race relations,
see p. 145.)
Foreigners are admitted to Britain to take up employment provided they
hold a permit issued to the prospective employer by the Department of
Employment and Productivity (the Ministry of Health and Social Services
for Northern Ireland if the proposed employment is in Northern Ireland).
In Great Britain, over 62,000 such permits were issued in 1968. About 16,300
workers, mainly skilled, came to work in industry and commerce, 19,200 to

Ireland but no control is imposed on persons travelling between Ireland and Britain.
2 People qualified by birth and residence to work in Northern Ireland.

work in the hotel and catering industry, 10,000 for domestic work and 7,500
as student employees. Employment is limited to a maximum of one year in
the first instance but may be extended on the employer’s application.
Before a permit is issued, the DEP must be satisfied that there is a vacancy
for which no suitable British or foreign worker already long-resident in
Britain is available, and that the wages and conditions of employment are not
less favourable than those enjoyed by British workers. These conditions are
waived for student employees who are admitted for limited periods in order
to improve their English and to gain a wider knowledge of their occupations.
A foreigner in employment in Britain may not change his job unless his
prospective employer has obtained prior approval from the DEP.
Britain, as a member of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and
Development, participates with 13 European countries in the arrangements
for assisting nationals of the countries concerned to obtain employment in
other member countries.
As part of its plans for increasing productivity in industry the Government is
fostering the expansion and improvement of industrial training. The whole
framework of training in industry and commerce was transformed by the
Industrial Training Act 1964. Under this Act industrial training boards are
appointed to be responsible for the quantity and quality of industrial training
in the industry concerned; up to June 1969, 26 boards had been set up com¬
prising over 15 million employees or about 85 per cent of those in industry
and commerce to whom the Act applies. Each board covers as wide a sector
of industry as possible to reduce costs of administration and simplify prob¬
lems of co-operation between boards. It can provide its own training courses
or arrange for other organisations to provide training. It raises a levy from
employers and makes grants to those whose training it approves. The
Secretary of State meets the initial administrative costs of each board and is
making grants towards certain other expenditure: for example, training
courses for trainers and research projects. To advise the Secretary of State
on the administration of the Act and on industrial training questions generally,
a Central Training Council (CTC) consisting of employer and trade union
members, representatives of nationalised industries, educationists, selected
chairmen of training boards and others with a special interest in industrial
training has been set up. It also advises on the running of the Industrial
Training Service (ITS), which includes assessing training needs both for
industries and individual companies, developing training schemes, and
promoting group training.
The Government Vocational Training Scheme, administered by the
Department of Employment and Productivity, is intended to augment what
industry is doing to overcome shortages of skilled workers in industries of
national importance as well as helping persons in special need, such as the
disabled (see p. 414) and ex-Forces men and women, to fit themselves for
suitable employment. Training is provided for suitable persons over 18 years
of age who are unskilled or whose prospects of work in their existing trade
are poor. (Employed persons as well as the unemployed are accepted for
training in trades of importance to the national economy.) Most of it is done
at Government Training Centres (GTCs), which are within easy reach of the
main industrial centres of the country, and between them offer courses in
over 40 different trades, with emphasis on those in which there is a shortage
of skilled labour. In June 1969 there were 42 GTCs (being increased to 55 by
Special DEP
Services
LABOUR 417
the spring of 1971). Schemes of training for particular trades are agreed with
representatives of the employers and workers concerned.
For the disabled and for ex-Regular Service men and women and the un¬
employed with special resettlement problems, training in trades and
commercial work is also available under the scheme at technical and commer¬
cial colleges and private training establishments or by means of individual
courses at employers’ establishments. For severely disabled persons training
is provided at four residential training colleges run by voluntary organisations
with government financial assistance.
During training, trainees are paid good allowances to maintain themselves
and their dependants. During 1968 more than 13,000 people were trained
under the scheme and over 90 per cent of them were subsequently employed
in the trade for which they had been trained.
Training can also be given in GTCs to workers sponsored by their
employers where it can be fitted in with the DEP’s other training commit¬
ments. The employer continues to pay the trainee’s wages. The DEP arranges
special six-week business training courses for Regulars and ex-Regulars
(mainly ex-officers) at commercial and technical colleges; four-week courses
in industrial supervision are provided at a centre in London for non-technical
warrant officers and senior NCOs (or other Service equivalent ranks). In
addition to full courses for a civilian trade, refresher courses and conversion
courses required for ex-Service men and women can be arranged under the
Vocational Training Scheme.
The DEP also provides assistance with training for firms moving into a
development area or expanding an existing business there. The assistance
includes grants for training carried out by the employer and direct training of
employees on the firm’s premises by staff loaned by the DEP. A new scheme of
grants administered by the industrial training boards has been introduced to
promote craft and technician training in development areas. Grants are
available to employers in these areas (see p. 254) who provide additional
off-the-job training facilities for apprentices or technicians, or otherwise
increase the numbers of such trainees.
A special service to industry is the Department of Employment and Producti¬
vity’s Training Within Industry for Supervisors (TWI) scheme. Its object is
to develop the skill of supervisors in instructing others, in human relations, in
improving methods and in preventing accidents (there are separate pro¬
grammes for each of these). There are special versions of TWI, usually in
courses of a week’s duration, for supervisors employed in offices, retail
distribution and hospitals, and an in-plant training development service
including the training of operatives as instructors. Training Officers of the
DEP either give these courses or train employers’ nominees to enable them to
run TWI courses in their own concerns.
In addition, two-week courses in industrial instructional techniques for the
training of apprentice and trade instructors are available to outside firms (as
well as GTC staff) at the Department of Employment and Productivity’s two
Instructor Training Colleges (one in England and one in Scotland), and at five
Instructor Training Units. A one-week refresher course is available for
instructors likely to benefit.
Vocational training services at GTCs, TWI courses, and courses at
Instructor Training Colleges are available to trainees from overseas under
approved schemes (for instance, those of the ILO or joint DEP/Ministry of
Overseas Development technical assistance).

TERMS OF EMPLOYMENT AND WORKING CONDITIONS
Legislation and There are few restrictions in Britain on the freedom of an employer to hire
Conventions an employee on any terms which the employee will accept. Recent legislation,
however, embodies certain safeguards for the employee. The Terms and
Conditions of Employment Act 1959 provides machinery for enforcing on
an employer the observance of terms or conditions established by collective
agreement in his industry; under the Contracts of Employment Act 1963
employers are required to give their employees written particulars of the
main terms of employment, and both employers and employees are given
rights to minimum periods of notice when employment is to be terminated ;
and under the Redundancy Payments Act 1965 employees with a minimum
period of service of two years are entitled to lump sum payments if their jobs
cease to exist (for example, because of technological improvements or because
of a fall in demand) and their employers cannot offer suitable alternative work,
the cost being partly met from a fund subscribed to by industry as a whole.
Under present law employers are under no legal obligation to recognise a
trade union, or to refrain from refusing to employ trade unionists; nor is a
collective agreement with a trade union held to be in itself a legal contract of
employment, though the terms of a collective agreement may be expressly or
by implication incorporated in an individual contract of employment. How¬
ever, it is by collective agreements that in the majority of trades and industries
minimum or standard wages, normal working hours and other terms of
employment are effectively settled. The negotiation and observance of settle¬
ments continue to depend primarily on the strength, integrity and repre¬
sentative character of the signatory organisations rather than on any legal
sanction. The determination by statute of minimum wages, holidays and
holiday pay is in principle confined to those trades and industries where the
organisation of employers or workers, or both, is inadequate to negotiate
collective agreements and to ensure their observance. (For government
powers embodied in prices and incomes legislation, see p. 236.)
Legislation prescribes minimum standards of safety, health and welfare in
most places of employment; a single comprehensive statute is under
discussion. However, it is recognised that the causes of many accidents are
not amenable to statutory control. Therefore, voluntary action taken by
employer organisations, often in association with trade unions, is encouraged.
The further considerations which affect workers’ satisfaction with their
jobs and promote harmony between employers and employed, which can be
summed up as ‘good human relations’ between management and individual
employees, are hardly susceptible to codification; they have been recognised
for some time and are receiving increasing attention from managements and
from voluntary and official organisations.
Earnings Minimum or standard time rates for the lowest-rated manual workers, as
determined by agreements or by statutory orders, vary between 5s. and
6s. 6d. an hour for men and between 3s. qd. and 5s. 3d. for women. Actual
earnings are usually higher. Higher rates are sometimes paid, and piece rates,1
shift rates and overtime rates raise the level of average earnings.
On the basis of the latest survey in a series conducted half-yearly by the
Department of Employment and Productivity into earnings and hours of
work in manufacturing industries and some leading non-manufacturing

industries throughout Britain, the average earnings of full-time male adult
manual workers in October 1968 were 9s. nd. an hour and £23 a week. Full¬
time women manual workers at the same date earned an average of 5s. nd.
an hour and ^11 6s. a week.
Minimum time rates for women manual workers tend to be set at around
70-90 per cent of the corresponding male rate, though the gap is gradually
closing. Women’s earnings are markedly lower than those of men, partly
because on average they work shorter hours, with less overtime paid at
premium rates, but also because a smaller proportion of women do skilled
work. The Government has announced its intention of implementing the
principle of equal pay and is having talks with the Trades Union Congress
and the Confederation of British Industry about the problems involved.
Earnings in coalmining, not covered by the half-yearly survey, are somewhat
above the average; earnings are about the average in railway work and below
the average in agriculture.
Between 1955 and October 1968 average weekly wage rates increased by
76 per cent and average weekly earnings by in per cent. Part of the increase
has been offset by a rise in prices of about 53 per cent. The trends of manual
workers’ wage rates and earnings, and retail prices from 1955 to 1968 are
shown in the diagram above.
Remuneration in commercial, technical and professional careers is normally
by annual salary, often on a scale carrying annual increases, and such careers
generally afford opportunities for promotion to posts with higher remunera¬
tion. Starting salaries may be in the range of ^800-^1,000 (lower for trainees
in their teens and higher for some graduates entering industry). The average
weekly earnings of male administrative, technical and clerical employees in

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
October 1968 were found by a Department of Employment and Productivity
survey to be ^29 15s. The average weekly figure for females was £15 15s.
Most of the senior posts in business, the professions and the Civil Service
are in the range of £2,750 to £7,000 a year. The posts with salaries in the
range of £8,000 to £15,000 a year include those of Cabinet Ministers, top-
ranking judicial appointments, the highest positions in government depart¬
ments and the largest municipal authorities, editors of daily newspapers,
some persons outstanding in their professions and in the higher managerial
posts in industry, commerce and banking. A few persons in business draw
still higher salaries, while the earnings of star entertainers and certain other
very successful people exceed £20,000 a year.
Women have the same right of entry as men to nearly all public offices,
administrative posts and professions. They are paid the same salary for
doing the same work in journalism, broadcasting and architecture, and as
Ministers of the Crown, members of Parliament, salaried magistrates and
solicitors. Women in independent professions are not expected to charge
lower fees than men. The principle of equal pay applies to non-manual work
in the public sector but remains the exception in private non-manual
employment.
The average earnings of all salaried employees increased by 107 per cent
between 1955 and 1968.
In October 1968 the number of hours actually worked by manual workers
averaged 46-4 for full-time men and 38-3 for women on full-time work. Agreed
weekly hours are mainly in the range 40 to 42 and are generally worked as
either a five-day or a five-and-a-half-day week according to the industry and
the rule of the particular establishment. Hours actually worked by men are
somewhat longer owing to overtime working. While the hours of work of
adult men are not, in general, restricted by statute, normal hours of work for
both sexes and those of all ages are usually within the legal limits on the hours
of women and young persons.
National legislation limits and defines permissible hours of work for
women and young persons in a number of industries or trades—the maximum
permitted, with limited exceptions, being 48 hours a week and 10 hours a
day (9 hours a day for 6-day-week workers) in premises covered by the
Factories Act (see p. 421) for adult women over 18 and young people between
16 and 18; young people under 16 are limited to 44 hours a week. The
employment of women and young people at night is prohibited in industrial
undertakings, except that in certain continuous process industries young men
over 16 may, subject to certain conditions, be so employed.
With a few exceptions, manual workers (including shop assistants) in indus¬
tries covered by agreements or statutory orders are entitled to paid holidays
of at least 12 days or two weeks. Moreover, payment is made for bank or
statutory public holidays, which are as follows: in addition to Good Friday
and Christmas Day, there are bank holidays in most parts of England, Wales
and the Channel Islands on Easter Monday, the last Monday in May or first
in June, the last Monday in August or first in September, and the first
weekday after Christmas (Boxing Day); and in Scotland on New Year’s Day,
the last Monday in May or first in June and the last Monday in August or
first in September.1 Northern Ireland observes all the English holidays and,

in addition, has a holiday on St. Patrick’s Day, 17th March, and on 12th July
(commemorating the Battle of the Boyne, 1690); the Tuesday after Easter is
also a customary holiday for industry and trade. Many agreements provide
that payments should also be made for specially proclaimed holidays.
In some industries agreements provide for extended holidays related to
length of service, work status, or both.
Where statutory wage-regulating machinery exists, it consists of bodies
known as Wages Councils. These are composed of equal numbers of repre¬
sentatives of employers and workers in the respective sectors of industry,
with additional independent members. Wages Councils may submit proposals
for fixing minimum remuneration and holidays with pay to the Secretary of
State who must then make orders giving statutory force to such proposals,
subject only to his right to return them as a whole for further consideration.
The DEP’s Wages Inspectorate helps employers and workers to interpret the
provisions of wage regulation orders and sees that they are complied with.
Agricultural Wages Boards (there are separate Boards for England and
Wales and for Scotland) perform similar functions in relation to employment
in agriculture.
A variety of additional benefits in monetary form exist in varying degree. It
has been estimated that in 1964 13 million employees were covered by
occupational sick pay schemes, and in 1967 12 million by occupational pension
schemes (additional or complementary to the State schemes, see p. 126). A
smaller number are covered by schemes for redundancy payments above the
statutory minimum (see p. 418). Such ‘fringe’ benefits are rather more usual
among clerical and professional employees receiving a standard salary than
among manual workers with a chance to earn overtime and other additions
to their pay. The former also tend to get longer holidays. Senior members
of firms may enjoy the use of a company car. Some firms provide for profit-
sharing.
Employers have a duty at common law to take reasonable care of their
employees and provide a safe system of working, while employees have a
duty of care towards each other. In addition, minimum required standards
of safety in certain kinds of workplaces or work are laid down under a number
of statutes; some of these also deal with health and welfare.
About 213,000 industrial premises (factories, warehouses, shipyards and
docks) come under the Factories Act 1961 (consolidating earlier legislation),
which is administered by the Department of Employment and Productivity
and enforced by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Factories, v/hich forms part of
the DEP. About 700,000 premises come under the Offices, Shops and Railway
Premises Act, which is also administered by the DEP; enforcement is shared
by Her Majesty’s Inspectorate of Factories and local authorities. Under these
Acts, anyone intending to employ other people in industrial or commercial
premises to which they apply has to notify the enforcing authority of his
intention before he begins to employ people and every fatal accident and every
accident causing more than three days’ incapacity must be reported; under the
Factories Act provision is also made for compulsory notification and for
investigation of certain dangerous occurrences.
The Acts are designed to secure the health, safety and welfare of employed
persons, and a wide range of provisions in the Acts and in regulations,
422
Other Work
Premises
Prevention
Advisory Bodies
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
according to the nature of the premises, deal with such matters as: the
fencing of machinery; precautions against fire, dangerous substances and
special risks; the safe condition of the premises, cleanliness, lighting,
temperature and ventilation; and the employment of women and young
persons.
Comparable provision with appropriate variations covers mines and
quarries under the Mines and Quarries Act 1954; two statutes are concerned
with agriculture—the Agriculture (Poisonous Substances) Act 1952 and the
Agriculture (Safety, Health and Welfare Provisions) Act 1956; and specialised
statutes and delegated legislation are concerned with transport—the Railway
Employment (Prevention of Accidents) Act 1900, the Merchant Shipping
Acts, the Road Traffic Acts and the Air Navigation Order and Regulations.
As with the Factories Act these other provisions are, with some exceptions,
enforced through inspectorates—the Mines and Quarries Inspectorate (part
of the Ministry of Power which is responsible for safety in mines and quarries),
the Agricultural Inspectorate of the agricultural departments, and, as regards
railways, the Railway Employment Inspectorate of the Ministry of Transport.
The Board of Trade is responsible for administering the Merchant Shipping
Acts and for safety in air transport (most of the powers in respect of air
worthiness are delegated to the Air Registration Board, see p. 351), and the
Minister of Transport is responsible for road and rail transport safety matters.
There are at present no specific statutory safety requirements in hotels,
places of entertainment or educational establishments, except in so far as
they are covered by fire regulations applicable under local authority by-laws
to all large buildings or (in respect of their offices and shops) by the Offices,
Shops and Railway Premises Act. The Department of Employment and
Productivity has no statutory responsibility in regard to safety in workshops
or laboratories in educational establishments, though it keeps in touch with
university authorities and the education departments. Employers, however,
are bound by their common law obligation to provide a safe system of work,
and employers and educational authorities may voluntarily seek the advice and
help of the Factory Inspectorate, which is given freely on request.
The voluntary accident prevention movement is strongly supported by the
Factory Inspectorate. Inspectors enquire into notified accidents and safety
aspects of machine design and specification, circulate expert advice by personal
exhortation, lectures and literature, and encourage the appointment of safety
officers and the formation of works safety committees. The Factory Inspector¬
ate maintains an industrial health and safety centre in London, at which
various types of machinery demonstrating the effectiveness of guards are
displayed, as well as a wide range of protective clothing and equipment. The
DEP also actively encourages the development of voluntary central organisa¬
tion within each industry at national level for the consideration of safety
matters and the formulation of policy on accident prevention.
Organisations in industry are now concerning themselves to an increasing
extent with the promotion of safety at work and the provision of information
and advisory services to their members. They participate also in joint standing
and advisory committees appointed by the Secretary of State. Representatives
of the Trades Union Congress, the Confederation of British Industry, the
nationalised industries and other interests meet on the Industrial Safety
Advisory Council under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State.

423
Training for safety is an important facet of the accident prevention effort and,
to help in this work, the Department of Employment and Productivity
provides a safety course in its TWI scheme (see p. 417) and the Industrial
Training Boards (see p. 416) include specific provisions for safety training in
their general training recommendations.
The Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents (RoSPA) provides a
variety of safety courses for special needs at its Industrial Safety Training
Centre in Birmingham and elsewhere. Other courses are organised by bodies
such as local accident prevention groups and organisations such as the
Federation of Civil Engineering Contractors. RoSPA also helps the accident
prevention movement by providing publicity and organising conferences; its
corps of Regional Industrial Safety Officers work to promote safety activity
among top-level managers. The British Safety Council also provides publicity
and offers safety training courses.
A substantial amount of research is being done by industry, universities
and other academic bodies, and government research organisations into
problems of guarding machines, ergonomics, safe handling, electrical hazards,
protective personal equipment, construction methods, fires and explosions,
psychological factors and causes of accidents, both generally and in particular
sectors of industry. A register of research into industrial health and safety
matters has been compiled by the DEP to give an indication of the scale and
nature of research being undertaken. Industrial research associations include
amongst their more purely economic research projects the improvement of
working conditions and the reduction of hazards.
The National Coal Board has its own safety organisation—a Standing
Committee on Safety, a chief safety engineer, and safety engineers at divisions,
areas and the largest collieries. It conducts courses of safety training for
workmen and officials and is constantly on the alert for new methods of
reducing risks. Its research programme includes a number of projects with a
direct bearing on safety.
The Minister of Power has a statutory responsibility for research concerning
the safety and health of coal miners. This responsibility is largely exercised
through its Safety in Mines Research Establishment.
To safeguard the many interests which might be adversely affected by the
use of chemicals in agriculture and food storage, a voluntary scheme is
operated by the Government with the help of an advisory committee and with
the full co-operation of the chemical industry.
Transport operators and ministries concerned with road and air travel give
high priority to safety measures affecting crews and passengers. Every
endeavour is made to counter the higher risks resulting from rising traffic
densities, by improving the design of vehicles, transport plant and equipment,
by traffic regulation and control of standards of maintenance and by training
crews in competency and safety awareness.
Local authorities have power, under the Public Health Acts, to regulate the
provision of suitable sanitary accommodation in houses and at places of work
and to treat workplaces which are dirty or badly ventilated or overcrowded
as nuisances the abatement of which can be enforced. Factories, certain other
industrial premises, offices, shops and railway premises must comply with the
health and welfare requirements of the Factories Act or the Offices, Shops and
Railway Premises Act. These include: the cleanliness of workrooms, adequate
ventilation and suitable temperature and lighting, the avoidance of over¬
crowding and the provision of sanitary accommodation, and the protection
IP
424 BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of workers against inhaling harmful dust or fumes; the provision of washing
facilities, lockers or other accommodation for outdoor clothing, drinking
water, first aid, and seats. Legislation concerning safety in other types of
work, for example, agriculture, also prescribes appropriate measures.
The laws restricting the employment of children, young persons and women
form an important part of protective legislation. National legislation, besides
forbidding employment of children under 13 years of age, forbids the
employment of children who have not reached the statutory minimum school¬
leaving age (see p. 153) in any industrial undertaking; of women and young
persons underground in mines and in certain other dangerous occupations
(for example, certain processes connected with lead manufacture); and of
women in factories and workshops within four weeks after childbirth. It also
limits and defines the permissible hours of employment for women and young
persons (see p. 420). Local authorities, moreover, have wide powers under the
Children and Young Persons Acts 1933-63 as well as the Education Acts
1944-48, which regulate hours and conditions of employment of children
under 15 years within their areas within the limits of national legislation.
There are some 1,550 appointed factory doctors1 and some 760 works
medical officers whose duties include the initial and periodic medical examina¬
tion of all young people entering industry, and certain other medical
examinations required under the Factories Act for workers in particular
hazardous trades.
These are the main legislative provisions relating to health and welfare at
work, but it is essential to note that employers frequently achieve standards
considerably higher than those prescribed by law. They are helped to do this
by the inspectorates, by government departments and agencies, by employers’
associations and trade unions and by expert voluntary bodies.
Industrial A number of employers voluntarily maintain medical services for their
Health Services employees over and above the statutory requirements. It is estimated that
there are about 580 factories with doctors providing full-time medical cover
and about 4,500 factories with part-time medical cover. In addition several
thousand nurses are employed in industry.
The big employers, including the State and the boards of nationalised
industries, have naturally taken the lead but a number of smaller factories
also provide medical services and in a few cases have joined together in group
medical services. The Secretary of State is advised on measures to further the
development of industrial health services by the Industrial Health Advisory
Committee which includes members nominated by the Confederation of
British Industry, the Trades Union Congress, the nationalised industries,
the British Medical Association, the Royal College of Nursing and other
organisations closely concerned with the promotion of industrial health.
Occupational hygiene services can give valuable assistance in securing
healthy working conditions in industry. Her Majesty’s Factory Inspectors
give advice on occupational hygiene problems as part of their normal duties.
In addition there are at present four centres in Great Britain (including the
TUC’s Institute of Occupational Health) which undertake studies of
particular problems or health risks and also carry out routine physical,
chemical and biological tests for industry.
Research facilities are provided by government agencies such as the
Medical Research Council; by university faculties of industrial health and
1 A report recommending reorganisation of the Appointed Factory Doctor Service is
currently under consideration.
