social medicine; and by the research departments of various industries and
large industrial concerns. Field investigations are carried out by the Factory
Inspectorate, which has specialised medical and technical branches.
Other types of amenity vary considerably from one firm to another. The
requirements of a factory, office or shop where the work is light, and where
many employers are women or young persons, are different from those of an
iron foundry or steelworks, where much of the work is arduous and is under¬
taken by men. Progressive firms are careful to find out what their employees
want, and welfare policy is often decided in consultation with the workers,
through regular consultative machinery or by other means. An increasing
number of firms pay part or all of the cost of recreational facilities. Some have
their own rehabilitation centres or support convalescent homes. The provision
of low-priced meals at the place of employment has become usual in large
undertakings and quite common in smaller ones. Many offices and shops
which are unable to provide canteen facilities for their staff have adopted
luncheon voucher schemes.
The safety, health and welfare of employees in Northern Ireland have been
the subject of legislation which, with some exceptions, is similar to that in
Great Britain and is embodied in the Factories Act (Northern Ireland) 1965
and the Office and Shop Premises Act (Northern Ireland) 1966. Many firms
voluntarily employ safety officers, and an Industrial Safety Group for the area,
supported by representatives of industry, trade unions, insurance companies
and public authorities, makes a valuable contribution in the field of industrial
accident prevention on similar lines to what is done in Great Britain.
Practically all large industrial firms and many small ones now have a personnel
department staffed by one or more specialist officers. While the form of
organisation of personnel departments varies, personnel officers are generally
responsible for advising all levels of management on every aspect of labour
relations. They also have particular duties with regard to recruitment,
selection, education and training, transfer of labour, the application of wage
agreements, the promotion of good communication and consultation and the
supervision of working conditions and employees’ amenities.
Recruitment and promotion policies are matters which each undertaking
decides for itself, although in some industries the decisions may be limited
by collective agreements or by trade practices. Great importance has recently
been attached to selection; and courses for training personnel officers in
modern interviewing techniques, including the use of test procedures, are
now well attended.
The Manpower and Productivity Service of the DEP (see p. 415) is
available to give advice on personnel policies, personnel management tech¬
niques and problems of human relations at the workplace. It can also assist
in the creation and support of machinery for the negotiation and settlement of
disputes.
Both official and voluntary organisations are concerned with promoting
better human relationships in industry. The Government has sought to
extend by research the available knowledge of the factors influencing human
relations in industry and human efficiency. Such research is sponsored or
conducted by the Social Science Research Council (see p. 203) and the
Medical Research Council (see p. 197). Voluntary organisations include
bodies which deal with management problems and provide a service to
426
INDUSTRIAL
RELATIONS
Employers’
Associations
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
subscribing firms; professional associations, linking individuals with a com¬
mon interest in particular functions of management; and bodies providing
specialist services, usually on a fee-paying basis.
The structure of labour relations in Britain is established mainly on a voluntary
basis, and the extensive changes currently proposed (see below) are
designed to retain the voluntary principle while modernising the conditions
in which it operates. The system will still rest on the organisation of employers
and workers into employers’ associations and trade unions. These organisa¬
tions1 discuss and negotiate terms and conditions of employment and other
matters affecting the workpeople at their work. In some industries these
negotiations are conducted simply by ad hoc meetings, which are held when
necessary; in others, voluntary joint machinery has been established on a
permanent basis. Industry-wide agreements are commonly supplemented by
further agreements at firm or factory level. Normally these arrangements for
collective bargaining suffice to settle all questions which are raised, but
provision is often made for matters not so settled to be referred for settlement
to independent arbitration; nowadays this provision is seldom used. The
machinery for settlement in certain trades where wages cannot be effectively
controlled by voluntary agreement has already been described (see p. 421).
The existence of these employers’ and employees’ bodies facilitates liaison
between the Government and industry on labour matters in which they have
a common interest (though it does not preclude individual contact). Standing
arrangements exist for consultation at national level between the Government,
the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), the Trades Union Congress
(TUC) (see pp. 427 and 428) and the nationalised industries through the
National Joint Advisory Council, which was set up in 1939 to advise the
Government on matters in which employers and workers have a common
interest. It meets under the chairmanship of the Secretary of State.
In January 1969 the Government announced (Cmnd. 3888) its proposals
for implementing some of the recommendations of the Royal Commission on
Trade Unions and Employers’ Associations (Cmnd. 3623). The principle is
to be recognised that every worker has a right to membership of a trade union;
new machinery is to be created to resolve disputes arising from refusal of
employers to recognise or negotiate with trade unions, or from inter-union
rivalries, and to consider complaints by individuals against trade unions;
registration of procedural agreements at the level of firm or factory (if they
cover an appreciable number of workers) is to be introduced; the Government
is to have power, under specific conditions, to impose a ‘conciliation pause’
or require a ballot of a trade union’s members before declaration of a strike;
and a Commission for Industrial Relations (CIR) is to form a focus for study
and development of improved industrial relations. Some of these changes
require legislation, but the CIR started work in March 1969 on a non-statutory
basis, and registration by the Manpower and Productivity Service of the DEP
of collective agreements has been introduced on a voluntary basis for companies
with 5,000 or more employees.
Many employers in Great Britain are members of employers’ organisations
wholly or partly concerned with labour questions. The primary aims of such
organisations are to help to establish suitable terms and conditions of
1 Some employers, including the central Government and the public corporations
operating the nationalised industries, negotiate directly with the trade unions repre¬
senting their different types of employees.
LABOUR
The Confederation
of British
Industry
Trade Unions
427
employment, including a sound wage structure and proper standards of
safety, health and welfare; to promote good relations with employees and
the efficient use of manpower; and to provide means of settling any disputes
which may arise. Different employers’ organisations vary in the emphasis
which they put upon these different aims and in the means by which they try
to achieve them. Although the negotiation of wages and working conditions
and the settlement of disputes remain their essential function, the majority
of the organisations provide help and advice on many aspects of industrial
relations, with the aim of developing positive employment policies and
promoting productivity.
There is diversity of structure as well as function. Generally, however,
employers’ organisations are organised on an industry basis rather than a
product basis. Some are purely local in character and deal with a section of
an industry; others are national in scope and are concerned with the whole
of a particular industry. In some of the chief industries there are local or
regional organisations combined into national federations, while in others,
within which different firms are engaged on making different principal
products, there is a complex structure with national and regional federations
for these different sections of the industry as well as for the industry as a
whole. Although there are some 1,360 employers’ organisations dealing with
labour matters, about 90 of these are national employers’ associations, many
of which are in membership of the OBI and are the ones that negotiate the
important national collective agreements with trade unions.
The final authority of a local or small national organisation may be a meeting
where all member firms are directly represented; but in larger organisations
some form of indirect representation is necessary, either through local
organisations or through regions or sections into which these are grouped.
The representatives thus chosen, together with a number of office holders,
form a general council or central committee, which meets perhaps once a
quarter, mainly to make major policy decisions, to elect committees and to
ratify their work. A small paid staff under a director or secretary carries out
the organisation’s day-to-day work. There is usually a small working group,
consisting of senior officials and committee chairmen, which meets to deal
with urgent questions and co-ordinate the work of committees.
The central body of employers’ organisations is the CBI, which deals with
all matters (not only labour relations) affecting the interests of organised
employers and represents them nationally to the Government and the public
and also internationally, for instance, in the International Labour Organisa¬
tion. CBI representatives sit on various government advisory committees, on
other statutory bodies and on a number of voluntary bodies concerned with
labour matters.
In nearly all industries and occupations some workers—and in some industries
nearly all workers—are organised into trade unions. These have grown up
gradually and independently over a great many years, and consequently, their
form and organisation vary considerably as do their traditions and attitudes,
for example, their degree of concern with political movements. Trade unions
started more than two hundred years ago among the skilled craftsmen and
spread later to the general labouring and unskilled classes. More recently
trade unionism has increased among clerical, supervisory, technical and
administrative workers. A number of associations of professional workers,
formed primarily for the preservation and improvement of professional
standards, have also come to exercise many of the functions of trade unions,
428
Trades Union
Congress
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
including negotiations on salary and fee scales, and are legally trade unions.
The qualification for membership of some unions is occupational (for
instance, they may recruit clerks or fitters wherever employed), while in others
the qualification is industrial (that is, they seek to recruit all persons in an
industry, whatever their occupation). In a number of unions recruitment is
based on a combination of these principles. A few large unions recruit
members in a number of different occupations and industries.
At the end of 1967 the total membership of British trade unions was just
under 10 million. There were 555 unions, but nearly 70 per cent of all trade
unionists were in the 19 largest unions, while just over a half were in the
nine unions with a membership of over 250,000. The number of trade
unionists has increased during the last decade but the number of unions has
gone down owing to amalgamations.
The basic unit of organisation in most British trade unions is the local
branch (sometimes called a lodge). Every member of the union belongs to a
branch. He may attend its meetings, make suggestions about terms and
conditions of employment, discuss the work of the union, and take part in the
election of the union’s officers. The branch takes action on certain matters
considered to be entirely, or mainly, of local interest and forwards its views on
wider issues for action by the union’s national or regional bodies. Many
unions also have shop stewards or other representatives at the place of work
to enrol members and collect dues, to ensure that local and national agreements
operate satisfactorily, to take up individual problems with management
and to keep the union informed of developments at the workplace. Only in a
few trade unions is organisation based primarily on the place of work.
In most large unions the central organisation is along the following lines:
elected officials, including a general secretary assisted by clerical and specialist
staff, are in charge of the work of the head office and are responsible to an
elected national executive council or committee which may be part-time or
full-time, and which is responsible to annual or biennial conferences of
delegates from the branches. Executive committees or councils play an
important part in the government of the unions; between conferences they
are the highest authorities and carry out policy decisions made by delegates.
Most unions also have some regional, district or area organisation.
Trade unions may affiliate to one or more federations or confederations
whose main purpose in most cases is to represent all or most of the trade
unions in an industry in negotiations with employers. The scope and authority
of these federations and confederations vary greatly.
In Britain the national centre of the trade union movement is the TUC, which
celebrated its centenary in June 1968. The TUC’s objects are to promote
the interests of its affiliated organisations and to improve the economic and
social conditions of the workers. Its membership comprises 160 organisations,
some of which are themselves federations of smaller organisations. Together
they represent about 8-73 million workpeople. The TUC deals with all
general questions which concern trade unions both nationally and inter¬
nationally and gives assistance on questions relating to particular trades or
industries at the request of the trade union concerned.
The congress of delegates, which constitutes the TUC proper, meets for a
week every year to discuss matters of general interest to trade unionists and
to employees generally. It elects annually a General Council which represents
it during the remaining 51 weeks of the year. This is responsible for carrying
out congress decisions, for watching economic and social developments, for
providing educational and advisory services to unions, and for presenting to
D
Scottish Trades

labour 429
the Government the trade union viewpoint on economic, social and industrial
issues. It is also empowered to mediate in inter-union disputes in certain
circumstances and, through the General Council’s Incomes Policy Com¬
mittee, to comment on claims for improvements in wages and working
conditions notified to the TUC by affiliated unions. A further enlargement of
its functions was agreed between the Government and the General Council
in June 1969. The General Council undertook to use its powers, strengthened
by a special congress held in the previous month, to deal with unauthorised
and unconstitutional stoppages of work.
The TUC is a non-political body but under the Trade Union Act 1913
individual trade unions can, by a ballot vote of members, decide to set up a
political fund, financed by a separate levy, which any member can refuse to
pay without loss of his normal union rights and benefits. About 100 separate
trade union organisations, including most of the largest trade unions, have
such a fund and, in most cases, it is used to support the Labour Party.
Both the TUC and many unions conduct extensive educational services for
members, mainly concerned with industrial subjects, trade unionism and
industrial relations principles and practice.
Branches of various trade unions in a locality generally affiliate to a local
trades council, which acts as a forum for the discussion of matters of common
interest and as a local agent of the TUC, by which it is registered each year.
There are just over 500 trades councils in England and Wales alone, grouped
together in 22 federations.
Affiliation to the TUC is open to all trade unions anywhere in the United
Kingdom, but Scottish trade unionists have their own national centre, the
Scottish Trades Union Congress, similar within its objects to the TUC. The
Scottish TUC, to which trade unions may affiliate in respect of their member¬
ship in Scotland (a number of unions are affiliated to both bodies), also accepts
affiliation from trades councils and has an affiliated membership of about
842,000. It holds an annual congress and has consultations with the Govern¬
ment on issues affecting Scottish trade unionists.
In most of the main industries there are, at national level, joint committees
(sometimes referred to as joint negotiating machinery) composed of represen¬
tatives of employers and trade unions. Their functions vary considerably,
some being simply negotiating bodies, while others deal with a wide range of
subjects affecting the interests of the industry concerned. Provision is
sometimes made in their constitution that a dispute on which it is not found
possible to reach agreement should be referred to some form of conciliation
or arbitration by independent persons, including the means provided under
the Conciliation Act 1896, or the Industrial Courts Act 1919.
Collective agreements between employers’ associations and trade unions are
not civil contracts between particular employers and employees, and are not
in themselves enforceable at law. Observance of agreed terms and conditions
is based mainly on the good faith of employers and the mutual respect and
vigilance of trade unions and employers’ organisations, but can be secured in
particular instances through reference to the Industrial Court.
Arrangements for negotiation and joint consultation also exist at district and
factory level in many industries, where matters are discussed either between
the appropriate representatives of the two sides on an ad hoc basis, or through
regular machinery provided by District Joint Industrial Councils or similar
bodies and Works Councils. Such bodies discuss how agreements reached at
43°
State Provision
for Conciliation,
Arbitration and
Investigation
Strikes and
Lockouts
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
a national level may be applied to their district or factory, but as a rule have
no power to alter the terms of such national agreements. They also discuss
new problems which may arise, and if no solution can be found at factory or
district level, refer them to the national body.
Matters which prove difficult to settle by negotiation are sometimes referred
by agreement to independent conciliators or arbitrators, and one way in which
the parties can find such persons is by invoking the help of the Secretary of
State. Under authority derived from the Conciliation Act 1896, and the
Industrial Courts Act 1919, the Secretary of State has certain powers to assist
industry to settle disputes which it is not found possible to resolve through an
industry’s own machinery and procedure. These powers are all intended to
supplement and not to supersede the industry’s own machinery. There is no
legal obligation on the parties to a dispute to notify the dispute to the Secretary
of State nor to place the question before a conciliator.
The Department of Employment and Productivity assists with conciliation
in industry through its Industrial Relations Division and the field staff of the
Manpower and Productivity Service, who keep in touch with the course of
relations between employers and workers at national, district and, in some
cases, factory level and assist them, if requested, to settle their problems by
joint discussion and negotiation. Conciliators have no legal powers.
Disputes which cannot be settled in this way may, at the request of both
parties, be referred to voluntary arbitration, either by a single arbitrator, or
an ad hoc Board of Arbitration, or by the Industrial Court, a permanent
tribunal established under the Industrial Courts Act. The court normally
consists of three members—the president, one member experienced in
representing employers and one in representing workpeople.
Like collective agreements, arbitration awards are not in themselves
enforceable at law, but under the Terms and Conditions of Employment
Act 1959, reports that a particular employer is not observing the recognised
terms or conditions of employment in his trade or industry may be made to
the Secretary of State by organisations which are parties to the relevant
agreement or award. If the matter is not otherwise settled, the Minister must
refer it to the Industrial Court which, after hearing the case, may issue an
award requiring the employer to observe the recognised terms or conditions.
Such an award becomes an implied term of the contract of employment of
individual employees and so enforceable at law.
The Secretary of State is also empowered to appoint a Court of Inquiry or
Committee of Investigation into a dispute, whether existing or apprehended.
These procedures are primarily means of informing public opinion of the
facts of a dispute (the report of a Court of Inquiry has to be laid before
Parliament). Although the recommendations contained in the reports of such
bodies are not binding on the parties, they often provide the basis for further
negotiations leading to a settlement.
Over the past 30 years the number of working days lost each year through
stoppages of work arising from industrial disputes, that is through strikes and
lockouts, has been on an average about 2| million which, taking the working
population as a whole, works out at approximately one hour per worker per
year. These figures, however, only record the time lost at establishments
where strikes actually take place; they take no account of the effect in other
establishments or industries. Nevertheless, the time lost through strikes is very
much less than that lost on account of sickness, accidents and absenteeism and
Communica¬

Labour

Public

Central and Local

labour 431
Britain’s record over the past ten years or so compares favourably with that of
most other industrial countries.
Strikes in Britain are not in general caused by a breakdown in the collective
bargaining machinery. This on the whole works smoothly and well. In fact
it is estimated that about 95 per cent of all strikes, accounting for between
60 and 70 per cent of the time lost through strikes, are the result of unofficial
(and usually unconstitutional) action.
These unofficial strikes are therefore symptoms of a breakdown in relations
between management and workers at the place of work itself. The problem of
securing a fundamental improvement in relations between employers and
workers and the loyal observance of agreements and constitutional procedures
freely negotiated is currently the subject of public discussion as well as in
industry generally, but it seems likely that there is no single solution.
Joint consultation in industry is based on the understanding that the work
force needs to have a proper comprehension of management’s aims and plans
if they are to co-operate in achieving and carrying them out. A wide range of
subjects can be fruitfully discussed by joint consultative committees including
hours of work (within the framework of agreements), safety and health,
productivity, absenteeism, labour turnover, training and education, and
amenities generally. These committees are usually kept informed about the
state of the firm’s business, and consider problems resulting from decisions
to change production methods. It has been generally agreed by both manage¬
ment and trade unions to exclude from these discussions all questions relating
to wages and conditions of employment, but developments in productivity
bargaining have tended to blur this distinction. In a number of instances such
bargaining at plant level has resulted in a merging of negotiation procedures
and joint consultation.
While labour relations in government service and in the nationalised industries
are, in general, organised on the same principle as in private industry, there
are some special features.
Non-industrial employees in central government service, where salaries and
conditions of service are dealt with by the Civil Service Department (see
p. 47) are permitted and encouraged to join the appropriate Civil Service
staff associations (trade unions) and there is a highly developed system of
negotiation and joint consultation by means of the National and Depart¬
mental Whitley Councils (see p. 64). If there is failure to reach agreement by
negotiation a department or association may, subject to certain limitations,
report the dispute to the Secretary of State for reference to the Civil Service
Arbitration Tribunal, an independent body appointed by the Secretary of
State by powers under the Industrial Courts Act 1919. Industrial employees
of the central Government are organised by trades and not by departments;
negotiations regarding their wages and conditions of employment take place
on Trade Joint Councils and unresolved matters are referred to the Industrial
Court for arbitration. In the major employing departments, Departmental
Joint Councils also exist for the discussion of matters other than trade
questions which are of mutual concern to the department and its industrial
employees (and which are domestic to the department).
In local government service there are separate National Joint Councils for
the main grades of employees (such as manual, clerical and technical
432
Nationalised
Industries
Northern
Ireland
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
employees) which deal with wages and conditions of service as well as other
matters. There are corresponding regional and district councils.
In the nationalised industries, the main corporations, though not subject to
detailed governmental control, have a statutory duty to establish satisfactory
arrangements for collective bargaining in their industries and for joint
consultation with their employees; but in carrying out these duties they are
free to choose suitable arrangements. The main difference from private
industry is that the corporations are not usually members of employers’
associations (although the majority are ‘industrial associates’ of the CBI). In
some industries they are sole or main employers, but even where part of the
industry is in private hands, as for example in road transport, the corporations
are separately and directly represented on wage-negotiating bodies.
Wages and conditions of service in the nationalised industries are generally
settled by negotiation between representatives of managements and trade
unions at the national level; in most cases there are also regional and local
bodies, similarly representative, to deal with local implications. Most of the
industries use the facilities for arbitration offered to industry generally by the
Department of Employment and Productivity but coalmining and rail
transport have their own special arrangements. Consultations at all levels,
including the workplace level, have been arranged in all the nationalised
industries according to the traditions and needs of each industry.
Some of the nationalised industries have felt that joint consultation was
best carried out by their negotiating bodies; others have established separate
and specially constituted joint committees at all levels.
The system of labour relations in Northern Ireland is based on the same
principles as that of Great Britain and the Minister of Health and Social
Services has powers and duties similar to those of the Secretary of State in
Great Britain. Nearly 90 per cent of trade unionists in Northern Ireland are
members of trade unions with headquarters in Great Britain.
17 SOUND AND
TELEVISION
BROADCASTING
Broadcasting of sound and of television in the United Kingdom is regulated
by the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications, formerly the Postmaster
General, under the Wireless Telegraphy Acts 1949-1967, which prohibit the
sending or receiving of radio communications, except under licence.
Sound broadcasting services are provided solely by the British Broadcasting
Corporation (BBC), which was established as a public corporation by Royal
Charter in 1927. Television services are provided both by the Corporation
and by the Independent Television Authority (ITA), which was established
by the Television Act 1954.
Users of sound and television sets must obtain an annual receiving licence,1
which can be bought from most post offices. There were some 17-9 million
receiving licences current in Britain in June 1969 of which more than 15-4
million were for sound and television combined and 2-4 million (including
a million for sets fitted in cars) for sound only. The cost of receiving licences
is £6 for sound and television combined (£11 for sound and colour television),
and £1 5s. for sound broadcasting alone. One licence covers all receiving sets
in a household, but a separate licence is required for a set fitted in a car.
Registered blind people are entitled to free sound licences, or to combined
licences at a reduced rate and special licences at reduced rates are available
for radio and television dealers’ business premises, and for retired people
resident in old persons’ homes.
Broadcasting The constitution and finances of the BBC are governed by the Royal Charter
Authorities of 1964 and the Licence and Agreement of 1969 and those of the ITA by the
Television Act 1964 and its 1969 Licence. Both the Royal Charter and the
1964 Act define the services of the BBC and ITA as a ‘public service’ with
the purpose of disseminating information, education and entertainment.
The BBC and the ITA are independent authorities in the day-to-day
operations of broadcasting, including programmes and administration. The
Government, however, retains ultimate control, and the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications, as the responsible minister, is answerable to Parliament
on broad questions of policy and may issue directions to the BBC and the
ITA on a number of technical and other subjects. Both organisations are
expected to show balance and due impartiality in their general presentation of
programmes—particularly where matters of public policy or controversial
subjects are concerned—and in this connection the Minister has powers to
prohibit the broadcasting of any particular matter or class of matter, or to
revoke the licences of the BBC or ITA at any time. These powers, however,
are treated as major reserve powers and, in fact, no formal veto has ever been
1 The Government announced in August 1969 that from April 1971 the sound only
licence, including those for car radios, would be abolished, and that the combined
licence fee would be raised to £6 10s.
434
The British

The Independent

BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
placed on the broadcasting of a particular item. Both the BBC and the ITA
are required to prepare annual reports and accounts which are presented to
Parliament.
The number of hours of television broadcasting are regulated by the
Minister and an arrangement has been approved which permits any one service
a basic maximum of 53 J hours a week (32 hours a week for BBC 2), but with
additional hours for outside broadcasts, religious and educational programmes,
and broadcasts in the Welsh language. In 1969 the BBC was broadcasting
about 65 hours of programmes from London in its domestic sound services
during a normal weekday.
The Corporation consists of 12 governors (including a chairman, a vice-
chairman and separate national governors for Scotland, Wales and Northern
Ireland), each appointed for a period of not more than five years by the
Queen on the advice of the Government. The governors, who are constitu¬
tionally responsible for the conduct of the whole broadcasting operation,
including the content and presentation of the programmes in sound and
television, and the provision and working of the necessary installations and
equipment, appoint the chief executive officer of the BBC—the Director
General, with whom they discuss all major matters of policy and finance.
A number of councils exist to advise the governors: they include the
General Advisory Councils and the regional advisory councils for the English
regions and for Northern Ireland which must be appointed under the terms
of the Charter, and a number of other councils and committees not specifically
required by the Charter but established by the BBC to advise on such matters
as religious broadcasting, charitable appeals, music, agriculture, school broad¬
casting, further education, programmes for immigrants, science and engineer¬
ing. The National Broadcasting Councils for Scotland and Wales control the
policy and content of sound and television programmes intended primarily
for reception in their respective countries. Local broadcasting councils,
representative of the local community, have been appointed by the former
Postmaster General (in consultation with the BBC) to help in the development
of local radio stations. The Corporation’s Board of Management consists of
the Director General; the Managing Director, Television; the Managing
Director, Radio; the Managing Director, External Broadcasting; the Director
of Programmes, Television; the Directors of Administration, Finance, Public
Affairs, and Engineering; and the Editor, News and Current Affairs.
The services of the BBC are financed from: an annual grant voted by
Parliament, for the domestic services, "which is the income from the sale of
broadcast receiving licences less certain deductions for collection and other
expenses; an annual grant-in-aid voted by Parliament, for the external
services; and profits from BBC publications, mainly the Radio Times, which
has a weekly sale of about 3-9 million copies and attracts a large advertising
revenue; and income from BBC Radio and Television Enterprises. The
net revenue from the sale of licences for the year ended March 1969
amounted to j£8o-6 million and the grant for the external services was ^11
million. The cost of providing the local radio services is raised partially from
local sources.
The Independent Television Authority consists of a chairman, a deputy
chairman and, at present, nine other members (three of whom have special
responsibility for Scotland, Wales and Monmouthshire, and Northern Ireland
severally) whose appointment is in the hands of the Minister of Posts and
Telecommunications. The ITA owns and operates the transmitting stations,

but the production studios and equipment are owned, and the actual pro¬
grammes are provided, by programme companies appointed by the ITA.
Fifteen programme companies are at present under contract: Anglia Televi¬
sion Limited; ATV Network Limited; Border Television Limited; Channel
Television Limited; Grampian Television Limited; Granada Television
Limited; Harlech Television Limited; London Weekend Television Limited;
Scottish Television Limited; Southern Independent Television Limited;

News Limited, a non-profit-making company in which all the programme
companies are shareholders.
The Authority has controlling and regulatory powers of a wide and
important character over the content and quality of programmes: for example,
it ensures that a ‘proper balance’ of views is expressed and has drawn up a
code on violence stating that special precautions are to be taken when children
are likely to be viewing. There are also safeguards in the Television Act 1964
to prevent newspaper shareholdings in a programme company leading to
results contrary to the public interest. However, the ITA believes that
newspapers bring valuable qualities to the development of television and is
not opposed to investment by them.
In the discharge of its duties the ITA is advised by a General Advisory
Council and by committees on educational broadcasting, religious broad¬
casting, charitable appeals and advertising. A specialist panel advises on
medical and allied advertisements.
The chief executive officer of the ITA is the Director General. There are
also two deputy directors general, and a headquarters and regional office staff
covering all technical and administrative services. Regional officers act as
representatives of the ITA to the programme companies.
There is an Independent Television Companies Association, a body
designed for joint discussion and action by the companies. It is particularly
concerned with advertising policy, in co-operation with the ITA.
The ITA receives no payments from licence revenue; the finance for its
operations is drawn from annual rental payments made to it by the programme
companies amounting to about £7-5 million in the year ended March 1969.
In return for the valuable public concession enjoyed, the programme com¬
panies also paid to the ITA for transfer to the Exchequer a further sum
(the levy) related to their advertising revenue; this amounted to about
£25-js million during the same period.
The BBC operates, nationally, four domestic sound broadcasting services,
two television services, and the external broadcasting services. The ITA
provides one television service.
Each of the separate, but inter-related, domestic sound services has its own
characteristics.1 Radio 1 (broadcasting 20J hours a day partly in conjunction
with Radio 2) provides a programme of continuous popular music while
Radio 2 provides light music and entertainment programmes. On average,
three-quarters of the daily radio audience listen to these services. Radio 3
includes the Music Programme (which provides a range of classical music for

some 10 hours during the day); the Third Programme, which offers works of

service on Saturday afternoons. Radio 4 (broadcasting 17 hours a day) is a
general programme providing the principal news and information services of
the BBC. In addition a wide range of music and drama is presented; broad¬
casts for schools are an important feature. The various regions of Britain have
their own version of the service.
Local radio is at present provided by the BBC in eight towns,1 Brighton,
Durham, Leeds, Leicester, Merseyside, Nottingham, Sheffield and Stoke. The
stations, transmit daily about six hours of programmes of particular interest to
the local community which they serve in addition to their output from the
BBC network.
In 1936 the BBC launched the world’s first regular public service by high
definition television. It now transmits two services: BBC 1, which is trans¬
mitted on 405 lines on very high frequency (VHF) and is available to over
99 per cent of the population of Britain; and BBC 2, which is transmitted on
625 lines on ultra-high frequency (UHF) and is available to about three-
quarters of the population. During 1967 the first regular colour television
service in Europe began on BBC 2. A duplicate BBC 1 service with colour is
to be introduced on 625 lines on UHF by 1970.
Productions on BBC television include talks and documentary programmes,
drama and films, sport and outside broadcasts, light entertainment, music,
family programmes, broadcasts for schools, educational programmes for
adults, and religious programmes. Provision is also made for programmes for
minority interests—an aspect of broadcasting which has been facilitated by
the introduction of BBC 2.
In the course of a year, the BBC television service broadcasts on a national
network for some 6,100 hours. Some 16,000 of its programmes are exported
annually to 88 overseas countries, including those in eastern Europe.
The external broadcasting services of the BBC are intended to provide a link
of culture, information and entertainment between the peoples of the United
Kingdom and those in other parts of the world; to report events of world-wide
importance with speed, accuracy and objectivity; and generally to reflect
British opinion and the British way of life. These services, which reach a
growing audience,2 broadcast in English and in 38 other languages for some
700 hours a week.
There are two divisions of the external services, one responsible for all the
transmitted output and the other concerned with programme production.
The Services Division comprises: the English Network, which includes the
World Service, broadcasting for 24 hours a day; the African Service, providing
programmes in Hausa, Somali and Swahili; the Arabic Service for the Middle
East and North Africa; the Eastern Service, providing programmes in
Bengali, Burmese, Hindi, Persian, Sinhala, Tamil and Urdu; the Far Eastern
Service, providing programmes in Cantonese, Standard Chinese (Kuoyu),
Indonesian, Japanese, Malay, Thai and Vietnamese; the Latin-American
Service, broadcasting in Spanish and Portuguese; the French Service to
Europe and Africa; the Central European Service, broadcasting in Czech,

Slovak, Hungarian, Polish and Finnish; the East European Service, broad¬

The Programme Division includes the External Services News Department,
which produces more than 150 news bulletins daily; the Talks and Features
Department, which supplies talks and documentary programmes; and the
English by Radio and Television Department, which broadcasts some 230
programmes of English lessons weekly, with explanations in 27 other
languages, and supplies recorded lessons to some 270 stations in 80 countries.
English by Television programmes, produced for teaching purposes, have
been shown in more than 50 countries.
In addition to the direct transmission, many programmes are produced and
recorded for distribution and sale to overseas radio stations. The Transcrip¬
tion Service, for instance, records nearly 500 hours of sound programmes
annually, and the Topical Tapes Service produces 16 weekly programme
series which are sent to more than 60 subscribing stations.
Another part of the external services is the Monitoring Service which
listens to and reports on foreign broadcasts. It works in collaboration with its
United States counterpart under an exchange agreement which gives virtually
world-wide coverage, and thus makes available speedy and accurate reports
or significant news and comment from overseas to the BBC, the Press, and
government departments.
Programme links, both permanent and temporary, are generally rented by
the BBC from the Post Office, although some are provided by the BBC with
Post Office agreement. The operation and maintenance of the transmitting
stations from which its various programmes are sent out are, however, solely
a BBC responsibility. For the domestic sound services there are 69 medium-
and long-wave transmitters in normal programme service at 45 transmitting
stations and 222 YHF transmitters at 73 stations, plus 9 VHF transmitters at
experimental local broadcasting stations. There are 105 television trans¬
mitting stations in use for BBC 1 and 40 for BBC 2. In addition, 68 trans¬
mitters are used for external broadcasting, 44 of which are in the United
Kingdom and 24 overseas for relay purposes—the latest of which is a new
medium-wave transmitter on the island of Masirah off the coast of Muscat
and Oman, which will greatly improve the reception of the Arabic, Persian and
world (in English) services between Saudi-Arabia and the Indian sub-continent.
For its domestic sound programmes, the BBC uses 151 studios, of which
60 are in London and 91 at various centres in the regional areas. The external
services use 44 London studios. In addition, there are 40 semi-automatic
studios which can be operated by programme officials without engineering
staff. BBC television productions come from main studios at the Television
Centre in west London and other studios in various parts of London, and
from fully equipped regional studios at Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff,
Glasgow and Manchester. A number of small interview studios have, in
addition, been established throughout the country. The Television Film
Department of the BBC is housed at the Ealing Film Studio, and television
news and newsreel programmes originate from Alexandra Palace, London.
Outside broadcasting is covered by a number of mobile units.

The first regular independent television (ITV) service was inaugurated in
x955 ^ a programme transmission from the ITA London station at Croydon.
Programmes are now transmitted on 405 lines on VHF from 32 stations
throughout Britain reaching more than 98 per cent of the population—
programme links being provided by the Post Office. From 15th November
1969, duplicate ITV programmes with colour will be introduced on 625 lines
on UHF in certain areas, to be followed in 1970 and 1971 with coverage of
further areas.
The main items broadcast in an average week by the programme companies
(which are subject to the same limitations on the number of broadcasting
hours as BBC 1) are films, entertainment programmes, plays and serials,
talks, discussions and documentaries, sport, and children’s and educational
programmes. More than one-third of viewing time is filled with ‘serious’
programmes.
Each programme company submits its quarterly programme schedule to
the ITA, and the ITA is also consulted about the content and timing of
individual programmes.
The programme companies broadcast for some 3,500 hours a year in each
region. Overseas sales of independent television programmes total about
16,000 a year.
Independent television programmes are produced at studio centres in Aber¬
deen, Belfast, Birmingham, Bristol, Cardiff, Carlisle, Dover, Glasgow, Leeds,
London, Manchester, Newcastle, Norwich, Plymouth, St. Helier, and
Southampton. The establishment of these studios is the direct result of the
ITA’s policy of encouraging the development of regional television, and the
programmes are designed for either local or national broadcasting.
Broadcasts on political issues include a daily factual and impartial account of
proceedings in Parliament, transmitted on BBC’s Radio 4 when Parliament
is in session, and weekly reports on the same subject broadcast on BBC 2 and
on ITN; and there is frequent coverage of political subjects in current affairs
programmes. Ministerial and party political broadcasts are also transmitted
from time to time under rules agreed between the major political parties,
the BBC and the ITA.
In 1968 experimental closed-circuit sound broadcasts of the proceedings
of both Houses of Parliament, and a three-day closed-circuit experiment of
televising the proceedings of the House of Lords, were carried out.
The BBC does not give publicity to any individual firm or organised interest
except when it is necessary to provide effective and informative programmes
under the terms of the Charter. It must not broadcast sponsored programmes
or, without the consent of the Minister of Posts and Telecommunications,
broadcast any matter for payment. Advertisements are broadcast on indepen¬
dent television subject to the relevant provisions in the Television Act, in
particular that there should be no sponsoring of programmes by advertisers,
that all advertisements should be clearly distinguishable as such and
recognisably separate from the programme, and the amount of time given to
advertising should not be so great as to detract from the value of the pro¬
grammes as a medium of information, education and entertainment. The
ITA has drawn up a code governing standards and practice in advertising,
giving guidance about the types and methods of advertisement that may not
be used. Certain types of advertising are prohibited, notably that of cigarettes
SOUND AND TELEVISION BROADCASTING

echnical

(under a government ruling of 1965) and for betting. Advertisements may
not be inserted in certain types of programmes, for example, in broadcasts to
schools. The cost of inserting advertisements in the ITA service is borne by
the advertisers, who pay the programme companies for advertising time.
The Minister of Posts and Telecommunications is advised on the technical
aspects of television and VHF sound broadcasting by the Television Advisory
Committee, which consists of an independent chairman, the Director General
of the BBC, the Director General of the ITA, representatives from the radio
industry, independent members, and representatives of interested government
departments.
Research into technical problems is carried out by the scientific and
engineering staffs of the BBC, the ITA, the Post Office, the Ministry of Posts
and Telecommunications, and the radio industry. Recent developments by the
BBC include: the electronic conversion of monochrome and colour television
pictures between the European and the American systems; the reproduction
of television pictures in slow motion; and the development of a sound-and-
vision system, which enables the television sound and picture to be carried
over a single 625-line vision circuit, and thus eliminates the operational
complexity and expense of a separate circuit for the sound.
The BBC and the ITA (together with the Independent Television Companies
Association) are active members of the European Broadcasting Union (EBU),
which was established to advance international broadcasting projects. The
union, whose administrative headquarters are in Geneva and technical centre
in Brussels, now has 28 full members among the broadcasting organisations in
Western Europe and nearly 50 associate members (mostly from outside
Europe, including the United States and many of the nations of the Common¬
wealth). It manages Eurovision; is responsible for the technical and admin¬
istrative arrangements for co-ordinating the exchange of programmes over
that network and for intercontinental satellite links; and it maintains a
technical monitoring station, where frequency measurements and other
observations on broadcasting stations are carried out.
Within the Commonwealth, where the range of broadcasting co-operation
is very wide, each national organisation extends to the others facilities, for
instance, in the use of studios, recording channels, and programme contribu¬
tions. The BBC, in addition, provides a large amount of technical aid,
particularly in staff training to Commonwealth broadcasting organisations,
and members of the BBC’s staff are seconded for service overseas. Co-opera¬
tion and mutual assistance between Commonwealth broadcasters is also
furthered by Commonwealth Broadcasting Conferences, the seventh of which
took place in New Zealand in 1968.
The BBC, Reuters, the Australian Broadcasting Commission, the Canadian
Broadcasting Corporation and the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation are
joint partners in Visnews Ltd., a Commonwealth and international newsfilm
agency which provides a daily service of international news on film for
television subscribers in 68 countries. The International Television Federa¬
tion (Intertel) whose members are broadcasting organisations from Canada,
Australia, the United States and the BBC produce high-quality information
programmes which are exchanged overseas. United Press International, a
television newsfilm agency, and Independent Television News jointly provide
an international service to television organisations via the Eurovision network
and by satellite.
p
44° BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
Both the BBC and the independent television companies are associated
with the Centre for Educational Television Overseas (CETO) (see p. 165),
which helps education in developing countries through television. The centre
receives an annual grant from the Government of £70,000, but most of its
funds come from private sources, including the independent television com¬
panies. The BBC provides free technical and other facilities. Training in
television work is also provided for overseas trainees at the Thomson Centre,
in Glasgow, run by the Thomson Foundation, a charitable trust. The
Ministry of Overseas Development spends about £100,000 annually on radio
and television training for overseas students in Britain.
The BBC and the ITA participate in the work of the International Tele¬
communication Union (ITU)—the United Nations specialised agency
responsible for the regulation and control of all international telecommuni¬
cation services (including sound and television), for the allocation and
registration of all radio frequencies and, through its international consultative
committees, for the promotion and co-ordination of the international study of
technical problems in broadcasting. The BBC is also represented on the
United Kingdom Committee of the International Special Committee on
Radio Interference (CISPR).
Inter-continental Inter-continental television relays by means of communication satellites began
Television in 1962 when the first live programme exchanges between the United States
and Europe were made via Telstar, and have increased in range and scale as
synchronous satellites, which are stationary relative to the earth and thus
permit two-way transmissions, have been commissioned.
Direct links with other continents were achieved in 1964: between Europe
and Japan, and between Britain and Australia. In 1967 the first world-wide
television programme, containing live sequences from several countries in
Europe and Africa, the United States, Canada, Mexico, Australia and Japan,
was broadcast.
18 THE PRESS
The British press caters for all political views, different levels of education
and a wide range of interests. It is not subject to State control or censorship.
A \ ery large number of newspapers per person are sold in Britain every day,
and although there are relatively few national newspapers, some of them have
circulations comparable with the greatest in any other part of the world. Ten
of the national newspapers (five dailies and five Sundays) and one London
evening newspaper have circulations in the millions.
The high consumption of newspapers in Britain is partly due to the fact
that some people buy more than one newspaper each day, and partly to the
concentration of the population in a relatively small area and the highly
developed system of distribution, which means that the national newspapers
are available almost everywhere on the day of publication.
Britain imports just over half its newsprint requirements, about i| million
tons annually, while the rest is made from imported raw materials. The average
size of national morning newspapers varies between 13 and 26 pages, and that
of the Sunday newspapers between 27 and 38. The price of the national
mornings ranges from 5d. to 8d. and that of the national Sunday newspapers
from 6d. to is. od. In addition to their normal paging a few newspapers carry
regular weekly colour supplements. The Times issues an entirely separate
Business News section with every edition.
According to The Newspaper Press Directory1 133 daily and Sunday news¬
papers and 1,177 weekly newspapers are published in Britain. These figures
include certain specialised papers, the circulations of which are limited not
by region, but by interest; for instance, business newspapers, sporting news¬
papers, newspapers in foreign languages for groups of nationals of other lands
resident in Britain, and religious newspapers.
Ownership Newspaper ownership in Britain is concentrated mainly in the hands of a
comparatively small number of large press groups, although some enterprises
are organised as limited liability companies and individual and partner
proprietorship survives. The six major newspaper and periodical publishers
are. International Publishing Corporation Limited; Associated Newspapers
Limited, Beaverbrook Newspapers Limited; the Thomson Organisation
Limited; United Newspapers Publications Limited and S. Pearson
Publishers Limited.
The large national newspaper and periodical publishers are major corpora¬
tions with diversified interests over the whole field of publishing and com¬
munications, and some have shares in the independent television contracting
companies. The International Publishing Corporation and the Thomson
Organisation Limited also have newspaper interests overseas.
Although pronounced views may be expressed in newspapers and their
political leanings may be obvious, they are financially independent of any
political party and not obliged to follow any specific party line.2 In order to
1 Changes in the number of newspapers occur constantly; figures are based on the
1909 edition of The Newspaper Press Directory.
2 The exception to non-alignment is the Morning Star which is owned by a co-operative
society and is accepted as expressing the views of the Communist Party of Great Britain.

preserve their character and traditions, certain newspapers and periodicals
(including The Guardian and The Observer) are governed by arrangements
which vest ownership of the undertaking in trustees, or operate it in accord¬
ance with a deed of trust, or provide that the transfer of shares be in the hands
of trustees. Others have management arrangements intended to ensure the
authority and independence of the editors.
The trend towards concentration of newspaper ownership, which began in
the early nineteen hundreds and was accentuated after the second world war,
giving rise to some public concern lest press monopoly would affect freedom
of information, was studied by two Royal Commissions on the Press, one of
which reported in 1949 and the other in 1962. The results of the recommenda¬
tions of these Commissions included the establishment and reconstitution of
the Press Council; the provision in the Television Act 1963 which stipulates
that, if it appears to the Independent Television Authority at any time that
newspaper shareholdings in television programme companies have led or are
leading to results which are contrary to the public interest, the Authority may,
with the consent of the Minister for Posts and Telecommunications (formerly
the Postmaster General) notify the companies that their programmes may
cease to be transmitted; and the provision in the Monopolies and Mergers
Act 1965 which gives the Board of Trade powers to control the transfer of a
newspaper or newspaper assets to a newspaper proprietor whose newspapers
have an average daily circulation amounting, with that of the newspaper to be
taken over, to 500,000 or more copies, after (in some cases) the Board of Trade
has received a report from the Monopolies Commission (see p. 242).
Technological Technological advances in the newspaper industry include the introduction
Developments of web-offset lithography (which is often combined with photo-composition
and the use of the computer in the composing room) and facsimile
transmission.
The ‘National* Ten morning papers are ‘national’ in the sense of circulating throughout
Press the British Isles, and there are seven national Sunday papers (see Table 38).
All the national dailies are produced in London, but those with big circulations
also print northern editions in Manchester, and the Daily Express has a Scottish
edition printed in Glasgow. The leading Scottish papers {The Scotsman and
The Glasgow Herald) have a considerable circulation outside Scotland. Each of
the (two) London evening papers has ownership affiliations with a national
daily, but both have their distinctive style, drawing their readership very
largely from people living in and around London.
The provincial newspapers of England and Wales (87 morning or evening
dailies and Sundays and 820 newspapers appearing once or twice a week)
provide mainly regional and local news. Some of the daily newspapers also
give extensive coverage to national affairs, and a number co-operate to
provide their own foreign news service. The leading provincial newspapers
have wide regional circulations; a few have nation-wide reputations.
Generally speaking, provincial evening newspapers are non-political, while
the morning newspapers are independent or conservative in outlook.
The total circulation of the provincial morning and evening papers is
estimated at about 8 million. Of the morning papers The Journal (Newcastle),
the Yorkshire Post (Leeds), the Northern Echo (Darlington) and the Western
Mail (Cardiff) have circulations of over 100,000 and two provincial Sunday
papers—the Sunday Sun (Newcastle upon Tyne) and the Sunday Mercury
