(Birmingham)—have circulations of over 200,000. Individual circulation
figures of provincial evening papers start at about 25,000; most are in the
50,000-100,000 range; a few have circulations of over 400,000. Weekly
papers are mainly of local appeal; they are also a valuable medium for local
advertising. Most have circulations in the 8,000-35,000 range, but one or two
have much higher circulations—of up to 100,000.
The London local weeklies (151) include papers for every district in
Greater London. They are assembled mainly in groups of six to eight,
affiliated in some cases to larger groups.
Scotland has six morning, seven evening and two Sunday newspapers, in
addition to the Scottish editions of the Daily Express and Sunday Express.
The leading morning papers are The Glasgow Herald and The Scotsman,
published in Edinburgh. Others are: the Daily Record and the Noon Record,
published in Glasgow, the Courier and Advertiser, published in Dundee, and
the Press and Journal of Aberdeen. Evening papers include the Evening News
of Edinburgh, Glasgow’s Evening Times and Evening Citizen, Dundee’s
Evening Telegraph and Post, Aberdeen’s Evening Express, the Paisley Daily
Express and the Greenock Telegraph. The Sunday papers are the Sunday Mail
and the Sunday Post.
Weekly newspapers published in Scotland number 155. The most widely
known is the People's Journal, which has many local editions.
Northern Ireland has two morning newspapers, one evening paper and one
Sunday paper, all published in Belfast: they are The News-Letter (Unionist)
and the Irish News (Nationalist), the evening Belfast Telegraph and the
Sunday News. There are 42 weekly newspapers in Northern Ireland, with
circulations ranging from about 5,000 to over 25,000. The majority are
published by individual companies.
Wales has one daily morning newspaper, the Western Mail, published in
Cardiff; it circulates mainly in southern Wales. In North Wales the Liverpool
Daily Post gives wide coverage to events in the area. Evening papers
published in Wales are the South Wales Echo, Cardiff, the South Wales Argus,
Newport, and the South Wales Evening Post, Swansea. North Wales is served by
the Liverpool Echo and to a smaller extent by the Manchester Evening News.
The weekly press (some 55 papers) includes the English language papers
(by far the largest category), some of which carry articles in Welsh; two
bilingual papers; and 11 papers in Welsh, of which five are denominational.
The Channel Islands have two daily (evening) papers (one in Guernsey and
one in Jersey), the Guernsey Star with morning and evening editions and a
Sunday paper [Island Sun) and two weeklies, which also circulate in Alderney
and Sark. The Isle of Man Times is issued from Mondays to Wednesdays with
a special weekly edition which is published on Friday: there are four other
weeklies.
There are over 4,100 periodical publications in Britain, classified as ‘general
and specialised’ and ‘trade, technical and professional’. There are also some
600 ‘house magazines’ produced by industrial undertakings, business houses
or public services for the benefit of their employees and/or clients.
General and specialised periodicals include magazines of general interest;
women’s magazines; publications for children; religious periodicals for all
THE PRESS
445
denominations; fiction magazines; magazines dealing with sport, gardening,
hobbies, and humour; journals specialising in various subjects such as politics,
finance and economics, science, agriculture, medicine and the arts; and the
publications of learned societies, trade unions, regiments, universities and
other associations.
The weekly periodicals with the highest sales in Britain are: Woman
(2,600,973); Woman's Own (2,046,993); Woman’s Weekly (1,762,200);
Woman's Realm (1,201,697); and Weekend (1,361,014); together with the
Radio Times (3,960,784) and TV Times (3,386,518). The leading journals of
opinion are The Economist (circulation 100,537), a politically independent
publication covering topics from a wider angle than its title implies; the
New Statesman (circulation 83,907), which is a review of politics, literature
and the arts with an independent socialist political tendency; the Spectator,
which covers much the same subjects from an independent conservative
standpoint; Tribune, which has a strongly left-wing but anti-communist bias;
New Society, which covers the sociological aspects of current affairs; and
New Scientist, which reports on the progress of science and technology in
terms which the non-specialist can understand. Punch (123,019), traditionally
the leading humorous periodical, has in recent years devoted increasing
attention to public affairs.
Literary and political journals and those specialising in international and
Commonwealth affairs, published monthly or quarterly, generally speaking
appeal to the more serious type of reader.
Business magazines include technical, trade, export and professional and
semi-professional journals, the publication of which has become one of the
more important aspects of the British publishing industry. In addition to
circulating in Britain, these journals have a considerable circulation outside
the United Kingdom and are an important media for selling British goods
overseas. Their publication ranges in frequency from weekly to quarterly.
In addition to the circulation of periodicals published in England, a farming
weekly, the Welsh Farm News, and several monthly and quarterly journals
in both Welsh and English are produced in Wales.
Four monthly illustrated periodicals are published in Scotland: Scottish
Field, Scotland's Magazine, Scots Magazine and Scotland-, and two weeklies
devoted to farming interests: Farming News and Scottish Farmer. Among
literary journals, probably the most famous is Blackwood's, published in
Edinburgh. Numerous popular magazines are also published in Scotland.
In Northern Ireland, weekly, monthly and quarterly publications cover
farming, the linen industry, building, motoring, politics and social work.
News Agencies There are three principal British news agencies:
Reuters Ltd. is a world news agency owned by the newspapers of the
United Kingdom, Australia and New Zealand through the Newspaper
Publishers Association, the Press Association, the Australian Associated Press
and the New Zealand Press Association, and operated on a non-profit-making
basis under the terms of a deed of trust which guarantees the independence
and integrity of the news service and ensures that all profits are used to
develop it. Founded in Aix-la-Chapelle in 1850 and transferred to London
in 1851, Reuters has about 1,000 correspondents in 175 countries and
territories throughout the world, and links with 69 associated news agencies,
which give it access to coverage by many thousands of local reporters.
Between 600,000 and 700,000 words of news and Economic Services reports
are received in London every day from which regionalised news services,
44-6 BRITAIN I970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
specially tailored to the needs of recipients in the United Kingdom and eight
main overseas regions, are transmitted through an extensive private network
of communications to 124 countries, and are distributed to approximately
6,600 daily newspapers with an aggregate circulation of over 300 million, as
well as to radio and television networks feeding nearly 650 million sets.
Reuters Economic Services supply a comprehensive service of market prices
and financial reports to some 5,800 private subscribers throughout the world.
A computerised message-handling system is used to speed up the handling
and distribution of news.
The Press Association Ltd., the British national news agency founded in
1868, is co-operatively owned by the principal newspapers of the United
Kingdom outside London, and Eire. It provides newspapers, the broadcasting
organisations, Reuters (of which it is the principal owner) and other inter¬
national agencies with a complete service of home news, including general and
parliamentary news, legal reports, and all branches of financial, commercial
and sports news. Provincial papers are also supplied with the world news of
Reuters and the Associated Press. Through its Photographic Department the
Press Association serves London and provincial newspapers with a daily
picture service, including its own world photos and those of the Associated
Press. Its Special Services Department supplies reports of local or special
interest to daily and weekly trade papers and periodicals. All profits are used
to develop the service.
The Exchange Telegraph Company Ltd. (Extel), an independent news
agency founded in 1872, is a public company with over 1,000 shareholders,
which supplies financial and sporting news to newspapers and broadcasting
organisations. Racing services are also supplied by teleprinter and telephone
to subscribers in London and the provinces from offices in all important cities
and towns.
The Associated Press Ltd., which is the British operating company of the
Associated Press of America, supplies a world-wide overseas news service to
the British press and broadcasting organisations.
A number of other United Kingdom, Commonwealth and foreign agencies
and news services have offices in London, and there are agencies in other
cities, specialising in various aspects of newspaper and periodical require¬
ments. Syndication of features is not as common in the United Kingdom as
in some countries, but a few agencies specialise in this type of work.
Training for The Industrial Training Board for the Printing and Publishing Industry
Journalism (which has 23 members—nine employers, nine employees and five from the
educational services) is responsible for overall training in the newspaper
industry. Under the Industrial Training Board the National Council for the
Training of Journalists (NCTJ), which represents the principal press organisa¬
tions, is the official training body for editorial staffs.
Training controlled by the NCTJ includes full-time courses of a year’s
duration for potential journalists of under 20 who have gained two passes at
the Advanced level of the General Certificate of Education, and a national
training scheme, compulsory for all junior entrants and in which adult
entrants also participate whenever possible, which consists of a six-month
probationary period followed by a three-year apprenticeship (two years for
graduates). During the apprenticeship, trainees combine on-the-job
experience with eight-week residential training courses at centres established
by the Council throughout Britain. There are now seven of these centres for
reporters (five in England, one in Wales, and one in Scotland) and one centre
Press
Institutions
The Press
Council
THE PRESS 447
for photographers. The syllabus covers practical journalism, shorthand,
English, law, government and current affairs, and at the end of their
apprenticeship trainees take a professional examination organised by the
Council. Specialist courses for senior journalists are also provided by the
centres and by the Council direct.
Other training developments include a university course in management,
sponsored by the Newspaper Publishers Association and the Newspaper
Society, at Warwick University.
Under the Commonwealth Press Union Travelling Fellowship Scheme for
the training and education of young journalists throughout the Common¬
wealth, each year about eight journalists from overseas spend five months
in the United Kingdom; two months in the offices of newspapers or
periodicals and three months acquiring a general idea of life in Britain.
A limited number of travelling scholarships are also awarded to British
journalists to enable them to visit Commonwealth countries overseas.
The Thomson Foundation offers scholarships and organises training
courses at its Centre in Cardiff for journalists from all parts of the world,
and provides consultants and tutors for courses for journalists overseas.
The most important organisations to which employers in the industry belong
are the Newspaper Publishers Association, whose members publish national
newspapers in London and Manchester; the Newspaper Society, which
represents the regional and London suburban press; the Scottish Daily News¬
paper Society, which represents the interests of daily and Sunday newspapers
in Scotland; the Scottish Newspaper Proprietors Association, which repre¬
sents the owners of weekly newspapers in Scotland; Associated Northern
Ireland Newspapers, whose members are the proprietors of weekly newspapers
in Northern Ireland; and the Periodical Publishers Association, whose
membership embraces the independent publishers of trade and technical
publications and general magazines. On the journalists side there are the
Institute of Journalists (loj), founded in 1884 as the National Association
of Journalists, and the National Union of Journalists (NUJ), founded in 1907.
All practising journalists (including those engaged in radio, television, public
relations and freelance journalism) are eligible for membership of both these
organisations. In order to achieve joint working and prepare the ground for a
single organisation, an arrangement has been made for dual membership
without the payment of extra subscriptions. At the same time, to avoid over¬
lapping, different activities have been allocated to each organisation, the loj
being responsible for professional questions and the NUJ, primarily, for
industrial relations. Total membership is about 24,200 (NUJ about 22,000,
loj about 2,200).
The main aims of the Guild of British Newspaper Editors are to sustain
the dignity of editorship, to raise and safeguard the professional status of
editors, to protect the rights and freedom of the press, and to improve the
education and training of journalists: the Guild has about 350 members. The
British Association of Industrial Editors is the professional organisation to
which most editors of house journals belong.
The Printing and Kindred Trades Federation is the federation of the printing
trade unions which include the National Graphical Association, the Society
of Graphical and Allied Trades, and the Scottish Typographical Association.
The Press Council, established in 1953 and reconstituted in 1963, has a lay
chairman and 25 members. Its aims are: to preserve the established freedom
448
The Press and
the Law
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
of the British press; to maintain the character of the British press in
accordance with the highest professional and commercial standards; to keep
under review any developments likely to restrict the supply of information of
public interest and importance; to deal with complaints about the conduct
of the press or the conduct of persons and organisations towards the press; to
report on developments in the British press which may tend towards greater
concentration or monopoly; to make representation on appropriate occasions
to the Government, to organs of the United Nations and to press organisations
abroad; to publish its adjudications and periodical reports recording its work,
and to review from time to time developments in the British press and the
factors affecting them. Reports, which include statistics of the newspaper and
periodical press and a series of articles examining the structure of the leading
press groups, are published annually.
The press in Britain has the same freedom as the individual to do and say
what it likes provided it does not transgress the law; in general, it is at liberty
to comment on matters of public interest. Apart from enactments relating
directly to such matters as the registration of newspapers for postal purposes,
there are no specific press laws but certain statutes include clauses which
apply, in particular or incidentally, to the press. These relate to such matters
as the extent of newspaper ownership in television companies; the transfer
of newspaper assets (see p. 442); restrictions on newspaper reporting of
preliminary hearings of indictable offences (in England, Wales and Northern
Ireland); the right of press representatives to be admitted to meetings of local
authorities; restrictions on the publication of (a) divorce and domestic pro¬
ceedings in courts of law, (b) advertisement and investment circulars, which
are governed by Acts dealing with the publication of false or misleading
descriptions of goods and services and with fraud and (c) advertisements of
remedies for certain diseases, which are covered by public health legislation;
agreements between the Post Office and newspaper proprietors on telegraphic
communications, which must comply with telegraphs legislation; restrictions
on certain types of prize competition; and copyrights, which come under
copyright laws.
Of particular relevance to the work of the press are the laws on libel and
defamation; contempt of court—a newspaper may not publish comments
on the conduct of judicial proceedings which are likely to prejudice their
reputation for fairness before or during the actual proceedings nor may it
publish before or during a trial anything which might tend to influence the
result; and seditious libel, incitement to disaffection and revealing official
secrets.
Legal proceedings against the press are comparatively infrequent; the
majority of actions that do take place are libel actions brought by private
individuals. In such cases, the editor, proprietor, publisher, printer and
distributor of the newspaper, as well as the author of the article, may all be
held responsible.
19 SPORT
Central and
Local
Government
Participation
In Britain, the word ‘sport’ is used generally to describe such activities as
organised outdoor games, athletics, field or country sports, indoor games and
sports, aquatic sports, and such popular pursuits as horse-racing, greyhound
racing, show jumping, riding, rock climbing, orienteering, motor racing, and
rifle shooting as well as those (for instance, archery, fencing, gliding and
skating) which, although less popular judged by the number of participants
and spectators, all have their own devotees. Those who engage in sport may be
professionals (that is, paid players) or amateurs.1 Professionals keep up the
technical standards of the sports in which they take part and spectators make
a vital contribution by their enthusiasm and their financial support; but the
sporting life of Britain derives its character principally from the amateur
element—people who devote time and energy to organising sport and to
teaching and training, as well as the many thousands of all ages who engage
in sport for pleasure alone.
The Government is not directly concerned with the organisation or promotion
of sport in Britain but it has assumed responsibility for providing encourage¬
ment, guidance and help; it gives financial aid to national and local voluntary
organisations towards approved expenditure on playing fields, swimming
baths and other facilities for physical recreation, and to national governing
bodies of sport in Great Britain towards the cost of their administration and
coaching schemes, participation in international events overseas and for the
holding of world championships and events of similar importance in Britain.
The Government is advised on matters relating to the development of
amateur sport and physical recreation by the Sports Council, whose members
serve in a voluntary capacity and are appointed for their wide experience of
all aspects of sport and recreation. The chairman of the Council is the Parlia¬
mentary Under-Secretary for Education and Science, who is the minister
with special responsibility for sport. Nine regional sports councils in England,
a sports council for Scotland and a sports council for Wales, bring together
representatives of local authorities, voluntary sports organisations and the
government departments principally concerned, to consider regional require¬
ments for facilities, to promote regional co-operation on planning and to
advise government departments on regional needs and priorities. In Northern
Ireland the Ministry of Education is advised by the Youth and Sports Council.
The Council works in close co-operation with the Central Council of
Physical Recreation, the National Playing Fields Association, the Scottish
equivalents of these bodies, and the British Olympic Association.
In 1968-69 direct government expenditure on sport in Great Britain
totalled some £2-3 million. This covered capital grants to national and local
voluntary organisations towards the provision of facilities, grants to national
voluntary organisations for administration, coaching and participation in
international events and grants for research projects sponsored by the Sports
Council. Local authorities also spend money on sports facilities, such
1 Some sports, for example, athletics, Rugby Union football, hockey and rowing, are
entirely amateur, but in other sports the distinction between professional and amateur
status is becoming less strictly defined.
45° BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
expenditure being taken into account in determining the aggregate amount of
Exchequer grant to local authorities under the rate support grant system
(see p. 72).
In Northern Ireland ^447,000 in grants was given to public authorities
and voluntary organisations for sports facilities and coaching schemes in 1968.
Facilities for The Secretary of State for Education and Science, the Secretary of State for
Sport Scotland and the Ministry of Education for Northern Ireland require that
all publicly maintained schools shall provide for the physical education
(gymnastics, games, athletics, dancing and swimming) of their pupils. Schools
in the national systems (excepting those solely for infants) must have their
own playing field, or the use of one, and most secondary schools have a
gymnasium and other amenities such as swimming pools, sports halls and
halls designed for dance and movement, which local education authorities are
encouraged to make available to the public in the evenings, at week-ends, and
during the school holidays. Facilities for, and instruction in, many kinds of
sport are likewise provided at the independent preparatory and public schools
and at the universities (some of which have departments of physical educa¬
tion). Local authorities also provide playing fields, gymnasia, tennis courts,
golf courses, boating lakes, swimming baths and sports centres on an
increasing scale, and some arrange further education classes in various
physical education subjects. In addition, some larger industrial and commer¬
cial undertakings have developed sports facilities for their employees.
Composite
National Bodies
The Central
Council of Physical
Recreation
The national voluntary organisations most closely concerned with the general
development of sport are the Central Council of Physical Recreation, the
Scottish Council of Physical Recreation, and the National Playing Fields
Association. The British Olympic Association, whose main functions are
connected with the participation of British teams and competitors in the
Olympic Games, is also interested in all matters likely to benefit sport or
physical recreation in Britain as a whole. In addition, each sport has its own
governing body with, in many cases, entirely separate autonomous governing
bodies in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.
The Central Council of Physical Recreation (CCPR) whose membership
represents all national bodies in England, Wales and Northern Ireland con¬
cerned with the development of post-school physical recreation, provides the
Sports Council with such services as may be agreed in the administration,
technical and research fields. It receives grants from the Department of
Education and Science and from the Ministry of Education for Northern
Ireland. Its General Secretary is also the Director of the Sports Council.
The CCPR consists of about 300 members, over 200 of whom represent
national bodies concerned wholly or in part with the development of some
branch of physical recreation. The Council’s headquarters are in London and
it has nine regional offices in other parts of England. Its activities in Wales
are controlled by a representative Welsh committee, and in Northern Ireland
by a separate section with its own executive committee.
Broadly, the Council’s function is to promote all forms of physical
recreation. Its activities include the organisation of courses for coaches and
instructors, classes in personal performance, lectures, displays and other
publicity events. It runs, on average, about 2,000 courses for more than
40,000 people each year. Its staff give advisory, technical and administrative
help wherever required, but particularly to the headquarters, regional, county
and local branches of the constituent organisations and to local educational
The Scottish
Council of Physical
Recreation
The National
Playing Fields
Association
National
Sports
Centres
Outdoor Games
and Sports
SPORT 45I
authorities and industrial concerns. Its regional officers are the secretaries of
the regional sports councils.
The Scottish Council of Physical Recreation (SCPR) is the counterpart in
Scotland of the CCPR, and has 140 affiliated organisations, including the
governing bodies of all the Scottish sports; it receives a grant-in-aid from
the Scottish Education Department.
The main aim of the National Playing Fields Association (NPFA) is to
stimulate the provision of playing fields, playgrounds and sports centres by
publicity and technical and financial assistance. Since its inception in 1925
it has distributed over £1-83 million in the form of grants for playing field and
playground schemes and about £443,000 in the form of loans. It assists more
than 400 schemes a year.
The NPFA council is composed of representatives of the governing bodies
of various sports organisations, of the British Olympic Association and the
CCPR, and of a number of educational bodies, voluntary youth organisations,
physical education associations and local authorities. The national head¬
quarters in London employs a small full-time staff, including a technical and
research department which gives advice on all aspects of recreational
planning including the provision and layout of indoor and outdoor sports
facilities. Advice is also given on matters relating to the play and recreational
needs of children from their earliest years, and the establishment of play¬
grounds and play leadership schemes. The Association derives its funds
mainly from voluntary contributions but it also receives a small contribution
towards administrative costs from the Department of Education and Science.
The NPFA has branches in Scotland and Northern Ireland; there are also
branches in nearly every English and Welsh county; administration is carried
out, in the main, on a voluntary basis—in many cases in association with a
local authority or Rural Community Council.
There are five National Sports Centres in Britain, outside London—two in
England, one in Wales and two in Scotland—administered by the CCPR
and the SCPR with the help of government grants. The centres, some of
which were established by voluntary funds, provide a wide range of courses
for coaches, instructors and performers in many games, sports and other
physical activities. A National Sailing Centre has recently been established
at Cowes, Isle of Wight, with a grant from the Department of Education and
Science. This centre, which is also administered by the CCPR, provides
courses on sailing, boat handling, cruising, navigation, racing, boat main¬
tenance and boat building, for school and youth groups and for adults.
The Crystal Palace National Sports Centre in London covers 36 acres; it
has a main stadium with seating for 12,000 spectators, a sports hall with
seating for 2,000 spectators, a swimming hall with pools of Olympic dimen¬
sions, a teaching pool and a gallery for 2,000 spectators, an indoor cricket
school, practice rooms suitable for all indoor activities, a hostel for 140
residents, and staff housing. These facilities, which are available for inter¬
national competitions as well as for the training of leaders, coaches and
performers, are managed by the CCPR and supported by grants from the
Greater London Council and the Department of Education and Science.
Outdoor games played in Britain include team games such as football,
cricket, and hockey, and games such as lawn tennis and golf, in which
individuals or couples match their skill. Judged by the number of participants
452
Football
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
and spectators, the most popular of the team games are football and cricket;
the most popular of the individual games is lawn tennis.
Although football of a kind was played in the Middle Ages or even earlier,
as an organised game it dates from just over a century ago. One type of
football, in which only the feet are used, was adopted at Cambridge in 1848;
the other type, in which the ball is handled as well as kicked, was first played
at Rugby School, whence it derives its name, and was adopted by the
Blackheath football club in 1859.
In England the controlling body of the non-handling game, Association
Football1 (‘soccer’), is the Football Association (FA) formed in 1863. Its chief
function is to promote the interests of the game and to prevent infringement
of the agreed rules; it also arranges for the instruction of promising young
players (some £50,000 is spent annually on coaching); organises various
matches and competitions, including the international matches played by
England, the Amateur Cup competition, the FA Sunday Cup competition,
two national youth competitions, and the competition for its own leading
trophy, the Football Association Challenge Cup; and chooses and manages
English international teams. Over 350 clubs are registered with the FA, more
than 250 as full members and between no and 120 as associate members.
There are also some 31,000 clubs affiliated to county (that is, district or
regional) associations. The FA derives its main income from subscriptions
and admission charges to international and cup matches, and ploughs back a
large portion of the money into the game. Scotland, Northern Ireland and
Wales have their own controlling bodies: the Scottish Football Association,
the Irish Football Association and the Football Association of Wales.
The principal professional matches in England and Wales (played once or
twice weekly) are controlled by the Football League, which comprises 92
professional clubs in these countries. The funds of the League are derived
largely from contributions paid by member clubs in the form of a levy of
4 per cent of the net gate receipts from league matches, after allowable
expenses have been deducted; from annual payments from the leading
football pools promoters for the use of league fixture lists; and from television
rights.
In Scotland the Scottish Football League comprises 37 clubs; Northern
Ireland has its own League. Clubs belonging to the English and Scottish
Leagues are organised in divisions, the members of which compete against one
another for the respective league championships. Their positions in the
divisional tables are decided at the end of the season by the number of points
gained for wins or draws. During the season about 29 million people watch
Football League matches and gate receipts usually amount to between
£8 million and £8| million.
Several million people stake small weekly sums on the results of the league
matches by filling in what are known as ‘pools’ coupons. The odds against
winning anything in the pools are very great, but the prizes are high and
individual payments of £300,000 are occasionally made. The promoters
deduct varying amounts from the stakes for commission and expenses.
The annual competition for the FA Cup is organised on a knock-out basis
and the Cup Final is one of the most important football matches of the year
in England; it is always played at Wembley Stadium, near London, which
1 Recommendations on the organisation, management, finance and administration of
association football have been made in the report of a Committee on Football made to
the Secretary of State for Education and Science in 1968.
SPORT
Cricket
453
can accommodate some 100,000 spectators. The Scottish Cup Final is played
at Hampden Park, Glasgow. The matches between England, Scotland, Wales
and Ireland also excite great interest, as do other international matches.
There are many more amateur association football players than there are
professionals (the comparative figures are nearly 1 million amateurs, including
schoolboys and members of the armed forces, to 7,000 or 8,000 professionals),
but with one or two notable exceptions their teams cannot compete on equal
terms, since professional teams are more systematically and intensively
trained. Amateur teams compete against each other for the Football
Association Amateur Challenge Cup.
Rugby football (‘rugger’) is played according to two different sets of rules.
Rugby Union Football is played (in England) under the auspices of the Rugby
Football Union, established in 1871. There are 15 players in a side. Inter¬
national matches between England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, and France are
played regularly at the leading rugby football grounds of each country,
including Twickenham, London—the headquarters of the Rugby Football
Union—and there are tours by international teams to and from New Zealand,
Australia and South Africa. Other important rugger matches are the county
championship competitions, the annual match between the universities of
Oxford and Cambridge, the Hospitals’ Cup Final, and the Inter-Services
tournament. Membership of the Rugby Union is strictly confined to amateur
clubs of which there are over 1,600 in membership, with about 1,000 schools.
Rugby League Football—a 13-a-side game played by professionals as well
as amateurs—is played mostly in the north of England. The League, which
was instituted in 1895 and now has its headquarters at Leeds, regularly sends
touring teams to Australia and New Zealand and has annual international
games, professional and amateur, against France. The major match of the
season—the Rugby League Challenge Cup Final—has attracted crowds of
100,000 at Wembley Stadium in recent years.
Cricket is often called the English national game. It originated as a rustic
medieval pastime; by 1550 it is known to have been played by boys at
Guildford Grammar School, and after the Restoration it became fashionable
with the nobility, who competed with each other to sponsor matches for very
large sums of money. Among the many clubs founded in the eighteenth
century was the famous Hambledon Club in Hampshire, whose members
were cricket’s elite and supported the most brilliant players of the day. In 1787
the Marylebone Cricket Club (MCC) was founded in London and, assuming
responsibility for reframing the ‘Laws of Cricket’, became the governing body
of the game in Great Britain. Its first headquarters were at a ground on the
site of the present Dorset Square, rented by a Yorkshireman called Thomas
Lord, who gave his name to this and the two succeeding grounds. The second
ground, at which MCC was established from 1811 to 1813, was on the
perimeter of Regent’s Park. The present ground, at St. John’s Wood, was
opened in 1814.
Cricket in Britain is now governed by the MCC Cricket Council, made up
of representatives of MCC, the Test and County Board of Control (represent¬
ing first-class cricket) and the National Cricket Association (representing club
and junior cricket). MCC retains world-wide responsibility for the laws of
cricket.
The game is played in schools and universities, and most towns and villages,
as well as industrial sports clubs, have teams which play at least one match a
week from late April to early September. In the London area a large number
of pitches are provided by local authorities to augment those leased or owned
454
Lawn Tennis
BRITAIN 1970: AN OFFICIAL HANDBOOK
by clubs. In the Midlands and the north of England there is a network of
League cricket, contested by teams of Saturday afternoon players reinforced
by one or more professionals, often distinguished overseas players.
The focus of the season centres on a series of ‘Test matches’ played between
England and a touring team from overseas (or sometimes two teams). The
first of these matches was played in Melbourne between England and
Australia in 1877. Since then international tours have taken place regularly
between countries of Test status, who now number seven. The matches last
30 playing hours spread over five to six days and arouse great popular interest.
The principal grounds in England on which Test matches are played are
Lord’s; the Oval, Kennington, London, headquarters of Surrey County
Cricket Club; Old Trafford, Manchester; Trent Bridge, Nottingham;
Headingley, Leeds; and Edgbaston, Birmingham.
In addition to the Test matches a First Class County Championship,
decided on a points system, is played for by 17 counties, each playing 24
three-day matches. The counties not deemed first-class and second elevens of
the first-class counties play in a Minor Counties Championship. The Univer¬
sity Elevens of Oxford and Cambridge rank as first-class and play an annual
match at Lord’s. Since 1963 the counties have also competed in a single
innings knock-out competition for the Gillette Cricket Cup and in 1969 a
Sunday League was inaugurated.
Since 1963, the distinction between amateur and professional players in
county and Test cricket has been abolished. In 1968 the qualification rules
were relaxed to allow a limited number of top-class overseas cricketers to play
in the English county championships.
The forerunner of modern lawn tennis (the game known as/^M de paume) was
introduced into England from France in the fifteenth century and a ‘tennis
court’, built by Henry VIII, is still in use at Hampton Court. The modern
game, first played in England in 1873, quickly became very popular; in 1877
the words ‘and lawn tennis’ were added to the title of the All England Croquet
Club at Wimbledon, near London, and in the same year the first champion¬
ships were played. The Lawn Tennis Association, the controlling body of the
game in Britain, was founded in 1888. The governing body of the game in the
world (the International Lawn Tennis Federation, with headquarters in
London and Paris) was founded in 1913.
The number of people who play lawn tennis has greatly increased during
the present century, particularly since the game has spread to practically
every country in the world. In Britain the game is played in almost all girls’
schools and in very many boys’ schools where the pupils are of secondary
school age. It is also played on private courts, in parks and recreation grounds
and at several thousand tennis clubs.
The annual championships held at Wimbledon for two weeks at the end
of June and beginning of July are the main event of the lawn tennis season
in Britain and, in fact, in the world. These championships, in which men and
women of many nationalities compete, draw large crowds; there is accom¬
modation for over 30,000 spectators in the grounds of the All England Club—
14,000 can be accommodated round the centre court where the finals are
played. Other tournaments which attract a good deal of attention are: the
British Hardcourt Championships, the British Junior Championships, and
the County Championships. There are also competitions for boys’ and girls’
schools on a national basis. The most important international events are the
Davis Cup (for men) and the Federation Cup competition (for women).
Golf
Hockey
Lacrosse
Sp0RT 45-
Women players from Britain and the United States of America also compete
annually for the Wightman Cup.
Golf originated in Scotland, where for centuries it has borne the title of the
Royal and Ancient Game, but it did not become really well known in the other
countries of the United Kingdom until towards the end of the nineteenth
century. Since then, however, it has gained steadily in popularity (particularly
since the mid-1950s); nowadays there are golf courses in the vicinity of many
towns and villages in all parts of Britain—some owned by local authorities,
but the majority owned by golf clubs—and the question of the game’s large
land requirements is being studied by the Department of Social and Economic
Research at the University of Glasgow. The headquarters of the Royal and
Ancient Golf Club is St. Andrews, Scotland.
The main event of the golfing year is the British Open Golf Championship,
which was first played in i860; other important matches include the Walker
Cup (for amateurs) and the Ryder Cup (for professionals), both played
between Britain and America; the Amateur Championship; the World
Amateur Team Championship; and the Ladies Championship.
Y ariants of hockey (as distinct from ice-hockey) have been played in Britain
for at least five centuries, and some, like hurley in Northern Ireland and Shinty
in Scotland, are still played extensively. Modern hockey, however, dates from
the formation (in 1886) of the Hockey Association of England. The Inter¬
national Hockey Rules Board, comprising the Association of England,
Scotland and Wales and the Irish Hockey Union, together with delegates from
the Federation Internationale de Hockey, representing the rest of the world,
controls the rules of the game. There are some 2,000 men’s hockey clubs
throughout Britain with at least 30,000 male adult players; some 600 boys’
schools also play the game. Although there are no professional county teams
and no cup ties in England, a county championship is held annually. In
Scotland there is a Scottish cup competition and six local league competitions
and the Welsh Hockey Association organise a Welsh cup competition.
Regular amateur international matches are also played. Men’s hockey is an
Olympic sport, and the arrangements for England and Scotland are in the
hands of the British Hockey Board.
The controlling bodies of women’s hockey are: the All England Women’s
Hockey Association (founded 1895) to which are affiliated some 900 clubs and
2,200 schools, representing a total membership of about 72,000 adults and
1 • 1 million schoolgirls; the Irish Ladies Hockey Union; the Scottish Women’s
Hockey Association; and the Welsh Women’s Hockey Association. The first
international women’s hockey match took place in 1896. Nowadays such a
match is played annually at Wembley Stadium (in addition to those played in
other parts of the country), where it attracts some 60,000 spectators.
Lacrosse, adapted from the game played by the Iroquois Indians of North
America, is played mainly by women—in girls’ schools, at lacrosse clubs, and
at universities. International matches are played, as well as regional matches,
by women’s teams representing the East, West, South, North and Midlands
of England, under the auspices of the All England Women’s Lacrosse
Association.
The men’s game, of which the controlling body is the English Lacrosse
Union, is played in ten universities, six teacher-training colleges, and by clubs
and schools, mainly in the London, Manchester, Leeds, Sheffield and
Nottingham areas. Matches played include county matches, an annual fixture

Mountaineering

between the North of England and the South, and international matches
between Australia, America, Canada and England.
Netball is a popular game for girls and women. The controlling body is the
All England Netball Association to which are affiliated the English county
associations, the netball clubs of the three Women’s Services and sections of
the national youth and university organisations for girls and women. Inter¬
county and home international matches are played regularly and inter-
Commonwealth tours are arranged.
Polo, of which the earliest records are Persian, was first played by the British
in India, and brought to England in 1869. The governing body of British
polo is the Hurlingham Polo Association to which all the Commonwealth
polo associations and that of South Africa are affiliated. Polo players are a very
small section of the community, for the cost of keeping polo ponies is high.
However, many of the clubs now own trained ponies which are hired out to
members at moderate cost. There are about 375 players handicapped by the
Hurlingham Polo Association, but many less expert players take part in club
games for which they may be locally handicapped.
Public interest in polo has increased in recent years and large numbers of
spectators attend inter-club tournaments and matches between high-handicap
teams composed of players from several countries.
The game of bowls has been played in Britain since the thirteenth century.
Nowadays the flat green game is regulated, as far as the English Bowling
Association is concerned, by the International Bowling Board (IBB), founded
in 1905. The Bowling Associations of Ireland, Scotland and Wales also come
under and play to the laws laid down by the IBB, but there are other bowling
associations in England—the English Bowling Federation, the Crown Green
Association and the English Women’s Bowling Association—which are not
under the IBB’s control.
During the summer bowls is played on bowling greens in the open; in
winter it is played on indoor greens, which are increasing in number. At one
time regarded as a pastime for the elderly, the game is now played by people
of all ages. Over 2,620 bowling clubs in England are affiliated to the English
Bowling Association alone. International, inter-county matches, and national
championship competitions of singles, pairs, triples and fours are played.
The popularity of mountaineering has greatly increased in recent years. The
number of clubs in the British Mountaineering Council (BMC) and the
Association of Scottish Climbing Clubs, the representative bodies of the sport,
is now over 190, ranging from national clubs, such as the Alpine Club (founded
in 1857, the oldest mountaineering club in the world) and the Scottish
Mountaineering Club, to small regional clubs with 20 to 30 members. A
number of local education authorities, as well as national bodies such as the
Central Council of Physical Recreation and the Outward Bound Trust,
have established mountaineering training centres in the hills. Training
courses are run jointly by the CCPR and BMC, the Youth Hostels Associa¬
tion and other bodies, and many universities and schools have mountaineering
sections. Membership of the known clubs is about 15,000 but several times this
number take part in climbing and mountaineering.
British mountaineers have taken a leading part in exploring most of the
great ranges of the world and in climbing their peaks; for example, the first
ascent of the Matterhorn in 1865, of Everest in 1953, and of Kangchenjunga
in 1955. In recent years frequent expeditions have gone to far off mountains,
SPORT
Ski-ing
Athletics
Highland Games
457
to Greenland, Alaska, the Andes, Patagonia, the Caucasus and the Pamirs,
as well as the Himalayas.
Ski-ing in Scotland has become very popular, especially at the winter sports
centres established in the Cairngorms, Deeside, Glencoe and Glenshee,
where ski-runs equal to those in other areas of Europe have been developed,
and ski-lifts, ski-tows and professional instruction are now available. There
are, in addition, 24 artificial ski-slopes in other parts of Britain.
Amateur athletics, which include running (track, road and cross-country),
relay racing, jumping, hurdling, throwing and race-walking, are governed by
the Amateur Athletic Association (AAA), which was founded in 1880 to
encourage amateur athletics, to improve the management of amateur athletic
meetings by the establishment of uniform regulations, and to promote annual
championship meetings. The Association, whose membership increased
rapidly, is now organised from club to national level by honorary officers
and managed by representative members appointed by the Northern, Midland,
Southern and Welsh areas and by affiliated clubs and associations (amateur
athletic clubs, schools and youth organisations), of which there are hundreds
throughout England and Wales. The AAA administers a coaching scheme
under which eight full-time national coaches, working mainly in separate
regions, lecture, demonstrate and coach in schools, youth clubs, evening
institutes, training colleges and universities and at special courses organised
by the national associations, by regional associations or by the Central Council
of Physical Recreation. Some of the work of the national coaches is directly
concerned with coaching young athletes but their main duties are to instruct
men who wish to qualify as AAA coaches, over 1,600 of whom give
voluntary services in the counties and districts of England and Wales. Scotland
and Northern Ireland have their own amateur athletic associations, with
similar functions; there are also separate women’s AAAs for each country.
International athletics and the selection of teams representing the United
Kingdom are dealt with by the British Amateur Athletic Board, which is
composed of representatives of the three national associations for men and
of the Women’s Council, and is affiliated to the International Amateur
Athletic Federation.
Track meetings are held throughout Britain from April to October. The
main events in England and Wales are: the AAA championships for men
and international matches held in London; area and county championships;
and the universities, Services, business houses and schools championship
meetings. Clubs usually compete in cross-country running from October
to March, and county, area and national cross-country championships
are held.
Teams representing Britain compete in the Olympic Games (held every
four years) and separate teams representing England, Wales, Scotland, and
Northern Ireland compete in the Commonwealth Games, held at four-yearly
intervals between the Olympic Games.
The Highland games are traditional gatherings of local people in the High¬
lands of Scotland, at which sports (including tossing the caber, putting the
weight, and throwing the hammer) and dancing and piping competitions
take place. Among the better known Highland games are the Braemar
Gathering on Deeside (traditionally attended by the royal family), the
Argyllshire Gathering at Oban, and the meeting at Aboyne. The Highland
